HEADLINE: Job Security Is an Issue At Hearings on Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
At the first Congressional airing yesterday of the Bush Administration's plan to break down trade barriers between the United States and Mexico, lawmakers were generally sympathetic but wary that American jobs might be lost because of lower Mexican wage and environmental standards.
Before the Senate Finance Committee, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, asserted there would be "measurable gains across a broad spectrum" of the American economy and "few losers." 
 The committee chairman, Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, agreed, saying, "I think we can find an agreement that will raise standards of living on both sides."
 
Proposal Is Denounced
 But the proposal was denounced by Thomas R. Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., as "an economic and social disaster" for American workers. The labor federation has made fighting the agreement its top legislative priority this year.
Mrs. Hills said the impact on industries identified as possible losers, like fruits and vegetables, glass products, textiles and footwear, would be softened by gradual reduction of barriers over time and programs of worker assistance.
The United States and Mexico are scheduled to start negotiatons this summer, joined by Canada, which has a two-year-old free trade agreement with the United States.
Several lawmakers said yesterday that they were worried lower standards in Mexico would lead to lower standards here.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, asked Mrs. Hills why a chemical plant in Louisiana, hurt by the cost of complying with last year's Clean Air Act, would not move to Mexico, pollute there and sell its product to the United States duty free.
As to concerns about plants moving across the frontier to take advantage of lower environmental standards, she said that corporate moves depend on any number of factors besides environmental conditions, such as transportation facilities, educational standards of the workforce and capital requirements.
"The wholesale migration of firms is not something we would anticipate," she said.
Mexico is already making major efforts to lift environmental standards, Mrs. Hills said, and had passed a tough environmental law with criminal penalties. She said it was moving toward requiring catalytic converters on automobiles by 1991.
She indicated she would resist linking enviromental compliance with the free trade negotiations apparently because this could severely complicate the talks. Mexico, she noted, is already working with the United States Environmental Protection Agency and has used American laws as the model for its own legislation.
Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, noted during the hearing that the average wage in Mexico was 57 cents an hour, compared with $10.47 an hour in the United States. He predicted, "Those wage rates will make manufacturing jobs slide away to Mexico."

HEADLINE: Study Foresees Closing Most Nuclear Arms Plants

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
In a study that envisions a sharply reduced need for nuclear arms in the 21st century, the Department of Energy proposes shutting down all but five of its weapons plants for good and letting private companies own the factories for making the weapons' nonnuclear components.
The new study, which is scheduled to be made public on Thursday, is intended by the Department of Energy to open a new era of more economical and safer production of atomic weapons. The department is seeking to end a 47-year period when radioactive materials for the nuclear arsenal were manufactured at great cost to public health, the environment and the Treasury. 
 Details of the study were made available by officials in Congress, the White House and the Energy Department who have read it. Prepared over the last 18 months for the White House and Congress, the study is the first step in an elaborate process to change and modernize an industry that had deteriorated so badly that by late 1988 it ceased to function.
 
First Step of Many
 This month, the Energy Department will hold the first of dozens of hearings around the country to obtain public comment, and the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs has scheduled a hearing on the report later this month.
Under one possible plan offered in the study, the Government's nuclear weapons industry in 2015 would consist of plants in Idaho, New Mexico, Nevada, South Carolina and one other state that has yet to be chosen. This option, one of four outlined in the study, calls for consolidating the functions of the Rocky Flats Plant, the Y-12 uranium plant in Oak Ridge, Tenn., and the Pantex plant, the main warhead assembly plant, near Amarillo, Tex.
The Energy Department's plants in Kansas City, Pinellas, Fla., and Miamisburg, Ohio, which manufacture electronic and other nonradioactive components for nuclear weapons are to be transferred to private industry, according to the study. The Energy Department is also looking to put into private hands the nonnuclear manufacturing operations at its nuclear plants in South Carolina, Tennessee and Colorado.
A separate study begun a month ago by the Department of Energy is evaluating proposals to consolidate the operations of two weapons design laboratories in New Mexico and another in California.
 
Dramatic Shrinkage of Industry
 Taken together, the actions proposed in the new study would greatly shrink an industry that since its birth during World War II, grew to operate at one time in more than 100 sites in 32 states. As late as 1988, the American nuclear weapons industry included production plants, laboratories, testing grounds and waste repositories at 17 sites in 12 states. Currently six of the plants have been shut since October 1988 for safety reasons, two of them permanently.
The new study is the second attempt by the Energy Department to characterize and estimate the nation's needs for nuclear materials. In December 1988, the Energy Department published another plan for the industry's modernization that called for spending $81 billion to shut old plants, relocate others and build several entirely new plants. The 1988 study, which is superseded by the new study, said the United States would need to maintain the production of nuclear materials for weapons, particularly plutonium and tritium, a radioactive isotope of hydrogen, at nearly the same levels as existed during the most anxious years of the Cold War.
The new plan makes much different assumptions about the level of tension between the United States and the Soviet Union, according to Congressional and Energy Department officials. According to the four separate possibilities presented, the number of nuclear weapons in the American arsenal is expected to be 30 percent to 85 percent lower than it is today. Experts outside the Government say the United States currently maintains 20,000 warheads in the arsenal.
No matter which plan is ultimately used as the basis for changing the industry, say the study's authors, the United States will never again need to turn on the nuclear reactors and chemical processing plants to produce virgin supplies of plutonium. The explosive radioactive metal, which was discovered 50 years ago this month at the University of California at Berkeley, was manufactured at the Hanford nuclear reservation from 1944 until 1988.
 
Rocky Flats Plant to Be Shut
 All planning possibilities also call for the permanent shutdown and relocation of the Rocky Flats Plant. Rocky Flats has been temporarily shut since November 1989, the second long shutdown in the last 29 months, because of persistent mechanical and managerial weaknesses that make it unsafe to operate, according to James D. Watkins, the Secretary of Energy.
But the study makes clear that the United States will still need the capacity to recover plutonium from retired warheads and process it for new warheads, for temporary storage or for permanent disposal in a new waste repository in New Mexico.
The Savannah River plant near Aiken, S.C., could become the principal site for producing and processing plutonium metal that is recovered from retired warheads. A new $86 million plutonium plant is being tested at Savannah River and is scheduled to be put into operation this summer.
Until it is closed, Rocky Flats, perhaps the most troubled of the nation's nuclear plants, is to remain a machining center to make plutonium parts for warheads and will have the ability to recover and process radioactive wastes from these operations. The new limited mission for Rocky Flats is a marked departure from the plant's role in the weapons industry as the principal site for processing plutonium for the nuclear arsenal.
Mr. Watkins has asked Congress for $283 million in a supplemental appropriation this fiscal year for emergency repairs at Rocky Flats. Congressional investigators said the repairs are to be made to buildings at Rocky Flats that machine plutonium into parts for new warheads and that recover and process plutonium wastes from these operations. The United States, according to independent arms control experts, has been unable to manufacture new warheads for more than six months because of the persistent problems at Rocky Flats.
According to Congressional investigators, the cost of eventually closing Rocky Flats, including its radioactive buildings and cleaning up mounds of accumulated chemical and radioactive wastes could be more than $7 billion.

HEADLINE: New York City Given Warning by Rohatyn On the 1992 Budget

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, warned yesterday that New York City's fiscal problems might deteriorate to the point where the city would have to postpone balancing its budget next year and instead borrow to meet expenses.
Without the borrowing, Mr. Rohatyn said, a declining economy may force the city to face a budget gap totaling $3 billion next year. Such a gap, he said, could not be closed without doing "extreme brutality" to the quality of life in the city. 
 "At some point the tradeoff between balancing the budget and the long-term social and economic harm may not make sense," Mr. Rohatyn said at a board meeting of the corporation, which was set up to raise capital for the city in 1975, when the city could not sell its bonds. He added that closing a gap of $3 billion could require up to 30,000 layoffs and $1.5 billion in new taxes.
By suggesting that the city might be unable or unwilling to balance its budget, Mr. Rohatyn, who once helped save the city from financial ruin and retains considerable power to assist it now, has broached a subject previously considered unthinkable and has opened a debate that could continue for months.
City officials, who believe they are making progress in confronting municipal fiscal problems, were stung by Mr. Rohatyn's gloomy assessment, with its suggestion that the administration might ultimately have to admit inability to control the city's destiny.
Asked whether Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was aware of his remarks, Mr. Rohatyn said, "Does he know my view, yes, but these ideas do not reflect his view."
Thomas Conroy, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, said he could not immediately comment on Mr. Rohatyn's remarks.
Mr. Rohatyn said that he was not predicting the onset of a full-scale fiscal crisis, but that the deep local recession could result in one.
Asked about Mr. Rohatyn's remarks, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said, "The Mayor clearly disagrees."
She said Mayor David N. Dinkins had repeatedly shown that he would take whatever steps were necessary to balance the budget so long as they did not undermine "the viability of the city."
"The Mayor's view is the glass is half full," she said, "Felix's view is the glass is half empty."
The city is required by law to balance its budget each year. If it does not, severe damage to its credit standing might result. The lapse might also trigger a state law that gives an appointed body, the state's Financial Control Board, power to abrogate city contracts and veto city spending decisions. The control board was created in 1975 to oversee city finances.
Instead, Mr. Rohatyn suggested that if the city faced damaging budget cuts, it could seek legislation changing the end of its fiscal year. It could then work with the state, municipal labor unions, rating agencies and the Financial Control Board to develop a plan to bring the city's budget back into balance over two to three years.
 
Postponing the Debt
 By extending its fiscal year, which ends June 30, the city would have more time to make cuts and find additional revenue to balance the buddget.
In a crisis, Mr. Rohatyn said, the Municipal Assistance Corporation could provide hundreds of millions in cash for the city next year -- by refinancing bonds to stretch out the payment of current interest over many years -- even if this would simply be postponing debt.
City officials and analysts denounced Mr. Rohatyn's suggestion as a gimmick that harked back to the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's -- borrowing to close deficits.
"The city has to balance its budget," said City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. "Deficit financing is not the answer. It is a no-no."
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses, said, "We should have the courage to deal with our problems today instead of foisting them off on our children."
Mr. Rohatyn said, "I asked my board to simply think about it, whether we could participate in such a thing."
 
Bond Sale Due Next Week
 The remarks surprised city officials because they came in the same week that Standard & Poor's, the bond-rating agency, decided to reaffirm the city's A- bond rating after it had considered lowering it. The rating agency, while warning of potential problems ahead, found that the city was acting in a "fairly reasonable fashion" to close its budget gap.
City officials said they did not think Mr. Rohatyn's comments would hurt the city next week, when it plans to sell $950 million in tax-exempt and taxable bonds. The market for city bonds has improved slightly in the last few days, city officials said.
Both the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the Financial Control Board, formerly called the Emergency Financial Control Board, were created in 1975 to help the city through its last major fiscal crisis.
The corporation, headed by Mr. Rohatyn, sold bonds on the city's behalf at a time when it was shut out of the bond market. The board, headed by Governor Cuomo, monitors the city's fiscal health and can intervene in city government if the city is unable to borrow or runs a deficit of more than $100 million.
 
Confrontations in the Past
 Since 1984 the corporation has agreed to turn over several billion dollars in surplus funds, including savings from bond refinancings, to the city treasury. Over the years this has provoked some angry confrontations betweeen Mr. Rohatyn and former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who thought he wanted too much say on how the money was to be spent.
During the last mayoral campaign, Mr. Rohatyn supported Mr. Dinkins over Mr. Koch, and last year the corporation agreed to give the city $500 million in cash for immediate budget relief and $250 million more this year.
Last fall Mr. Rohatyn angrily denounced a labor settlement between the city and the teachers' union as one the city could not afford. When some labor leaders attacked him for interfering, he announced that he was stepping down as chairman of the assistance corporation.
But in January Governor Cuomo convinced him to stay, at least through the adoption of next year's city budget. At the time, Mr. Cuomo had grown increasingly alarmed over the city's fiscal's management, according to his aides.

Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said New York City may have to resort to stop-gap borrowing and a postponement of budget balancing to stave off fiscal problems. With him yesterday at meeting was Deputy Mayor Sally Hernandez-Pinero. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times) (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: After Many Hours and Miles, L.I. Boy Is Rescued From Kidnappers

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
A 14-year-old boy from the North Shore of Long Island was rescued at dawn yesterday from a Queens apartment, 55 hours after two masked men wielding a gun barged into his family's house on Sunday night and kidnapped him.
Much of that time the boy was kept blindfolded in a closet in a small apartment in Ridgewood, Queens. Meanwhile, one kidnapper led the police and F.B.I. agents on an erratic journey -- by stolen car, subway, taxi and on foot -- through much of Queens and Manhattan. 
 Twice the kidnapper even drove back to the boy's home in Upper Brookville to negotiate with his parents and the police. The police let him go the first time in the hope that he would lead them to the boy. The second time they arrested him. The other suspect was seized at the Queens apartment.
 
'They Were Novices'
 "This is my fourth kidnapping case, and it's the most bizarre," said Inspector Donald White of the Nassau County Police Department.
The suspects, both Romanian immigrants, told the police that they were unemployed machinists in need of money to return to Romania. "Maybe it was that they were strange to this country," Inspector White said. "Definitely they were novices to the crime of kidnapping."
They were identified as Vasilica Parteni, 22, and Roberto Ciaprazi, 23, both of 617 Fairview Avenue in Ridgewood. They were charged with first-degree kidnapping, first-degree robbery and first-degree burglary.
The kidnapped boy, who was not harmed, was identified as William Chichester McClean IV, nicknamed Chi by his parents, Ferrel and William Chichester McClean III, both investment bankers in Manhattan. "All I can say is that we're happy our son's safe and that it's over," Mr. McClean told The Associated Press yesterday.
He was abducted about 8 P.M. on Sunday from the McClean home, a large, colonial-style house with green shutters and white awnings that sits atop a hill at the end of Mill River Road.
"Two men in ski masks walked into the house through an unlocked kitchen door," said Hank McCann, a spokesman for the Nassau police. "One was armed with a revolver.
"One of them said, 'We are taking the boy. We will contact you. Do not notify the media or the police or we will kill him,' " Mr. McCann added.
The kidnappers blindfolded the boy and forced him into the family's new, white Jeep, the police said. "They drove the Jeep 60, 70 yards and parked it, hidden away from the road in a neighbor's driveway, then got back in their own car with the kid and drove off," Mr. McCann said.
 
Tape-Recorded Message
 The McCleans did call the police. But only after 18 hours did the kidnappers call -- 2 P.M. on Monday. "They demanded $200,000 for the boy's release and said they would call back to give details on the delivery," Mr. McCann said. "Part of the call was a tape-recorded message from young Chi saying: 'Mom and Dad, I want to come home. Pay the money. I am alright.' "
For 27 hours the police and F.B.I. agents sat in the house with the parents, waiting for a phone call. Suddenly, a man in a ski mask again walked into the house through an unlocked door, Mr. McCann said. The police later identified the masked man as Mr. Parteni.
Detective Robert Ryder of the Old Brookville Police Department said the kidnapper "was cool and calculated, not scared at all."
"He said, 'If I don't get out of here, the kid is dead,' " Detective Ryder said. "He was holding all the cards, and he knew it."
Mr. McCann said: "The kidnapper declared, 'I am here for the ransom, and if you try to take off my mask or detain me, the boy will be killed.' The parents said, 'Let him have the money, we want our son back.' The man then put the money in a canvas gym bag, walked out and, for the second time, stole the white jeep."
 
Followed for Four Hours
 Then began a four-hour odyssey in which the kidnapper was followed by police officers and F.B.I. agents. It was unclear whether the kidnapper was always aware that he was being followed. A police official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said law-enforcement agents had attached an electronic tracking device to the Jeep before the man left. A helicopter also took part in the pursuit, the official said.
The suspect drove into Queens, circling back and forth between LaGuardia and Kennedy Airports. He parked the Jeep near the Long Island Rail Road terminal in Jamaica, walked to a nearby subway station and rode a train to Forest Park in mid-Queens. After wandering on foot near the park, he hailed a gyspy cab and ordered it to drive in a circuitous route that finally led to Fresh Pond Road and Myrtle Avenue in Ridgewood, the police said.
"He disappeared for about 15 minutes," Mr. McCann said. "We were all over the place. Suddenly he reappears, goes to a street phone, calls the McClean household and says, 'Get these cops away from me. Tell them to back off.' "
 
'I Want to Make a Deal'
 The man hailed a yellow cab, ordering it to drive on the Long Island Expressway through the Queens Midtown Tunnel into Manhattan, then doubling back to Queens. He then had the cab drive him to the Jeep in Jamaica.
"And he drove back to the McClean household," Mr. McCann said. "We watched him every step of the way. He went into the household again, unmasked, and said, 'I want to make a deal. I will give you back your son, unharmed, and we keep the money and go free.' "
"At that point, the Nassau police said, 'End of the line,' and placed him under arrest," Mr. McCann said.
Inside the Jeep, the police said, they found Mr. Parteni's wallet, which had his address -- 617 Fairview Avenue, Ridgewood.
About 6:30 A.M. yesterday, the police from Nassau County, Old Brookville and New York City as well as F.B.I agents surrounded the house on Fairview Avenue and rang the bell. "The accomplice opened the door and stepped out," Mr. McCann said, "and the boy came right behind him." The $200,000 was recovered.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vasilica Parteni, left, and Roberto Ciaprazi, left rear, both of Ridgewood Queens, being escorted yesterday by Nassau County Police Officers in Levittown after being charged with kidnapping a 14-year-old boy from the North Shore of Long Island. (Kevin P. Coughlin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush Plan to Fight Infant Deaths Would Use Money Going to Poor

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Administration officials told Congress today that they intended to finance a proposal by President Bush to combat infant mortality in 10 cities by taking money from other health programs that serve pregnant women, poor children and the homeless.
In a letter to Congress, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the Bush Administration planned to take $24 million from community health centers and $34 million from the existing Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant this year. 
 For next year, Dr. Sullivan said, the Administration plans to take $33 million from those two programs and shift it to the 10 cities with high infant mortality. In addition, the Administration would seek a separate appropriation of $139 million, for which no source has been specified. New budget procedures adopted last year set an overall limit on domestic spending, and increases in one program usually must be offset by cutbacks in others.
By redirecting Federal money to 10 cities with acute needs, the Administration hopes to "reduce the infant mortality rate in targeted communities by 50 percent," Dr. Sullivan said in his letter, which gave new details of the proposal mentioned in Mr. Bush's budget. Mr. Bush said the 10 cities would be chosen from among "cities with exceptionally high rates of infant mortality," and while there are some likely choices, the Government has not disclosed the selection criteria.
 
No Guarantee of Selection
 Washington, Detroit, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Baltimore and Memphis are among the big cities with high rates, but there is no guarantee they will be selected.
The plan immediately stirred concern among public health experts and state officials, who said Mr. Bush was taking money from underserved communities to pay for a high-profile initiative with strong political appeal.
Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, chairman of the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality, welcomed Mr. Bush's new attention to the problem of infant mortality, but said the President was "robbing Peter to pay Paul." Mr. Chiles has been chairman of the 16-member commission since shortly after its creation by Congress in 1986.
The Administration's plan contradicts a confidential recommendation from the White House Task Force on Infant Mortality, which last fall urged Mr. Bush to increase money for both community health centers and the Maternal and Child Health Block Grant.
Administration officials said they recognized the merit in that recommendation but could not immediately find money to carry it out.
Catherine Hess, director of the Association of Maternal and Child Health Programs, which represents state officials, said the Administration was "taking funds for this new initiative from existing programs that already serve low-income pregnant women and infants."
"If infant mortality is such a priority, why not commit new resources to it, rather than just shifting funds from one program to another?" she asked.
 Some Federal health officials said they shared that concern. Others defended Mr. Bush's proposal as an exercise in setting priorities. "We are in the business of making tough decisions," said Kevin E. Moley, budget officer for the Department of Health and Human Services. "We have to make choices between some worthy projects and some that are more worthy."
In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 29, the President did not specifically mention infant mortality. But he said: "Good health care is every American's right and every American's responsibility. And so we are proposing an aggressive program of new prevention initiatives for infants, for children, for adults and for the elderly."
By definition, the nation's 550 community health centers care for "medically underserved populations." They receive Federal money under current law only if they serve an area with a high infant mortality rate and a high poverty rate.
Administration officials said they had originally considered asking some community health centers outside the 10 cities to give back some of the money they have already received, but abandoned that idea as too controversial. The money Mr. Bush proposes shifting would come from money already appropriated but not yet disbursed.
Dr. Sullivan said the money could be used to provide prenatal care and to discourage smoking, drinking and drug abuse by pregnant women.
David R. Hawkins, director of policy analysis at the National Association of Community Health Centers, said Mr. Bush's plan meant that "a poor sick infant in Seattle will not get care so that a poor sick infant in another city, like Chicago, can get care."
 
What About the Rural Areas?
 Lula Clara Dorsey, executive director of the Delta Health Center in Mound Bayou, Miss., said in a telephone interview: "By targeting 10 cities, you can reduce infant mortality in those places without a doubt. But what happens to places like rural Mississippi and rural Alabama that are not on the 10-city list? Infant mortality will increase in those places."
Governor Chiles, a Democrat, said, "The only difference between the current apportionment for infant mortality and this budget's new allowance is that instead of allowing all 50 states to receive their share of the money, now 10 cities must vie for desperately needed funds."
Members of Congress observed similar tradeoffs in other parts of Mr. Bush's budget request. Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said he was pleased to see that Mr. Bush had sought more money to run the unemployment insurance program, so people would not have to wait five or six weeks for benefits. But at the same time, he said, Mr. Bush is trying to eliminate the trade adjustment assistance program, which pays benefits to workers who lose jobs because of competition from foreign imports.
 
Centers Make a Contribution
 Numerous studies have concluded that community health centers make a substantial contribution to lowering infant mortality because they serve low-income people who would not otherwise receive prenatal, obstetric or pediatric care.
President Bush's budget, sent to Congress on Monday, says that "infant mortality is most severe in some of the nation's cities, several of which have infant mortality rates rivaling those of developing nations."
The budget also notes that the "mortality rate for black babies is more than twice the rate for white babies."
In 1989, Mr. Hawkins said, 10,000 babies were born to women under 16 years old. About 3,500 of those women received prenatal care in community health centers and had their babies delivered by doctors working for such centers, he said.
Of the 5.35 million people served each year by community health centers, 60 percent have annual incomes below the poverty level ($13,360 for a family of four last year). In addition, 30 percent of the patients have incomes between the poverty level and twice that amount.
Cornell Scott, executive director of the Hill Health Center in New Haven, which serves 12,000 people and is receiving $500,000 from the Federal Government this year, said: "There are more than 10 cities that have problems with infant mortality. If we are sincere about addressing the problem, we ought to increase the available resources and not just reallocate existing money."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington;
BAKER SKETCHES FUTURE GULF ROLE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d sketched the Administration's postwar vision for the Persian Gulf for the first time today, suggesting it would require some continued American military role in the region and possibly international aid to rebuild Iraq's economy.
While Mr. Baker was not specific on this point, it would seem that any postwar reconstruction aid to Iraq would be conditioned on the removal of Saddam Hussein as President, something President Bush said Tuesday he would welcome as a result of the war.
 
Recovery, Not Revenge
 "No one should forget that for the second time in a decade the people of Iraq will be recovering from a disastrous conflict," Mr. Baker said in testimony to the House Foreign Affairs Committee. "The time of reconstruction and recovery should not be the occasion for vengeful actions against a nation forced to war by a dictator's ambition. The secure and prosperous future everyone hopes to see in the gulf must include Iraq." 
 Mr. Baker said that in the view of the Bush Administration, any postwar settlement would have to be based on five pillars. The first would be a new security arrangement among gulf countries, including Iraq and Iran, to stabilize the balance of power in the region and deter any nation from devouring its neighbor.
The second should be an arms control agreement, at least among supplier nations, that would constrain Iraq from rebuilding its chemical, biological and nuclear weapons plants, he said, and the third would be a program of economic reconstruction to ease tensions between the haves and have-nots in the Arab world.
The fourth element of a postwar settlement would be a renewed effort to settle Israeli conflicts with Palestinians and with Arab countries, to remove one of the main sources of instability in the region, Mr. Baker said, and the fifth would be a "comprehensive strategy" by the United States to reduce its dependence on imported oil.
Sketching the outlines of the Administration's approach to the postwar period -- which were drawn up in consultations involving the White House, the Pentagon and the State Department -- Mr. Baker emphasized that the exact policies adopted by Washington would depend greatly on how the gulf war ends.
"It would be irresponsible" not to begin thinking about the postwar order, he said, but "it would be premature and unwise for us to lay out a detailed blueprint for the postwar gulf, or for the region as a whole."
 
Different Messages
 In going even as far as he did today, Mr. Baker seemed to be speaking to several different audiences. To a Congress beginning to wonder whether the war might end with an American military victory followed by a political defeat, Mr. Baker seemed to be saying the Administration was going to do its best not to let that happen.
To the Iraqis, he seemed to be saying that the United States bears animosity not toward them as a people, but only toward Mr. Hussein, and that if he is removed, Washington and its allies could be very forthcoming. He thus spoke to the point made Tuesday by Mr. Bush, who said, "We do not seek Iraq's destruction, nor do we seek to punish the Iraqi people for the decisions and policies of their leaders."
To the Arab world, Mr. Baker seemed to be trying to say that Washington is not looking to impose a "pax Americana" in the Middle East, and that the United States would, in conjunction with the region's peoples, address other festering issues like the Arab-Israeli dispute after the war is over.
 
Optimism Versus Caution
 A certain tension between optimism and sobriety ran through Mr. Baker's words. That tension appears to be running through the Administration as a whole, with some officials believing that opportunities for peacemaking in the Middle East will abound after this war and others believing that the United States should limit itself to getting the Iraqis out of Kuwait and then coming home as fast as possible.
At times Mr. Baker's approach to a postwar Middle East seemed coldly realistic, based on very low expectations of what any outside power can do to reorder that part of the world. At other times it seemed almost naive, particularly when he spoke about working not simply for an end to the state of war between Israel and the Arabs, but for "real reconciliation based on enduring respect, tolerance and mutual trust."
He reminded the lawmakers that "modern history has shown that no single nation can long impose its will or remake the Middle East in its own image."
But he added, "I truly believe that there must be a way, working in consultation with all of the affected nations, to set a course that brings greater security for all and enduring peace."
 
Regional Bodies Cited
 Elaborating on his plan, Mr. Baker said the new security arrangement to stabilize the balance of power would have to be based on "the states of the gulf and regional organizations such as the Gulf Cooperation Council" that would take the "lead in building a reinforcing network of new and strengthened security ties" so no nation would feel free to devour its neighbor.
"No regional state should be excluded from these arrangements," he said, in a clear overture to Iran and the future Iraq. "Postwar Iraq could have an important contribution to play. And so could Iran as a major power in the gulu.f'
But Mr. Baker quickly added that outside powers would also have to play a role to make sure that borders are respected. He seemed to suggest that the United States would maintain its longstanding naval presence in the gulf, and forge separate security arrangements with various Arab states that would allow it to position war materiel on their soil and engage in regular joint military exercises.
He reiterated the President's commitment to remove all American ground forces from the gulf once Iraq is ousted from Kuwait. But he said there would be a transitional period immediately after the war, and suggested the possibility of a permanent ground force made up of local troops under the Gulf Cooperation Council or the United Nations.
 
Looking to Arms Control
 On the subject of arms control, Mr. Baker noted that five Middle Eastern countries had more main battle tanks than Britain or France. After the war, he said, the United States and other powers will have to ask not only how they can insure that Iraq never again acquires weapons of mass destruction, but also how to tighten "supply restraints on the flow of weapons and dual-use technology into the region."
Mr. Baker said efforts should also be made to rebuild Iraq economically, both to make it a stable and functioning state and to remove one of the main "sources of conflict" in the region -- a widespread feeling that the Arab oil countries are not sharing their wealth or investing it with their neighbors.
"It might be possible for a coalition of countries, using both local and external resources, to transform the outlook for the region, in expanding free trade and investment and assisting development and in promoting growth oriented economic policies," he said.
As for renewed efforts to solve the Arab-Israeli dispute, Mr. Baker emphasized the need for "real reconciliation," but added, "The course of this crisis has stirred emotions among Israelis and Palestinians that will not yield easily to reconciliation." If the parties themselves are really willing to move toward peace, he said, Washington will be there to help.
 
--------

 
Briton Weighs Postwar Ideas
 LONDON, Feb. 6 (Special to The New York Times) -- The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said today that he would fly to Egypt and Saudi Arabia this weekend to solicit ideas about security arrangements in the gulf after the end of the war.
"There's a pretty fair consensus that the main ideas have got to come from the region," he told a group of American correspondents tonight. "The whole instinct in Britain and the United States will be to bring the boys home as soon as possible. We don't imagine it will be possible to keep ground forces in the area."
"Naval and air forces, and prepositioned equipment, are a different thing," he said, but it would be up to the countries in the region to say whether they would be required.
The Foreign Secretary and other aides to Prime Minister John Major said today that the timing of an allied ground offensive to force Iraq out of Kuwait would depend on an assessment of how much the bombing campaign had weakened Iraq's ability to inflict heavy casualties.
Mr. Hurd, like other European officials, has emphasized the importance of seeking after the war to reach a settlement of the Palestinian problem, which in Britain's view would mean Israel's giving up the West Bank in exchange for an Arab commitment to peace.
The Foreign Secretary dismissed Iraq's announcement today that it was breaking off diplomatic relations with the United States and its allies in the war as "a pretty empty decision."

HEADLINE: Times Mirror Net Off 38.5%

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Company, the nation's third- largest media company, said today that fourth-quarter profits fell 38.5 percent, to $45.6 million, and that it expects the slump to stretch through the first quarter.
"With the nation's economy still in a recession and advertising revenues severely impacted by the outbreak of war, we now anticipate significant deterioration in our operating performance in the first quarter of 1991," Robert Erburu, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.
Earnings per share in the quarter fell to 35 cents, from 57 cents a year earlier, when earnings were $74.1 million. Quarterly revenues edged up 2.3 percent, to $956.5 million from $935.4 million.
Earnings for the year fell 39.4 percent, to $180.5 million, from $298 million a year earlier, while revenues rose to $3.63 billion from $3.52 billion.
The company, owns The Los Angeles Times, a number of other newspapers, and book publishing, magazine, broadcasting and cable television properties.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Why They Say The Bear Is Dead

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
IS it the beginning of the end of the bear market? Or is it a fool's rally that will fizzle with the next grim headline from the Persian Gulf or the next disappointing statistics from Washington?
Some leading market forecasters -- Steven G. Einhorn, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Byron R. Wien, the market strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, for example -- are declaring the bear market dead. A new bull is born, they proclaim. Of course, so does Joseph Granville, the flamboyant forecaster who in September was warning of a 1929-style crash and depression. 
 Mr. Wien observed: "The Standard & Poor's 500 is up from about 310 in January to more than 350 now -- in less than four weeks. I don't know how high it's going, but that is a good year's performance in a month."
Laggards have already missed part of this rally, if one measures the market's performance from Oct. 11, the date of its lowest point since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. More recently, "the Dow was at 2,475 just two days before the war broke out, and that was only 100 points above its October low," said Mr. Einhorn, adding: "The bear market ended, and it ended in October. But this is a bull market, and in a bull, there is a lot more to go than just the 12 to 13 percent we've had."
The most commonly cited reason for the investor enthusiasm is the recent efforts by the Federal Reserve to spur the economy and increase the available money supply through the easing of interest rates. "The market has a rule: never fight the Fed," Mr. Wien said.Some technical analysts, who monitor the market by studying its mathematical relationships, have also declared an end to the bear market. Some, for example, define the arrival of a bull market as that point when the major market barometers -- the Dow, the S.& P. 500, the Dow averages of transportation and utility stocks -- have advanced beyond their average level for the previous 200 days. Last week, those market barometers did just that, said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
One factor supporting the bullish case is the amount of cash in the hands of institutional money managers. At the end of December, for example, stock mutual funds had 11.4 percent of their assets in cash. That was down from a record 12.9 percent at the end of October, shortly after the market's pivot point, but it is well above normal levels.
Most institutional investors -- pension funds, big mutual funds, insurance companies -- would find it hard to put all their cash to work quickly. Thus, they are desperate for advice about when to jump aboard, said Mr. Miller. "Institutions don't feel they can afford to fall behind, especially since their performance has suffered so much in the past few quarters," Mr. Miller said. "They see this market as a moving train that you don't have the luxury of missing."
The reason is simple, said Mr. Wien of Morgan Stanley. "It is usually in the first few weeks of a bull market that you get the fastest and most dramatic improvement," Mr. Wien said.
There are other esoteric indicators that suggest a bull market has arrived, said Richard Eakle, a technician who is president of Eakle Associates in Fair Haven, N.J. He has calculated the year-over-year rate of change for the S.& P. 500 for each month, and compared that with its average change for the previous year. Tracing that historic pattern and comparing it with the market's subsequent behavior, Mr. Eakle found there were certain points when this freshly minted indicator signaled that it was time to buy stocks -- that is, times when the market was beginning a long climb upward. Such signals were rare, Mr. Eakle found. But one occurred, by his calculation, at the end of January.
What is ahead? If there is cautious agreement that the bear market may be dead, there is little consensus among leading strategists about the path the bull market may take. Mr. Einhorn is unequivocal: "The market is going to be a very pleasant place to be for the next 12 to 15 months."
Mr. Wien agrees that the market is heading higher but foresees a roller-coaster market that soars and then falls back as investors conclude that stock prices have outpaced reality.
Mr. Miller is the most cautious of the lot. While he conceded that "the burden of proof is clearly on the bears," he said the rebirth of the bull market rests firmly -- and exclusively -- on faith in the ability of the Federal Reserve to get the nation's money supply to grow at a pace that will encourage investment. "But this economy is showing some sick reflections of 1929-30, and the Fed may not be able to get the job done this time," he warned.
And the day the market begins to suspect that the Federal Reserve is powerless to push liquidity into a sluggish economy, he added, is likely to be the day that investment gurus will start debating about when the bull died.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Geffen Sells His 10.6% Stake In Parent of WWOR-TV

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
David Geffen, the record company executive, said yesterday that he had sold his 10.6 percent interest in Pinelands Inc., the company that owns WWOR-TV, the independent New Jersey television station, for about $30 million.
The station had been part of MCA Inc., of which Mr. Geffen was the largest shareholder. When Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Company bought MCA last year, it spun off the television station into a separate company. United States law forbids foreigners from owning more than 20 percent of an American broadcast property. 
 Mr. Geffen, who has made hundreds of millions of dollars from recent deals, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he sold about 1.7 million shares of Pinelands at prices ranging from $17.50 to $18.50 a share. No reason was given for the sale. He declined to comment on the transaction when reached by telephone.
The stock was sold in the open market late Tuesday by Morgan Stanley & Company. It could not be immediately determined if one company or person had bought Mr. Geffen's stake.
WWOR, based in Secaucus, N.J., broadcasts on Channel 9 in the New York market.
Given the softness of the television business because of a weak advertising market, the most logical buyers of a stake in Pinelands, or possibly of the whole operation, would be companies that already own stations and that would want another one in a major urban market. That list would include Chris-Craft Industries, Paramount Communications and the Walt Disney Company.
However, there may not be many buyers right now. Industry experts said they doubted that either Paramount or Disney were buyers of the stock, in part because the price for the entire company is considered high.
 
Pinelands' Major Shareholders
 Pinelands' major shareholders are Gabelli & Company, a New York investment firm headed by Mario J. Gabelli; a variety of trusts controlled by Lew Wasserman, the chairman of MCA, and Capital Guardian Research Group, the Los Angeles-based investment firm. Gabelli and Capital each hold about 5 percent of the stock.
Although Mr. Geffen had indicated in the last few months that he might increase his stake in Pinelands, Mr. Gabelli said yesterday that he had been skeptical of such a move.
"We felt that there was no intention that Geffen was going to buy Pinelands," Mr. Gabelli said. "It did not make economic sense as a stand-alone purchase."
Shares of Pinelands closed at $18 yesterday, up 37.5 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Howard Stark, an investment banker who specializes in broadcast properties, said the station had cash flow of about $30 million in the first nine months of 1990 on revenues of about $140 million. That would put the cash flow for the year at $40 million. If the station were sold for 10 times cash flow, it would be worth about $400 million.

HEADLINE: Insurance Giants No Longer Ask To Be All Things to All People

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
Some of the oldest and best-known American insurance companies have decided to abandon their all-things-to-all-people approach in favor of a narrower focus. The change could substantially affect rates for many kinds of insurance, the prices of insurance stocks and the economy in the Northeast, where the largest insurance companies are based.
Stung by losses or shrinking profits in many of their businesses, the insurers are sharply cutting back on or abandoning entire areas of insurance, selling unrelated businesses, closing offices and laying off workers. 
 Not long ago, for instance, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced that it would no longer sell individual health insurance policies nationwide. It has also stopped selling automobile and homeowner policies in seven states and hinted that it might leave those businesses.
 
Cutbacks in Many Areas
 The Cigna Corporation has withdrawn from insuring private automobiles as well as from insuring banks against employee fraud. It is also cutting back in workers' compensation and professional liability insurance.
The Travelers Corporation has sold its mutual funds company and announced a withdrawal from personal insurance -- individual policies dealing with homes, cars and health -- in nine states.
"There was a time when this company wanted to write every type of policy in all 50 states," said Walter Fitzgibbon, chief actuary of Aetna. "We just don't want to do that any longer."
In scaling back, the insurers are rapidly bringing to a close the lengthy era of the "multiline insurer," the company that attempted to sell everything from life policies for newlyweds to fire insurance for homeowners to liability coverage for corporations.
 
Subsidizing Losses
 Some economists say that because of the change, insurers will no longer need to hold prices artificially high in some lines of coverage -- health insurance, for example -- to subsidize losses suffered in, say, automobile insurance.
But others say that the withdrawal from various markets by insurers will allow competitors to raise prices and leave an increasing number of people unable to find affordable insurance, forcing them into government-run insurance pools.
The sharp reductions in insurance-industry employment resulting from the increased specialization -- for example, cuts in middle managers like those made in recent years by many industrial companies -- could hurt the Northeast economy. Many multiline insurers have their headquarters in the New York (Continental, Chubb), Hartford (Aetna, Travelers, ITT Hartford) and Philadelphia (Cigna) areas.
The multiline insurers collectively employ 400,000 people in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts.
Aetna said in October that it would lay off 2,600 employees, or 5 percent of its United States work force, and subject each of its remaining businesses to a profitability test -- retaining only those businesses that passed. "We must have an expectation that over time the business will not only become significant but produce an adequate return -- 15 percent," said Edmund S. Kelly, president of Aetna's employee benefits division.
 
Questions Remain
 As industry profitability improves because of the increasing specialization, investors in the stocks of multi line insurers could expect improvement on the weak returns they have seen in recent years, analysts say. (A number of other insurance giants, including Prudential, based in Newark, and Metropolitan Life and Equitable Life Assurance, based in New York, are owned by their policyholders rather than investors and in any case are already specialists, typically in life and health insurance.)
But questions remain about whether any of these companies can successfully become specialists. It is unclear whether the multiline insurers can sell their unwanted divisions at anything but unacceptably large losses. And some experts wonder whether the industry's top executives will have the resolve to make the changes. The restructuring that has begun among the multiline insurers could require large layoffs at companies that have had unwritten policies of lifetime employment.
"The cultural adjustments needed are staggering," said Robert Posnak, chairman of the insurance practice at Ernst & Young, the big accounting and consulting firm. "Given the paternalistic history of this business, it will be very hard for any of these giant companies to make the needed changes."
Insurance companies, many of which began in the 19th century as fire insurers, diversified into many lines at the turn of the century as a way of countering the cyclical nature of various lines of insurance. Property and casualty insurance, for example, is notorious for its ups and downs in prices and profits. Just as industrial conglomerates sprang up in the 1960's as a way to smooth earnings, so too insurance executives reasoned that losses in the property-casualty business could be offset by profits in, say, life insurance.
 
Medical Costs Cited
 But now, many of the businesses in which the multiline insurers compete have gone bad at once, and so the insurers are finding it harder to offset one business's losses with another's profits.
In auto insurance, the problems have included rapidly rising medical and car-repair costs. In liability insurance for business, the troubles have included competitive price cutting and large jury awards. In life insurance, increasing rates of return paid to policyholders and problems with life insurers' investments, most notably real estate, have cut deeply into profits. In workers' compensation insurance, regulations have held down premiums and profits.
As a result, many multiline insurers are earning less than 10 percent a year for their investors, barely more than they could earn on a risk-free investment like a Treasury bill.
Insurers are also being forced to streamline by the increasing militance of their institutional investors and by the growing worry of policyholders over solvency. Insurance company failures fell to 35 in 1990 after reaching a 1980's peak of 44 in 1989. Still, industry executives believe that the best way to alleviate public concern is to generate higher profits -- and quickly.
"The old modus operandi has obviously not worked," said Miron Picoult, the insurance analyst at Oppenheimer Inc.
 
Differences Are Widening
 The shifts among multiline insurers are already widening the differences among the players. Aetna, Travelers and Cigna are making major pushes in group health insurance by setting up "managed care" networks of doctors and hospitals for clients trying to contain costs. Chubb continues to focus on the upper end of the market -- large, blue-chip companies and wealthy individuals. The Continental Corporation, having sold its life- and health-insurance businesses, is now purely a property-and-casualty insurer focusing on mid-sized manufacturers and shipping concerns.
Among other changes: Crum & Forster, the insurance subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation, has been shrinking its workers' compensation division. The Lincoln National Corporation has sold its reinsurance division.
Some insurers, such like Cigna, are trying wholesale withdrawals from certain lines. Others, including Aetna, are pulling out only in certain states, although two states, Massachusetts and New Jersey, are resisting such "cherry picking" by insisting that insurers sell all or nothing. Still others, like Crum & Forster, are reducing the amount they sell of certain lines across the country.
Some economists argue that it is always positive for consumers and investors when an industry applies more discipline. High-cost operations are weeded out and leaner players can offer better prices.
 
A Possible Void
 "An industry that has been portrayed by many as sleepy is waking up with a vengeance," said George G. C. Parker, who teaches the course in financial institutions at the Stanford Business School. "This restructuring, while painful to insurers, could be beneficial to consumers."
Others are not convinced. For example, as Aetna, Travelers, Cigna, Crum & Forster and other insurers scale back their money-losing auto-insurance operations, one possibility is that no other insurer will find the business sufficiently attractive to fill the void.
"You could get into availability problems," said William Meehan, a senior insurance specialist at McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm. "More and more people would go uninsured; more and more people would be forced into state-run insurance pools."
Other experts see low-cost, high-volume operators like State Farm and Allstate rushing in to pick up the business. But this, carried to the extreme, could have a troublesome consequence: "If a State Farm or an Allstate got up to 30 percent in terms of market share, you'd begin to see something approaching a classic oligopoly," said David Cummins, a professor of insurance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan;
Jordanian Ends Neutrality, Assailing Allied War Effort

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Evoking Islamic faith and Arab honor, King Hussein of Jordan abandoned his professed neutrality in the Persian Gulf war tonight to align himself with Iraq.
The allied war effort, he declared, is "against all Arabs and all Muslims and not against Iraq alone" and is intended to assert "foreign hegemony" in the Middle East. 
 The King's 30-minute address to the nation on television represented his most unequivocal pro-Iraqi statement of the crisis and seemed a direct rebuttal of an appeal to him by President Bush for a public statement of understanding for America's position in the war.
Without once referring to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Jordanian leader seemed to abandon his previous professions of neutrality in the conflict, saying he saluted Iraq's people and army "as they defend us all and raise the banner that says: God is great." His speech echoed themes routinely broadcast by Iraq.
 
Talk of a Cease-Fire
 The true intention of the Western allies, the King said, is to "destroy Iraq and reorganize the area in a manner far more dangerous to our people than the Sykes-Picot agreement," which split the Middle East into areas of French and British spheres of influence after the First World War. The mere mention of the British-French agreement is highly emotive in the Arab world because it symbolizes dominance and manipulation by foreigners not of the Islamic faith.
The King laced his speech with references to pan-Arab nationalism and urged Arabs to demand a cease-fire and negotiations.
"Let us bring this war to an end," he said. "The starting point is immediate and serious work to make the alliance accept a cease-fire in preparation for a responsible dialogue between the antagonists, an Iraqi-American dialogue and an Arab-Arab dialogue that resorts to reason and balances interests against international legitimacy, the legitimacy of security, justice, peace and equality."
He seemed to be addressing his own domestic constituency, more than half of which is composed of fervently pro-Iraqi Palestinians, and to be signaling renewed support to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. But the reasons behind the timing of the address were unclear.
 
Western Diplomats Surprised
 The speech took Western diplomats by surprise since many had argued that the King would seek to maintain a position of neutrality so as to carve out a mediator's position and seek Western economic benevolence at a time of crisis.
In Arab political terms, the King also seemed to abandon the caution by which he has ruled as a frequently pro-Western figure in this troubled region for 37 years, criticizing both Egypt and Saudi Arabia for their roles in the Western-led alliance.
"This war is a war against all Arabs and all Muslims and not against Iraq alone," he said, urging Arabs and Muslims to support Iraq against the "fierce war imposed on brotherly Iraq."
Earlier today, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said the United States was not seeking to destabilize Jordan. Many Jordanians have suggested just that because of recent United States pronouncements urging all Americans to leave the country as soon as possible and suggesting complicity between Jordanian truck drivers bringing oil from Iraq and Iraqi military transporters in western Iraq.
Allied warplanes have launched sustained bombing raids on the main highway through western Iraq, apparently striking at military vehicles suspected of carrying Scud-B missile spares, but also killing eight Jordanian truck drivers and wrecking more than 35 tanker-trucks.
"There were new attempts to deprive us of our needs of oil and that was one way of imposing sanctions against us for no reason except our basic position" of neutrality, the King said. Jordan, he said, is "not willing to dance to the tune others play without being able to freely express our opinion, which we will not give up."
"If the battle is imposed on us we will be up to it," the King said.
 
New Sources of Oil Sought
 He evoked his family dynasty as the Hashemite descendants of the Prophet Mohammed, a dynasty that fought bitter disputes with the ruling Saudi family in the 1920's.
"This is a cry from a Hashemite Arab," he said, "Let us join our efforts to stop this tragedy and to save the people of Iraq from what is planned for it and to end this war."
The uncharacteristically virulent speech and the King's public embrace of unusually radical views coincided with a deepening threat of economic disruption here.
Jordan's main oil supply route through western Iraq has become so perilous that the country is receiving only a fraction of its usual supplies, raising the possibility of severe shortages of both fuel and electric power from oil-powered generators. The losses have deepened a profound sense of grievance that this small kingdom is being punished by the West in general and the United States in particular for a predicament over which it has no control.
 
A Mistake, Bush Says
 
By Reuters
President Bush yesterday rejected Jordan's call for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war and said King Hussein was making a mistake by aligning his country more closely with Iraq.
Mr. Bush, responding to the Jordanian leader's speech earlier in the day, told reporters en route to New York that the United States had not exceeded the United Nations mandate to force Iraq out of Kuwait. "I'm afraid that we have a major disagreement on that," Mr. Bush said. "It's not true,
"We've tried to make clear with Jordan that we have no argument with Jordan," he said. "I think they made a mistake to align themselves so closely to Saddam Hussein against the rest of the world."

HEADLINE: Bush Is Confident Economy Will Rebound

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

 BODY:
President Bush, elected on a platform of peace and prosperity only to find himself plunged into war and recession, promised the business community last night that the economy would overcome "temporary disturbances and short-term setbacks."
"While our economy may be beset by difficulty, it should not be beset by doubt," Mr. Bush told business executives at a dinner of the Economic Club at the New York Hilton in midtown Manhattan. 
 In a speech upbeat in tone but short on specifics, Mr. Bush tried to reassure the business community with predictions that "our best days are before us."
No President wants to take the blame for a recession and Mr. Bush is no exception. He asserted that a slowing American economy had been pushed over the edge into recession by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
 
Shock of Invasion
 "When Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, it was a shock to the world's conscience," and business and consumer confidence fell, the President said.
But in response to questions after his speech Mr. Bush forecast that the recession would be shallow and that "in a couple of quarters, we'll come out of this and we'll have a robust economy." In support of that forecast, he pointed to the recent strong rally in the stock market and said it indicated pessimism was on the decline.
Mr. Bush's trip to New York was his first visit outside Washington unrelated to the military since the United State-led force attacked Iraq three weeks ago.
The President arrived at the hotel in a 40-car motorcade from Newark International Airport amid tightened security precautions that included 1,500 plainclothes and uniformed officers guarding his route and sharpshooters positioned on rooftops, the police said. About 3,500 antiwar protesters staged a noisy demonstration outside the hotel and 10 were arrested, but mostly for blocking traffic, the police said.
In his speech, Mr. Bush acknowledged that the war, the savings and loan crisis and the recession "haven't helped a bit" in controlling the deficit that has burdened the nation. But he promised that with the bipartisan budget agreement in place, the deficit would be "virtually eliminated" by 1995.
Mr. Bush said the Administration would also try to spur economic growth by scaling back on "counter-productive" Government regulations, providing incentives to promote private savings and "job-creating investments" and putting Federal money into education, public works and space technology.
Asked about whether the so-called peace dividend that had been hoped for as the Cold War with the Soviet Union ended could still materialize, the President said defense spending was reduced in the budget he submitted to Congress this week. But he joked that he had been brought up to believe that dividends were paid out of profits, and he noted: "We're operating at a three-hundred-and-some-jillion-dollar deficit, so we're not in exactly a dividend-paying mode."
The President voiced optimism that the stalled Uruguay round of trade talks would be concluded successfully but he added that both Japan and Germany "have got to give us access to markets." He said he hoped that a victory in the gulf would add to the United States' credibility in those talks and perhaps make Japan and Germany more willing to compromise.
 
Must Avoid Extreme Measures
 In his speech the President also somewhat defensively continued to reject suggestions, heightened since the war, that he propose conservation measures and strategies to make the country less dependent on foreign oil.
"Some will argue that reducing our energy vulnerability is not enough, and that we should embark upon more drastic measures designed to achieve total energy independence," he said. "The reality is that we are a long way from total energy independence. We must avoid unwise and extreme measures that would seriously hurt American consumers, American jobs and American industries."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Kodak Posts Improved Earnings

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company, best known as a producer of photographic film, yesterday reported strong earnings for the fourth quarter and year, despite a $564 million after-tax charge to settle its patent-infringement case with the Polaroid Corporation. Most of the quarterly growth came from overseas operations.
"Despite a sluggish U.S. economy, 1990 was clearly a recovery year for Kodak," Kay R. Whitmore, the chairman, said in a statement. "Significant factors contributing to higher earnings were gains in manufacturing productivity and the favorable effects of foreign currency rate changes." 
 He said the company expected "good gains in sales, with acceleration expected later in the year, as economic conditions improve and the impact of new products is felt."
 
Higher Costs Foreseen
 But the forecast warned of higher costs for advertising, research and development and plant start-ups, which could hold down profitability. "These investments in the Kodak brand, in innovation and technology will place us in an advantaged position when economic recovery comes," the statement said.
Wall Street was not impressed, though. On the New York Stock Exchange, on a day when the market roared ahead, Kodak's shares lost $2.25 each, to $44. The shares fell after release of the earnings, which were slightly below expectations.
Analysts said Kodak officials had told them that estimates that the company would earn $4.25 a share this year were too high, and also cited disappointment with the 1990 result.
"The stock had run up in anticipation of the earnings, and it was overpriced," said David Presson of Edward D. Jones & Company. The closing price of $46.25 on Tuesday was the highest since October 1989.
Kodak's year-to-year comparisons were affected by the one-time costs of the settlement in 1990 and an $875 million charge in 1989 reflecting the costs of restructuring.
 
Earnings at $326 Million
 In the quarter, the company earned $326 million, or $1.01 a share, compared with a loss of $60 million. Its sales totaled $5.15 billion, up 5.5 percent from $4.88 billion.
For the year, earnings totaled $703 million, or $2.17 a share, up 32.8 percent from $529 million, or $1.63 a share. Kodak's sales totaled $18.90 billion, up slightly from $18.39 billion.
A Federal judge imposed a penalty of $909 million on Kodak last year after the company had been found guilty of violating Polaroid's patents on instant photography. The award was subsequently reduced to $888 million, which produced the $564 million charge after taxes.
Overseas sales increased 11.2 percent, to $2.3 billion, while domestic sales rose 1 percent, to $2.8 billion. For the year, domestic sales declined 1.8 percent, to $10.1 billion, while international sales rose 8.5 percent, to $8.8 billion.
Earnings of the company's imaging, or photography, division totaled $425 million in the quarter, compared with $306 million before restructuring costs and an actual $94 million. Kodak said higher film sales and prices overseas were responsible for the gain.
Kodak's information, or copier, sector posted a loss of $61 million in the quarter, compared with a profit of $28 million before the one-time costs. The company said higher costs were to blame for the earnings decline.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises By 42.57, To 2,830.94

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks rallied briskly yesterday for the third day in a row as investors scrambled to pour more money into what many on Wall Street see as the start of a new bull market.
From the blue chips on the New York Stock Exchange to the smaller, lesser-known issues on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market, stocks moved sharply higher as banks, insurance companies and mutual funds entered the market. 
 Although some money managers were already sounding warnings of speculative excesses and more earnings disappointments, the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 42.57 points, or 1.5 percent, to 2,830.94.
 
Highest Close Since August
 This was the highest close for the Dow since Aug. 2, the day Iraq invaded Kuwait -- when the average closed at 2,864.60 -- and its first close above 2,800 since Aug. 3.
Trading soared to 276.9 million shares, only slightly less than 290.6 million the day before. In a decidedly bullish ratio approaching three to one, 1,222 Big Board stocks advanced while only 449 declined. And 173 stocks, including Merck, I.B.M. and International Paper, hit new highs.
The Dow now stands only 168 points away from its all-time high in July, when it came within an inch of 3,000. And now, some of Wall Street's leading forecasters are declaring the bear market dead. [Page D12.]
Yesterday's disappointment was Kodak, which slumped 2 1/4, to 44, although it reported fourth-quarter profits of $326 million. Analysts said the profit was less than expected.
 
Impetus From the Fed
 One reason investors are jumping into the market is because everyone is doing it. But the rather late conclusion by the Federal Reserve Board that the time has come for action to bring down interest rates is generally regarded as the main reason.
Both the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks and the Amex's market-value index jumped almost 2 percent, or the equivalent of a little more than 50 Dow points. The Nasdaq composite index of O-T-C stocks climbed 45 Dow points.
The Dow transportation index climbed more than 2 percent, with Delta Air Lines ahead 2 1/2, to 72 1/8; UAL up 2 5/8, to 136 1/2, and gains of a point of more by AMR, Airborne Freight, Southwest Airlines, Burlington Northern, Xtra and Union Pacific.
Interest-sensitive stocks continued to gain, although at a slower pace. BankAmerica rose 5/8, to 32 5/8, in heavy trading. CNA surged 3 1/2, to 78; AIG 2 1/2, to 88; Chubb 1 3/8, to 63 5/8, and Marsh & McLennan 1 3/4, to 76 3/4.
Chemical stocks, which would be a big beneficiary of an economic upturn, rose almost across the board. Monsanto, which forecast a profit rebound, jumped 4, to 57, in strong trading. ARCO Chemical rose 2 1/4, to 38 3/4, and Du Pont added 1 3/4, to 37.
Technology stocks also moved sharply higher in heavy trading. I.B.M. rose 1 3/8, to 129 7/8, after hitting a new high for the year of 130. Honeywell rose 1 3/4, to 51 1/4, while Digital Equipment tacked on 2 1/2, to 72 7/8. Microsoft rose 4 1/2, to 105 3/4, and Intel rose 2, to 50, both in heavy trading. Compaq Computer, which rose as high as 71 3/8, fell 2, to 69 1/8.
International Paper, a leader in the forestry group, rose 2 1/8, to 61 3/4, after touching a new high of 62 1/4. Kimberly-Clark, which hit a new high of 87 3/8, rose 1 1/8, to 87.
On a cautionary note, William S. Stack, chief investment officer for the Lexington Management Corporation, with $2.5 billion in investments, said: "The market's a little ahead of itself because we still have disappointing earnings ahead. It's telling us that the recession's over but it isn't."
Asked if he was putting any more money into the market, he replied, "Not lately; we think the market's too hot and we'll see better prices."
New data suggest that the enormous flow of money into the market has come in just the last few days. Indata, the weekly service based in Stamford, Conn., said that 59 mutual fund clients held 10.8 percent of their assets in cash as of Jan. 18, but that the total fell to 10.3 percent by Jan. 25, suggesting that $678 million -- or roughly $135 million a day -- poured into the market in one week.
But by Jan. 31, Indata said, cash was 10.4 percent of assets, or more than $2 billion, and money managers had not spent any through that period. As a result, the heavy inflow may have come between Jan. 31 and now.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said heavy computerized buying lifted the Dow 43 points yesterday. The New York Stock Exchange said such trading was 17 percent of the volume, or more than 30 million shares a day, in the week ending Jan. 18. The week before, it accounted for 10.1 percent, or 14.3 million shares daily.
