HEADLINE: Planners' Vision of Newark Arts Center

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 6

 BODY:
A comprehensive master plan for a $200 million arts complex near Newark's troubled central business district was made public today by the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
As the state's governor and the city's mayor pledged their support during a news conference, the planners announced an ambitious blueprint for using an arts complex as a device to stimulate growth in a downtown area that has undergone something of a revival after suffering major losses in population and employment over the past several decades. The plan calls for a four-building, Lincoln Center-like arts plaza, and also sought to establish planning guidelines for a new cultural district that would unite Newark's disparate downtown area for the first time in its history. 
 "My presence here is intended to be a reassurance that the state is making a full commitment to this program," said Gov. Jim Florio in an interview. His attendance at the news conference gave the support of the Democratic Governor to a project originally endorsed by a Republican, Gov. Thomas H. Kean, in 1987.
The Governor, who recently announced deep cuts in government across the state, said his commitment to the project was firm. He referred to $20 million in low-interest state bonds that he pledged to buy a 12-acre tract and do site reconstruction. The state will buy the land and lease it back to the arts center for 99 years.
In the first phase of development, scheduled for completion for the 1995-96 cultural season, $70 million will be needed for a multi-use hall, plus another $70 million for site work, including the construction of a plaza and the refurbishment of a 1,100-space parking garage. The second phase of the plan, the construction of a concert hall, is budgeted at $60 million and scheduled for completion in 1998.
So far, New Jersey's business community has pledged $33 million toward the completion of the arts center. In addition to the $20 million pledged by Governor Florio, the Federal Government has committed $1.2 million toward planning, design and construction, said to Lawrence P. Goldman, the president of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Mr. Goldman said the remainder would come from private contributions and Federal, state, county and city sources.
The master plan, in preparation for more than a year, was designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and James Stewart Polshek & Partners. It envisions an arts center consisting of a 2,700-seat multi-purpose hall in a building that also houses a 300-seat experimental theater. A second concert hall, with 2,400 seats, would be the home of the New Jersey Symphony.
The complex would have an open plaza comparable in size to Lincoln Center's, and would include two office and residential buildings, bringing leasing and investment revenues to the center.
The 12-acre site for the center is to be part of a 50-acre cultural district facing Newark's waterfront.
If the city approves -- and Mayor Sharpe James said yesterday that he supported the cultural district plan -- the area would be zoned to create ordered development, establishing uniform lighting and streetscape standards, and providing for shops, cafes, restaurants, promenades and pedestrian malls.
 
What They Don't Want
 "The Newark waterfront is destined to develop, and when it does, we want to keep it from becoming Stamford, Conn.," said Mr. Goldman. "There, you have superblocks lined by parking garages, where there is no human scale, and consequently you see no people. We do not intend to miss the opportunity to make the cultural district a place where people like to be."
In November, the arts center appointed Barton Myers, a 56-year-old professor of architecture at the University of California at Los Angeles, to design the art center's $70-million multi-use performance hall, which would be home to the New Jersey Symphony until the concert hall is constructed, and would be suitable for theater, dance, opera and pop and ethnic musical presentations.
The multi-use hall is to be on a two-acre site at Park Place and Saybrook Place, across from Military Park in downtown Newark. The arts center's site slopes down from Military Park toward the Passaic River, and includes the knoll upon which Newark's Puritan founders first set foot in 1666.
The master plan specifies that 40 percent of the 12 acres be devoted to private commercial development, concentrated in two buildings. "The arts center will try to capture the value that cultural assets bring to an area," said Mr. Goldman.
 
Profiting From Success
 He said that Lincoln Center did not benefit in revenues from the office and residential buildings that sprang up around it, but that he hoped the Newark center, in accommodating such development on its own land, would profit as has Carnegie Hall after building Carnegie Tower, and the Museum of Modern Art after building Museum Tower.
"In this way, the arts center says to donors, 'We will be entrepreneurial in helping ourselves,' " said Mr. Goldman. "If Lincoln Center had known it would be so successful in 1958, this is exactly what it would have done."
The master plan calls for the realignment of Mulberry Street and Center Street to create "a lively giant outdoor living room where people will feel at home," said Marilyn Jordan Taylor, a partner at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.
On the waterfront at Center Street, the plan envisions a hotel and residential complex, as well as a marina, retail shops and a riverside esplanade, similar to that at the World Financial Center.
 
Commercial Point of View
 Currently 55,000 people travel to jobs each day in the sprawling downtown business enclaves in Newark, Mr. Goldman said. "Some people consider them to be office workers, but we see them as ticket buyers," he said.
The master plan, Mr. Goldman said, will be the bridge between the three disparate areas of Newark's downtown: the building clusters built in the 1920's, the 1950's and the 1970's and 1980's.
 It joins together many of the city's cultural and business landmarks and would link the Ironbound section and Pennsylvania Station in the south with Military Park and Washington Park in the north. Facing Washington Park are the Newark Public Library and the Newark Museum on Washington Street, with its recent $21 million reconstruction by the architect Michael Graves.
The master plan envisions the construction of a tree-lined promenade along Newark's obsolete waterfront that would permit pedestrians to stroll from Pennsylvania Station along the margin of the Passaic River to the arts center site.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 563 words

HEADLINE: Safer Banks

 BODY:
Making banks safe. That's what the Treasury Department's proposed overhaul of the banking system would help accomplish if Congress goes along. Despite some imperfections, the plan incorporates the ingredients needed to propel American banking soundly into the 21st century.
Congress ordered the review of the banking system in the aftermath of the $500 billion bailout of savings and loan institutions. The task was to restructure the industry so that banks could prosper without risking another bailout. The Treasury report meets that challenge intelligently with two fundamental recommendations. 
 First, it proposes allowing diversified investments. Banks would be allowed to open branches across the country and offer their customers insurance, mutual funds and securities underwriting. And banks could be bought by commercial and industrial concerns, providing a desperately needed infusion of capital. In each case, the plan builds in safeguards against misuse of federally insured deposits.
The purpose of such diversification is not to promote high-risk ventures but to dilute the risk of bad investments. Savings and loan institutions went bankrupt because, in the main, they were confined to high-risk real estate loans in states where they were based. When the real estate market in Texas collapsed, so did the S.& L.'s there. If they had included branch offices in Florida and Oregon, they would not have been as vulnerable.
Second, Treasury calls for mandatory intervention. The plan would require regulators to intervene once bank reserves begin to slip. Currently they are sometimes permitted to stop struggling banks from paying out dividends or making new loans. Under the Treasury plan, such intervention would become mandatory.
The far-reaching proposals are already exciting concern from special interests. Small bankers fear interstate banking; insurance agents and securities underwriters fear added competition. But these fears are exaggerated, and Congress would make a grave error were it to stifle competition to protect local fiefs.
 The proposal needs improvement. It would unwisely limit individuals to two federally insured accounts -- each for $100,000 -- at any one bank. Savvy individuals would spread out their money over many banks. But the plan fails to protect unsophisticated pensioners and, in the case of Freedom Bank in Harlem, charities and corporations. Even worse, any rule that makes depositors vulnerable to bank collapse could trip waves of panic withdrawals from sound banks that are the object of fearmongering rumors.
Equally misguided is the report's proposal to outlaw brokered deposits, which are federally insured accounts placed by brokerage houses on behalf of their customers. It is a myth that bidding for brokered deposits drove savings and loans into bankruptcy, according to George Benston of Emory University, a banking expert.
The chief error of the Treasury report is not that it goes too far, as some critics allege, but that it doesn't go far enough. Had the plan called for even higher capital requirements, in combination with mandatory regulatory response, it could have lifted all caps on federally insured deposits without fear.
But that's quibbling. Diversified investments and mandatory intervention are the main ticket to safe banks. The Treasury plan gets that exactly right.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Despite It All, New York Takes Care of Business

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Forecasts that New York City will lose 90,000 jobs in 1991 are distressing, but concerned New Yorkers should also note signs of strength throughout the city's economy. International banking is an example. In 1974, there were 114 foreign banks in New York City; today, there are almost 300. In the last 36 months, 81 foreign banks have signed leases in New York City. As a result, New York's importance as a banking and financial center has skyrocketed.
New York City remains an extremely attractive place to conduct business and an indispensable venue for many companies, where a presence is not just convenient, but even required. The mass of talent -- in accounting, communications, law, finance -- is unavailable elsewhere. The numbers of decision makers, industrialists and financiers per square foot makes New York the world's most important center of commerce.
Short term, the recession will adversely affect employment in New York City. But nothing likely in the current economic cycle will change the fact that tens of thousands of companies are committed to New York because of the prestige they derive from operations here and access to resources available only in New York.
 
DAVID E. BODNER
New York, Jan . 17, 1991
 
 
The writer is an executive vice president of the Zurich-based Bank Julius Baer and general manager of its New York branch.

HEADLINE: Insurance Giants No Longer Ask To Be All Things to All People

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
Some of the oldest and best-known American insurance companies have decided to abandon their all-things-to-all-people approach in favor of a narrower focus. The change could substantially affect rates for many kinds of insurance, the prices of insurance stocks and the economy in the Northeast, where the largest insurance companies are based.
Stung by losses or shrinking profits in many of their businesses, the insurers are sharply cutting back on or abandoning entire areas of insurance, selling unrelated businesses, closing offices and laying off workers. 
 Not long ago, for instance, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced that it would no longer sell individual health insurance policies nationwide. It has also stopped selling automobile and homeowner policies in seven states and hinted that it might leave those businesses.
 
Cutbacks in Many Areas
 The Cigna Corporation has withdrawn from insuring private automobiles as well as from insuring banks against employee fraud. It is also cutting back in workers' compensation and professional liability insurance.
The Travelers Corporation has sold its mutual funds company and announced a withdrawal from personal insurance -- individual policies dealing with homes, cars and health -- in nine states.
"There was a time when this company wanted to write every type of policy in all 50 states," said Walter Fitzgibbon, chief actuary of Aetna. "We just don't want to do that any longer."
In scaling back, the insurers are rapidly bringing to a close the lengthy era of the "multiline insurer," the company that attempted to sell everything from life policies for newlyweds to fire insurance for homeowners to liability coverage for corporations.
 
Subsidizing Losses
 Some economists say that because of the change, insurers will no longer need to hold prices artificially high in some lines of coverage -- health insurance, for example -- to subsidize losses suffered in, say, automobile insurance.
But others say that the withdrawal from various markets by insurers will allow competitors to raise prices and leave an increasing number of people unable to find affordable insurance, forcing them into government-run insurance pools.
The sharp reductions in insurance-industry employment resulting from the increased specialization -- for example, cuts in middle managers like those made in recent years by many industrial companies -- could hurt the Northeast economy. Many multiline insurers have their headquarters in the New York (Continental, Chubb), Hartford (Aetna, Travelers, ITT Hartford) and Philadelphia (Cigna) areas.
The multiline insurers collectively employ 400,000 people in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts.
Aetna said in October that it would lay off 2,600 employees, or 5 percent of its United States work force, and subject each of its remaining businesses to a profitability test -- retaining only those businesses that passed. "We must have an expectation that over time the business will not only become significant but produce an adequate return -- 15 percent," said Edmund S. Kelly, president of Aetna's employee benefits division.
 
Questions Remain
 As industry profitability improves because of the increasing specialization, investors in the stocks of multi line insurers could expect improvement on the weak returns they have seen in recent years, analysts say. (A number of other insurance giants, including Prudential, based in Newark, and Metropolitan Life and Equitable Life Assurance, based in New York, are owned by their policyholders rather than investors and in any case are already specialists, typically in life and health insurance.)
But questions remain about whether any of these companies can successfully become specialists. It is unclear whether the multiline insurers can sell their unwanted divisions at anything but unacceptably large losses. And some experts wonder whether the industry's top executives will have the resolve to make the changes. The restructuring that has begun among the multiline insurers could require large layoffs at companies that have had unwritten policies of lifetime employment.
"The cultural adjustments needed are staggering," said Robert Posnak, chairman of the insurance practice at Ernst & Young, the big accounting and consulting firm. "Given the paternalistic history of this business, it will be very hard for any of these giant companies to make the needed changes."
Insurance companies, many of which began in the 19th century as fire insurers, diversified into many lines at the turn of the century as a way of countering the cyclical nature of various lines of insurance. Property and casualty insurance, for example, is notorious for its ups and downs in prices and profits. Just as industrial conglomerates sprang up in the 1960's as a way to smooth earnings, so too insurance executives reasoned that losses in the property-casualty business could be offset by profits in, say, life insurance.
 
Medical Costs Cited
 But now, many of the businesses in which the multiline insurers compete have gone bad at once, and so the insurers are finding it harder to offset one business's losses with another's profits.
In auto insurance, the problems have included rapidly rising medical and car-repair costs. In liability insurance for business, the troubles have included competitive price cutting and large jury awards. In life insurance, increasing rates of return paid to policyholders and problems with life insurers' investments, most notably real estate, have cut deeply into profits. In workers' compensation insurance, regulations have held down premiums and profits.
As a result, many multiline insurers are earning less than 10 percent a year for their investors, barely more than they could earn on a risk-free investment like a Treasury bill.
Insurers are also being forced to streamline by the increasing militance of their institutional investors and by the growing worry of policyholders over solvency. Insurance company failures fell to 35 in 1990 after reaching a 1980's peak of 44 in 1989. Still, industry executives believe that the best way to alleviate public concern is to generate higher profits -- and quickly.
"The old modus operandi has obviously not worked," said Miron Picoult, the insurance analyst at Oppenheimer Inc.
 
Differences Are Widening
 The shifts among multiline insurers are already widening the differences among the players. Aetna, Travelers and Cigna are making major pushes in group health insurance by setting up "managed care" networks of doctors and hospitals for clients trying to contain costs. Chubb continues to focus on the upper end of the market -- large, blue-chip companies and wealthy individuals. The Continental Corporation, having sold its life- and health-insurance businesses, is now purely a property-and-casualty insurer focusing on mid-sized manufacturers and shipping concerns.
Among other changes: Crum & Forster, the insurance subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation, has been shrinking its workers' compensation division. The Lincoln National Corporation has sold its reinsurance division.
Some insurers, such like Cigna, are trying wholesale withdrawals from certain lines. Others, including Aetna, are pulling out only in certain states, although two states, Massachusetts and New Jersey, are resisting such "cherry picking" by insisting that insurers sell all or nothing. Still others, like Crum & Forster, are reducing the amount they sell of certain lines across the country.
Some economists argue that it is always positive for consumers and investors when an industry applies more discipline. High-cost operations are weeded out and leaner players can offer better prices.
 
A Possible Void
 "An industry that has been portrayed by many as sleepy is waking up with a vengeance," said George G. C. Parker, who teaches the course in financial institutions at the Stanford Business School. "This restructuring, while painful to insurers, could be beneficial to consumers."
Others are not convinced. For example, as Aetna, Travelers, Cigna, Crum & Forster and other insurers scale back their money-losing auto-insurance operations, one possibility is that no other insurer will find the business sufficiently attractive to fill the void.
"You could get into availability problems," said William Meehan, a senior insurance specialist at McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm. "More and more people would go uninsured; more and more people would be forced into state-run insurance pools."
Other experts see low-cost, high-volume operators like State Farm and Allstate rushing in to pick up the business. But this, carried to the extreme, could have a troublesome consequence: "If a State Farm or an Allstate got up to 30 percent in terms of market share, you'd begin to see something approaching a classic oligopoly," said David Cummins, a professor of insurance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 8, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about changes in the insurance industry referred incorrectly to the reinsurance business of the Lincoln National Corporation, based in Fort Wayne, Ind. While Lincoln recently sold a reinsurance company, it remains in the reinsurance business.

HEADLINE: Salvador E. Luria Is Dead at 78; Shared a Nobel Prize in Medicine

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO

 BODY:
Salvador E. Luria, a biologist and physician who shared a 1969 Nobel Prize for his pioneering work in medicine and physiology, died yesterday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 78 years old.
Dr. Luria suffered a heart attack, said a spokesman for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where Dr. Luria had taught since 1959. 
 He won the Nobel Prize for research he did in a loose association with Max Delbruck of the California Institute of Technology and Alfred D. Hershey of the Carnegie Institution's genetics research laboratory in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.
The three were cited for their "discoveries concerning the replication mechanism and the genetic structure of viruses." Their work began the transformation of genetics and contributed to the foundation on which modern molecular biology rests. It shed much light on how viruses work and how more complex organisms reproduce and pass on hereditary characteristics.
 
Active in Peace Movement
 Dr. Luria, who was born in Turin, Italy, was also widely known as an active member of the peace movement and was outspokenly critical of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon and the American intervention in Vietnam.
Apparently because of his candor and independence on such issues, his name appeared on a Federal blacklist of 48 scientists in 1969, the year he won the Nobel Prize.
The National Institutes of Health, which drew up the blacklist, never specified why Dr. Luria, a Jew who became a United States citizen in 1947 after having fled Fascist Italy nine years earlier, should be barred from the institutes' panels.
Dr. Luria was also a critic of what he regarded as a lack of safeguards on nuclear power. In 1976 he joined other scientists in calling for a halt to the building of new atomic power plants.
Besides the work that won the Nobel Prize, Dr. Luria organized a teaching and research program in microbiology at M.I.T. and later founded the M.I.T. Center for Cancer Research, which he directed from 1972 until 1985.
 
A Highly Esteemed Title
 Although he retired from M.I.T. in 1978, he remained active there. At his death he was Institute Professor Emeritus, a title that M.I.T. reserves for the most esteemed members of its faculty.
Dr. Luria's interest in the humanities rivaled his achievements in science. In 1985 he said scientists who "exile themselves from the arena of social struggles" were failing the societies they were supposed to serve.
He urged his science students to develop interests in the humanities. Besides his lectures in science, he offered a course in world literature to graduate students at M.I.T.
In 1974 he won a National Book Award in the Sciences for a nonacademic work, "Life: The Unfinished Experiment." The book, which was published by Charles Scribner's Sons, was translated into Italian, French, Spanish, German and Japanese.
 
'Active Participant' in Politics
 While Dr. Luria was angry over his blacklisting, it did not prevent him from confronting issues he regarded as important. "I made up my mind that as a citizen I would be an active participant in American politics," he once said, "taking advantage of the democratic opportunities that were not available to me in Italy."
He added: "What scientific achievement I have reached is due to the freedom provided in this wealthy country to all aspects of intellectual enterprise."
He advocated "human standards of justice, decency and compassion," and, in a letter to The New York Times in 1982, he said he thought that the Israeli military campaign in Lebanon "violates those standards."
Salvador Edward Luria was born in 1912 and was graduated from the University of Turin, summa cum laude, in 1935. He became a radiology specialist in Rome, but fled Italy in 1938 and continued his research in Paris before immigrating to the United States in 1940.
 
A Teacher and Lecturer
 He did graduate work at Columbia University for two years, and then did more work at Vanderbilt and Princeton universities.
He taught at Indiana University from 1943 to 1959. Before joining M.I.T. he also lectured in biophysics at the University of Colorado, and was Jesup Lecturer in zoology at Columbia. In 1959 he was Niewland Lecturer in biology at the University of Notre Dame.
He served since 1984 as senior scientist at the Repligen Corporation, a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass.
Among his affiliations were the National Academy of Sciences, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Philosophical Society and the American Academy of Microbiology. He was president of microbiology academy in 1967 and 1968.
He held many honorary doctorates, including ones from the University of Chicago, Brown University and the University of Palermo.
Surviving are his wife, Zella Hurwitz Luria, a professor of psychology at Tufts University in Medford, Mass., and a son, Daniel, an economist. Funeral arrangements are private but M.I.T. said a memorial service would be held at a date to be announced.

HEADLINE: Michael Guerriero, Professor, 72

 BODY:
Michael Guerriero, professor emeritus in the department of school services at the City College of New York, died last Friday in Plantation, Fla., where he was vacationing. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.
He died of a cerebral hemorrhage after a series of strokes, colleagues said.
Dr. Guerriero retired in 1986 after 34 years on the City College faculty. He was born in Brooklyn, held a bachelor's degree from Columbia University and received a doctorate from Teachers College at Columbia.
In the 1960's he was senior project coordinator for the Job Corps in the Office of Economic Opportunity. In recent years he was a leader of Project Life, which seeks to place disabled people in jobs and housing.
There are no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Argument Over the Banks

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE battle has begun over the Administration's proposals for the most drastic overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Depression. President Bush's aim is to restore confidence in the banking system and make America's banks world leaders again.
As the Treasury stresses, of the 30 biggest banks in the world, ranked by deposits, nine were American in 1969, with the top three the Bank of America, Chase and First National City, which became Citibank; in 1989, only one of the top 30 was American, with Citibank in 27th place. The Administration's aim is admirable, but there are risks. 
 It says one of its main goals is to "make banks stronger and safer by strengthening the role of capital -- not by raising capital standards, but with a plan to attract capital to the banking industry." One element would be to permit industrial companies to buy banks. But critics say that would transform the economy and society into a far more concentrated structure, dominated by big corporations.
Henry Kaufman, president of Henry Kaufman & Company, an investment advisory firm, regards this proposal as "very dangerous." In an interview, he said it would confer too much power on a corporate and financial elite, with close ties to the Government, transforming the United States from an economic democracy to a "corporate state."
Other critics of the plan say the "too big to fail" doctrine, which would be retained, would increase the concentration of financial power by throwing the weight of Government behind big banks and would contradict the Administration's professed support of market-determined solutions.
Robert Glauber, Treasury Under Secretary and former Harvard professor, who had most to do with the drafting of the plan, rejects charges that it would favor the big over the small. He said in an interview that there would not be a big push by industrial corporations into banking. Few, he said, are so flush with cash that they would want to put billions into bank investments and acquisitions. And relatively few banks would look attractive now, given the competition from other financial service companies and "non-bank banks," their low and often overstated profits, low stock values, large numbers of nonperforming loans, and the necessity of being subjected to Government regulation. One almost wonders why the Administration even wants to propose acquisition of banks by industrial companies.
On both the adequacy of capital and "too big to fail" issues, Mr. Glauber said the Administration's aim was to reduce failures by big and small banks alike and to improve banks' profitability by widening their opportunities to compete in other lines of business and across state borders.
But "despite the Administration's market orientation," he said, it would have to act to prevent failures of big banks that would threaten the economic system. Central banks in all countries act to prevent "systemic risk." The issue is always which banks to save, and here the Administration provides for joint decision-making between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury. "Secretary Brady doesn't believe bigger is better," Mr. Glauber said. "He believes in strong community and regional banks, and our plan will help regional banks to grow and expand across state borders." Yet many smaller banks fear that the plan would open their territory to big money-center banks, and they will fight it in Congress.
Should the Glass-Steagall Act be repealed, as the Administration proposes, and commercial banks allowed to do investment banking and sell insurance? Albert Gailord Hart, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University, a noted banking scholar, told his seminar this week: "The idea that banks can be put in good shape by letting them horn in on the overcrowded businesses of investment banking and insurance is crazy. Whenever banks go into a new line where experience as commercial bankers is not the key to success, they come a cropper."
As evidence, he cited "the Florida real estate disaster when banks went into real estate investment trusts," the losses (including the failure at Continental Illinois) when banks engaged in syndication of loans based on oil and related real estate in the Southwest, the evaporation (which still plagues us) of "sovereign loans" in the third world. "The further mess created by the banks' involvement in corporate takeovers in the 1980's," he said, "is just beginning to become clear to outsiders, but will prove at least as expensive as those just mentioned."
Like Professor Hart, Gail Fosler, chief economist of the Conference Board, fears that diversification by banks into other businesses will weaken their ability to perform their "remarkable function as instruments of monetary policy." She stressed the danger of banks being driven further into riskier credit markets, creating pressures on the Federal Reserve to "overliquefy -- and ultimately create more inflation."
In Congress this year, the banking issue will be the most urgent after the war in the Persian Gulf, and it is an issue even more crucial to the nation's economic strength.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: AFRICA;
In East Africa, U.S. Cuts Diplomatic Presence

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Across East Africa, the United States has moved to ward off terrorist attacks as a result of the Persian Gulf war. After incidents of violence and threats by Muslims sympathetic to Iraq, Washington has closed its embassy in the Sudan, evacuated officials in Tanzania and increased precautions in Uganda and Kenya.
In the Sudan, the American Ambassador, James R. Cheek, and remaining staff members at the embassy in Khartoum, about 50 people, were evacuated from the building hours before the first strikes against Iraq. The embassy building is now closed. Two American diplomats remain in the Sudanese capital and are working out of the British Embassy, which is heavily guarded by British soldiers flown in to provide extra protection. 
 The Islamic fundamentalist junta in the Sudan, historically an American ally, has backed Iraq since last August and has become steadily more anti-American.
Reports circulated earlier this week that the Sudan was harboring Iraqi planes, but officials in Washington have said they do not think this is true. One official said there were no landing strips in the Sudan capable of taking the advanced fighter planes described in the reports. At the end of January, Egypt said its air force had conducted military exercises near its border with the Sudan to warn its neighbor against any attempts to station Iraqi planes or missiles there.
Because no officials of the United States Agency for International Development are now in Khartoum, concern is rising in Washington about how effectively large amounts of famine relief aid being sent to the Sudan will be distributed.
The United States has pledged to send 330,000 tons of grain to the Sudan to try to avert famine that some experts have predicted will affect up to eight million Sudanese. Some of the food is already on ships en route to Port Sudan.
The most violent incident in the region involved an explosive device thrown shortly after the war started onto the tennis court at the American Club in Kampala, Uganda, soon after the United States Ambassador, John A. Burroughs Jr., had finished playing.
"We assume it may have been thrown at him," said Dudley Sims the public affairs officer at the embassy.
About 20 percent of Kampala's roughly one million people are Muslim.
 
Extra Security in Uganda
 American officials said they believed the explosive tossed at the American Club was thrown by a Ugandan rather than a terrorist sent to Uganda to target Westerners. After the gulf war started, American officials in Kampala were warned to take extra security precautions.
In Tanzania, "credible threats" were made against American officials in the capital, Dar es Salaam, where up to half the population is Muslim, American diplomats said. All non-essential staff-members were ordered to leave by last week. The embassy is working with only a skeleton staff. The 43 Peace Corps volunteers were also evacuated. The United States Information Service library has been closed.
The diplomats said it was necessary to scale back operations in Tanzania because the Government there had been unable to provide necessary security.
In Kenya, Government authorities have provided extra security outside the residence of the American Ambassador, Smith Hempstone.

HEADLINE: O'HARE JOURNAL;
War Brings Eerie Peace To Busiest Airline Hub

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 7

 BODY:
These days, you can find a parking space at O'Hare International Airport right by the elevators. You can walk the terminals without your bag bumping into somebody else's. You can find a seat at the gate. You can have the souvenir shops, taverns, rental car vans and just about anything else you want all to yourself.
O'Hare, the nation's busiest airport, where on any given day tens of thousands of people routinely pass through the gates, is nearly empty.
Since the outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf three weeks ago, O'Hare and other airports, already hurt by a slumping economy, have become barometers of Americans' fear of terrorism, ghost towns abandoned by all but the most determined travelers who often find themselves outnumbered by airport personnel.
Many airports say they have not yet compiled statistics to document the decline in passengers in the last few weeks. But estimates by airline analysts range from 10 to 50 percent, and some gate personnel at O'Hare say they have sent off 727's with just six people aboard.
American Airlines, which has a hub at O'Hare, has reported that 9 percent fewer passengers boarded its planes at the airport in January than in the previous January. It is not clear how sharp the drop was after the war broke out in mid-January.
"We have a recession of unknown depth and duration and fears of possible terrorism, and there you are," said Edward Starkman, an airline analyst at Paine Webber.
The effects can be seen far beyond the gates and ticket counters. At Los Angeles International Airport, there are 20 percent fewer cars in the parking lots. Buses bound for Manhattan have left Newark Airport with just one or two passengers.
"It's been very, very, very slow," said Tim Jeffries, manager of a sports shop at O'Hare, where rows of Chicago Bulls and Blackhawks T-shirts stood neatly hung, untouched by customers for hours at a time.
"We just try to keep busy," he said. Mostly that means straightening up and wiping the counters.
In the airport's underground passageways, cavernous corridors normally thick with travelers hurrying between terminals, Mike Barber, a street trumpeter, played "Misty" for baggage handlers on break.
Upstairs, the car rental counters were virtually deserted.
"See those escalators?" said Lisa Valentine, an Avis clerk, pointing to the moving stairs carrying three passengers. "People would be jampacked down those escalators this time of day. It would be elbow-to-elbow at baggage claim. There would be so many people at our counter, we couldn't sit down."
Not now. Now she was reading the newspaper instead. Her co-worker, Karen Huebner, sat twirling a telephone cord around her finger. Two-thirds of the way through a 10-hour period in which they would normally rent cars to 100 people, only 20 people had come by for cars.
Across the airport, police officers, skycaps, bartenders, clerks at the duty-free shops could be seen, head in hand, drawing circles with their toes, looking more like the Maytag repairman than airport workers during a nationwide state of alert.
Bill Jech and David Buescher, two publishing executives and frequent fliers who were headed to Montreal, sat in a vast, private American Airlines lounge, arms stretched out over a bank of seats. "I've never seen it this empty," Mr. Buescher said. "This place is usually overflowing. Sometimes we've milled around here where we can't even get a phone."
O'Hare and airline officials are trying to put a good face on the situation. "It's primarily the meeters and greeters and seer-offers who are gone," said Sara Dornacker, a spokeswoman for United Airlines.
But people who make their daily livelihood off the passengers say the passengers are not there either. For Zakaria Maaitah, a taxi driver who works O'Hare, there are so few passengers that the waiting time for a fare has more than doubled, to more than two hours.
On a recent evening, it took that long just to make it to the head of the line at the terminal curbside, then another half hour for what looked remotely like a possible fare. And that was during rush hour.
"We can't make it anymore," he said. "It's not worth it to come out here."
That night, Mr. Maaitah got out of his cab hurried over to an elderly woman. But she was being picked up by a relative. He politely, slightly desperately, sprinted toward a second woman. She was looking for a hotel van. Finally, Paul Dodman, a business executive, walked out and looked in Mr. Maaitah's direction.
His luggage was in the trunk before he could say where he wanted to go. He offered a single comment. "The airport was empty," Mr. Dodman said, "and so was the plane."

HEADLINE: Technology Is Found to Exist To Cut Global Warming Gases

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Current technologies can sharply reduce gases that scientists say would contribute to global warming, but not without significant expense and dramatic changes in how Americans use energy, a Congressional study reported today.
The report estimated that substantially cutting emissions of one of the gases, carbon dioxide, could eventually cost the economy as much as $150 billion a year, about what Americans now pay for compliance with all existing environmental laws. 
 The study by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment comes as delegates from 130 nations are meeting near here to work toward a worldwide treaty on global warming. It also follows pressure from some members of Congress to commit the United States to specific goals to reduce gases that contribute to global warming, something the Bush Administration says should await more study.
There is division among scientist over the extent, and indeed the existence, of global warming. But many scientists believe that global temperatures will rise because increasing levels of carbon dioxide and other manmade gases will trap and retain heat from the sun in a process similar to what happens in a greenhouse. Such a warming trend could cause sea levels to rise, cause severe droughts and storms and severely disprupt the earth's biological systems.
 
Number of Gases Involved
 The phenomenon has been attributed to a number of gases, including chlorofluorocarbons and methane. But carbon dioxide, primarily from the burning of fossil fuels, accounts for more than half of the gases identified as creating the greenhouse effect. And scientists believe significant cuts in carbon dioxide emissions will require sharp reductions in the burning of fossil fuels, oil, coal and wood.
The new study concluded that carbon dioxide reductions of 35 percent are feasible over the next 25 years in the United States with the adoption of stringent energy-saving policies.
"Such emission reductions will be difficult to achieve and could be costly," said the study, which had been requested by several Congressional committees, but it added that the reductions would require no major technological breakthroughs,
The report said the cost was difficult to estimate. Energy savings would increase because of conservation and fuel efficiencies, but the cost of appliances, automobiles and houses, would most likely increase.
The report said predictions on how much it would cost to deal with global warming vary widely, from saving the economy money to costing as much as $150 billion a year to cut carbon dioxide emissions alone by the year 2015.
Environmentalists have argued that at the very least, industrial nations must reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 20 percent to have any hopes of reversing the trend toward unusual warming of the earth.
The report said a substantial cut in carbon dioxide emissions would require energy conservation measures to be taken by virtually all sectors of the economy, including construction, manufacturing, transportation and energy industries.
 
Energy Taxes Could Be Needed
 The energy savings most likely would have to be brought about through a mixture of energy taxes, financial incentives and government regulation, the study concluded.
The Congressional study did not endorse any specific approach or suggest what kinds of energy taxes or incentives might be preferred. But it suggested that tougher energy efficiency standards would have to be developed for commercial buildings as well as for homes, appliances, heating and cooling systems, windows and other elements of construction.
It cited the need for more energy-efficient transportation systems, including steep increases in automobile fuel economy standards, more incentives toward development of mass transit and perhaps reinstituting the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit nationwide.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Warmer Forecast in Europe Ends the Rally in Oil Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices fell yesterday after a rally driven by the price of heating oil faded on forecasts of warmer weather in Europe.
"The cold weather is supposed to lift by Sunday and as soon as that weather lifts, the weak U.S. demand will be apparent," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. 
 Energy prices rose on Wednesday as the European cold snap sent heating oil prices sharply higher, and oil began trading yesterday up slightly.
But light sweet crude oil for delivery in March closed at $21.22 a barrel, down 27 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In London, North Sea Brent Blend crude oil closed at $20.18 a barrel, up 2 cents, on the International Petroleum Exchange.
Home heating oil for delivery in March settled at 65.52 cents a gallon, down 0.83 cent, in New York.
Unleaded gasoline for March delivery closed at 60.58 cents a gallon, down 1.16 cents. Natural gas for delivery in March closed at $1.380 a 1,000 cubic feet, up 0.9 cent.
"I think we're in a period where things are just going to drift back and forth without any strong, sustainable influence, as long as this war drags on," said Philip L. Dodge, an oil analyst with Nomura Securities International Inc. After that, many experts predict oil prices will tumble, at least temporarily, as the global market contends with a sizable glut that even now cannot be sold off.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Intervention Lifts the Dollar; Gold Is Up $4.90 on Comex

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher in domestic trading for the first time in more than a week yesterday after two central banks intervened to shore up the flagging United States currency, traders said.
Gold was up moderately in New York, rising $4.90 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, to $367.80. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $367.10 an ounce, up $4.80 from late Wednesday. 
 The slight domestic rise of the dollar helped it recover somewhat from a post-World War II low reached Wednesday against the German mark. Traders said, however, that the market's belief that the Fed would act to lower interest rates to lift the sagging United States economy threatened to push the dollar to new lows in coming sessions.
Lower interest rates generally mean lower investment returns on securities, so foreigners desire less currency to buy those securities.
"The dollar still feels very heavy," said Tom Benfer, senior market representative in foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal. "The economic fundamentals still augur for a lower dollar."
 
Touched 1.4460 German Marks
 Traders said the Fed and the Bank of Canada stepped in to buy dollars in the early afternoon after the dollar touched a new postwar low of 1.4460 German marks.
While the dollar-buying was relatively small in volume, trading was thin enough for the intervention to lift the dollar against the mark, they said.
The intervention came on the heels of comments by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that the United States was not pursuing a low-dollar policy, traders said.
By late in the day, the dollar stood at 1.4553 German marks, up from 1.4483 marks late Wednesday.
Robert Hatcher, corporate dealer with Barclays Bank P.L.C., said there was a widening belief in the currency markets that the Fed interventions -- yesterday's was the fourth in as many days -- were designed to slow the dollar's decline, not reverse it.
"On balance, I would say the market is still anti-dollar," he said. "The central banks have been able to discourage a serious drop in the dollar. The problem is the sentiment is still pretty bad."
 
Pound Below $2 in Britain
 In London, the British pound fell to $1.9980 from late Wednesday's 10-year high of $2.0000. In New York, the pound weakened to $2.0000, from $2.0035 late Wednesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.53 yen, to a closing 128.60 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 127.80 yen, and in New York the dollar bought 128.52 yen, up from late Wednesday's 128.13 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's, included: 1.2437 Swiss francs, up from 1.2316; 4.9535 French francs, up from 4.9325; 1,093.75 Italian lire, up from 1,088.50, and 1.1587 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1575.

HEADLINE: Homebuyers Send Funds To Neediest

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
With the purchase of a new home, people often become preoccupied with interest rates and mortgage payments, buying furniture and coordinating colors in the living room. But for some, the change in residence also inspires a desire to help others and to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
In May, Deidre and Ed Hogan moved from their apartment on 84th Street near Lexington Avenue to a Dutch colonial house in Darien, Conn. Last month, the Hogans sent their first contribution, a gift of $100, to the fund. In the corner of the check was written "housing donation," and their letter said, "Perhaps we'll make our gift like our mortgage, a 30-year 'tradition.' " 
 Ms. Hogan said in a telephone interview that she and her husband had noticed the increasing numbers of homeless people while living in Manhattan, but "it did not hit home" until they left.
"Moving into a house made us more aware that there were people who aren't as fortunate as we are," she said. There was something about owning a home that made them realize they "had a place and others did not."
Another contributor, Elizabeth C. Segal, gave $35 and wrote: "Making a donation has been a holiday tradition with me for many years (at least eight), and I am happy to continue it. This year, I feel particularly fortunate, as I became for the first time a homeowner this autumn. I would therefore especially like to be able to do at least a little for the many people who are much less fortunate than I am, and if possible would like this donation to be used to help a homeless person."
 
3 Weeks Remain
 Money from the Neediest Cases has helped prevent hundreds of people from being evicted from their homes, provided food and clothing for disadvantaged children and sent dozens of homemakers to visit the elderly. Proceeds are distributed to seven charities to help the sick and the poor, and The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead.
The 1990-91 appeal closes on Feb. 28, and the fund is still short $268,364.49 of the amount that was raised last year. But dozens of people continue to send in contributions, moved by the plight of the city's homeless.
Ursula Wolfe of New Providence, N.J., sent $100 and wrote: "As I sat by the fire after a good meal, my inward eye saw the hungry homeless huddled in cardboard boxes against the cold. Please help."
A gift of $25 from Michael Lieder arrived at the beginning of January. "It snowed last night, and I'm thankful that I have a roof over my head," he wrote. "Many others don't."
And there was also a $100 contribution from Imran Riffrat, a New Yorker who has been living in Cairo. "We return to our city each year and are saddened to see the state of things as they are today," he wrote. "There seems to be a steady deterioration, and our contribution, small as it may seem, may help to stem the decline."

HEADLINE: New York Faces Loss of Insurers For Bond Issue

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Next week, for the first time in many years, New York City bonds are likely to be issued without insurance backing because the Wall Street house underwriting the issue could not find an agency interested in providing it.
Some investment bankers say the lack of insurance has more symbolic than economic importance. The city cannot obtain it because the insurance companies' appetite for New York City bonds is sated, not because the city is viewed as too great a credit risk, they say. 
 Typically, the city pays an insurance premium to a triple A-rated municipal bond insurance agency, which in exchange lends its credit rating to some of the bonds.
 
Higher Interest Likely
 Without insurance, investors are likely to demand higher interest on the city's bonds, raising the cost to the city. Usually the difference between insured and uninsured bonds is about 1 1/4 percentage points.
Next week's bond issue is for $950 million, but since only a portion of that -- typically about 10 percent -- would normally be insured, the cost to the city of going without insurance will be about $1 million.
The insurance agencies set internal limits on how much credit they want to guarantee for any one entity, and New York has been issuing so many bonds in the last few years that it has reached those limits.
"All of us already have so much exposure to the City of New York that if we took any more we would have to let other risks roll off," said Mary Anderson, a senior vice president at Ambac, a municipal bond insurance company.
The lack of insurance could make it harder to sell New York City bonds, not just next week, but over the next few years, when the city is expected to issue about $1 billion in bonds a quarter. Only the United States Treasury issues more bonds each year.
 
Concern Among Investors
 As more and more municipal governments have run into financial trouble, investors have grown increasingly sensitive to risk. "We detect concern," said Robert Godfrey, executive vice president of the Municipal Bond Insurance Association. "Investors have started to focus on credit quality -- they like the triple A."
The percentage of new municipal bonds that carry insurance has risen from 3 percent in 1980 to 26 percent last year.
"Using insurance would certainly help the city," said Stan Ciemniecki, an executive vice president at Lehman Brothers, which is underwriting the city's new bond issue. But he said he was confident his concern would have no problem selling the city's bonds.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Fell In December

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Consumer credit fell at an annual rate of 2.3 percent in December, the steepest decline in nearly four years, the Federal Reserve said today. The report surprised analysts, because December is usually a busy shopping month.
Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group in Washington, cited consumer fears about the economy. "We have lost a million jobs since June," she said. "Wage rates are way behind inflation. In many areas, the values of homes are declining. People are worried about the banking situation." 
 As so, she continued, "people are not buying much of anything and, therefore, are not using their credit cards."
Bill Wood, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., said the decline would not have been so unexpected in January, usually a slow time for retailers and other store owners.
"It does not bode well for January," he said, suggesting that the January credit report could be worse because of the added element of concern over the Persian Gulf war.
The Fed said consumer installment debt dropped a seasonally adjusted $1.45 billion, the first decline since a two-tenths of 1 percent dip in February 1989 and the sharpest fall since a 5.2 percent drop in February 1987.
 
Auto Loans Increased

For the year, credit growth slowed to just 3.1 percent, down from 6 percent in 1989 and 8.5 percent in 1988. November's 4.5 percent growth was stronger than the 2.8 percent gain first reported, however.
Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. Total consumer spending represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Only automobile loans increased in December. All other types of consumer debt, including credit card debt, declined in the month that included the bulk of Christmas shopping.
Auto loans, which had fallen for six months until a slight three-tenths of 1 percent gain in November, rose another 3.3 percent, or a seasonally adjusted $786 million, in December.
Revolving credit, the category that includes credit cards, fell 6.7 percent after increasing 7.6 percent in November, the last week of which has marked the start of the holiday shopping season.
Total revolving debt fell $1.23 billion in December, compared with a $1.38 billion gain the previous month.
The Commerce Department had reported earlier that retail sales in December fell four-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Boy Scout Crisis: Who Will Help America's Youth?

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.

 BODY:
Douglas Gordon is an Eagle Scout who didn't know he was missing. Neither did Gordon Andrew. And Peter Ruhlin still doesn't know it. They have been living normally all these years, suspecting nothing.
But now authorities from their childhood have tracked down these men and hope that they, along with about 9,997 other missing Eagle Scouts in the area, will help solve an acute crisis in the New York region for the Boy Scouts of America. 
 The crisis in this venerable institution is not a shortage of boys willing to wear shorts, salute with three fingers and memorize the 12 points of Scout Law. There are, in fact, too many who seek such a structured ladder of socially acceptable achievement these days, even in New York City, where to many minds the sight of a teen-ager's hand reaching out for an elderly woman's elbow at a crosswalk does not bring to mind a daily good deed.
The Boy Scout crisis is instead a shortage of adults willing to donate their own precious time to become troop leaders, assistant leaders, merit badge counselors and general role models.
 There is, for one thing, more competition for the time of adults in this era of economic uncertainty. For another, even in those households that still have two parents, only a small fraction now are the traditional model of one parent in the work place and one parent in the home place.
 A very large num ber have two working parents. They have enough problems juggling their personal assignments and ambitions with the competing demands, schedules and ill-timed illnesses of their own children, let alone trying to leave work in midafternoon once a week to help a dozen 12-year-olds send semaphore signals the length of a church basement.
The Boy Scouts have made adjustments. After at least one lawsuit, women can now be scoutmasters. Troop and pack meetings, once confined to immediate post-school hours, often convene at 8 P.M. or even on weekends. And there are lessons on drug and sexual abuse.
Still, several thousand New York-area youths are on Scout waiting lists eager to begin climbing the Tenderfoot achievement ladder but unable to because there are no adult leaders. With one adult needed for every eight youngsters, that makes for a lot of missing leaders.
Where better to look for Scout leaders than among former Scouts? More precisely from the 1.3 million American Scouts who have completed the 21 steps on the trail to Eagle rank, which include demonstrations of troop leadership.
So the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts are in the midst of a hunt for the 10,000 Eagle Scouts they estimate live around here. They've been on radio. They've written known Eagle Scouts urging them to turn in others. The councils got a notice in the newsletter for Metro-North's 100,000 train riders. The letter told Eagle Scouts to phone 1-800-3EAGLE-0.
So far, 4,236 have. The typical profile: a married college graduate between age 30 and 40 working as a professional in Manhattan but living in the suburbs. Like Gordon Andrew of Fairfield, Conn., and Douglas Gordon here.
Now a civil engineer selling custom air-conditioners, Mr. Gordon was once a leader of Troop 104 in Jefferson City, Mo. He found scouting invaluable in learning values in a structured environment, and he hopes his 18-month-old son will some day seek the same scouting satisfaction. "You set goals," he said. "You work for them. You achieve them. You're rewarded." Just like college, or business before the overlay of office politics.
Mr. Andrew belonged to Troop 103 in West Hartford, Conn. The teasing he suffered in high school was nothing compared with what he heard in 1967 as he strolled through Haight-Ashbury en route to the World Jamboree -- in uniform. The owner of his own company, who still keeps his Eagle's certificate framed on the wall, he credits much of his self-confidence and goal-orientation to self-discipline and successes he learned in eight years of scouting. And he was mildly disappointed when his oldest child had no scouting interest.
While his Scout knife could never pass airport security now, Mr. Andrew senses a strong Scout influence on his daily values, and not just when he needs to tie a clove hitch out back. "I guess it's corny," he said. "But some sectors of our society could pay useful attention to corny values such as courtesy, kindness and loyalty."
Both men would Be Prepared to volunteer scouting time in their communities, but probably not in the city. "Can you imagine," said Mr. Gordon, "teaching archery in Manhattan? With or without a uniform."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Drop After Auction

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices in the credit markets gave ground for the first time in days yesterday, as market participants apparently took profits after a successful auction of $11 billion in new 30-year Treasury bonds.
Bids at the bond sale, the last leg of the Treasury's $34.5 billion quarterly refunding auctions, produced an average yield on the securities of 7.98 percent, down substantially from the 8.71 percent average yield at the last bond sale in November. It is the lowest yield on a new 30-year Treasury bond since the auction in November 1989. 
 Traders said demand for the new issue had been good. Nevertheless, prices in the secondary market for Treasury securities, which had been firm as the auction approached, began to deteriorate once the results of the sale were announced.
"Based on the auction, I am surprised this sort of selling is happening," one government bond trader said.
Others said the selloff was not so surprising, given the strong gains that have been recorded recently.
"A lot of this is due to profit taking," said Charles Lieberman, a managing director at the Manufacturers Hanover Securities Corporation.
Mr. Lieberman and others said Japanese firms, which are estimated to have placed bids for 20 to 25 percent of the new bonds, began to liquidate positions shortly after the auction results were announced. Those sales in turn encouraged others to lighten up positions.
By late in the day, the new bonds were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.03 percent.
Analysts and traders said the selloff, which amounted to as much as 5/8 point for some securities, was not likely to last long. The economy remains weak, and with the refunding auctions completed, the market will not have to cope with meaningful amounts of new Treasury securities for a few weeks.
"In the past, the trading pattern has been that the long end gets sold off the most aggressively because that is where the bulk of the risk is," another government bond trader said. "But in a day or two, the market will go back up. The economy is still in awful shape."
Poor economic conditions are good for prices in the credit markets because they tend to dampen inflation. Lower rates of inflation lift returns on fixed-income securities.
The Treasury's auction took place on an exceptionally busy day in the world's primary bond markets.
In addition to the Treasury auction, Government bond auctions were held in Japan, France, Germany and Britain yesterday.
"There was a rash of worldwide supply and the markets have absorbed all of it quite well," said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, a money management firm in New York.
 
In the Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered late yesterday at a price of 107 25/32, down a little more than 5/8 point, to yield 8.05 percent, up from 8.00 percent late Wednesday.
Among oustanding Treasury note issues, the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, down 7/32, to yield 7.43 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were unchanged, at 100 3/8, to yield 6.79 percent.
In when-issued trading, the 6 7/8 percent three-year notes auctioned on Tuesday were offered at a price to yield 7 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.83 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.92 percent late yesterday, up 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.87 percent.
 
Corporate Issues
 New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market slowed yesterday after several days of heavy flow.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues dipped by 1/4 point to 3/8 point, dealers said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 1/8 point in quiet trading.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Jan. 28.
The report, which was largely in line with analysts' expectations, had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Hints at Stretching Budget Problems Over Years

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
Raising the possibility that New York City would resort to measures not seen since its fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, Mayor David N. Dinkins hinted yesterday that he might consider a plan under which the city would stretch its current budget problems over several years.
The Mayor's comments came one day after Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, offered a dire prognosis for New York City's finances. 
 Mr. Rohatyn said the city's financial situation could deteroriate to the point where the cuts needed to balance the budget would cause lasting harm. In that case, he said, the city should consider some kind of borrowing to stretch the problem out over several years.
"At some point the trade-off between balancing the budget and that long-term social and economic harm may not make sense," Mr. Rohatyn said.
 
The Best Alternative
 Initially, Mr. Dinkins had seemed hostile to Mr. Rohaytn's suggestions. But yesterday he said he agreed that stretching out the problem might be the best alternative.
"One has to be constantly mindful that to push debt into the future is frowned upon and not deemed to be the wisest course," he said. "On the other hand, however, it is recognized that when you have a very severe situation, it frequently cannot be met in a limited period of time and therefore there is some argument for an expansion. Instead of a one-year budget, a budget of several years."
Mr. Dinkins repeatedly stressed that the city was prepared to balance its budget this year and that it had already taken significant steps to close toward doing so.
 
More Study Needed
 Aides to Mr. Dinkins said the idea of a "multiyear" budget was still in the early stages and required more study. "I think what the Mayor was saying was that the city was prepared to consider the possibility of a multiyear budget," Albert Scardino, the Mayor's press secretary, said.
But fiscal experts warned yesterday that deferring the city's problems could trigger a takeover of the city budget by the Financial Control Board, a state oversight panel formed during the fiscal troubles of the mid-1970's.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is the chairman of the Financial Control Board and would, in the case of a takeover, become responsible for the city budget. It is widely agreed in both City Hall and the State Capitol that such a takeover would be a huge political liability for Mr. Cuomo.
In Albany, Goveror Cuomo said he thought that it was "too early" to conclude that extraordinary measures would be needed to solve the problem.
The city's budget problems have become a source of enormous tension between the city and the state, which is grappling with tremendous budget troubles of its own. Yesterday, Mr. Cuomo, apparently trying to avoid a new round of finger-pointing, responded noncommitally to the proposition that the city would not be able to balance its budget this year. He said he would leave discussions about worst-case scenarios to "kibbitzers."
"This is kibbitzing," he said to a reporter who pressed him on the issue. "This is what you do, not what I do."
 
Deep Concern
 In recent months, Mr. Cuomo himself has often voiced deep concern over the city's fiscal problems. At the same time, he has insisted that he has absolute faith in Mayor Dinkins's ability to overcome them.
Governor Cuomo has traditionally been an ally of Mr. Rohatyn, who was one of the architects of the city's fiscal recovery. The Governor recently asked Mr. Rohatyn to stay on as chairman of the M.A.C. after he threatened to leave. But yesterday he seemed taken aback by the reports of Mr. Rohatyn's remarks and he suggested that they had been misunderstood.
In an interview, Mr. Rohatyn, too, insisted that his comments had been misinterpreted. He said he had simply been issuing a warning about steps that might be needed if the Persian Gulf war were prolonged and the economy continued to slide. "It didn't seem to me to be revolutionary," he said.

HEADLINE: Test for Japan's Leader;
Kaifu Faces Growing Difficulty in Building A Consensus on Tokyo's Role in Gulf War

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 7

 BODY:
An extraordinary national debate over Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's pledge of aid for the war against Iraq is suddenly proving to be the biggest test of Japanese friendship for the United States in many years -- and the biggest test so far of Mr. Kaifu's ability to remain in office.
All week long, Mr. Kaifu has been battered by sharp questioning in public from his parliamentary foes along with what is said to be a growing sentiment behind the scenes that he and his Cabinet would have to resign if the $9 billion aid package falls through. 
 The high stakes have lent a tone of urgency to all discussions about the fate of the aid package, even as Government officials have become somewhat more optimistic about its prospects in recent days.
"I don't foresee any possibility in which the Government will not be able to secure that $9 billion," said Nobuo Matsunaga, a former Ambassador to the United States. But he warned that its defeat would display Mr. Kaifu's "inability to govern" and badly damage Japan's credibility.
In any case, Mr. Kaifu and his aides are waging an all-out campaign of high rhetorical flourishes combined with political horse-trading and even sleight of hand, the likes of which rarely comes into the open in Japan as it has in the last several days.
The backdrop of Mr. Kaifu's problems is that despite the absence of sizable anti-war demonstrations, Japanese public opinion has swung round to a deep-seated skepticism about the war and even deeper anxieties about being drawn into it.
Surveys show that a majority of Japanese opposed the American attacks, although paradoxically many of these same people favor aiding the United States to avoid international criticism. There is even more opposition to the Government's plan to send military planes to the region to evacuate refugees.
Running through the debate, in the nation if not in Parliament, is more than a trace of anti-American sentiment, a legacy of Japan's annoyance over feeling pushed around for years on trade issues and taken for granted on Iraq by President Bush.
 
'America Started This War'
 "We didn't ask for war," Hiroshi Kume, a popular television news anchorman, told viewers the other day. "Japan said differences should be settled through diplomatic means, but Bush didn't listen. We should tell him that America started this war, and it's up to America to finish it."
Japan had already pledged $4 billion to aid the gulf mobilization last year, half of it for economic aid to the region and the other for assistance to the military buildup restricted to payment for transportation and other non-combat costs.
There have been delays in disbursement, but the Government said last week that most of the money had finally been spent or committed.
This week, in the face of the antiwar sentiment, Mr. Kaifu has made more compromises to secure the new $9 billion pakcage. He announced, for instance, that the money would again not go for weapons or ammunition, but for transportation, medical services, food and other "logistical" matters.
 
Courting Opposition Party
 Mr. Kaifu's objective is to secure the votes of the Clean Government Party, or Komeito, which holds the swing votes in the opposition-controlled upper house of Parliament. But the party is still holding out for more concessions.
By tradition, the Komeito is both conservative and pacifist, since it draws its membership from small shopkeepers and businessmen in the cities allied with a popular Buddhist sect. Many of its rank-and-file are women who are most opposed to Japanese involvement in the war.
A senior Government officials commented that it was "insanity" to restrict Japan's aid to non-lethal goods, but such a step had to be taken and that more concessions might be in the offing.
There is now some talk of dropping the proposed tax on tobacco to pay for the aid, for example, and instead cutting Japan's budget in other areas, as the Komeito wants. Indeed, the entire tax package may be deferred until a later date, officials say.
 
An Official Is Sacrificed
 As for political logrolling, the talk of the capital nowadays is that the first Japanese casualty of the war appears not to be any Japanese soldier, but the longtime Governor of the district of Tokyo, Shunichi Suzuki.
In a fascinating display of American-style political hardball, Mr. Suzuki is being denied renomination by Mr. Kaifu's governing Liberal Democratic Party so that the party can back a neutral candidate more to the liking of the Clean Government Party -- again, to get its votes on the gulf.
What is going on behind the scenes is also a matter of speculation, some of it nasty. It has long been an open secret that the ruling party pays off the opposition at crucial moments with cash under the table, but a furor was provoked this week when a ruling party mentioned the practice in the open.
Suddenly irked over opposition taunts, a Liberal Democratic Party lawmaker declared that it was "impudence" for one colleague to level criticism, especially since he was on the take for 500,000 yen, or about $3,800, paid "as many as 20 times a year" from the ruling party.
 
Charges of Payoffs
 The comment brought a storm of protests and denials, a fact that amused some old hands in the party, who commented privately that it might now be more difficult to make such a payoff in the future.
Mr. Kaifu has won praise within the party for handling of the issues, although it is clear that the horse trading is being carried out mainly by the more powerful party kingpins who are his patrons. But many fear that even if he survives this battle, his future is not assured.
In the event of ground war in Iraq, political analysts say that the intensity of anti-war sentiment will likely increase.
