HEADLINE: Watch Your Car, Here Comes Repo Man!

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Angel Cordova appeared puzzled by the black unmarked tow truck in front of his apartment building. He was only three months behind on his car payments. He had been discussing his problems with the finance company. Besides, the car had a faulty relay switch. Who makes payments on a lemon?
"I'm with Nissan Motor Acceptance," the tow truck driver, Brian Papp, a 325-pound former semi-pro football tackle, said to Mr. Cordova. "Where's the car?" 
 Despite bankruptcies, foreclosures, layoffs and bank failures, all is not gloom-and-doom in the Northeast these days. For some people, like Mr. Papp, the recession has hardly made a dent in business. Mr. Papp is a repo man.
Mr. Papp, who calls himself "a financial educator," is a co-owner of Hawk Repossessions, a small but fast-growing business that operates throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, recovering cars, often surreptitiously, from owners who have fallen behind on loan payments.
 
Anything and Everything
 Since starting five years ago, Hawk, with offices in Norwich, Conn., and Newark, has repossessed cheap cars, expensive cars, sailboats, cigarette boats, campers, trailers, mobile homes and all manner of recreational vehicles, not to mention a bulldozer, a tow truck used byanother repossession service and a limousine owned by the talk-show host Morton Downey Jr.
Mr. Papp's pound in Norwich, a city of about 38,500 people 10 miles north of New London, also holds less mobile repossessions, like six weight-lifting machines from a fitness club.
"I expected a check from the guy, not the equipment," Mr. Papp said. "But he said: 'Take it. No one ever uses it.' "
The health of the repossession industry in the Northeast is difficult to assess. Only about two dozen companies are registered with the American Recovery Association, a New Orleans-based trade association that represents more than 500 repossession companies in the United States and several other countries. Dozens more, though, operate either exclusively as repossession companies or as part of towing businesses.
The association says business has declined in the last two years because credit has been tightened, especially among car dealers whose long-term, low-payment loans were more likely to end in a repossession. And some businesses say their work is down.
"If new car sales are down, you can expect repossessions to follow suit," said A. J. Christensen, president of Commercial Services Corporation in Newark.
 
Competition Grows
 But more people are also entering the business, intensifying competition.
"Everybody is going into repossessions," said Donald Rimbach, the manager of Thomas J. Rimbach, which recovers about 30 vehicles a week and has offices in Queens and Binghamton, N.Y. "You're getting collection people who were laid off. A lot of undercutting of prices is going on."
Finance companies, like the General Motors Acceptance Corporation in Detroit, cite a steady rise in repossessions, but they caution that the increases may only be keeping pace with a larger volume of loans made each year. According to G.M.A.C. figures, about 116,000 of their loans resulted in repossession in 1987. That figure rose to 143,000 in 1988 and 153,000 in 1989. No figures have been released for 1990.
Hawk sees a steady and slightly expanding amount of work. "Business has been steadily increasing," said Mr. Papp, whose 30 trucks recover about 200 vehicles a week.
Mr. Papp, who is 31 years old, estimated that the 50 cars, campers and boats impounded at his Norwich lot were worth more than $500,000. Most will be auctioned, with the proceeds going to banks and finance companies. If the sale price for a car is not enough to pay off the loan, the original owner is liable for the balance.
The fee charged by Hawk for its services runs between $125 and $600 an assignment. "I tell them, 'Look, I got to eat, too,' " Mr. Papp said. " 'If I don't take your car, they're going to come for my car.' "
Hawk has repossessed the rare Rolls-Royce and Lamborghini, but most of its cases involve middle-class owners of Hyundais and Hondas who have recently lost a job or a secondsource of income. A few find their cars repossessed if a lender learns they are insufficiently insured.
 
'People Who Just Walk Away'
 Some, like Mr. Cordova, stop making payments if their car is involved in an accident and they fail, either out of negligence or because of a lack of insurance, to make repairs.
"There are some people who just walk away," Mr. Papp said.
Danger, of course, can be part of a repo man's life; nationally, four were killed last year in arguments with car owners. Mr. Papp, who carries a handgun, was beaten by a group of men while on an assignment in the North End of Hartford last year.
"I do it for the excitement," he said. "Basically, you're stealing a car and not getting arrested."
Most car owners, however, when told of their loan status, turn in their keys. Occasionally, a repossession consists of a quick, quiet "tow and go" involving nothing more ingenious than a tow truck.
Other times, Slim Jims, lock picks, portable key-cutting equipment and steering-wheel-pullers are employed.
Nocturnal visits are more myth than reality. "People think we're coming at night, so we try to find them during the day," Mr. Papp said, scanning license plates at lunchtime in a factory parking lot in Putnam, and an hour later in a condominium complex in nearby Brooklyn, Conn.
On those rare instances when a face-to-face request for keys or a car is required, the situation seldom simmers above a slightly heated conversation.
Such was the case with Mr. Cordova, a 25-year-old bank employee living at home with his parents. After a couple of curses and a few futile phone calls to the finance company, he handed his car keys to Mr. Papp and helped him open the garage door.
"O.K., you guys can have the car," he said. "I'll make it easy on you."

HEADLINE: Senators Proposing Overhaul Of U.S. Intelligence Agencies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Concerned that United States intelligence agencies often produce homogenized, timid assessments of world events and remain focused on cold war issues, the leaders of an important Senate committee today proposed a reorganization of the Government's espionage operations.
The proposed changes, the most extensive since the intelligence establishment started to take shape in 1947 with the creation of the Central Intelligence Agency, would revise the organization and leadership as well as the aims of the nation's spy agencies. 
 In making the proposal, the Democrat and Republican leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee said the changes were necessary to remove a tendency by the agencies to produce bland, hedged assessments that are watered down by bureaucratic battles.
In addition, the two Senators, David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, and Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said they hoped to eliminate overlapping responsibilities, streamline management, improve accountability for mistakes and reduce wasteful expenses.
 
Bill to Be Offered in Spring
 Their recommendations are to be detailed in legislation they plan to introduce this spring. Leaders of the House Intelligence Committee have said they intend to propose similar changes. It is unclear whether Congress will approve the proposals. The White House said today that it was satisfied with the current system.
The Government's primary intelligence agencies include the C.I.A.; the National Security Agency, which monitors international communications; the Defense Intelligence Agency, which provides military intelligence, and the National Reconnaissance Office, which is responsible for developing and launching spy satellites.
Under the current system, the head of the C.I.A. also serves as the Director of Central Intelligence, in charge of setting overall goals for the intelligence community and supervising the production of assessments on political, economic and military developments abroad for the President.
One of the central recommendations from Mr. Boren and Mr. Murkowski would be to establish a new position -- a director of national intelligence -- that is not imbeded in any of the agencies. The person in that new post would coordinate operations unencumbered by loyalty to a particular organization.
 
Boren Views on Proposals
 Mr. Boren said in an interview today that the changes were needed to renew an espionage apparatus whose leadership is spread throughout the Government, whose duties often overlap and whose overwhelming concern -- the Soviet military threat -- is rapidly becoming ancient history.
"Some of the major agencies -- the Defense Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency -- weren't even in existence when we created the C.I.A.," Mr. Boren noted.
Even a simple organization chart of the espionage community takes up "pages and pages and pages," Mr. Murkowski said.
Mr. Boren said his committee would also study bolstering the authority of the Defense Intelligence Agency, which analyzes intelligence for the military services, and making public the Government's overall spending on intelligence operations. The budget is classified but estimates place it at about $30 billion.
In interviews today, Mr. Boren and Mr. Murkowski, the newly appointed vice chairman of the committee, said they were optimistic that legislation could be enacted in their remaining two years of service on the intelligence panel.
 
Strong Support Cited
 Senator Boren said the proposal had the strong backing of key officials on the Senate Armed Services Committee, which shares authority over intelligence spending. He also noted that the new Democratic chairman of the House intelligence panel, Representative Dave McCurdy, also of Oklahoma, announced his own plans this week to study reorganizing the espionage apparatus.
But Mr. Boren also said that he had not consulted the White House or the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, about the proposals and that their support is uncertain.
Mr. McCurdy drew criticism from Republicans today. They were reacting to what Mr. McCurdy said this week in separate interviews with The Associated Press and The Washington Post. Mr. McCurdy said that he did not believe his committee had been aggressive enough in the past and that he intended "to stand up to Webster."
Today, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the third-ranking House Republican, accused Mr. McCurdy of "picking a public fight" with the Director of the Central Intelligence and said the White House was very concerned about the intentions of the House panel.
Mr. Boren sought today to erase any partisan tinge to his plans, saying he would have sought a reorganization even if the President and his C.I.A. director were Democrats. "We have no agendas in terms of settling political scores," he said. "Our only agenda is to build a better mousetrap."
 
Argument for Streamlining
 He and Mr. Murkowski said Federal budget problems and the political changes of the post-cold war era made the time ripe to streamline intelligence operations. Spending on intelligence declined by about 5 percent in real dollars this year, other officials have said.
Both men also suggested that reorganization was badly needed to increase the independence and accountability of espionage agencies. Mr. Murkowski expressed irritation at his frequent inability to fix blame or credit for such incidents as the Soviet Union's successful attempts in the 1980's to plant eavesdropping devices in the new United States Embassy in Moscow.
"If you try to look at responsibility," he said, "You can't find out. Guys say, 'That was not under my watch.' Maybe I'm naive, but I'd like to restructure this thing so there is clear accountability."
Senator Boren said that intelligence analyses of important world events are now so thoroughly processed by review panels and senior officials, each determined to avoid a wrong conclusion, that they are devoid of independent thought.
"In these briefings we get, when you're through with 75 percent of them, you don't know whether there's likely to be a revolution in Country X or not," he said. "Nobody will stick his neck out, and it's the person who will stick his neck out that really needs to be heard."

HEADLINE: Companies Cut Stock Dividends As Profits Drop

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Another of the corporate excesses of the 1980's is being reversed in executive suites across the country.
The common stock dividend, the venerable piece of the capitalist system's pie that grew robustly at many companies in the last decade, is being sliced. Profits are shrinking as the recession digs in, leaving the nation's auto, aerospace, appliance and other companies with little extra cash to pay to shareholders. 
 The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest car maker, cut its quarterly payout Monday nearly by half -- a step that Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, called "an extremely difficult decision." The Ford Motor Company, which put off its dividend decision for a few months, and the Chrysler Corporation are expected to follow G.M.'s lead.
On Tuesday, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the aerospace and defense company, trimmed its regular payment to shareholders. And yesterday, the Maytag Corporation, the big appliance maker, and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company cut their dividends sharply.
Until now, the beleaguered banking industry was the most notable dividend-cutter, as bankers searched for ways to conserve cash and raise capital. Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover and others lowered their payouts in the last couple of months, saving funds to offset problems with bad loans.
"There is a tremendous squeeze these days," said Arnold Kaufman, editor of Standard & Poor's Outlook newsletter, which tracks dividend trends. "Profits are no longer high enough to pay for dividends at many companies."
Dividend costs at many companies are high these days, thanks to a run-up in profits and an outpouring of corporate largesse in the 1980's. The generous payments were partly to buy the loyalty of shareholders and thus discourage corporate raiders. Such was the ethos of the 1980's that even companies facing no imminent threat were under pressure from shareholders to pass out cash.
The Commerce Department estimates that American corporations paid out 44 percent of their pretax profits in dividends last year, up from 23 percent in 1980.
Strong business conditions often made those decisions easier. But in many cases, corporations loaded up on debt while dividends were rising. This brought a decline in retained earnings as companies doled out more to shareholders while making higher interest payments.
Thus, an increasing share of profit was diverted from reinvestment in factories, training or research on new products. At a time when international competition is intensifying and some of America's leading rivals, notably the Japanese, pay meager dividends and invest heavily, many analysts find this trend disturbing and a threat to the nation's economic growth.
"We should be running American companies for the long term," said Joseph L. Bower, a professor and director of research at the Harvard Business School. "Companies should be creating opportunities for growth and investment rather than paying out their funds as dividends."
 
Matter of Dispute
 Dividend policy is a matter of lively dispute, both in board rooms and academia. One camp contends that dividends should be modest-sized and flexible, if they are paid at all. Exponents of this view point to growing high-technology companies, which often pay no dividends and spend heavily on research and investment.
The Intel Corporation, for example, a $3.9-billion-a-year maker of semiconductors, has never paid a dividend. The company, whose stock trades over the counter, considered a dividend last year, but decided against it, choosing to bolster its share price instead by purchasing some of its own shares. Intel recently announced that it would spend up to $1 billion this year on new plants and equipment.
"We have opportunities for growth inside this company, and that is where we're putting our money," said Robert Reed, the company's chief financial officer.
 
Discipline for Management
 But others argue that dividend payments are a healthy discipline for corporate managements. The need to pay ample dividends, they say, helps force companies to take the steps necessary to cut costs and become more efficient. Besides, they add, shareholders are better able to make objective investment decisions than are corporate managements.
One of Mr. Bower's colleagues at the Harvard Business School, Prof. Michael C. Jensen, is an outspoken proponent of this view. He notes that there is a "casual relationship" between high-growth technology companies and low dividend payments, but stresses that that should not lead people to conclude that companies that hold onto funds will invest them productively.
"The issue is not that our corpoations spend too little on new equipment or research and development, but that the money is being wasted," Professor Jensen said. "Unless we go to extraordinary lengths, the managements will keep the money within the corporations and invest it on things that are by and large unprofitable for the shareholders and for society."
 
2 Contrasting Cases
 Avon Products Inc. yesterday took an extraordinary step reminiscent of the 1980's, increasing its annual dividend 40 percent. It also said it would pay out a special dividend of $3 a share, more than a year's worth of profits. The move was intended to please shareholders and help management win a threatened proxy fight.
Maytag, by contrast, appears to be a case of a company that is paying for the excesses of the 1980's with its dividend cut, from 90 cents to 50 cents a year. Maytag grew nearly fivefold since 1985, to $3.1 billion in sales last year, with a series of acquisitions. But it borrowed heavily, and long-term debt jumped 35-fold in the period, to $845 million last year.
Daniel J. Krumm, Maytag's chairman, said the dividend cut was "the prudent thing to do" in the current recession, allowing the company to conserve cash and continue "vital capital spending programs."
When G.M. decided earlier this week to cut its dividend, it also announced cuts in spending and in its work force. Robert T. O'Connell, G.M.'s chief financial officer and an executive vice president, stressed that the move was motivated by the need to keep capital spending at $7 billion a year through 1994 and "stay the course aggressively on our new product program."
 
Informing Big Shareholders
 Before the board meeting in New York on Monday at which the dividend cut was decided upon, G.M. had been in contact with some of its big shareholders, explaining the compay's concerns about the soft economy and the need to keep up the pace of new-model development.
"Nobody likes to see the dividend cut," Mr. O'Connell said, "but there was a great measure of understanding in the investor community."
DeWitt Bowman, chief investment officer of the California Public Employees Retirement System, one of the nation's largest institutional investors and a major holder of G.M. stock, supported the company's moves.
"We were pleased to see the dividend cut and the other actions," he said. "The company could not bleed money the way they were and continue their basic manufacturing."
Mr. Bowman said that he regarded dividends as good corporate discipline, however, and that he preferred to have the money to invest where he saw fit and not in the hands of management.
 
Changing Market Reaction
 Traditionally, a company's share price drops sharply after a dividend cut -- a key reason why managements typically resist making the move. Managements often also feel obligated to small shareholders, especially retirees who rely on dividends to pay household expenses.
But G.M.'s stock has held steady since the company cut its payout, and market analysts and investors say that similar reactions to dividend cuts of other companies recently were a sign that the accepted wisdom may no longer hold.
"That's a big change in market perception," said Peter L. Bernstein, a Wall Street economist.
Increasingly, analysts say, the stock market's reaction to a dividend cut will be determined by the motivation and strategy behind the change.
"What is critical in the decision to cut a dividend or not pay one is the credibility of the management," said Ennius Bergsma, a director of McKinsey & Company, a management consultant.
 
Part of a Strategy
 The Occidental Petroleum Corporation recently provided an example of a dividend cut made as part of a larger strategy. In January, a month after the company's longtime chairman, Armand Hammer, died, the company said it would cut its dividend from $2.50 a year to $1. The dividend reduction was part of the new management's program to reduce debt and focus on its oil and chemicals businesses. Occidental's share price rose after the announcement.
"Occidental's dividend cut was a model of how it should be done, because it came in the context of a clear strategic vision that was articulated by the management," said Bryan Jacoboski, an analyst at Paine Webber Group.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: JORDAN;
2 Risky Gambles for Jordan's Ruler

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 7

 BODY:
In a region whose political bazaar rarely fixes absolute prices and where reality is filtered through emotional perceptions, King Hussein has taken two gambles by aligning himself with Iraq.
 The first bet is that by supporting the Iraqis, the Jordanian King can contain and continue to lead his restive domestic constituency without forfeiting his longstanding ties to the West. That seems a safer bet than the other gamble: that he can win wider Arab support in a region splintered by the allied offensive against Baghdad. 
 Both bets hinge on competing notions of Arab legitimacy that are likely to determine the credibility of Arab leaders and the direction of their politics, however the gulf war is concluded.
Addressing his nation on television on Wednesday night, King Hussein transformed Jordan's tilt toward Iraq into an open embrace, depicting the United States and its allies as the lineal successors of European imperialists out to destroy Arab pride and mold the region to their will.
Iraq, he said, is "defending us all" against the intruders.
 
Arabs Against the West
 In this vision, President Saddam Hussein's battered Iraqi nation becomes the bulwark of Arab aspirations, not the brutalizer of Kuwait. It is a political vision that looks beyond the occupation of Kuwait to the region's perennial battle against alien intruders.
The Jordanian ruler's intention, Western and other specialists say, is to reassert control of his own troubled land, in which more than half the population is Palestinian, Many here are frustrated, and eager to grasp at Iraqi promises of Palestinian statehood and Arab redemption.
"As he has done throughout the crisis, his intention was to get out ahead of the street," said an Arab diplomat who spoke on the condition of anonymity, referring to a Jordanian public that sees the Iraqi President as a champion.
There were some nuances. While King Hussein did not allude to the invasion of Kuwait at any point in his 30-minute address, he did not mention Saddam Hussein by name, either. Moreover, he spoke repeatedly of the imminent destruction of Iraq, perhaps hinting to Jordanians that they may well have to contemplate the defeat of an Arab leader who stature has grown here as the war has unfolded.
 
Ties to U.S. at Risk
 Yet, by setting the markers of domestic politics, the King risked further alienating the United States and jeopardizing his personal relationship with President Bush, who had asked the King for a public expression of understanding for America's views.
That was part of the first, more certain gamble: Washington, the King calculated, would understand his predicament at home and would not wish to cut off communication with an Arab leader who has during 37 years in power, played an important role in much of Washington's Middle East diplomacy.
The second gamble, far riskier, suggested a calculation that the only Arab leaders likely to emerge from the gulf war with credibility and legitimacy would be those who did not collaborate in the spilling of Arab blood by infidels.
"It is very difficult for anyone who has been party to the war camp to have a real say in the future," said Ibrahim Izzedine, Jordan's Information Minister and a former ambassador to Washington. "You have to have credibility." By "war camp," he meant Arab countries supporting the American-led coalition in the gulf, notably Egypt and Saudi Arabia.
 
'Symbols for Legitimacy'
 "In any society there are some symbols for legitimacy to influence and to continue to influence decisions. You can't do it if you put yourself in the war camp," Mr. Izzedine said.
Western European diplomats acknowledged that such an the argument exerts a strong pull. Syria supported non-Arab Iran against Arab Iraq throughout the 1980-88 war, one envoy noted, and "paid the price of Arab isolation for doing so."
In his speech, the Jordanian King singled out Egypt, Turkey and Saudi Arabia, all staunch United States allies, as countries that had brought shame upon Islam by supporting the United States in what he called the destruction of an Arab nation: Iraq.
King Hussein's words might be viewed as a careless, even reckless, move to alienate neighbors, particularly Saudi Arabia, whose oil wealth potentially could rescue Jordan's sinking economy.
But Mr. Izzedine said Amman's view was that as the war unfolds, more and more Arabs and Muslims will feel repelled by the allied offensive. "I don't think it's going to be accepted by any Arab," he said, seemingly implying that many would turn against Governments supporting the allied war effort.
 
Appeal to the Masses
 The King may ultimately be reaching past the leaders of some Arab governments to build a broad consituency among their peoples. Mr. Izzedine pointed to the historical role played by the King's Hashemite dynasty, once the custodian of Islam's holiest shrines in what is now Saudi Arabia.
"The King belongs to a historic family," the Information Miniter said. "He believes he has a historic responsibility. His family has played a very important role in the Arab world and in shaping public opinion that goes beyond the borders of any state."
Although the King's statement seemed unequivocally pro-Iraqi, it did not commit him to specific action. Despite his abandonment of political neutrality, there was no suggestion that Jordan wishes to enter the war.
"We are not party to the conflict and we are not going to be drawn in," Mr Izzedine said. Moreoever, he said, Jordan still supports the return of "legitimacy" in Kuwait and has not abandoned its earlier position criticizing the Iraqi invasion.
The timing of King Hussein's speech, reflected his concern that the intensity of the allied onslaught might soon preclude any peace initiative.
"The basic message he tried to send," a high-ranking official said, "was that he would like to see an Iraq-American dialogue and an Arab-Arab dialogue. It would be impossible for him to see Baghdad destroyed."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: WASHINGTON;
U.S. Says It Is Reviewing Aid to Jordan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
The Bush Administration announced today that it was reviewing all of its economic aid to Jordan after a speech by King Hussein in which he seemed to abandon his professed neutrality in the Persian Gulf war and threw his support behind Iraq.
"We are reviewing all military and economic assistance to Jordan," the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said. The announcement came after President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d conferred on the issue this afternoon. 
 In fiscal 1990, Jordan received $102 million in economic and military aid from the United States. In fiscal 1991, which began last October, it received $57.2 million -- $20 million in military assistance, $35 million in economic assistance and $2.2 million in training programs.
Officials said Jordan's 1991 allocation now being dispersed would not be affected. The review would apply to how much money Jordan might be allocated in fiscal year 1992, which starts next Oct. 1. The fiscal 1992 foreign aid allotments are only now being drawn up, but officials said Jordan was scheduled to receive roughly the same $50 million before the review.
The aid to Jordan could either be reduced, eliminated altogether or maintained at its present level.
 
Official Protest Lodged
 Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker, while they still have some sympathy for the difficult predicament in which King Hussein finds himself, decided that his latest speech was so "gratuitously" anti-American that they simply could not let it stand without at least a symbolic rejoinder, an Administration official said.
The Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern Affairs, John H. Kelly, summoned Jordan's Ambassador to Washington to the State Department on Wednesday night to lodge an official protest.
In his speech, the Jordanian King, most of whose subjects are Palestinians, declared that the allied war effort was directed against "all Muslims and not against Iraq alone" and is aimed at establishing "foreign hegemony" over the Middle East and destroying "brotherly Iraq."
Before the gulf crisis, King Hussein was considered not only a longtime friend of the United States but a personal friend of Mr. Bush. The Amman Government has long been viewed as a voice for moderation in Arab-Israeli affairs, a strategic buffer between Israel and Iraq and a bulwark against a Palestinian state in Jordan.
 
Quandary for Washington
 King Hussein's steady drift into Iraq's orbit has put the Bush Administration in something of a quandary, which was reflected in today's decision to review aid, but not necessarily to slash it. To put it simply, Administration officials say, increasingly they can't live with King Hussein, but they can't live without him either.
While they are deeply disturbed by his increasingly strident support for Iraq, Administration officials say, the only alternative to King Hussein that seems likely to emerge would be a Jordan dominated by the Palestine Liberation Organization, and that, they say, would be even worse. Given a choice between a King Hussein who is espousing the slogans of the P.L.O. and Iraq, or a Jordan dominated by the P.L.O. itself, Washington still prefers King Hussein as the lesser of two evils, officials said.
"We have a major disagreement with the King and what he said in that speech and the position that he has taken," Mr. Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, when asked for his reaction to the Jordanian King's speech.
"To allege that our effort against Iraq is unjust and exceeds the U.N. resolution is something that is patently not true," Mr. Baker added. "We have repeatedly emphasized that our objective is not the destruction of Iraq, it is the liberation of Kuwait, and quite frankly we find it very sad that the King omitted in this rather long speech any reference whatsoever, not one single reference, to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and omitted any reference therefore to any call for withdrawal."
Mr. Baker said the Administration intended to "keep lines of communication open to the King notwithstanding the fact that he's on the wrong side and we have a major disagreement here with him."
That is because, Mr. Baker said, "when we look at alternatives we don't see what we perceive to be a particularly pretty picture -- alternatives to the King, and therefore we would not -- we would think that it's important to keep our lines of communication open and to make it clear to him and to that Government that we fundamentally disagree with that position."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Claiborne Pell, left, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, before Mr. Baker addressed the committee yesterday in Washington. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: January Sales Data Reflect Continued Retail Weakness

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Leading retailers reported generally disappointing results for January, creating concern over profits in the final quarter and the year as a whole.
Twelve of the 19 largest chains announcing their results had declines or minimal gains at stores open at least a year, a category known as same-store sales, Some, like Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest, and the J. C. Penney Company, No. 4, had overall sales declines, including new stores. Wal-Mart, though, showed strong sales growth. 
 If the year appeared to end with a whimper, retail analysts noted that the sluggish trend had endured all year, although it worsened after the war began.
 
'Havoc' on the Consumer
 "The January results reflect the havoc that was created by the Mideast war on the American consumer," said Kurt Barnard, a New York retail analyst and newsletter publisher.
While January is historically the year's second-smallest monthly contributor to annual apparel sales, 6 percent compared with December's 14 percent, analysts noted that it was an important month because it represented a final effort to clear out inventory for the benefit of year-end profits.
"The sales reported by the big retailers confirm the continued weakness in spending for discretionary items, a trend in place even before Iraq invaded Kuwait," said Janet Mangano, research vice president at Jesup, Josephthal & Company in New York.
Despite its disappointing results, Sears managed to maintain a small lead over the fast-running Wal-Mart Stores. The K Mart Corporation, enjoying a relatively good month, stayed ahead of Wal-Mart in January, but it fell under Wal-Mart's yearly total.
At J. C. Penney, the chairman, William R. Howell, said catalogue demand was off substantially but store sales increased in January.
Indicating a broad-based consumer shopping lag, department store chains experienced a difficult month.
"We remain very conservative in our planning for 1991 in view of the uncertainties in this economic environment." said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman of the Dayton Hudson Corporation.
In evaluating the results, Mr. Barnard and Ms. Mangano said the best results were turned in by "value oriented" retailers, like Wal-Mart and Venture Stores. Mr. Barnard added, "The best ones also have attractive merchandise and pleasing shopping environments."
Ms. Mangano said, "The results show steady demand at those value-oriented retailers that offer commodity items at everyday low prices."
 
Results Vary
 But results at discounters varied sharply. Venture said its January sales rose 10.4 percent, to $78.2 million, and its same-store sales were up 6.2 percent, while its annual sales increased 6.1 percent, to $1.42 billion. But the Jamesway Corporation had 2 percent higher sales in January, to $33.4 million, and same-store sales, considered a more accurate indicator of retailing performance, fell 4 percent.
The specialty shop field, with eight big companies, had mixed results with the Limited Inc., the Melville Corporation, the Neiman Marcus Group, Ross Stores Inc. and Charming Shoppes Inc. reporting slow same-store sales. But new store expansion seemed to help, with Melville, the Limited, and the Gap Inc. reporting stronger overall sales. Merry-Go-Round Enterprises was up 30 percent, and Edison Brothers Stores had a 15.6 percent gain in the month.
Following is a list of the domestic January sales and sales for the fiscal year to date reported yesterday. The sales compare the current year's sales with those of the previous year:
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same-store sales fell 3.7 percent; overall sales fell 1.7 percent, to $355.7 million. For fiscal 1990, same-store sales fell 1.9 percent; overall sales fell nine- tenths of a percent, to $2.17 billion.
Dayton Hudson Corp.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same-store sales rose 1.2 percent; overall sales rose 11.8 percent, to $988 million. For fiscal 1990, same-store sales rose 3.5 percent; overall sales rose 13.5 percent, to $14.50 billion.
Gap Inc.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same- store sales rose 12 percent; overall sales rose 24 percent, to $305 million. For fiscal 1990, same-store sales rose 14 percent; overall sales rose 24 percent, to $1.79 billion.
J. C. Penney Co.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same-store sales fell 3 percent; overall sales fell 1.4 percent, to $982 million. For fiscal 1990, same-store sales fell three- tenths of a percent; overall sales rose 1 percent, to $15.27 billion.
K Mart Corp.: For five weeks ended Jan. 30,same-store sales rose 3.8 percent; overall sales rose 8.9 percent, to $2.42 billion. For fiscal 1990, same-store sales rose 1.9 percent; overall sales rose 9.9 percent, to $32.07 billion.
Limited Inc.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same-store sales rose 4 percent; overall sales rose 19 percent, to $824.2 million. For fiscal 1990, overall sales rose 17.8 percent, to $4.84 billion. (Limited did not report a yearly same-store sales percentage.)
May Department Stores Co.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same-store sales fell 2.1 percent; overall sales rose 8 percent, to $613.5 million. For fiscal 1990, same-store sales rose nine-tenths of a percent; overall sales rose 7.5 percent, to $10.04 billion.
Melville Corp.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same-store sales rose three-tenths of a percent; overall sales rose 23.8 percent, to $657.5 million. For fiscal 1990, overall sales rose 14.9 percent, to $8.68 billion. (Melville did not report a yearly same-store sales percentage.)
Sears, Roebuck & Co.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same-store sales fell 3.2 percent; overall sales fell 3.4 percent, to $2.57 billion. For fiscal 1990, same-store sales rose six- tenths of a percent; overall sales rose 1.5 percent, to $33.95 billion.
TJX Cos.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, overall sales rose 19.4 percent, to $293.4 million. For fiscal 1990, overall sales rose 13.6 percent, to $2.29 billion. (TJX did not report any same-store sales percentages.)
Wal-Mart Stores: For January, same-store sales rose 11 percent; overall sales rose 36 percent, to $2.5 billion For fiscal 1990, same- store sales rose 10 percent; overall sales rose 26 percent, to $32.6 billion. (1991 figures include results of the recently acquired McLane subsidiary).
Woolworth Corp.: For five weeks ended Feb. 2, same-store sales rose seven-tenths of a percent; overall sales rose 5.5 percent, to $780 million. For fiscal 1990, same-store sales rose 3.4 percent; overall sales rose 7.1 percent, to $5.11 billion.

The Economy
The common stock dividend is being sliced. With profits shrinking as the recession digs in, the nation's auto, aerospace, appliance and other companies are left with little extra cash to pay to shareholders. Thus another of the corporate excesses of the 1980's is being reversed. [Page A1.]
Leading retailers reported generally disappointing results for January, creating concern over profits in the final quarter and the year as a whole. Twelve of the 19 largest chains announcing their results had same-store declines or minimal gains. [D1.]
Former F.D.I.C. regulators told a Congressional hearing that for more than a year their superiors had thwarted their efforts to recover large losses from the billionaire owner of a Phoenix savings and loan that failed. [D2.]
"An invitation to regulatory civil war." That is what William Seidman calls the Administration's radical plan to change the way banks are run. As head of the F.D.I.C., Seidman stands to lose some of his extensive power under the new bank plan. [D2.]
Consumer credit fell at an annual rate of 2.3 percent in December, the steepest decline in nearly four years, the Fed said. [D3.]
New York City bonds are likely to be issued without insurance backing for the first time in years. [B3.]
 
Companies
Chrysler surprised Wall Street by posting a $31 million profit in the fourth quarter in the face of plunging car and truck sales. But its profit was too narrow to quiet growing concerns that the No. 3 auto maker may soon face severe financial difficulties. [D1.]
Avon said it would increase its dividend 40 percent and pay a special dividend of $3 a share, or more than a year's profits. Analysts said the surprise move could help it win a coming proxy fight with Chartwell Associates. [D1.]
MIPS Computer Systems has emerged as one of two leaders in the race to sell computers based on the RISC chip design. [D1.]
Sony is reportedy talking to Orion Pictures about buying that financially troubled film and TV company. Sony is said to be acting through Castle Rock Entertainment, a small film production company one-third owned by Columbia Pictures. [D1.]
Mesa Limited Partnership agreed to sell 11 percent of its natural gas reserves for $275 million in cash. [D3.]
A team trying to arrange an employee stake in The Daily News met to lay out its strategy. [B4.]
 
Markets
Prices in the credit markets gave ground for the first time in days, as market participants apparently took profits after a successful auction of $11 billion in new 30-year Treasury bonds. [D1.]
Stocks fell for the first time in almost a week, but trading remained exceptionally heavy. The Dow lost 20.30, to 2,810.64, as many investors switched into lower-priced stocks. [D6.]
The dollar edged higher in domestic trading for the first time in more than a week after two central banks intervened to shore up the currency. [D13.]
Oil prices fell after a rally driven by the price of heating oil faded on forecasts of warmer weather in Europe. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
The battle has begun over the Administration's proposals for the most drastic overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Depression. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Volvo awarded its $40 million account to Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer. The account review had been closely watched in the industry recently. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D5.]
Just what is a securities exchange? More than 50 years after Congress adopted the Securities Exchange Act, putting the regulatory framework in place for the modern marketplace, a debate is raging on that question. Market Place. [D6.]

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 3; Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:
'Gypsy' Returning
The Tony Award winner Tyne Daly is coming back to Broadway as Mama Rose when "Gypsy" reopens on April 23 for a 12-week engagement, this time at the Marquis Theater. The producers, Barry and Fran Weissler, previously announced that a company headed by Miss Daly, who played the role for nine months on Broadway last season, would open in London in late spring. But those plans were made before the war in the Persian Gulf began. 
 Mr. Weissler says: "Some people in the company have expressed concern about flying certain airlines. And if a ground war starts now, will anyone come to the theater? I want to be where I can take care of the show, especially if you can expect surprises. To do it all by phone makes me uncomfortable." He says he hopes to open "Gypsy" in London next fall.
 
No Reservation? No Problem.
 The war and the recession have hit the theater hard, and along with it the restaurants in the theater district, whose business depends on how many hits are up and running. Out of 36 Broadway theaters, 17 are dark. And according to the grosses reported in Variety, many of the 19 shows now running are doing weak business. Perhaps the most sobering proof is last Wednesday's matinee of "The Phantom of the Opera." The show actually "went dead" with about 140 tickets, meaning that for the first time since the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical opened, seats went unsold.
The restaurants near 45th Street seem to be hardest hit. The block between Broadway and Eighth Avenue has always been considered the prime booking location on Broadway. But now, four of its six theaters are empty.
Vincent Sardi Jr., who owns his family's restaurant on 44th Street, says: "There was an instant reaction the day the war started. We are missing the foreign businessmen and travelers. They've practically disappeared. We went through all kinds of paperwork to be able to accept JAL, a Japanese credit card, and we haven't even used it yet."
Joe Allen, who owns the restaurant named for him, as well as Orso, both on 46th Street, confirms that foreign business is way down. Hunter Cain, a manager at Sam's on 52d Street, says his pre- and post-theater business is off, but not as drastically as that of his competitors in the mid-40's. He attributes his better fortune to his restaurant's being on the same street as the strong "City of Angels" and "Jackie Mason: Brand New." He also says he expects a big increase when the heavily pre-sold "Miss Saigon" opens at the Broadway Theater at 53d Street in April.
Other restaurateurs in the mid-40's are eagerly awaiting Neil Simon's "Lost in Yonkers," scheduled to open at the Richard Rodgers Theater on 46th Street on Feb. 21. Mr. Allen says, "Neil Simon doesn't realize the awesome responsibility he has to save a whole neighborhood."
 
Not for the Drama League
 Arthur Kopit's new play at the Circle Repertory Theater, "Road to Nirvana," starring Peter Riegert and Saundra Santiago, is already causing debate even though it doesn't open until March 7. The work is about two film producers who will do anything to make the ultimate deal, and the theater's artistic director, Tanya Berezin, calls it shocking. The script calls for the characters to eat feces, she says, and "there's lots of sex." She adds, "It's harsh, but also hilarious."
Apparently, Julia Hansen, president of the Drama League, fails to see the humor. Her nonprofit organization, which administers a variety of programs and special events for its members, sponsors a subscription series that, she says, "encourages them to be imaginative and see work that's entertaining and interesting, to keep educated about the theater and be as supportive as they can be." Circle Rep has kept those members entertained in the past, but after the Drama League's marketing director requested a script of "Road to Nirvana," Ms. Berezin was told that the play was "not for their audience."
In response, Ms. Berezin says she wrote Mrs. Hansen a note saying she was surprised at the reaction. Ms. Berezin says the note went un answered. Mrs. Hansen would not say whether the "Nirvana" script had been read and rejected. She would say only that the Drama League chose plays at the WPA and Second Stage theaters instead. The reason: one of the Drama League's programs, the Director's Project, had participants working on productions there.
Ms. Berezin says: "When I committed to do this play, I knew I would not want people to bring their 8-year-olds. Whoever we lose, we lose. That's what risk is all about."
 
'Earth and Sky' and Hollywood
 Hollywood's latest obsession is Douglas Post. The 30-year-old playwright's "Earth and Sky" opened at the Second Stage on Monday. Although critics' responses were mixed, the consensus among film and television executives is that this thriller about a woman's investigation into her lover's mysterious death, with its tour de force leading role, played by Jennifer Van Dyke, is hot with a capital H. (Michelle Pfeiffer and Jodie Foster are already being mentioned for a film version.) Second Stage subscribers have sat next to representatives of Columbia Pictures, Paramount, M-G-M, Universal, Warner Brothers, 20th Century Fox, Orion, TriBeCa (Robert De Niro's company) and the director-producers James Brooks, Norman Jewison and Alan J. Pakula.
Helen Harvey, Mr. Post's agent, says no deal has yet been made. Robyn Goodman, co-artistic director of Second Stage, says a sale was delayed until the play opened so there wouldn't be extra pressure on Mr. Post during his first New York production. "All you have to do with Hollywood people is say no," she says, "and here they all are."
 
Casting Notes

HEADLINE: For Children

BYLINE: By Dulcie Leimbach

 BODY:
Potato People
Dalton School
108 East 89th Street
Manhattan
(212) 744-1649
Recommended ages: 3 to 12
Tomorrow
The Potato People wear papier-mache masks with no mouths, yet they manage to convey their slapstick humor and antics through mime and exaggerated body language and with the help of a Madonna tune or two. Indeed, you might wonder why it's so hard for your children to express themselves sometimes after you spend an hour with the Potato People. Produced by the Theater Beyond Words in Ontario, Canada, formerly the Canadian Mime Theater, the company has toured extensively through its own country, the United States and even the Soviet Union, where potatoes are almost a natural resource. The main characters are indolent Poppa Potato, Momma Potato in her curlers and blue slippers, and Nancy Potato, an overgrown 3-year-old. Momma and Poppa are a domestic Laurel and Hardy, providing a lot of self-mocking fun, though Nancy garners a round of giggles when she blows her nose like a trumpet. The Martin Theater at the Dalton School holds 500 people, so the stage is close and seating is democratic. There is no intermission and no refreshments are served. Strollers can be left in the school's central lobby. Tickets are $7.50.
 
The Ice Studio
1034 Lexington Avenue, at 73d Street
(212) 535-0304
Recommended ages: 4 and up
Archie Walker, a former skater with the Ice Capades, is the effusive owner of this dance-studio-size indoor rink, which has been here 14 years. The smallish rink, with its large windows and ballet barres, is separated by a glass wall from the reception area, where wooden benches draw parents who aren't up to skating but who want to watch and relax. On a recent Saturday, the studio was not at all crowded, and the intimate atmosphere was one of calm civility: just right for the Upper East Side. Lessons, a coat check and a restroom are available. Hours for general skating are 8:30 to 10 P.M. on Thursdays; 5 to 6 P.M. and 8:30 to 10 P.M. on Fridays, and noon to 1 P.M. and 5:15 to 6:15 P.M. on weedends. On Sundays, an additional session from 3:15 to 4:15 P.M. is available. Admission: $5 for one hour; $6 for an hour and a half. Skate rental: $2.75.
 
'Music Under the Big Top'
Avery Fisher Hall
Lincoln Center
(212) 704-2100 or (212) 874-6770 (Centercharge)
Recommended ages: 6 to 12
Tomorrow
 As part of the Happy Concerts for Young People, series the Little Orchestra Society of Manhattan is presenting the No Elephant Circus, a troupe of jugglers, dancers, acrobats and clowns that tours with symphony orchestras. Under the baton of Dino Anagnost, who takes the time to talk to the young audience about the music the orchestra is playing, the wily circus performers eat fire, walk on stilts and clown on unicyles. They just don't have any elephants. No matter. The rousing circus-theme music, by such composers as Copland, Dvorak and Bizet, excites the audience just as well, conjuring up images of cotton candy, calliopes, sawdust and far-flung aerialists. Tickets to the 50-minute programs, which are performed without intermissions, are $15 to $28, at the Avery Fisher Hall box office or through the telephone numbers above. Fisher Hall is a worldly yet comfortable place, with restrooms on each floor, elevators, two restaurants and a snack bar selling muffins, cookies, sandwiches and drinks in the lobby before and after the performances, which begin at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. Children dress up in suits and patent-leather shoes, but casual clothes fit in, too.
 
'Walt Disney's World on Ice: Mickey Mouse Diamond Jubilee'
Radio City Music Hall
(212) 247-4777 or (212) 307-7171
Recommended ages: 2 and up
Through Sunday
Mickey may have starred in more than 130 films and hundreds of stage, television and video events, but at 60 years old he is just approaching his prime. His low-key, almost modest manner has not changed since his debut in "Steamboat Willie." In fact, he seems a bit shy at this current event at Radio City celebrating his birthday. Dressed in red satin pants, a black topcoat with tails and mouse skates, Mickey amiably shares the limelight with Goofy, Pluto, Donald, Daisy and Minnie. There is certainly enough stage time, with 2 acts and 11 short scenes, for Mickey's cohorts and other Disney characters to skate in skits from such stories as "Steamboat Willie," "Sorcerer's Apprentice" and "Puppy Love." Though most of the audience may not have seen the first "Puppy Love," which made its debut in 1933, they will appreciate seeing how Mickey and Minnie first met. For the most part, children are riveted for the two hours as they bask in the aura of Mickey Mouse, which is important because many acts lack complete narratives or theatrical direction. The scenes in the second act are slightly more cohesive and dramatic. In "The Land Above the Clouds," for example, a giant's moving hand makes the children suitably uneasy, if not impressed. What is lacking is made up for by the lavish pure Walt Disney sets and costumes, as well as the computerized lighting that adds tension to many scenes. A 20-minute intermission is welcome, if only to note the bustle at the souvenir stands in the lobby, where the recession seems to have been thoroughly snuffed out. Strollers are checked by the kindly ushers, and elevators can whisk you upstairs if the main staircase is too daunting. Tickets are $14 and $18, and show times are at 2:30 and 7 P.M. today; at 11 A.M., 2:30 and 7 P.M. tomorrow, and at 11 A.M. and 2:30 P.M. on Sunday.
 
North Meadow Recreation Center
Central Park
96th Street and Central Park West entrance
(212) 348-4867
Recommended ages: 8 and up
Saturdays and Sundays
Follow the concrete path midway through the park to a pair of low, red-brick buildings sitting on a slope. The North Meadow Recreation Center is in the building on the left, but you have to walk through an army of bright green park vehicles in the courtyard to get to its front door. The Central Park Conservancy and the New York City Department of Recreation and Parks sponsor the center's weekday and weekend activities for boys and girls; on Saturdays, Tony Velez is in charge; on Sundays, Ron Green runs the show. Depending on the weather and the number of people who come and what their mood is, the day could consist of football (touch or tackle), basketball, kite flying, paddle ball and handball on the clean athletic fields and handball courts. Inside the airy one-room center, with its trussed ceiling and large windows, quieter pursuits like Ping-Pong, bingo, board games and macrame take place. The center provides all the equipment free. No food is available, and on the weekends after dark there is no formal arrangement to escort people out of the park, though most walk home at the same time or in groups. The hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on the weekends and 3:15 to 5:45 P.M. on weekdays. Registration is necessary, and can be done any day.

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;
Trump Plans to Meet With Arum and Duva

 BODY:
Donald Trump said yesterday he would meet tomorrow with the co-promoters Bob Arum and Dan Duva in an effort to iron out any differences that might jeopardize the heavyweight title fight between Evander Holyfield and George Foreman.
The bout is scheduled to be held at the Atlantic City Convention Center on April 19, but Arum says he might have to shift the match to Las Vegas if Trump persists in trying to re-negotiate his deal for the live-site rights.
Arum said yesterday that he had spoken to representatives of Caesars Palace about moving the fight there, following assertions on Wednesday by Trump that an "act of war" clause in his contract gave him the right to revise the deal.
Trump, who agreed to pay $3.5 million and guarantee another $7.5 million in gate receipts for the right to stage the fight in Atlantic City, said the war in the Persian Gulf had altered the economic climate for the bout and he wanted to reduce his site fee. But Arum said Trump was raising false issues to cloud the fact that he could not meet the next installment of $2.5 million due the promoters tomorrow.
"He's breached the contract by saying what he has said," Arum said. "Now he can cure the breach by putting up the money. If he doesn't, this fight's going to end up at Caesars Palace."
Arum said that money, or Trump's lack of it, was the real issue, and that the deal for the live-site rights had been signed Jan. 19, three days after the war started.
Trump contends that the fight cannot be moved without his approval. "The fight stays," said Trump, "or else there will be a lot of litigation."

HEADLINE: A Gas Tax Could Nip the Next Crisis in the Bud

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Perhaps the greatest benefit the war in the Middle East could provide is to rouse us into a sensible energy policy. A gas tax could help avert the next crisis before it begins.
If we're willing to send half a million fellow citizens into battle, to protect oil supplies and our economic way of life, we should be no less willing to make the small sacrifice of paying more for gasoline. A revenue-neutral plan that reduced Social Security taxes by $1 billion for every penny a gallon of gas tax would leave the working poor and middle class better off than before. In the long term, the whole country would benefit from reducing the hidden tax of pollution, congestion and dependence on foreign oil.
With oil prices now down substantially, let's not squander this opportunity to win the next war without firing a shot.
 
ERIK BRYNJOLFSSON
Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 18, 1991
 
The writer is an assistant professor of management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: U.N. Force Offers Israeli-Palestinian Solution;
Peace Treaty Now

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A. M. Rosenthal argues ("Bill of Reckoning," column, Jan. 22) that the Iraqi Scud attacks on Israel prove the case for continuing the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. Had the missiles come from the West Bank, he writes, they could have been equipped with larger or more dangerous warheads and would have caused more damage. The opposite is more nearly the case.
As the Israeli novelist A. B. Yehoshua has pointed out, the Scud attacks simply confirm that the concept of strategic depth is largely obsolete and that only a political solution can assure Israel's security.
Now more than ever, Israel needs a peace treaty with the Palestinians. Withdrawal from the West Bank is no longer the traumatic issue it was a few years ago: as a result of the Palestinian uprising, it has already happened. The pre-1967 border is back in place, the integration of the Israeli economy with the occupied territories has been largely reversed, and the historic sites where the Jewish people first became a nation are essentially inaccessible anyway. The price of withdrawal has been paid; it is time to reap some of the benefits.
A peace treaty would not result in the nightmare of Iraq-on-the-Jordan. A treaty would require that the West Bank be a demilitarized zone, with only a police force and no offensive capacities. Neither tanks nor poison gas plants are easily hidden in an unindustrialized country with interested neighbors no more than a few miles away. Any attempt at a military buildup would be detected by Israel, which could immediately respond -- before the buildup reached dangerous levels. The contrast to Iraq, which built the world's fourth or fifth largest army with the active or passive support of nearly every major country in the developed world, could not be stronger.
Indeed, a Palestinian government would have the strongest possible incentive to protect Israeli security. Today, Palestinians in the Persian Gulf, Jordan and the West Bank are loudly calling for Saddam Hussein to bombard Tel Aviv with everything he has. But after a peace treaty, a Palestinian government would have to restrain its people: terror coming from the Palestinian territory would invite a fearful response from Israel. Underlying all Palestinian strategic decisions would be the certain knowledge that if Israel were forced to invade to protect its domestic security, there would never be a second withdrawal.
Meanwhile, the Israeli army would be freed of the demoralizing task of policing a hostile occupied population and could concentrate on insuring that its antimissile defenses are ready and functional before the next distant madman decides that the most effective way to fight the United States army is to bomb Israeli civilians. Israel could concentrate its resources and energies on building its own democracy by integrating the Russian and Ethiopian immigrants -- newcomers who want to be part of the state -- instead of policing hostile Palestinians, who do not. Even a cold peace, like the one Israel has with Egypt, would allow Israelis to return to the national mission of building a democratic state in the land of Israel.
 
DANIEL J. H. GREENWOOD
New York, Jan. 24, 1991

HEADLINE: Aryness Wickens, 90, Economist Who Developed Major Cost Index

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Aryness Joy Wickens, an economist and statistician who played the crucial role in developing the Government's cost-of-living index, now the Consumer Price Index, died last Saturday at the Lakeland Health Care Center in Jackson, Miss. She was 90 years old and lived in Jackson.
She died of a heart attack, her family said. 
 Mrs. Wickens retired from the Department of Labor in 1970 after a 42-year career in Fderal service that began when she joined the Federal Reserve Board as a research assistant in 1928 after having taught at Mount Holyoke College for four years.
In 1933 she served on a committee organized by the American Statistical Association to advise Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins on setting up the Bureau of Labor Statistics program. A few years later she directed the bureau's studies for the Temporary National Economic Committee's investigation of monopolistic practices in industry.
When the bureau was reorganized in 1940, Mrs. Wickens became chief of the branch studying prices and the cost of living. From 1946 to 1961 she was assistant and then deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics.
In 1952 she was president of the American Statistical Association. Eight years later, in recognition of her outstanding Government service, she was one of six recipients of the first Federal Women's Awards of the Civil Service Commission.
 
Adviser at U.N. Conferences
 In 1961, after having been a United States adviser at many United Nations and other international conferences, Mrs. Wickens was named economic adviser to the Secretary of Labor. In that post she laid the statistical base for what became the department's Manpower Administration and its Employment and Training Administration.
After retirement Mrs. Wickens served on the advisory board of the United States Export-Import Bank. In 1976 she returned to government work as director of statistical studies for the Commission on Federal Paperwork.
Mrs. Wickens was born in Bellingham, Wash. She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Washington and held a master's degree from the University of Chicago. She lived near Vienna, Va., before moving to Jackson four years ago.
Her husband, David L. Wickens, an economist, died in 1970. She is survived by a son, Donaldson, of Jackson, and three grandsons.

HEADLINE: CHENEY FORESEES NEW SOVIET UNREST

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told Congress today that he foresaw "continued economic decline" and "increased unrest" in the Soviet Union. As a result, he said in his exceedingly bleak assessment, the Administration may reconsider its request for reductions in military spending over the next six years.
 "The possibility for major unrest may be such that we would not feel safe recommending to the Congress of the United States the kind of long-term six-year reductions" in military spending requested by President Bush in his latest budget, Mr. Cheney said. The budget was sent to Congress three days ago. 
Mr. Cheney's comments, in testimony before the House Armed Services Committee, were the clearest statement to date of his might implode and that the Administration might have to rethink Pentagon spending plans.
 "The Warsaw Pact is dead," and "the Soviets will continue to withdraw from Eastern Europe," but "the Soviet economy is collapsing," Mr. Cheney said.
 Moreover, he said: "We have to plan on enormous uncertainty about developments inside the Soviet Union in the future. I have to believe there will be continued economic decline, that that means increased unrest and the possibility which Soviets frankly discuss among themselves, perhaps even of civil war in the Soviet Union."
 Thus, Mr. Cheney said, "the greatest threat to the neighbors of the Soviet Union in the future may well come more from the Soviet inability to control events inside the Soviet Union than it will from any conscious policy of seeking to expand their influence by military means."
 Mr. Cheney did not say precisely how such a threat might emerge. Some experts on Soviet affairs have expressed concern that if the Soviet Union drifted into chaos, nuclear weapons and other military equipment might fall into the hands of irresponsible people.
 "Violent disintegration of the Soviet Union may create terrible convulsions outside the Soviet Union," said Dimitri K. Simes, senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "If reactionary forces establish a dictatorship, surely it would affect Soviet foreign policy."
 
'Where Would It Stop?'
 "There are more nuclear weapons in the Ukraine than in all of Europe outside the Soviet bloc," Mr. Simes said. "If economic decline leads to civil war in the Soviet Union, with clearly defined sides like Russia against the Ukraine, or conservatives against democrats, where would it stop? I can easily visualize scenarios where Europeans would want a credible American deterrent to maintain stability."
 Mr. Bush's new budget was drafted on the premise that the Soviet threat had diminished. Military spending would decline from $298.9 billion this year to $295.2 billion next year and $292 billion in 1993.
 Mr. Cheney said today that economic and political turmoil in the Soviet Union cast doubt on the prospects for further arms control agreements between Moscow and Washington.
 "Those moves toward democracy and demilitarization of the Soviet Union that we all welcomed so thoroughly in recent years now appear to be in doubt," Mr. Cheney said. "Mr. Gorbachev has resorted to and sanctioned a crackdown in the Baltics, appears to be prepared to use force to fall back upon the security services in the military, to try to maintain order inside the Soviet Union," he added. "We're beginning to see now a reversal of some of the trends in terms of human rights and freedom of the press, and of course a continuing conflict between nationalities."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 9, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of a mechanical error, an article yesterday about Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's bleak assessment of the Soviet Union's future omitted part of the third paragraph. It should have read, "Mr. Cheney's comments, in testimony before the House Armed Services Committee, were the clearest statement to date of his concern that the Soviet Union might implode and that the Administration might have to rethink Pentagon spending plans."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
More Cost Cutting Expected at Ford

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
A senior executive of the Ford Motor Company said the automobile maker would intensify cost cutting in response to the industry's recession but would not lower capital spending as the General Motors Corporation has decided to do. Alexander J. Trotman, executive vice president of the No. 2 car maker and head of its North American operations, declined to elaborate on how Ford would further reduce costs but said, "It's not business as usual."
G.M., Ford and the Chrysler Corporation began cost-cutting programs in the late 1980's but have accelerated and deepened them as the American economy turned sour last year. Mr. Trotman's comments came at a press preview of the Chicago Auto Show, which opens on Saturday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances in Europe; Gold Is Higher Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced in Europe yesterday but was mixed in domestic dealings despite waves of concerted central bank intervention that capped a week of government efforts to shore up the currency.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $370.10 an ounce, up $2.30 from Thursday. At the Republic National Bank, gold gained $2.65 an ounce to settle at $369.75. 
 The move to buy dollars, mostly offset by sales of German marks, began when trading opened in Europe and continued when dealing shifted to the United States. Most big European central banks participated and were joined by the Federal Reserve.
"We haven't had concerted, worldwide intervention like this since November 1988, when the dollar was under heavy selling pressure" following the election of George Bush, said James McGroarty, a senior vice president at Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. in Greenwich, Conn.
 
Initiaive by European Banks
 What differentiated yesterday's intervention from other recent moves was that European central banks took the initiative and that the rounds of interventions continued after the dollar moved to higher levels, Mr. McGroarty said.
The Fed as well as some European central banks were active participants in the foreign currency market throughout the week. Yesterday's effort was high in profile, traders said, and succeeded mostly in lifting the dollar from its lows.
With the central banks concentrating on dollar-mark transactions, traders still intent on selling the dollar did so mostly against the yen and the pound, traders said.
The mood surrounding the dollar remains bearish. Traders continue to point to the declining United States economy. In addition, "interest-rate differentials weigh very heavily against the dollar and are keeping it under pressure," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
United States interest rates have been declining as yields on many European fixed-income securities have risen, making European investments more valuable. And when United States securities become less attractive, it reduces investors' need for dollars.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.40 yen, to a closing 128.20 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 127.85 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 127.78 yen, down from 128.52 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9875, from $1.9980 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.9885 to buy 1, less expensive than Thursday's $2.0000.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4556 German marks, up from 1.4553; 1.2435 Swiss francs, down from 1.2437; 4.9595 French francs, up from 4.9535; 1,096.25 Italian lire, up from 1,093.75, and 1.1580 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1587.

HEADLINE: War in Persian Gulf Inspires Some Donors to the Neediest

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
Amid the daily reports of bombings, troop movements and Pentagon news conferences, it has become difficult for many Americans to think about any issue besides the war in the Persian Gulf. But for some people, battles overseas are also a reminder of the problems at home.
A number of recent donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund said that their gifts to the fund were inspired by the war. They feared that the attention paid to the nation's soldiers could mean further neglect of the city's homeless. 
 These expressions of concern about the war's impact on the sick and the poor came from people who opposed the fighting as well as those who favored it.
On one side of the issue was Madeline Walling of Highland Park, N.J., who contributed $10. "I am giving this money now, as I know that with the war, everyone will forget about the problems here," she wrote. "I am well aware that the war in the Gulf is not about Saddam, oil or even money. It's about ignoring the problems here.
"I know this is not much," she said of her gift, "but I don't make much. I am showing that I won't forget."
Another donor, Jay Rosenberg, had an almost opposite view of the war, but shared Ms. Walling's commitment to the needy.
In a letter attached to a gift of $100 written the night before the war began, he wrote, "As our country prepares to go to war and hundreds of thousands of Americans risk their lives for what I truly believe to be a just cause, I search my conscience and know that I must begin to make sacrifices for my country and my fellow citizens."
Proceeds from the Neediest Cases are distributed among seven charities to provide disadvantaged children, the elderly and the unemployed with food, clothing and shelter among other services. The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead, and the drive runs through Feb. 28.
With less than three weeks remaining, the fund has already collected the second highest total in its 79-year history. But it must raise another $267,000 if it is to pass the record set in the previous drive. And several charity officials said yesterday that the recession and the war seem likely to make the next few weeks a difficult time to raise money.
One donor, Christopher B. Steward of Brooklyn, wrote his check for $200 to the fund on the night that the United States began bombing Iraq. He said that he had almost forgotten to contribute but then realized that "with recession looming -- and as of tonight war -- it is more important than ever to remember those who will suffer most."
