HEADLINE: For Banks, Suitors May Be Few

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
What if the Treasury Department threw a party and nobody came? That could be the response to the department's proposal earlier this week to reshape the financial system by making the banking franchise more attractive and by inviting in new participants with a wad of capital.
Although it is unclear whether the Treasury's proposals will win approval in Congress, bankers certainly applaud the department's attempts to help them enter the securities business and to sell insurance where state laws allow that. But when it comes to luring in more capital by allowing commercial and industrial companies to own banks, the Administration may be sorely disappointed with the results if such a development ever comes to pass. 
 Those companies that have already dabbled with offering their customers certain financial services have expressed little interest in owning and operating a full-fledged commercial bank.
 
Two Experiments

The McDonald's Corporation, for instance, has experimented with letting banks put automated teller machines in some restaurants as a convenience to customers, but that program is still in the trial stage, and a McDonald's spokesman said the company had no interest in adding banking as a line of business.
Likewise, the K Mart Corporation allowed several banks to install small branches in some stores, but the synergies between shopping and banking never materialized, and that program has been phased out. "People don't go to a K Mart to take out a loan," said Mary L. Lorencz, a spokesman for the company. "We're not interested in being in the banking business."
The companies that are most likely to take advantage of any eventual liberalization are companies that have one foot in banking already. The American Express Company, for instance, already owns three non-bank banks, which can accept insured deposits or make commercial loans, but not both. It also owns two industrial loan corporations and one international bank. Each of those institutions has to abide by some cumbersome regulatory limitations on the services it can offer and the extent to which it can cross-market its products and services.
"We have to turn ourselves into pretzels to do what we want to do," said Paul A. Seader, the company's assistant general counsel. The American Express Centurion Bank in Delaware, for instance, which provides services to the company's Optima credit card customers, is prohibited by law from allowing its assets to grow more than 7 percent a year.
 
 No Big Commitment Planned
 At some point in the future, Mr. Seader said, the company might try to convert one of its non-bank banks into a commercial bank, or buy a bank to simplify its financial service business. But as for developing a banking franchise that would draw the kind of capital into the industry that the Treasury is hoping for, Mr. Seader said American Express would not be interested. "We really don't have any desires or plans to get into commercial banking," he said.
Some banking specialists predict that few commercial companies will ultimately choose to enter banking. They point to the banking industry's poor profitability and the high cost of doing business. If they are right, the situation will hardly cause havoc, but it leaves open the question of how banking will ever succeed in drawing in new, deep-pocketed participants.
"People can do everything a bank can do and not be a bank. So why put up with all the garbage?" asked George J. Benston, professor of finance, accounting and economics at Emory University in Atlanta. "You can do everything except take insured deposits, and if they keep raising the deposit insurance rates, why would anyone want to do it?"
 
 One Regulator's Concerns
 If new buyers from outside the financial industry do not emerge, that would be just fine with some bank regulators. E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, has been particularly vocal in opposing a blending of banking and commerce.
Shortly before the Treasury issued its proposal, Mr. Corrigan made a speech before a banking group in which he seemed to throw down the gauntlet by challenging many of the arguments that the Treasury subsequently used in its report.
Mr. Corrigan disputed the Treasury's central thesis that banking needs more capital and must attract money from commercial and industrial companies. Capital is the cushion of permanent financing that helps a bank absorb losses. Mr. Corrigan did not deny that some banks need more capital, but he said the system as a whole has enough capital to provide "the finite quantity of good loans which the economy can support."
Mr. Corrigan again expressed his longstanding concern that if the parent company of a bank ran into financial trouble, the bank would be perceived as an integral part of that company and could become vulnerable, too.
Imagine, for instance, that Eastern Airlines, which recently filed for protection under the Chapter 11 bankruptcy laws, owned a bank. Would depositors, fearful about the safety of their deposits, rush to pull their money out? And if the regulators had to intervene, would the deposit insurance fund have to be used to bail Eastern's bank depositors out? And would the Federal Reserve be under pressure to make its financial resources available to the airline's parent company to stabilize the bank?
 
 Some Potential Perils
 "At a time when the public is focusing on the horrendous exposure to the savings and loan industry, and now the banks, do we really want to raise the question of creating exposure to the automobile industry or a company that makes washing machines?" asked Michael Bradfield, a former general counsel of the Federal Reserve who is now a lawyer specializing in banking in the Washington office of the firm of Jones Day Reavis & Pogue.
The Treasury, in its report, said that adequate safeguards could be put in place to prevent insured deposits from being misused and that it was important to be able to draw new capital and management talent into the industry. If commercial companies are not permitted to buy banks, it added, many Wall Street firms, which might be logical bidders, would be precluded from making offers because they are owned by commercial companies. Kidder, Peabody & Company, for instance, is owned by the General Electric Company, and Dean Witter Reynolds is owned by Sears, Roebuck & Company.
Resistance to the blending of banking and commerce has traditionally stemmed from fears that banks could become too powerful if they joined with large industrial companies, causing distortions in the business of making loans. A company that owns a bank could conceivably get loans on overly favorable terms from its captive lender, or loans might be extended to the parent company's best customers, while a competitor of the parent company and its customers might be denied credit.
The Treasury contends that the potential for abuse could be overcome by making sure that no entity other than a bank would be allowed access to deposit insurance or to the Fed's discount window, where banks can borrow from the central bank at favorable interest rates.
In addition, unusually large transfers of money between a bank and its affiliates would have to be reported to the bank's regulator. And if an industrial company was abusing its banking subsidiary by siphoning off money or allowing it to falter, the Treasury proposal would allow bank regulators to restrict dividend payments, force the parent company to raise more capital or even require that the bank be sold.
Banking experts are skeptical that the "firewalls" that the Treasury says can be erected would actually work in a financial crisis. They point to several recent examples in which the problems of troubled brokerage firms spilled over onto their parents, even though they were ostensibly at arm's length. Over the last few yers, companies like American Express, Credit Suisse and General Electric have all felt compelled to inject substantial amounts of money into their ailing brokerage subsidiaries rather than let them founder and risk tarnishing their own image.
Likewise, when Drexel Burnham Lambert's holding company filed for bankruptcy last year, it was unable to prevent its financial problems from overwhelming its brokerage subsidiary, which was supposedly separately capitalized. "Once the holding company went, it was clear that the brokerage could only be kept alive by extraodinary measures," said H. Rodgin Cohen, a banking attorney at the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. "Drexel put the nail in the coffin of the concept of firewalls."

HEADLINE: Yield on 30-Year U.S. Bond Falls Below 8%

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The yield on the benchmark long-term Treasury bond fell below 8 percent yesterday and held steadfastly there for the first time in more than a year as strong retail demand caused a rebound in prices.
Dealers said the demand was not unexpected, given the enthusiastic reception accorded this week's auctions of $34.5 billion of Treasury notes and bonds. 
 But the retail investors -- pension and mutual funds and other institutions -- prudently waited to begin buying until dealers and other successful bidders had taken quick profits after the last of the three auctions ended Thursday. As usual, the sales by profit takers caused prices to weaken.
"The retail buyers seemed to be eager to lock in current yields on the longer Treasury paper, often selling shorter-note maturities to pay for the long-term bonds," said Mark A. McCluskey, chief trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich.
Mr. McCluskey said the buyers were also encouraged by the relatively high level of market liquidity "for a no-news Friday."
"The market's basic view," he said, "is that it does not expect the economy to show any signs of revival that would cause interest rates to rebound soon."
In the stock market, bullishness returned after Thursday's downturn. The Dow Jones industrial average closed yesterday with a gain of 20.05 points, to 2,830.69, ending a week of near-record trading volume. For the week, the Dow was up 100 points, or 3.7 percent. [Page 32.]
Eugene J. Sherman, senior vice president and chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, said the credit market's quick selloff on Thursday after the auction of the 30-year bond "may also have been prompted by fears that Japanese and other successful foreign bidders would be first to unload their acquisitions largely because of the continued weakness of the dollar."
"We believe the refunding was a success despite the dollar's weakness," he added, "simply because there wasn't as much foreign participation as many were led to believe. We think it was a largely domestic affair and domestic institutions do not have many promising alternative investments today."
While the yield on the Treasury's new 30-year bond slipped slightly below the pychologically important level of 8 percent shortly after the issue was auctioned Thursday, it was not until the yield on the outstanding 30-year bond slipped below 8 percent that the trend was confirmed.
The bellwether old 30-year bonds, the 8.75 percent issue due August 2020, were offered late in the session yesterday at 108 22/32, up 29/32. This caused the yield to plunge to 7.98 percent, its lowest since late December 1989. The yield was down from 8.05 percent the day before and 8.08 percent a week ago.
The yield on the new 7 7/8 percent long bonds of February 2021, which were auctioned Thursday, slipped to 7.95 percent in trading on a when-issued basis, down from 7.98 percent the day before. Also in when-issued trading, the yield on the new 7.75 percent 10-year notes auctioned Wednesday dropped to 7.76 percent, from 7.83 the day before, and that on the new 6 7/8 percent three-year notes auctioned Tuesday dipped to 6.96 percent, from 7 percent the previous day.
Some investors were also encouraged by the Federal Reserve's move to keep the interbank lending rate from moving above the 6.25 percent level that is now considered to be the central bank's target. The Fed added $2.5 billion of reserves to the banking system at midday when the funds rate was at 6 5/16 percent. The funds subsequently traded down to 5.75 percent at yesterday's close.
But the discount rates on Treasury bills, normally most sensitive to any changes in the funds rate, barely moved. The rate on 90-day bills fell 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.92 percent; the six-month bills were unchanged at 5.89 percent, and the one-year bills lost 2 basis points, to 5.86 percent. The recent decline in bill rates, to their lowest level in almost three years, reflects the eagerness of investors to lock in current yields in the expectation that yields will decline further with the economy.
The Treasury announced that it planned to auction $11.75 billion of new one-year bills on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Big Price Rises for Farm Products Called Unlikely

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
For the most part, American consumers will probably not see drastic price increases, reduced supplies or inferior quality in California fruits and vegetables in spite of the drought and state and Federal water cutbacks to agriculture, farming experts and growers' representatives say.
If one farmer cuts back on a crop for lack of water deliveries, another with abundant ground water is likely to increase planting of that crop, said Mike Henry, a spokesman for the California Farm Bureau Federation in Sacramento. "The diversity of California agriculture has saved the consumer in the past four years and may save us again," he said of the long drought. But the prices of some crops may be much more volatile because of periodic shortages. 
 Even a severe cutback in production of some crops will probably not cause large price increases. In some cases, like California almonds, a large carry-over of the 1990 crop will insure an adequate supply. In others, like canned fruits and vegetables, the cost of the crop itself is a relatively small part of the shelf price.
 
 Smaller Tomatoes
 Growers of tomatoes for canning anticipate a million-ton drop in production from last year, to about 8.2 million tons, "but that alone will not have a dramatic impact on price," said David Zollinger, executive vice president of the California Tomato Growers Association in Stockton. While quality will also not be affected, "the size of individual tomotoes will be smaller, and that in turn will impact the tonnage," he said.
In some crops, California farmers' losses will be made up by other states. California acreage planted to cotton, a particularly thirsty crop, will be cut by several hundred thousand acres, but because the drought struck before the planting season, the shortfall will be made up in other states, said Kevin McDermott, vice president for economics research for Calcot Ltd., a cotton marketing cooperative based in Bakersfield. "You'll see acreage in Texas and Mississippi expand 16 to 20 percent," he said.
For many fruits and vegetables, it may be too early to gauge crop size and prices. Fruit trees will not begin blossoming until later in the spring. Paradoxically, late rains, as occurred last year, could knock off blossoms and reduce crops of apples, pears and grapes. Growers say prices for some of these products could soar if crops are unusually short.
 
 Frost Lifted Citrus Prices
 Citrus fruit prices have already taken a big jump, because the crop suffered heavy damage from record frosts in December. Prices for California oranges have doubled from the typical season prices of 59 to 79 cents a pound, to $1.39, and have prompted the usual corresponding rise in apple and banana prices even though those fruits are in abundant supply. Prices of these fruits tend to rise and fall together because consumers view them as alternatives to one another.
Without adequate water, many frost-weakened trees will die, said Curt Anderson, a spokesman for Sunkist Growers in Sherman Oaks. "As one grower said to me, 'The freeze may look like a Sunday school picnic compared to the drought,' " he said.
The wine industry, already reeling from steep increases in Federal excise taxes, could see grape prices rise as well. This would have the most extreme impact on producers of inexpensive jug wines, which use grapes from the heavily irrigated Central Valley. Vines in premium wine-growing areas, like Napa and Sonoma counties, tend to have deeper roots and require less irrigation.
With record vintages in 1989 and 1990, wine-grape prices have drifted down from 1988 highs, "but any contraction on the supply side has a greater effect on the price side," said George M. Schofield, a winery consultant based in St. Helena. Drought years are often thought to be good-quality vintages, but that is not always the case. Wines from the drought year of 1976 "are really intense, but some people don't like the concentration," Mr. Schofield said.
This year, California farms, which consume about 80 percent of the state's water, will have about half the normal supplies, with the water coming from local and Federal reservoirs and from ground water. The California State Water Project has said it will deliver no water for agriculture, but it supplies only about 10 percent of irrigation water in a normal year. The Federal Central Valley Project is expected to deliver from one-third to one-half of the normal supply.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Jordan

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times; ANGER AND DISMAY OVER U.S. ACTIONS

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Isolated in the Middle East and vulnerable to potentially fierce pressures from the war in the Persian Gulf, many Jordanians reacted sharply today to White House criticism of King Hussein's alignment with Iraq and to Washington's earlier decision to review economic aid.
The Bush Administration's moves, diplomats said, will almost certainly deepen the widespread anti-American sentiment that puts pressure on the Jordanian King to shelter his government with the public embrace of Arab nationalist and anti-Western principles. 
 "I think we've been subjected to strangulation," said Abdul-Karim Kabariti, a legislator and former Government minister. "If relations are said to be chilling, then it's fair to say they are heading toward the freezing point."
The decision to review aid, $85.6 million last year, coincided with other American moves that Jordanians considered hostile. Even those Jordanians with long affection for the United States say they are bewildered by what they interpret as a deliberate campaign to destabilize their country, which is wedged between Iraq and Israel.
 
Americans Are Urged to Leave
 Last week, at the same time the State Department criticized Jordan's continued importing of crude oil from Iraq, Jordanians were becoming incensed by allied air strikes against the main highway in western Iraq, attacks that killed nine Jordanian tanker-truck drivers.
The United States also reduced its diplomatic representation here, ordering some diplomats home, and urged Americans to leave Jordan as soon as possible. The decision was interpreted by some Jordanian officials as a show of no-confidence in the King's ability to protect foreigners in a country seething with pro-Iraqi fervor and anti-American anger.
"Why are they doing this to us," said a Jordanian businessman here who refused to give his name. His comment reflected a widespread sense of aggrievement that the United States, once admired by many educated Jordanians, was willfully misinterpreting the King.
 
Analyzing a Speech
 Senior Jordanian officials sought to play down the impact of the latest American move. Like some Arab and Western diplomats, they argued that a speech by the King two days ago, in which he called the allied war effort unjust and aligned himself politically with Iraq, was directed specifically at an Arab audience.
Finance Minister Basil Jardaneh echoed other Cabinet officials, who have said that, for Westerners, the twin messages of the King's speech were his affirmation that Jordan was not a party to the military conflict and his renewed call for dialogue to end the fighting before it further escalation.
"The King's remarks were intended for Jordan," a high official said. "But unfortunately they were received in the United States."
Two incidents today highlighted some of the threats facing the King from a Jordanian population that is more than one half Palestinian and easily ignited by displays of perceived American hostility.
In the northern town of Ramtha, police fired tear gas and arrested four people who were involved in a rare clash with the authorities. Police officials said protesters poured from a mosque after noon prayers on the Islamic holy day and smashed cars and burned tires as they chanted anti-American and pro-Iraqi slogans.
The authorities have generally sought to coax protesters into peaceful demonstrations, and the King is thought to hope that his recent political liberalization, including a freeing of Parliament and the press, offers a safety valve for the passions of his people. But, diplomats said, further violent protests like today's could erode the King's popularity if it seemed that his security forces were suppressing pro-Iraq sentiment.
In the second incident, in the south, three people infiltrated into Israel early today and were shot to death after a firefight with Israeli soldiers. An Israeli official called the mission "suicidal."
 
Lessons From the '67 War
 While the two incidents were apparently unrelated, they again served notice on the King of the volatility of his population.
"The King has not forgotten the 1970's, when the Palestinians rose against him," an Arab diplomat said.
For this reason, Western European diplomats said, the King has ordered his security services to try to curtail unlawful armed militias.
But as today's incursion into Israel showed, Jordan's long border with Israel cannot easily be sealed by either side and neither can all privately held weapons be traced, leaving the King vulnerable to the impact of incursions that are designed to provoke an Israeli response.
Also in the King's memories is the 1967 Middle East war, when Israeli forces drove Jordan's far smaller and less-equipped army out of the West Bank. Many Jordanians acknowledge that a new military conflict with Israel would hold no greater chance of victory than 24 years ago.
"The King has made clear he does not want military involvement," said a Western diplomat, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "He has said the same to both Iraq and Israel."
Zeid Bin Shaker, the head of the Royal Court, today denied a news agency report in which unidentified officials were quoted as saying the King was so angry with the United States that he was "carefully studying" the likely impact of severing diplomatic relations, despite decades of close ties with Washington. The report, Mr. Ben Shaker said, was "part of a disinformation campaign against Jordan."

HEADLINE: Cracks in California's Economy

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The Gaylord Container Corporation is shutting two-thirds of its paper mill in Antioch, Calif., dismissing 330 of the 525 employees. The mill is no longer economically competitive, in part because of California's dire water shortage.
"You cannot produce paper without water," said Walt E. Murray, a manager at the plant across the bay from San Francisco. "Water itself is one of the highest-cost raw-material items. You go to the East Coast and that's not the case." 
 The price Gaylord pays for its water is about to go up by a factor of seven, said Mr. Murray, who is also president of a local business group. And the river water that normally supplies part of the company's needs has become too salty to use, since saltwater from San Francisco Bay is moving upstream as the river's flow dwindles.
 
Adding to Economic Pain
 After five years of drought, the Golden State has turned brown, and it is sending shivers though an economy that has been a star in the national picture for the last decade.
The drought's biggest and most immediate impact is, of course, on the state's vast farmlands. The state's water project cut off supplies to farmers this week, forcing some to abandon crops for the year and threatening some with loss of their farms.
But California is also one of the largest producers of wood, oil, gold, computers and computer chips. And from the northern forests to the southern oilfields, in Silicon Valley and Napa Valley, the drought is starting to add to the economic pain caused by war and recession. Some small businesses, including landscapers and swimming-pool builders, are also suffering.
Several economists estimate that agricultural losses alone will be about $1 billion of the state's $18 billion farm output. Those losses will in turn lead to losses for food processors and other segments linked to farms.
The result could be an overall loss of $3 billion for the state's economy, said Tapan Munroe, chief economist for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.
To be sure, that is a tiny fraction of the state's $700 billion economy and is almost unnoticeable on a national scale. Compared with the real estate slump and military spending cuts, the drought is "not a prevalent factor in the outlook," said David Hensley, acting director of the business forecasting project at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Still, the drought, which began in 1986, could slow the state's growth. Some businesses will suffer lost production and customers, and virtually all companies will have to take steps to save water. Businessmen here have one eye on the sky, hoping for rain, and the other on Sacramento, where state officials are devising possibly Draconian water-use restrictions to be announced this month.
Ski resorts in the Sierra Nevada, in eastern California, and businesses near lakes have been badly hurt. Some executives fear that tourists may stay away this summer, envisioning a Yosemite National Park with dried-up waterfalls and trees ready to ignite. Tourism was already expected to be down because of the fear of flying induced by the Persian Gulf war.
 
Trees Are Dying
 The forest-products industry, suffering from the housing slump, is now seeing its future source of income -- trees -- dying in droves.
"We've probably had about a tenfold increase in the amount of trees that have been dying," said Bill Snyder, chief forester of the Fibreboard Corporation, who added that drought-weakened trees could not fight off beetle infestations. And the trees that survive are growing only about half as fast as they normally would.
The damage is most extensive in the eastern part of the state; the coastal redwood areas have fared better. Other companies with large timber holdings in California include the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, the Pacific Lumber Company and the Simpson Paper Company.
Brian Barrette, chief of forest management for the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection, said trees worth 9 billion board feet might die of drought-related causes this year. That is more than twice the amount normally harvested from California forests in a year. Looked at another way, it is enough for all the houses in several San Franciscos. Some of the dead trees, but not all, can be salvaged and used.
 
Thirsty Mining Process
 In California's gold country in the Sierra foothills, a new mining process has made it feasible to reopen mines that had been closed since the days of the forty-niners. But the process requires a lot of water.
The Sonora Mining Corporation's mine in Jamestown, which uses 3,000 gallons a minute, should have no problems if it rains again this winter, but may have to reduce production if there is no rainfall. "The bottom line is no rain, no mine," said Stephen M. Hair, a company spokesman.
Wine producers in the Napa and Sonoma valleys will almost certainly see reduced grape harvests. Getting water for tank-cleaning and other steps in the production process could also be more difficult.
At the Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma, the reservoirs used for vineyard irrigation have dried up. And last fall, in the thick of the harvest, the output of the well that provides water for the wine-making process suddenly dropped sharply. The winery ordered an emergency delivery by truck and began a crash conservation program that has cut use by 45 percent, said Jill Davis, vice president of production and wine making.
 
Huge Use by Industry
 Refineries use huge amounts of water for cooling and for generating steam for heat and power. Computer chip companies wash silicon wafers over and over in the process of etching circuits on them. Executives at such companies say they expect to get by for now.
"We would find a way to meet it; I don't see us cutting production," said Pat Avery, manager of environmental, health and safety at an ARCO refinery outside Los Angeles.
About half of the 12 million gallons a day the refinery uses comes from the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, which is now talking about cuts of 30 percent. If that happens, ARCO will rely more on well water, Mr. Avery said. If the wells run dry, the company will treat and re-use its water even more extensively than it now does, he said.
Many companies said they had already taken steps to conserve and now have less room to maneuver.
"We've done the big-ticket items, and now it's going to be substantially more painful," said Ken Knutsen, a vice president of the National Semiconductor Corporation. The Silicon Valley chip maker, which uses a million gallons a day, has cut consumption by a third since 1987.
The Santa Clara Valley Water District, which supplies Silicon Valley, has already required customers to cut their use by 20 to 25 percent, and is looking for an additional 10 percent cut. "We're pretty devastated," said Teddy Morse, a spokeswoman for the water district. "We're out there looking for water wherever we can find it."
 
 Less Water, More Pollution

The drought hurts companies in subtle ways as well. Electric power bills rise because utilities substitute expensive oil and gas for cheaper hydroelectric power. Re-using water can increase the concentration of pollutants in waste water, making it harder for companies to meet environmental requirements. National Semiconductor is being simultaneously praised by its city water department for conservation efforts and warned by the sewer department to make its waste water cleaner.
A big question is whether the drought will slow the state's formerly robust growth. The water shortage could be one more reason for people and companies to leave California or to stay away, along with high housing costs, smog and traffic jams.
But some doubt that will be the case. "I liken it a little to the earthquake," said Leslie Appleton-Young, vice president of research and economics for the California Association of Realtors. "You don't see an exodus out of the state because of the earthquake."
In a survey of more than 800 executives conducted for the California Business Roundtable, 14 percent said they did plan to move some or all of their operations out of the state. But they cited housing costs, taxes and other problems far more than the drought. And even as some companies leave, others are lured by California's huge markets, the climate and the state's ringside seat on the booming Pacific Rim.
The drought could slow growth, however, by prompting communities to ban new construction or water hookups. For home builders, who were already expecting 1991 California housing starts to be less than half the 1986 level, that prospect is "very, very frightening," said Ira Norris, president of Inco Homes in Upland, Calif. He said builders were organizing efforts to head off such measures.
 
 Businesses Join Water Planning
 Indeed, business groups, which once left water issues to the water authorities, are suddenly becoming more involved. A new group called Californians for Water has been formed, in part to put the influence of the business community behind the push for more water projects.
Businesses also want to take part as cities develop rationing plans, in part to make sure they are given credit for conservation steps they previously took.
Business and industry use only about 5 percent of the state's water, while residences use 11 percent and farms about 80 percent. Still, companies that use a lot of water could come under pressure to bear a big share of the looming cuts. They will likely respond by saying cuts will mean lost jobs, not just brown lawns.
"We really have very little discretionary use of water in a refinery," said Mr. Avery of ARCO. "We really don't wash cars or take showers or water the lawn."
Businesses linked to such discretionary uses, like landscapers and swimming-pool builders, are among those hurt most by the drought.
Instead of making gardens, builders will be "putting down black plastic and gravel on top," said Olof Soderback, a landscaper in Marin County. Water authorities in the trend-setting county across the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco voted on Wednesday to limit each resident to 50 gallons a day, less than half what is normally used. That might discourage the use of hot tubs, for which the county is famous.
But hot tub vendors are repositioning their products as water savers. Said Len Woodall, a salesman at Creative Energy, a Marin County dealer, "If you own a spa, all of a sudden you won't take a bath anymore."

HEADLINE: Discount Rate Cut Was Urged at Meeting

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Most Federal Reserve banks, noting "appreciable weakening in economic activity," urged a half-point reduction in the discount rate at the December meeting of the Fed's policy makers, according to minutes released today.
Immediately after the Dec. 18 meeting, the central bank's board of governors voted 6 to 0 to lower the key bank lending rate from 7.0 percent to 6 1/2 percent, a move intended to lower interest rates generally and help pull the economy out of a recession. 
 The discount rate represents the interest the Fed charges on loans to banks and other financial institutions. A decrease often results in less-expensive costs for other short-term loans, like adjustable-rate mortgages and car loans.
 
Vote on Increasing Reserves

At the same meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, members voted 11 to 0 to increase reserves and permit the Federal funds rate to fall as developments dictated. The funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, dropped from 7.25 percent to 7.0 percent the next day.
Since then, the Fed pushed the discount rate down another one-half percentage point on Feb. 1, to 6 percent, while at the same time it permitted the funds rate to drop to a target of 6.25 percent.
"The information reviewed at this meeting suggested that economic activity had fallen appreciably in recent months," according to the minutes that noted declining consumer and business activity and growing unemployment.
"Members commented that a relatively mild and short recession remained a reasonable expectation, but they emphasized the risks of a more severe and prolonged contraction in economic activity," the minutes said.
 
 Inflation Status

At the same time, inflation -- which had prompted the Fed to keep interest rates relatively high for two years -- appeared to be moderating.
"Members saw growing indications that a disinflationary process might be getting under way, and some viewed recent price and wage developments as consistent with an outlook for faster progress in reducing inflation than they had anticipated some months ago," the minutes said.
The Federal Open Market Committee, which gathers eight times a year, met again last Tuesday, and many analysts believe it agreed to continue pushing interest rates lower in March. The committee is the central bank's arm for setting monetary policy. Composed of the seven board members and five of the 12 presidents of the Fed's regional banks, it controls the funds rate. There is currently one vacancy on the board itself, which controls the discount rate.

HEADLINE: $1.50 Worth of Help for $200, but No credit

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Some consumers responding to recent direct-mail and telephone promotions for "low interest" credit cards are getting big bills instead of cards.
Some have paid as much as $200, only to get a list of banks that offer credit cards with low interest rates. Others have received applications for secured credit cards, which require the applicant to put up cash or collateral equal to a card's credit line. 
 Some banks make legitimate offers by mail or telephone for low-interest credit. But many recent offers are coming not from banks but from marketing companies that cannot issue credit cards. The abuses are so common that officials in Colorado and Oregon have brought charges of fraud against companies that claim to offer low-interest credit cards.
In a report on a recent survey, Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer-advocacy group in Herndon, Va., said it found dozens of companies using misleading marketing schemes aimed at people who want low-interest credit cards. In many promotions, a consumer receives a postcard saying that he or she can receive a major credit card with interest as low as 11.88 percent simply by calling a toll-free number, said Mary Beth Butler, the group's program associate. Many banks now charge interest rates of 16.8 percent or more on credit cards.
 
Getting a Pitch, Not a Card
 Ms. Butler said people who respond to the promotions are not offered a card but are urged instead to buy information that will supposedly help them get a credit card. That information, which can cost $98 to $200, typically comes in the form of a list of banks offering low-interest credit cards or a booklet of general financial advice, she said.
The same information is available for a lot less. A list of banks offering low-interest credit cards can be got for $1.50 from Bankcard Holders of America, 560 Herndon Parkway, Suite 120, Herndon, Va. 22070. Cardtrak, a monthly newsletter published by Ram Research , P.O. Box 17, Frederick, Md. 21702, also provides information on banks offering cards with low rates. The newsletter is $5 a copy.
Robert McKinley, the publisher of Cardtrak, said some unscrupulous marketers are also using 900 numbers to promote low-interest credit-card offers. A person who calls the number may be charged a flat fee as high as $50, Mr. McKinley said.
People responding to such offers do get credit cards, he added, but sometimes the cards can be used only to charge merchandise in a mail-order catalogue. Some people also receive applications for secured credit cards. Along with requiring collateral, some secured credit cards carry high fees. "They can be very expensive," Mr. McKinley said.
 
'Deal Directly With Banks'

 
 Steven Apesos, a spokesman for Mastercard International , said consumers should be leery of any solicitation that suggests that low-rate cards are easy to get. Usually, only people with the best credit records qualify for such cards.
<> <> "The most important advice we have is to deal directly with banks and avoid unscrupulous marketers," Mr. Apesos said.
Dennis Fiene, the director of security for Visa International , said his company had tried to stop marketers who illegally use its emblem in promotions. "Using our logo gives these promotions an air of legitimacy," he said.
The attorneys general of Oregon and Colorado recently filed fraud actions seeking to close two credit-card marketing companies. But the problem is not easy to solve. In many cases, an unscrupulous marketer will set up his operation outside the state where the consumers being solicited live. That makes it harder for state officials to act on consumer complaints.
Mr. Fiene of Visa said several Federal agencies, including the Postal Service and the Federal Trade Commission, are looking into the problem. "I don't know of a single consumer that has received a credit card through these kinds of promotions," he said.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Lincoln, Revolution And Civil Liberties

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
Abraham Lincoln and the Second American Revolution
By James M. McPherson
173 pages. Oxford University Press. $17.95.
 
The Fate of Liberty
Abraham Lincoln and Civil Liberties
By Mark E. Neely Jr.
278 pages. Oxford University Press. $24.95.
In Prof. James M. McPherson's informative and intelligent book of essays, "Abraham Lincoln and the Second American Revolution," the Princeton history professor raises a tantalizing question: 
 Was Lincoln a conservative or a revolutionary?
Professor McPherson, author of "Battle Cry of Freedom," the strongest one-volume history of the Civil War, concludes that Lincoln was a conservative revolutionary. In this respect, he disputes those scholars who contend that the 16th President was made by events and did not have any real philosophy of his own in the White House.
"Not an ideological revolutionary, to be sure -- Lincoln was no Robespierre or Lenin with a blueprint for a new order -- but he was a pragmatic revolutionary who found it necessary to destroy slavery and create a new birth of freedom in order to preserve the Union," Professor McPherson writes.
To support his position, the author emphasizes a neglected area of study: the relationship of Lincoln and Congress. Before Lincoln became President, the Southern-dominated Democratic Party that controlled the Federal Government had repeatedly defeated efforts to foster economic development through tariffs, to regulate the banking system, to subsidize land grants and to support education. During Lincoln's Presidency, Republicans passed all these measures: a higher tariff, a homestead act, a land-grant college act, an act for a transcontinental railroad, a national banking act, a progressive income tax.
Giving Lincoln a strong share of the credit for the resulting changes, Professor McPherson says: "This astonishing blitz of laws, most of them passed within the span of less than one year, did more to reshape the relation of the government to the economy than any comparable effort except perhaps the first hundred days of the New Deal."
The essays in "The Second American Revolution" occasionally ramble and repeat, but they are straightforward and well written. By no means does the book attempt to cover the whole Lincoln story. For example, the importance of Lincoln's legal background to his thinking on the Constitution is barely mentioned. Readers interested in this subject can turn to "Lincoln as a Lawyer," by John P. Frank, a classic work that has just been reissued (Americana House, Chicago); and the current Lincoln Legals project in Springfield, Ill., is finding dozens of new State Supreme Court cases in which Lincoln was involved.
One of the fascinating essays in Professor McPherson's book is called, with only slight exaggeration, "How Lincoln Won the War with Metaphors." How was Lincoln, with practically no formal education, able to speak and write so well?
Professor McPherson explains that because Lincoln worked on the frontier, he grew up close to the rhythms of nature. This primitive life infused his speech with living images. When he turned to books, his favorites were the King James Bible, Aesop's Fables, Pilgrim's Progress and Shakespeare's plays. All of these sources, the author notes, are rich in figurative language, which Lincoln used to communicate the justice of the Union cause to the people.
In "The Fate of Liberty," by Mark E. Neely Jr., Lincoln's controversial stand on civil liberties is thoroughly examined. Mr. Neely, director of the Lincoln Museum in Fort Wayne, Ind., and author of "The Abraham Lincoln Encyclopedia," has written a fair-minded book that provides fresh details about the writ of habeas corpus and its suspension during the war. He emphasizes that Lincoln had a war on his hands almost from the moment he became President until his death. What we might call fifth columnists operated inside the Union.
"The great writ remained a symbol of individual freedom and many knowledgeable Americans in 1861 believed that its suspension would have dire and lasting effects," Mr. Neely says. "That feeling would nag the consciences of some Republicans. And it would intensify the sincere anxieties as well as inflate the partisan rhetoric of many Democrats. But military arrests of civilians never provoked widespread disobedience of the law or violent protests. Only military conscription could do that."
As President-elect, Lincoln faced the immediate secession of several states from the Union he was supposed to govern. Legal and political considerations were carefully balanced. For instance, when Maryland threatened to secede, Lincoln ordered his generals not to suspend the writ unless Marylanders took up arms. His judgment was vindicated when the Maryland legislature, though dominated by Democrats, refused to consider a secession ordinance.
Mr. Neely's book draws a distinction between arrests made in the Border States, the North and the South. He says that suspending the writ was a political liability and was always regarded that way by the Lincoln Administration. But most military arrests of civilians did not involve torture or prejudice against any ethnic group.
The author estimates that there were at least 10,000 arrests during the war. His book is based on information in a thousand arrest records in the National Archives. It is always wise for historians to go to the original sources instead of citing one anothers' books as documentation. That is what makes "The Fate of Liberty" a valuable addition to the Civil War bookshelf.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Budget Stand

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
By musing on the merits of stretching out New York City's current budget problems over several years, Mayor David N. Dinkins spoke words this week that no New York mayor had dared utter since a city humbled by its brush with bankruptcy was forced to submit to the credo of pay-as-you-go.
Mr. Dinkins and his senior aides repeated yesterday that they intend to balance the budget for the coming fiscal year as required by law, on time and as usual -- with spending cuts and tax increases -- despite a projected shortfall of more than $2 billion in their $29 billion budget. 
 That Mr. Dinkins reflected publicly even in a glancing way on an idea to borrow large sums to fill the immediate gap raised concern among fiscal monitors and is part of a strange and complex drama that touches on everything from Presidential politics to racial sensibilities to the reluctance of a powerful person, Felix G. Rohatyn, to recede from influence.
 
Law, Finance and Politics
 But most of all it reflects the depth of the concern over the city's finances. Some of the Mayor's senior advisers acknowledge that they have discussed the possibility that the city's problems could grow so deep as to require measures beyond cuts and taxes, including steps that raise a range of complicated legal, financial and political questions. Looking for special ways to bring the budget into balance over several years, they say, is not an idea that they are pursuing, but it is one that they cannot rule out.
At the core of the idea is this: the city could seek to reduce its operating deficit by an infusion of funds borrowed by the Municipal Assistance Corportation, which was created by the state to get the city out of its last fiscal crisis. Such assistance could spare the Dinkins administration from additional tax increases or severe cuts in services otherwise needed to keep the budget in balance as required by law.
 But that solution is not as easy as it sounds. Since the law requires a balanced budget, any arrangement that could be seen as paying current bills through borrowing could risk rejection by the Financial Control Board, the state body that has watched over the city's fiscal health since it recovered from the 1975 crisis.
The Mayor's comments on Thursday, in their very equivocation, reflected some of the tension now at work in the political world of New York City finances. There are those who hold city debtfor whom a long-term bailout plan could be anathema, while there are those who receive city services for whom it might be preferable to sharp budget cuts.
 
Rohatyn Broke the Spell
 "I do know that the attitude of many of the monitors, certainly the bond-rating people, is that deferment of debt is frowned upon," Mr. Dinkins said in an interview on Thursday, "although there's much to be said for the notion that for a government, state or city, it is very difficult to take horrendous cuts and handle it in a short period of time, as opposed to stretching it out."
Mr. Dinkins was responding to questions about statements by Mr. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, who first broke the spell on this sensitive subject on Wednesday. Since Mr. Rohatyn was an architect of the very fiscal restrictions under which the city has operated since 1975, his remarks caused a particular stir.
Aides to Mr. Dinkins at first flatly dismissed Mr. Rohatyn's suggestion that the assistance corporation could raise hundreds of millions of dollars through bonds to help the city spread its fiscal pain over a more manageable length of time.
But later, some officials acknowledges, as one senior aide speaking on condition of anonymity said yesterday, "You don't have to be a genius to see that that's a possibility."
 
Like Heresy by the Pope
 Mr. Rohatyn suggested that if the city's economy continued to worsen, the assistance corporation might refinance bonds to stretch out the payment of current interest over many years, even if that meant postponing debt.
Some fiscal monitors said Mr. Rohatyn's suggestion was the equivalent of heresy by the Pope. Others were quick to note that Mr. Rohatyn is a close adviser to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and that his idea could help Mr. Cuomo, who is facing enormous fiscal problems of his own.
A bailout by the assistance corporation could let the Governor avoid hurting the city with cuts in state aid that he has proposed to balance his budget, could ease the state's problems by allowing it to stretch out aid payments and could smooth potential problems for Mr. Cuomo that could arise just when he might be a Presidential contender in 1992.
Mr. Cuomo has special influence over the city's finances as chairman of the Financial Control Board, which was established to run the city's fiscal affairs in the mid-1970's. It now has only advisory powers but could reassert binding ones should the city fail to balance its budget or to sell bonds -- a situation that could be politically damaging to Mr. Cuomo if he were seen as usurping the powers of the city's first black mayor, and to Mr. Dinkins, if he lost stewardship of the citys's finances.
 
'Violates the Spirit'
 Mr. Rohatyn said his suggestion would not require the Control Board to reimpose its powers or require changes in law. But others were not so sure.
"If it doesn't violate the letter of the law, it violates the spirit," said Alair A. Townsend, a former city budget director and deputy mayor who is now publisher of Crain's New York Business.
Mr. Rohatyn, stung by Mr. Dinkins's rejection of his warnings to freeze labor costs and by union leaders' attacks on him, said last fall that he would step down as chairman of the assistance corporation but changed his mind after Mr. Cuomo asked him to stay.
Now the city is reacting warily to the golden apple that Mr. Rohatyn is dangling, though Mr. Rohatyn said he would not favor any proposal that jeopardized bond ratings. And bond rating agencies have warned the city that its credit rating -- which it has been struggling to maintain -- would be jeopardized by such moves, though Mr. Rohatyn said he would not favor any proposal that jeopardized bond ratings.
 
Politically Tempting
 "What they're doing is counterproductive, and it doesn't square with our rating," said Hyman Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's. "Which means if they do anytning like what has been discussed, they won't have our rating."
Still, Mr. Rohatyn's idea is politically tempting for the city.
But First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the city was, at least for the moment, resisting the temptation. "We understand the arguments on both sides of the equation, and why it looks like it might be helpful but why it creates enormous problems," he said. "But our position is that we're not exploring that option. We intend to balance our budget in one year."
Mr. Rohatyn now says the fiscal critics have misinterpreted his remarks; that he never intended to imply that the city should modify the accounting rules or budgeting laws adopted during the fiscal crisis, only that it might need to consider extraordinary measures.
"I thought we had inflated a spare tire, and all of a sudden I saw that we'd fired a Scud missile," he said yesterday. "If it's sinful to consider these things, then I've sinned."

HEADLINE: Bank Lending Still Tight Despite Easing by the Fed

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board's latest readings on whether banks are lending show that despite aggressive easing by the central bank recently, they continued to tighten lending standards this winter.
As a result, the nation's money supply barely edged up in January. 
 The Federal Reserve is focusing on two measures of credit availability -- both highly imperfect -- to quantify the problem: a quarterly survey of senior lending officers at several dozen leading commercial banks and a monthly measure of the money supply, or M-2, which includes money market accounts as well as checking accounts and cash.
Some bankers were not surprised by the survey. "The credit crunch wasn't started by high interest rates, so why should we expect lower rates to stop it?" asked S. Waite Rawls 3d, vice chairman of the Continental Bank Corporation.
But Federal Reserve officials, bankers and economists say they are confident that traditional monetary medicine -- along with a tilt toward forebearance by bank regulators -- will encourage bankers to increase lending, and thus prevent a deeper recession. Citing the recent rebound in bank stocks, a Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said, "There's some feeling on the part of the market that the worst of the bank problems are over."
"Will it work?" asked John B. McCoy, chairman of the BancOne Corporation. "Oh yeah. We've had positive loan growth in January. The spreads in our business continue to widen. That helps earnings. Lower rates increase the number of good transactions out there."
The loan officers' survey, which last month polled 60 senior loan officers at both United States commercial banks and branches of foreign banks with United States branches, showed that banks tightened business lending standards and terms over the last three months.
"To put it into perspective, the amount by which spreads were raised was pretty minimal, at least in the Ninth District," said Herbert L. Baer, a senior economist at the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank. The spreads Mr. Baer referred to are the difference between what a bank charges prime customers and less creditworthy borrowers. The survey asked loan officers about their activities in the last three months.
Significantly, banks clamped down more on their biggest borrowers. Nearly half of United States banks reduced borrowing limits for those customers. That compares with 7 percent that reported doing so for small-business borrowers.
Nearly 60 percent of banks raised loan spreads for large companies. But just 40 percent of banks surveyed did so for their smaller customers.
"That goes 180 degrees against the popular version," Mr. Baer said. He pointed out that banks have been under pressure to diversify their loan portfolios. Pushing a big borrower out the door is a convenient way to do that, he said.
 
 Flat Money Supply
 The Federal Reserve's separate weekly money supply report, which was released on Thursday, shows that the amount of money circulating in the economy grew at less than a 1 percent annual rate from December to January. Stephen H. Axilrod, vice chairman of Nikko Securities Inc. in New York, said, "Flat M-2 could indicate either that people aren't eager to put their money into the banking system" because they lack confidence in it, "or that the Fed hasn't pushed enough reserves into the system."
But that does not mean that the Fed's latest move to lower the discount rate a week ago has been ineffective, said James S. Duesenberry, a monetary economist at Harvard University. "It's only six weeks since the Fed really began to change its monetary policy," he said. "It will take a few months for monetary growth to pick up. Expecting to see a big change today is like expecting to win the war with Iraq after one night's bombing."

HEADLINE: Bush's Energy Plan Emphasizes Gains in Output Over Efficiency

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The White House has drafted a national energy policy that would encourage the growth of the domestic oil industry and remove obstacles to the construction of nuclear power plants. But the plan calls for only a modest effort to encourage energy efficiency.
The plan, which is taking final form as war in the oil-rich Persian Gulf has focused new attention on long-term energy supply problems, is intended to make the nation less dependent on foreign sources. Through deregulation and tax breaks, it would encourage the oil, gas and coal industries to begin aggressive programs for increasing the domestic output of fossil fuels in the United States. The Office of Management and Budget circulated a draft of the legislation embodying the policy to Federal departments and agencies this week. 
 The proposals include few programs aimed at substantially reducing the consumption of energy. Conservation groups have called for such actions by the Government, but none of the proposals would encourage motorists to reduce their use of gasoline, the largest single use for oil in the United States.
Copies of the draft were made available to several news organizations today. White House officials said that the draft was receiving a last review from the Energy Department and other agencies and that when those had been incorporated it would be given to President Bush for his signature. James D. Watkins, the Energy Secretary, is scheduled to testify before the Senate Energy Committee and Natural Resources Committee on Feb. 19, and Senator Timothy Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, said Mr. Watkins would present the plan then.
The draft of a letter accompanying the plan, from Mr. Watkins to Representative Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, described the policy's purpose. "To secure future energy supplies, we must consider fossil fuels, nuclear power, renewable energy, fusion energy and enhanced R.&D.," the letter said. "As events in the Persian Gulf have demonstrated so aptly, we must reduce our dependence on imported oil from unstable regions. This will require both reducing our overall dependence on oil, particularly in the transportation sector, and increasing domestic production in an environmentally sound manner."
 
Oil Industry's View
 Oil industry executives, who were made aware of its details today, applauded the Administration's aggressive plan to take some restraints off the domestic oil industry. "If this is as described, it certainly sounds very positive, not only for the industry, but for the consumer," said Douglas G. Elmets, a spokesman for ARCO in Los Angeles. "It certainly makes us less reliant on insecure sources of oil."
But leaders of environmental groups who read the draft today said it was one-sided and would fail to solve the nation's dependence on foreign oil, which supplies more than half the American consumption. "There is no leadership here, no vision for a future of clean, efficient use of energy," said James L. Wolf, executive director of the Alliance to Save Energy, a group in Washington that lobbies for energy conservation measures. "It's very aggressive in ignoring transportation efficiencies, which is the root of the oil problem."
Democratic lawmakers predicted today that if the legislation proposed by the White House was similar to the draft circulating today, its chances of passage are slim. "It was only a couple of months ago that Admiral Watkins said in an interim report that the single loudest message he heard all across the country was support for energy efficiency in all sectors of the economy, and almost all of these opportunities were ignored," Senator Wirth said.
 
 Opening the Wildlife Refuge
 Among the measures in the 142-page draft is a proposal to open 1.5 million acres of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska for oil exploration.
The Administration wants to put 300,000 acres of the 19-million acre refuge up for bid to oil companies in the first round of oil lease sales; every two years after that, 300,000 more acres would be open for leasing to oil companies. The Interior Department, which owns the refuge and believes as much as 3.6 billion barrels of oil lie below the coastal plain, said this week that new studies show the probability for a successful strike is more than twice what scientists said just four years ago.
The Administration's proposal includes an array of restrictions and regulations to protect animals and their habitats in the vast refuge, but they are not likely to satisfy environmental groups, including the National Wildlife Federation and Sierra Club, which have been lobbying to keep the oil companies out of the refuge.
 
Oil and Gas Pipelines
 Other proposed programs would aid the oil and natural gas industry, including eliminating requirements that energy companies get approval from the Government to import or export natural gas. Several other proposals would reduce restrictions on owners of oil and natural gas pipelines.
The formal process of developing the Administration energy policy began in August 1989 with a public hearing in Washington, the first of several around the country, at which Mr. Watkins presided. "This national energy strategy," Mr. Watkins said, "will be a dynamic, living process, not just a document, from this day forward."
Among the proposals that Mr. Watkins promoted from the start, and that remain in the draft made available today, were new rules for severe limits on the ability of the public to comment on new nuclear power plants before they are started. The proposal is intended to eliminate situations in which new plants are held up or permanently closed because of public protests in the weeks before they are to open.
 
Concern for the Economy
 Mr. Watkins also said he was interested in conserving energy with new, imaginative programs that would aid the economy as well as the environment. In the draft policy, just a few of the ideas offered at public hearings across the country survived. There are new tax credits for producing energy with the sun, water, and wind, and ideas that could encourage the development of alternative sources of electricity. There is also a proposal to set new standards for making lights more energy-efficient.
But nearly all proposals for conservation and efficiency, according to lawmakers on Capitol Hill, are likely to be eliminated by the White House over the weekend. The White House has also proposed to weaken an existing regulation requiring automobiles to become more fuel-efficient.
On Capitol Hill, the White House legislation will compete with several other proposals that have already been introduced.
Bennett Johnston, a Democrat and chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, has co-sponsored a new bill with Malcolm Wallop, a Republican from Wyoming, that would increase the size of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve and rewrite the nation's principal law that regulates electric utilities.
Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Democrat from Nevada, has reintroduced a measure that was narrowly defeated last year to increase automobile fuel mileage standards.
Representative Philip R. Sharp, Democrat of Indiana, would require states to promote energy conservation, calls for Federal power agencies that sell electricity to utilities to require their customers to establish conservation plans, and would call on Federal lending agencies to promote energy efficiency through mortgage incentives for energy-efficient homes. And Senator Frank Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, reintroduced legislation that was withdrawn after the Exxon Valdez in 1989 to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling.

HEADLINE: Filling Plate Takes Priority Over Curbing the Appetite

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The problem with a nation whose oil production satisfies barely half its oil appetite is not its appetite, the Bush administration has apparently concluded, but its production.
 With most eyes now focused on the war in the oilfields of the Middle East, many elected officials and private analysts are calling for cutting imports. That was a goal, Secretary of State James Baker 3d said in a speech earlier this week. 
 But the oil segment of the draft of the National Energy Strategy is aimed mainly at supplying the American appetite, rather than curbing it. This is in sharp contrast to the energy policies generated by the oil crises of 1973-74 and 1979. Those earlier policies assumed that the cause of the imbalance lay at least in part on the consumption side.
 
Other Sources of Energy

Imported oil amounts to nearly half the oil used in this country but only 10 percent of total energy consumption, which includes natural gas, nuclear power, coal and hydroelectric power. The United States also imports natural gas and other fuels but exports coal. The net result is that the nation produces about 82 percent of all the energy it uses.
Opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to drilling is the oil companies' biggest hope for expanding reserves, and thus production. But in the view of industry and others, this is not salvation. The Department of Energy said last fall that the median estimate of its size was 3.2 billion barrels, which is huge by the standards of what is found in the United States these days, but small relative to consumption. And there is always the possibility that it will come up dry.
"This will not prevent an increase in the level and share of imports," said John H. Lichtblau, the president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a nonprofit group in New York. "Increase is inevitable," he said. "The rate might be slightly slower than if the Government had not come up with anything."
 
 Competitive Problems
 Brooks B. Yeager, a lobbyist for the National Audubon Society, contends that policies aimed at production cannot make much difference in the level of imports. A bigger factor in production, he said, is prices. "Our ability to pump oil out and market oil is always dependent on whether it is competitive with Middle East oil," he said. Because of geology, it simply is not, he said. But measures that would make domestic drilling competitive, like import fees, have generally been ruled out by the Bush Administration, which says they would interfere with a free market.
Other facets of the policy statement will not cut oil consumption significantly either.
Nuclear power, for example, the other main focus of the energy package, does not usually substitute for oil; it mostly replaces coal and natural gas.
And efforts to encourage greater production of other energy sources -- mostly through a return to market principles -- will also have a relatively minor impact on oil consumption and imports.
 
 Fewer Approvals to Get

Builders of oil and gas pipelines would be relieved of having to obtain an entire category of cumbersome approvals. Nuclear power plant builders would no longer have potentially contentious and delaying hearings at the end of construction. And nearly anybody and his brother could enter the wholesale electricity market as producers.
The treatment of consumption by the energy policy plan stands in sharp contrast. Gone is all mention of gasoline taxes, taxes on all fuels based on energy content or on carbon production, or new taxes on cars based on their fuel economy.
Taxing cars based on fuel economy is one idea that is certain to be revived in Congress this year. Cars are widely veiwed as the biggest single target for greater efficiency, and the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards, imposed after the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo, include one of the two major elements of energy policy surviving from that era. The other is the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which is barely mentioned in the draft, with a call for stockpiling oil products, as well as crude oil.
 
 Not Much Spending Required

The Department of Energy had considered a variety of methods for stimulating oil production, mostly centering on tax breaks. Some of those would have cost the Treasury $16 or more for every barrel produced. Very few of the proposals that survived to the draft plan stage would require Washington to spend money.
Mr. Bush's approach also differs from his predecessors' in largely avoiding reliance on new technology, although it would encourage some fleet vehicles to run on alternative fuels, which have not been demonstrated on a large scale, with some reduction in gasoline demand. It would also provide some money for research.
 
 Ideas Around for Years
 Those ideas have been around for years. But it was clear early in the process of developing the strategy that in a political sense, the options were limited. Energy is so basic to so much of the economy that any change represents the swing of an elbow that hits someone in the eye.
The oil exploration industry got what it wanted most; the refining industry did not get a huge new requirement for alternative fuels, although it may have a new market to meet if fleets turn to other fuels. The auto industry avoided the mileage standards it did not want. The electric utility industry got a change that will please most of its members.
And the strategy seems mindful of the war in one particular way. By not moving to curb consumption or imports, the Saudis, the Venezuelans and other oil exporters with whom this country has cultivated a good relationship were spared the shrinkage of a big market.

HEADLINE: Mayors Attack Bush Plan to Shift Control Over $15 Billion to States

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The nation's mayors today denounced President Bush's proposal to give states control over $15 billion worth of Federal programs, saying it would permit governors to skim money that now flows directly from Washington to hundreds of cities around the country.
Speaking officially through the bipartisan United States Conference of Mayors, the mayors also contended that Mr. Bush's proposal would add a new layer of bureaucracy, at the state level, to many health, education, welfare, housing and law-enforcement programs. 
 "We the mayors of America, Republicans and Democrats, are united that this simply won't work and isn't a good idea," said Mayor William J. Althaus of York, Pa., a Republican, who asserted that Mr. Bush's proposal was "entirely wrong."
 
'This Is Fraud'
 Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, vice president of the mayors' conference, said, "This isn't federalism; this is fraud." At a news conference here, the Boston Democrat vowed that mayors would "go to the wall" fighting Mr. Bush's proposal to transfer selected programs to the states with a lump sum of Federal money.
The mayors estimate that cities now receive more than $12 billion a year under the Federal programs Mr. Bush wants to turn over to the states. The programs include Community Development Block Grants, which disburse more than $2 billion a year directly to cities and urban counties. The remaining $10 billion comes from health, education, welfare and housing programs under which states are required to share Federal money with units of local government.
If the mayors lobby as aggressively as Mr. Flynn indicated, they could substantially reduce the chances for Congressional approval of Mr. Bush's proposal. Many governors have cautiously welcomed the block grant proposal and plan to negotiate details with the Administration.
 
Aim of Bush Proposal
 In the budget submitted to Congress on Monday, Mr. Bush suggested that states might receive "a single consolidated grant" in place of the many they now receive to help pay for social services, elementary and secondary schools, public libraries, heating the homes of low-income families and administering welfare, food stamps and Medicaid.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said on Thursday that the proposal was an important item on Mr. Bush's domestic policy agenda because it would give states more flexibility and discretion in using Federal money.
"All the states want it -- governors, state legislatures -- and people around the country understand its significance and value," Mr. Sununu said of the proposal. But he added, "We're not sure Congress will pass it."
It is not clear whether the Administration will make a serious effort to persuade Congress to approve the President's proposal. Debra R. Anderson, the White House official responsible for dealing with governors and mayors, was not immediately available to respond to the criticism from the mayors' conference. Elisa Lund, an assistant to Ms. Anderson, said she was tied up with other business.
The mayors said the Federal Government should preserve programs, like the Community Development Block Grant, that disburse money directly to cities.
 
A National Problem
 Referring to the social and economic difficulties of the nation's cities, Mayor Flynn said: "This isn't a city problem. This isn't a poor people's problem or a minority problem. This is an American problem."
Leaders of the mayors' conference plan to meet next week with Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, to argue against the President's proposal.
Mr. Flynn complained that "the Federal Government has been walking away from America's cities" at a time when they must find homes for babies born to mothers addicted to crack, care for people with AIDS, shelter the homeless and cope with extraordinarily high rates of poverty, infant mortality and murder.
Mr. Flynn said there were political reasons for what he called the nation's neglect of its cities. Political power has shifted, he said, and cities can no longer deliver votes or campaign contributions to candidates as they once did. As a result, he said, "cities have no influence whatsoever in Congress."
In a statement distributed at the news conference, Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York, also a Democrat, said the President's proposal could have "grave consequences" for the people of his city next year, jeopardizing a $183 million grant to the city for community development and $579 million for public housing.
Mayor Sharpe James of Newark said there was no reason he should have to apply to the state government in Trenton for the community development funds he now receives from Washington. Cities and urban counties are entitled to such grants under a formula established by Federal law.
"We don't need to create another layer of bureaucracy," said Mr. James, a Democrat. That would only delay the distribution of funds urgently needed to combat drug abuse and to repair run-down housing, he contended. Mr. James asserted that the Bush proposal threatened "the viability and quality of life of our citizens."
