HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington;
President Increases Pressure On Jordan to Stay Neutral

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
With the Administration concerned that any change in Jordan's neutral status in inter-Arab politics would have a profound effect on the entire Middle East, President Bush stepped up pressure on King Hussein today not to join forces with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
"I have some concern now about what appears to be a shift in the Jordanian position," Mr. Bush said at a picture-taking session during a meeting in the Oval Office with the Argentine Foreign Minister, Guido Di Tella. The American people, he added, "don't understand some of the rhetoric coming out of there." 
 "We've always had a historically good relationship with Jordan," Mr. Bush said, "but this complicates things. He seems to have moved over, way over, into Saddam Hussein's camp."
The President's remarks followed the announcement on Thursday that the Bush Administration was reviewing its $55 million in 1991 foreign aid to Jordan in response to a speech this week by King Hussein, in which the Jordanian leader assailed the United States and backed Iraq.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said that today's harder line toward Jordan grew out of a closer review by the President of the King's speech. Mr. Fitzwater said the address on Wednesday made it clear "that Jordan has declared his allegiance to Iraq."
"The statements by King Hussein were very precise in terms of his attack on the United States," Mr. Fitzwater added.
 
Maneuvering for Postwar Era
 Administration officials say they understand what the King seems to be doing, which is positioning himself for the postwar Middle East. They believe he has concluded, wrongly, that when the gulf war is over Arab radicals will take revenge against all of the Arab leaders who joined with the United States in destroying Iraq.
Therefore, through his tilt toward Baghdad and denunciations of the United States, the King is trying to buy himself some life insurance for the postwar era, these officials say.
Given the King's life history, this is not altogether irrational. As an 15-year-old Prince, Hussein was at the side of his grandfather, King Abdullah, in 1951 when Abdullah was shot to death by a Palestinian who accused him of selling out the Palestinian cause after the 1948 Middle East war. After the 1967 Middle East war, King Hussein's own throne was challenged by Palestinian radicals, who wanted to sweep him and other Arab leaders aside for their failure to defeat Israel in that war.
But while Administration officials say they are ready to accept a certain amount of posturing by the King, who has provided some useful intelligence on Iraq, and tacit military cooperation, since the gulf war began, they felt that his speech of this week crossed a line and that unless they yanked him back he might be lost indefinitely from the pro-American Arab camp.
 
A Valuable Buffer
 Although Jordan is not a militarily powerful or rich country, it plays a crucial geopolitical role in the Middle East from Washington's point of view. The country is often taken for granted, until officials begin to contemplate what the region might be like without it.
Jordan under King Hussein has served as a stable, moderate and pro-American buffer between a variety of contending parties. It is a buffer between Israel and Iraq, between Syria and Saudi Arabia, between Egypt and Iraq and between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which at different times has tried to take over Jordan for itself.
A senior Administration official said Mr. Bush's remarks today were calculated to put the King on notice that as far as Washington was concerned he had crossed a line and was in danger of going from one of America's oldest Arab friends to one of its newest Arab foes. It was decided by officials that the President himself had to come down hard on the Jordanian leader so there would be no misunderstanding in Amman about how angry the United States was about his remarks.
Not only is the United States reviewing its own foreign aid to Jordan, but Administration officials also said they were stopping all of their efforts to solicit money from American allies to ease Jordan's economic crisis, a result of the gulf war.
Administration officials fear that when the ground war against Iraqi troops in Kuwait begins there could be even more of an anti-American outcry in the Arab world, and they want to keep Jordan at least neutral in order to minimize any political fallout.
 
Putting Americans 'at Risk'
 Mr. Fitzwater said that Saddam Hussein was using "any pretext and any means to try to split" the Arab and Western alliance fighting to reverse Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, and that King Hussein "was playing a role in that effort."
The King still has Arab nationalist credentials, and if he, along with Iraq, denounces the Americans, it could not only embarrass the pro-American Arab governments, but also lay the groundwork for a postwar inter-Arab cold war that would make any peacemaking in the area that much more difficult.
The King's latest speech, a senior Administration official said, "was clearly an effort to delegitimize the American war effort."
"We are not worried that he is going to make Saddam legitimate," the official said. "But there is a war going on now. Americans are at risk, and what the King is doing and saying is putting them more at risk. That is not the way friends behave -- even friends who are under pressure.
"We cannot be the ones always doing what we can to help him. And then he goes and pockets that and doesn't care if he says things that make life more difficult for us. There are limits to our patience, and he needs to know that more clearly."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

War in the Gulf 6-8
A ground assault will be needed to flush out Iraqi troops and expose them to further air bombardment, Defense Secretary Cheney said, suggesting the U.S. plans some strategy other than a frontal attack. Page 1
Cheney and Powell promise an early end to the war 6

HEADLINE: Manufacturers Urge Big U.S. Export Push

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 8

 BODY:
Arguing that exports are the bright spot in an otherwise bleak economy, the National Association of Manufacturers is urging the Bush Administration to play a much more aggressive role in promoting the sale of American products abroad.
The lobbying effort, outlined here today at the group's twice-a-year board meeting, is based largely on the premise that more exports, particularly of manufactured goods, can reverse the recession. Should the Bush Administration respond to the appeal and adopt the proposals, it would become deeply involved in promoting and even managing trade. 
 "Exports were probably what kept us from slipping into a recession in the first half of 1990, and they can hasten a recovery in 1991," said Jerry Jasinowski, the association's president and chief lobbyist. He added that stepped-up production in recent years to supply a growing export market accounted for a third of the nation's economic growth.
Mr. Jasinowski said the role of exports in economic growth had been noted by Bush Administration officials, with whom he has discussed the group's new lobbying effort. But the Administration has not publicly commented on potential export policy much beyond President Bush's brief reference in his State of the Union Message.
"Exports," he said in the speech, "are running solid and strong."
The association, representing 13,500 companies that produce 80 percent of the nation's manufactured goods, has always lobbied for pro-export policies. But it is undertaking what is perhaps its most ambitious campaign just as many of its members, rather than export, have established factories abroad to supply overseas customers.
The Maytag Corporation, for example, whose chairman, Donald Krumm, is a former chairman of the manufacturers' group, makes nearly all the appliances it sells abroad in factories in France, Britain and Australia. That is primarily because American-style washing machines, vacuum cleaners and other appliances are not used abroad.
"Basically, no appliance maker is shipping from the United States," Mr. Krumm said. His company gets a third of its $3.1 billion in sales revenue from overseas operations.
 
 Building Here and There
 Others are more like Valmont Industries, a Nebraska manufacturer of irrigation equipment, street light systems and power supplies. Valmont both exports and manufactures abroad.
A factory near Madrid that makes irrigation systems was set up in the early 1980's when the strong dollar made American products too expensive when sold in foreign currencies. But since the dollar has fallen sharply in the last two years, Valmont's factory in Valley, Neb., can now supply its markets in Spain, southern Europe and North Africa more inexpensively than its Madrid plant, said William F. Walsh, Valmont's chief executive.
The company's exports, in fact, have risen slightly, to about $55 million out of total revenue of $870 million, and revenue from the sale of products manufactured abroad has fallen slightly, to just under $50 million. But Mr. Walsh said the Madrid plant would not be closed, in part because it operated inside the European Community, safe from European trade barriers, and because the Spanish Government finances Valmont products exported from Spain.
"We will never retreat from having plants overseas for these reasons," Mr. Walsh said, referring also to Valmont's plants in Austria and France. "There are financing alternatives overseas that are not available here."
The association's export proposals do not refer to the trend toward overseas manufacturing, although today the foreign affiliates of American companies manufacture and sell abroad more than $700 billion a year in products, or roughly twice the value of merchandise exports from this country.
 
 Exchange Rate Is Noted
 In making his pitch for aggressive export policies, Mr. Jasinowski noted that two-thirds of the group's members neither exported nor manufactured abroad. And since the dollar began to fall in 1985, the value of American merchandise exports, other than agricultural products, has almost doubled, even when adjusted for inflation, according to Commerce Department figures.
"The exchange rate is the dominant explanation for the sharp growth in exports since the mid-1980's," Mr. Jasinowski said.
To sustain this growth, one association proposal would commit the Government to maintain the dollar at its current weak level of less than 130 Japanese yen and 1.46 West German marks. Another would funnel more American foreign aid to road building and other capital projects, with the stipulation that American equipment to carry out the projects be purchased with the aid money. A third proposal would abolish the numerous restrictions that require Government permission for the export of many American products.
A fourth proposal would increase Government financing of American exports. And a fifth would encourage the Government to impose sanctions quickly against countries that exclude American products.

HEADLINE: America's Kitchen Midden

 BODY:
Chroniclers of American culture can breathe easy. Sears, Roebuck & Company now insists that neither competition nor the recession can make it give up its catalogue. That preserves a historic marketing device -- and a historic document.
Sears started in the 1880's when Richard Sears, a Minnesota railroad station agent, began offering other agents the chance to earn commissions by selling off shipments of unclaimed watches. Young Sears found this so profitable that he soon abandoned the railroad business and moved to Chicago to sell watches and other goods by mail. 
 The business flourished as it fed the hunger of rural America for access to the cornucopia of American industry. The 1897 Sears catalogue numbered more than 770 pages and offered tens of thousands of items.
In those days, the "wish book" was a form of entertainment as well as a way to shop. While the farmer browsing through the catalogue on a winter evening sized up an Improved Disc Harrow With Seeder Attachment ($34), his wife might look over the ornate cast-iron Sunshine Range ($38.75). His son could dream about the White Bone Handle Jack Knife (12 cents) or perhaps a Spalding Baseman's Mitt ($3.60). His teen-age daughter might ponder a bottle of skin-freshening Eau de la Jeunnesse (75 cents) or even a device called the Princess Bust Developer ($1.46).
As each catalogue offered shoppers variety, convenience and low prices, it gave social historians a rich core sample of American life. "One can well imagine some archaeologist of the twenty-fifth century scratching his head . . . over this gigantic kitchen midden," wrote S. J. Perelman.
Today's catalogue offers such exotica as radar detectors, laptop computers and pulsating shower heads. Should it disappear, 25th-century archeologists, not to mention nostalgia buffs of the 21st, would be poorer indeed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Reading History on Harbor Waves

BYLINE: By ROGER STARR

 BODY:
Much of New York City's economic history was inscribed on the salt waters that separate all but one of the modern city's boroughs from the rest of North America.
History written on water tends to disappear. But a glimpse of the past can be found on a tidal shelf of the Arthur Kill, the waterway that divides part of New York from New Jersey. On the Staten Island side of the kill, now crowded with tankers and container ships that shun the city in favor of Newark and Elizabeth, a ship-breaker's yard has become the final resting place of scores of abandoned harbor craft. These wood and steel fossils awaiting final dissection offer clues to the past and hints of the future. 
 A visitor wandering among the old hulks, as a Times photographer did recently, can find a wooden-hulled steam towboat that once plied the Hudson trailing as many as 50 ice barges. A family lived on every barge; some children could say they had never set foot ashore during the first 10 years of their lives. When spring opened the upper Hudson to navigation, the flotillas of barges brought ice, cut from northern lakes, to the metropolis that until the early 1920's lacked any other widely available refrigerant.
A smaller, sleeker hull, with a deckhouse and a rusting steel mast, is the corpse of a self-propelled express steam lighter, built to transfer heavy, valuable cargoes (such as high-speed German diesel engines) from ships at anchor to the New Jersey railheads. Near it may be the remains of a floating grain elevator that emptied wheat from Erie Canal barges into oceangoing freighters. Navigational improvements in Midwest canals and the Mississippi have made New Orleans the nation's grain export center; New York has not used its floating grain elevators in 30 years.
Covered barges, their rotted roof beams now open to rain, once carried bagged cement from the rail terminals; they've been replaced by ocean vessels that carry cement in bulk, pumped out pneumatically.
The costs of repeated loading and unloading, from ship to harbor craft to truck, encouraged the development of big cargo containers, reduced the number and variety of harbor craft, cut to a fraction the number of longshoremen needed to work a single freighter hatch and made development of container ports on the empty New Jersey waterside sites inevitable.
Recognition of the changes wrought by economic and technological displacement suggest the possibility of further changes. As metropolitan traffic congestion rises, and the capital cost of new trans-harbor tunnels and bridges looms ever larger, time may reverse itself, allowing local water transport to regain its place in the Upper Bay.
Already, passenger ferries are carrying significant numbers of workers to their jobs, and luxury yachts offer a fancy meal or a platform that provides nice vistas for a wedding ceremony. A revival of maritime diversity in the harbor would stimulate employment, regenerate the significance of geography among New Yorkers and restore some of the excitement and productivity of New York's historic water without necessarily distracting the waiters or the bride and groom.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
The 51st State?

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
"I want Puerto Rico to become the 51st state," President Bush has said. Does he realize that would mean fewer Puerto Ricans in private-sector jobs, more on welfare, and a probable additional cost of $17 billion to the U.S. Treasury?
 Attorney General Dick Thornburgh told Congress this week that the Administration favors a plebiscite in which Puerto Ricans might well vote for statehood. Senator Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, the chairman of the committee preparing plebiscite legislation, says Puerto Ricans' choice in that vote would be "morally binding" on Congress. 
 Mr. Thornburgh questioned the constitutionality of the only other likely status alternative -- an improved, virtually autonomous version of the present Puerto Rican "commonwealth." A third option, independence, is not believed to have sufficient support to be a real possibility for the island.
 Mr. Bush's desire for statehood is hard to understand, although the island's Republican Party also favors it. From a narrowly partisan point of view, Puerto Rico as a state would rate two senators and five or six members of the House. That's larger than a number of present delegations, including some that usually vote Republican; and the Puerto Rican delegation might well be all or mostly Democratic.
 From a broader perspective, moreover, the island insists on maintaining its Spanish culture, which would make it the only state with Spanish as its official language. Even Puerto Rican Republicans agree on that -- though mainland Republicans hardly can be enthusiastic about such an exception.
 Economically, statehood would be a disaster for the island. It would mean the loss of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's exemption from U.S. taxes, under Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code. No state is entitled to claim such an exemption, which has been applicable to Puerto Rico since before commonwealth status was achieved in 1952. That's one good reason the island's annual per capita income has risen since then from a few hundred dollars to more than $6,000 last year.
 Not only would statehood bring the Federal income tax to Puerto Rico; a Peat Marwick study estimated that 72 percent of the companies that have put about 2,000 industrial plants on the island, because of its tax advantages, might leave once statehood caused the loss of those advantages. That would mean the flight of 80,000 to 145,000 jobs, the study suggested.
 A Congressional Budget Office report similarly found that if Puerto Rico's commonwealth tax advantages were lost, unemployment -- averaging 14.6 percent even now -- would increase by 100,000 within the decade. Under statehood, Puerto Rican gross product would fall by 10 to 15 percent in the same period.
 Under the prevailing commonwealth status, however, economic growth is projected at a real annual rate of 2.5 to 4 percent. That's important to other Americans because Puerto Rico already buys more mainland goods than Brazil, Chile, Argentina and Colombia combined -- $9.4 billion in 1989.
 Why would Puerto Ricans opt for statehood if it meant they had to pay United States income taxes while their economy was shattered? One reason is that many islanders are too poor to pay income tax, and statehood would make many eligible for nearly doubled welfare benefits -- causing an estimated $17 billion rise in Federal outlays for Puerto Rico, a short-term bonanza.
 Statehood would allow the islanders to participate in Presidential elections, and to send a voting delegation to Congress. Many Puerto Ricans seem also to believe that it would magically produce for them a living standard equal to that of mainland Americans, whose per capita income is far higher -- even in Mississippi, the poorest of the current states.
 Commonwealth supporters, like Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon, believe they can win a plebiscite, though polls now give statehood a narrow lead. They hope commonwealth status can be so defined in the Senate's plebiscite legislation that, if voters opt for it, Congress could not change it in the future. But Mr. Thornburgh said the Constitution required United States territories, other than states, to be controlled by Congress; therefore, he argued, Congress could take away commonwealth status any time it chose.
 If sustained by Bennett Johnston's committee, that's a telling argument against commonwealth and for statehood -- and one that raises the question whether President Bush grasps the real consequences of what he says he wants for Puerto Rico.

HEADLINE: As Yugoslavia Breaks Apart

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Though the Yugoslavs are divided along national and religious lines, the current crisis in Yugoslavia is not fueled by old ethnic feuds alone. Indeed, it is more of a struggle between federal authorities and the provinces. In many ways it is similar to the states-rights controversies that now and then rock the American boat. 
 The two main actors in the Yugoslav drama are Ante Markovic, the Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, and Franjo Tudjman, the Croatian head of state. Both are ethnic Croats. Mr. Markovic wants a strong Yugoslavia. Mr. Tudjman wants its dissolution. Although Serbia seems to support Mr. Markovic, the Serbs have been at odds with him over other issues.
Serbian support of their Croatian Prime Minister on the federal question does not mean they are the source of Yugoslavia's problem. Although Serbia versus Croatia may be Yugoslavia's big concern in the near future, today it is a showdown between federal authorities (most of them former Communists) and provincial authorities (who wave a lot of American flags, but are also mostly former Communists).
Serbia, concerned about the millions of Serbs who live in Yugoslavia's other provinces (some of them hostile), may be rooting for the federal government, but it did not precipitate the debate, nor is it responsible for the confrontation.
As an American Serb, I cannot say I support the further existence of Yugoslavia. The pain and detriment it brought my kin far outweigh whatever negligible benefit they may have gained. An absence of concern over self-interest seems a dominant trait in the Serbian psyche. Consumed with the noble idea of a Balkan melting pot, the Serbs sacrificed everything for a truly integrated and united Yugoslavia. Most of their fellow Yugoslavs, however, never committed themselves to the same objective.
As a result, the Serbs have been forced to tolerate a disastrous marriage for more than seven decades, and no abused spouse has ever been more deserving of a quick and painless divorce.
Mr. Markovic's ultimate agenda may collide with my perception of Serbian interests, but as a Westerner I cannot but credit him for his remarkable economic and political strides. Moreover, although some members of Congress with influential Yugoslav constituencies balk, our Government supports the continued unity of Yugoslavia.
Other Americans who want to take sides and, for whatever incredible reason, are tempted to blame the Serbs, should first ask themselves where American interests lie, and what the United States Government has to say.
 
ALEXANDAR D. MALICH
Monroeville, Pa., Jan. 25, 1991

SECTION: Section 1; Page 9; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1607 words

HEADLINE: Recession Is Forcing Many To Lessen Hopes for College

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
The deepening recession is forcing growing numbers of parents to reconsider plans to send their children to colleges whose tuitions they may no longer be able to afford.
Many say they will wait as long as possible this spring before mailing deposits for the next academic year, and college admissions officers say they expect a large number of students to apply for admission to state schools, where tuition is lower, if the economy continues to slide. 
 "Kids that in the past might have gone to Trinity or Wesleyan or the University of Vermont are coming here," said William Hawkins, director of financial aid at Western Connecticut State University in Danbury. "Or they're transferring here from private colleges because their parents have lost a job or are afraid of losing it. The middle class is getting hammered, and they are telling their kids, 'Hey, we don't have the money for those schools.' "
Especially hard hit, the educators say, will be small private institutions, particularly ones with religious affilations, that were already leading marginal existences with dwindling enrollments, and large universities with budgets based on filling 2,000 or more freshman spaces. Also bracing for a blow to enrollment prospects are private secondary schools.
 
Holding Their Breaths
 Job layoffs, especially in middle-income and professional households, and general unease about how far the economy will slide this year are the main forces behind the apprehensiveness of college officials.
"The uncertainty is so great many colleges and universities don't know what kind of freshman class they are going to enroll next September," said Robert Lay, dean of enrollment at Boston College.
For thousands of the families the sagging economy is just one more blow to plans for a college education. Emily Kokie is a 17-year-old senior near the top of her class at Cranford High School in New Jersey who hopes to be a lawyer. But even by taking out student loans and working part time, she and her parents will not be able to afford any of the seven private colleges to which she has applied, including Yale , unless the colleges pick up the rest of the costs with scholarship aid.
"I don't want my daughter to graduate college with $40,000 in loans to pay back," said Sonia Kokie, wife of a high school basketball coach. "That's about as much as my husband, at his age, makes in one year, and with this economy I know a lot of college grads who can't get a job."
Helene Unger, guidance director at Emily's school, said the competition for financial aid was placing tremendous emotional stress on everyone.
"It becomes an exercise in creativity to find a place for a kid with good S.A.T. scores and decent class rank," she said.
In more affluent homes the distress is deep, too. One woman in New Canaan, Conn., who spoke only on condition that she not be identified, said:
"There was no bonus this year for my husband, a banker, who feels very vulnerable in his job. No one's going to cry for us; we've been very privileged. But at the moment we feel very insecure.
"We have a daughter in a small private college that costs more than $20,000 a year and a son who is a senior in high school. We've told him to put in an application to the University of Connecticut or find a private college with comparable costs."
 
Two Incomes No Longer Enough
 Adele Bihn of Santa Clara, Calif., is worried about college costs for her four children, one in college and another in high school, even though she and her husband own a marketing company with 15 employees.
"We don't know if a bigger depression is going to roll in here from the Northeast one of these days and we may be faced with spending $45,000 after-tax dollars or so a year to send two or three kids to college," she said in a telephone interview. "The day when a woman went to work to pay for college costs are over. Women are already working to pay for groceries and the mortgage."
The economy slumped at a time when higher education was already struggling with two trends affecting recruitment: resistance to rising fees for tuition, room and board, now more than $20,000 at many private colleges; and demographic shifts that have led to a smaller population of 18-year-olds.
As a result, colleges will be selecting next fall's freshmen from a smaller pool of graduating high school seniors and from an even smaller number who can afford the costs.
 
Less Scholarship Money
 Two additional concerns arise from the recession. Colleges fear they may have to cut back on scholarships to poor and minority students, who add diversity to privileged institutions. And alumni and corporations whose contributions underwrite scholarships and other programs are themselves feeling the pinch of recession.
In the mid-1980's, when college enrollments boomed and competition to get into top institutions was fierce, springtime was filled with tension for students who awaited college acceptance notices mailed out around April 1. Now it is college admission officers who will sweat out the spring, awaiting return mail from those willing to put down a deposit on the fall semester.
"Everyone has real concerns about the influence of all these factors," said Lawrence J. Momo, director of undergraduate admissions at Columbia University in New York. "It's our turn to do the nail biting."
Administrators report a surge in requests by students for information on financial assistance. They are now getting calls for emergency financial aid from families of current students who never needed it before.
 
Darwinism in Action
 The only institutions that are expected to ride out the recession relatively unscathed are those with blue-ribbon academic reputations and blue-chip endowments, places like Harvard, Princeton, Stanford and Yale. "There's a survival of the species going on this year, and I wouldn't be surprised if we lost a number of weaker schools, and the Northeast will be the hardest hit," said Richard Steele, admissions director at Duke University. "There is a greater sensitivity to costs now than I've seen in 25 years of admission work."
As institutions reel from the effects of the recession, students are being stunned by the realization that they have to lower their academic goals. Howard Greene, a consultant on college selection with offices in New York and Connecticut, said, "It's heartbreaking when kids have done everything expected of them in the classroom and they can't go to the school of their dreams because the family can no longer afford it.
"In homes where the mother and father never saved a penny because their income was so high they could write checks for tuitions out of their Christmas bonus, the shock is unbelievable when a job is lost or the firm no longer pays a year-end bonus," he went on. "They are sitting there with high assets and no income and they are devastated by the change in their lives."
 
'Safe' Means Affordable
 High school counselors said the financial squeeze was changing students' definition of a "safe" college. In the past, that meant one they knew would accept them; now it is a place they know they can afford.
At the University of Connecticut, where tuition for Connecticut residents is a fraction of that of top private schools, the number of applications received by Jan. 1 was up 20 percent over the year before. "In the weeks before Christmas we got many calls from parents begging us to take late applications for the spring semester," said Ann Huckenbeck, director of undergraduate admissions. "They couldn't pay the tuition bill at some private campus." The deadline, she told them, could not be extended.
As economic pressures force top students to attend state universities, those with weaker academic credentials and limited finances will have to settle for openings in second-tier public institutions or community colleges.
"With so many new applications," said Mr. Hawkins, the financial aid director at Western Connecticut, "this university is becoming far more selective. And if the state budget is cut, which looks likely, the freshman class will shrink."
In some cases, families who can afford the tuition at prestigious colleges are finding the admissions process easier than they expected. John Schnedeker, guidance director at Summit High School in New Jersey, said that this year "a lot of students who received early acceptance from institutions had borderline academic credentials that in the past would have put them on the wait list."
 
Courting Those Who Can Pay
 At large institutions like Boston and Syracuse Universities, which thrived in the 1980's as they built enrollments and national reputations, the financial squeeze on students has created a particularly painful dilemma.
To meet expenses, these universities must collect tuition from huge numbers of students without compromising newly won academic prestige by lowering admission standards. They have strengthened recruitment efforts in regions less affected by the troubled economy, especially the West, and opened the door wider to students from abroad who can pay their own way. At the University of Pennsylvania, foreign students made up 10 percent of the 2,000 freshmen enrolled last fall, up from 4 percent six years earlier.
"Any way you look at it, it's going to be a tough year," said Frank Burtnett, executive director of the National Association of College Admission Counselors. "There's no longer a prescribed formula on how to pay for college. I can see more kids taking five and six years to get through four years, dropping out to work to meet the costs."

HEADLINE: Tough One to Call

BYLINE: By Ethan Bronner; Ethan Bronner, the author of "Battle for Justice: How the Bork Nomination Shook America," covers the Supreme Court and legal affairs for The Boston Globe.

 BODY:

A CONFLICT OF RIGHTS
The Supreme Court and Affirmative Action.
By Melvin I. Urofsky.
270 pp. New York:
Charles Scribner's Sons.
$22.95. 
 Affirmative action is an issue about which relatively small segments of the population hold ferociously strong and opposing views while the bewildered majority leans one way and then the other, depending on how the question is framed. The debate over how to construe an unfair past and establish a more just future stirs primal emotions. Both sides bring powerful arguments.
Those favoring affirmative action maintain that a social and economic spoils system has been restricted for generations to white men engaged in their own affirmative action. To correct that imbalance, women and minority group members must be given special breaks.
Those against affirmative action argue that if the civil rights revolution taught us that people must not be judged by their skin color or sex, aren't such breaks -- whether called "quotas" or "goals and timetables" -- the wrong application of that lesson? Isn't the point to reaffirm the individualism of all rather than to promote the Balkanization of the country?
Since the 1978 Bakke case, when nine Supreme Court justices produced six opinions on the legality of a medical school's plan that set aside 16 spots out of 100 for disadvantaged minority students, the Court has found itself caught, like the rest of the nation, between those two arguments. What appeared to emerge from Bakke was approval for race-conscious recruitment but rejection of quotas; since then the Court has upheld some affirmative action plans and struck down others, often without clear continuity of reason.
One of the more noteworthy of those decisions, in this instance involving a woman, came in the 1987 Johnson v. Santa Clara County case, when the High Court upheld, 6 to 3, a California transportation agency's promotion of Diane Joyce over Paul Johnson to the job of road dispatcher -- this, despite Mr. Johnson's greater experience and initial selection by a board of men rather like himself. Ms. Joyce was sufficiently experienced to make the grade, tested virtually as well as Mr. Johnson and noted that none of the county road department's 238 skilled-craft jobs had ever been held by a woman.
The story, both human and legal, is a good one, and Melvin I. Urofsky, a professor of history and constitutional law at Virginia Commonwealth University and the author of many books on the Supreme Court, generally does it justice in "A Conflict of Rights," a timely and modest work. Mr. Urofsky is careful for the most part to stay evenhanded throughout the book.
We meet Mr. Johnson, quiet and industrious, born to poor Kansas farmers, brought up by relatives in Texas, who pushed himself along, justly setting his sights on a well-paying job only to be denied it because he was a white man. And we meet Ms. Joyce, a tough, likable widowed mother of four who spent much of her life being told she couldn't have a variety of jobs because they were only for men. This time she had a county government behind her, she badly needed the money, she was willing to fight and she won.
Mr. Urofsky, who writes cleanly and briskly, makes us see how essentially similar are the values that Ms. Joyce and Mr. Johnson believe they fought to uphold, values of equal opportunity and reward for merit. He offers, too, a nice glimpse of the High Court's deliberations on the case through the access that the retired Justice William J. Brennan Jr. gave him to his files.
The book does have a failing: it does not deliver the human texture it promises. We meet Mr. Johnson and Ms. Joyce, but we do not really get to know them, or their lawyers, colleagues and judges. Depth and drama are missing from some key moments. But for those seeking a reliable and accessible examination of a growing national debate, this is a fine place to start.

HEADLINE: Somebody Always Knows Best

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman; Walter Goodman is a television critic for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE IDEA BROKERS
Think Tanks and the Rise of the New Policy Elite.
By James Allen Smith.
313 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95. 
 The connection between knowledge and power is no doubt most fascinating to people who have some of the former and crave more of the latter. Still, readers with no aspirations to govern the governors can find rewards in "The Idea Brokers," James Allen Smith's account of the increasing influence of experts on Washington during the past century, particularly for the light it casts on intellectual fashions and fallibilities.
After an overview of the changing role of what Mr. Smith calls the policy elite -- people who apply their knowledge of economics or political theory or foreign policy or whatever to public affairs, to "speak a useful truth," as he puts it -- he returns to the beginnings of the American Association for the Promotion of Social Science. To the worthies who founded it in Boston in 1865, Mr. Smith tells us, "social science, reform, and notions of Christian charitable obligation were virtually synonymous."
Although the religious element would be muted or discarded in time, the principle of doing good by first doing research would remain at the heart of the rationale for the brain trusters, think tankers and assorted academics and specialists who found their way into Government service (to use a kind term) as the executive branch flowered in the ensuing decades. In 1988, some 28,100 social scientists were making their livings off the Federal Government.
Early in the 20th century, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Carnegie Corporation and the Russell Sage Foundation went into the betterment business in a big way. Influenced by the Progressive spirit, Margaret Olivia Sage, then the richest woman in the world, set the objective for generations of enlightened benefactors: apply research to the solution of social ills. The social minded Sageites organized themselves into groups with no-frill titles like Child-Helping, Women's Work and Charity Organization. Mr. Smith credits such movements with seeking explanations for poverty and ill health not in moral failings of the poor but in what he calls "the interplay of social phenomena."
Mr. Smith, who has taught American history at several colleges, lacks the knack for bringing personalities like Mrs. Sage to life on the page, and his narrative, while serviceable, does not have a lot of snap to it. But he is good at explaining how major policy-research institutions grew out of the popular notions of their times. For example, he finds the mania for efficiency of the early 1900's in the workings of the Brookings Institution, the Twentieth Century Fund and the National Bureau of Economic Research; all shared the conviction that harmony in the workplace could be attained by the application of reason. Considering that Marxism was making its mark elsewhere in these years, the faith in efficiency might be taken as enlightened capitalism's counterattack.
Bad times are good for experts, and Mr. Smith gives a shrewd account of the role of Franklin D. Roosevelt's brain trust (Rexford G. Tugwell, Adolf A. Berle and Raymond Moley, charter members) in the New Deal. The President was no intellectual, but he was quick to pick up on fresh ideas and he had the daring to try them out. Planning became a catchword (the National Resources Planning Board actually put out a document in 1934 called "A Plan for Planning"), and some of the innovations made their way into New Deal programs. Here Mr. Smith discerns a significant change, from the expert as bearer of disinterested knowledge to the expert as political instrument. The line between knowledge and power was becoming porous and would remain so ever after.
War, like depression, means prosperity for experts. Economists especially flocked to Washington after 1941 to work out ways to hold down prices at home while food and goods were dedicated to the war effort. They did a creditable job, though not without mistakes. "The experience of being disastrously wrong is salutary," observed John Kenneth Galbraith. Government paid its tribute after the war by setting up the Council of Economic Advisers. Now the outsiders were inside.
Cold war seems to have been as inviting as the hot kind as far as experts were concerned. Research organizations like the RAND Corporation, which contracted its services to the Pentagon grew fast, and phrases like "systems analysis" and "game theory" began showing up in the newspapers. Robert McNamara brought a famous company of "action intellectuals" from RAND to the Kennedy Administration's Defense Department.
Mr. Smith reminds us that the 1950's saw a drawing away by intellectuals from abstract ideas, along with an increased suspicion of ideology. Some influential historians portrayed the United States as the exemplar of the liberal consensus; policy experts could see themselves as expediting national desires like those expressed in Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society program, which also happened to suit their own political tastes. Mr. Smith attributes their imminent decline to their "hyperrational attempt to impose a quantitative order on the world." He says their failure to educate the public had "tragic" consequences.
The book adopts a somewhat puzzling tone of lamentation about the failure of the experts to realize their promise. Although Mr. Smith does not quite come right out and say so, what seems to be bothering him is the spectacular rise to influence of conservative intellectuals, like Irving Kristol, who prospered from the concentration on cold war strategies and the spotty record of liberal domestic reforms, such as the War on Poverty.
Laying the credit or blame for the neoconservative upsurge of the 1970's to a failure of communication by liberals may be a touch too simple. But Mr. Smith does make a case that entrepreneurially inclined operators like the American Enterprise Institute, the Heritage Foundation and the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research have outmaneuvered liberal groups in working the marketplace of ideas. The conservatives were not hurt, of course, by the big money available from richies like Joseph Coors, John Scaife and the John M. Olin Foundation. As interested in advocacy as in research, all have marketed their message in the form of congenial books and personalities.
Nearly two-thirds of the 100 or so policy research groups now in Washington were set up after 1970. The drift has been rightward, but the collapse of world Communism and the onset of world recession may bring another of the periodic shifts that Mr. Smith helpfully chronicles. For now, as viewers of television news programs and talk shows can confirm, experts of a sort that our author calls policy interpreters are flourishing. Whatever their other qualifications, they know what the tube likes, and have earned their labels of "instant experts," "media professors" and "quote doctors."
For his peroration, Mr. Smith quotes Henry A. Kissinger, probably the highest ascender from the corridors of academe to the groves of power: "Most foreign policies that history has marked highly, in whatever country, have been originated by leaders who were opposed by experts. It is, after all, the responsibility of the expert to operate the familiar and that of the leader to transcend it."
Reflecting on the largely unpredicted events in Eastern and Central Europe in 1989, he adds that when experts can neither foresee nor explain, "the shroud of their mystique is ripped away." For anybody who agrees with Woodrow Wilson that experts had best be kept in their place, that is a comforting observation.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
In Times Square, Dignity by Day, Glitter by Night

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

 BODY:
In the shotgun marriage of office buildings and honky-tonk that is coming, slowly but steadily, to replace the tawdry Times Square of old, the newly finished skyscraper at 1585 Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets, represents an achievement of sorts: it is a building that manages to come off more as sleek than showy, more as refined than glitzy. The special zoning laws that were adopted several years ago to preserve some of Times Square's old rakish flavor -- requiring that new office towers have huge advertising signs and special lighting -- have been followed so slyly here that there is no real way to tell that this building is any different from the towers that go up anywhere else in town.
The architects of this 42-story building, the firm of Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, and the developer, Solomon Equities, were no fans of the city's new zoning. Plopping signs onto the facade of a building signaled esthetic violence to the architects, who saw it as destructive of the beauty of their building's form, and economic disaster to the developer, who feared that advertising would drive away prospective tenants and undercut any attempt to give the tower a blue-chip image. The compromise that was devised between the city's zoning laws and these architects' and builders' own interests is in fact quite ingenious: 1585 Broadway has been designed with a base of glass and metal panels behind which elaborate signs, visible only at night, will be hidden. The notion is that at night the building will dazzle, while by day it exudes corporate dignity. 
 There's no way yet to tell how well this will work, of course, since what nobody realized when the city passed its special zoning laws in the mid-1980's was how difficult it would be to rent the spaces set aside for signs on the facades of Times Square's new buildings. No one has taken the sign space on 1585 Broadway yet: the spaces are huge, and the cost of electronic equipment for up-to-date signs is enormous.
 But this building is not alone -- even before the present economic downturn, most of the new sign spaces required by law on new Times Square skyscrapers were going begging. The one thing that can absolutely be said in favor of the Gwathmey Siegel solution is that it leaves 1585 Broadway better prepared for the recession, at least esthetically. For this building has a real facade, designed to stand on its own, that looks reasonable even when not a square inch of the sign space is rented. By contrast, the tower's neighbor a block uptown, the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza, has ugly, unfinished brick waiting for a sign that may not come for years, a glaring offense at the pedestrian.
 It's for reasons other than signs, though, that 1585 Broadway has been probably the most eagerly awaited of Times Square's new pieces of architecture. It is the first major skyscraper designed by Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel, architects whose elaborately detailed, lavishly executed modernist houses and offices have made them big-time architectural stars of the last two decades. Mr. Gwathmey and Mr. Siegel tried one tall building a little more than a decade ago, a dormitory at Columbia University that turned out to be a structure with an exceptionally harsh, almost crude, presence. After that disappointment, they produced mainly sleek modernist houses, small office buildings, and interiors for clients like David Geffen, Steven Spielberg, and Saul and Robert Steinberg.
 Almost everything they did was widely published, but the partners' work was as closely followed in schools of architecture as in the pages of the glossy magazines: they seemed, for a while, to be serving as serious architecture's leading emissaries to the world of 1980's glitter.
 Maybe that balance -- a little theory, a little knowledge of the commercial realities of the world -- is the ideal preparation for designing a Manhattan skyscraper. For at 1585 Broadway Mr. Gwathmey and Mr. Siegel have pulled off the difficult leap from small buildings to large ones, a leap that has daunted many practitioners before them. Whatever else can be said about this building, it looks to have been designed by architects at ease with and excited by the demands of making a tall building. It isn't an East Hampton villa turned on its side: it's a tower made for midtown Manhattan.
 To start with what's best, Mr. Gwathmey and Mr. Siegel have given this building an exquisite sheathing of blue-green glass, white patterned glass, mirror glass, silver-gray aluminum panels and polished stainless steel. It's a kind of laundry list of modern elements, but here put together into a geometric pattern that manages to be neither flat nor dull. The real achievement is that the architects have found a way within the modernist vocabulary to give their building the thing most modern buildings most urgently lack: texture.
 There's a loose similarity between 1585 Broadway's "skin" and that of Citicorp Center, and the comparison is instructive: this building's facades, made of panels developed by PPG, have a sense of visual depth, and they change dramatically in different kinds of light. Citicorp's aluminum skin is flatter, and looks the same except at a few rare moments in the setting sun. What Mr. Gwathmey and Mr. Siegel have struggled to prove here is that it is possible to do in metal almost all the things that more traditional architecture does in masonry: offer richness, depth, texture and graphic complexity.
 This building steps away, at least tentatively, from the modernist tradition of lightness -- not to real heaviness, but to a tantalizing combination of solidity and airiness. What is most appealing visually about 1585 Broadway is the sense it projects of being both dense and light at the same time.
 As in so many buildings today, there is a little too much architecture here. The facade, for all the richness and strength of those aluminum panels, has a bit too much going on. It doesn't help to have little sections of mirror glass at the corners as a weak allusion to classical quoins. And the top, in which four sides slant inward to create a kind of cross between a gabled roof and a cut-off pyramid, couldn't be more wrong for this building. It's as if the architects wanted so much to prove that they could use the modernist vocabulary to play post-modern visual games that they went overboard, and the result is superficial and glib. Moreover, this quasi gable emphasizes the other real problem with this building's shape: its squatness.
 From the street, though, 1585 Broadway sits comfortably, even sumptuously, on its site, presiding rather more grandly over the north end of Times Square today than it will in the future, when another tower goes up on the site across the street that is now being excavated. The shape of the building, if clunky at the top, is exactly right at street level, with a strong base aligned to the building's frontage on Broadway, and a series of setbacks neatly shifting the tower's axis so that the main shaft rises not in line with Broadway's diagonal, but lined up with the rest of the Manhattan grid. One of the setbacks, at the sixth floor, bows out in a graceful curve that is not only handsome in itself, but is also the key element in the deft shift of the building's visual axis.
 But best of all is what happens just inside the doors of 1585 Broadway. There is a grand lobby running from 47th to 48th Streets that is not only exceptional among Manhattan office-tower lobbies, it ranks among the best public rooms created in this city in the last decade. It is a kind of modernist ballroom, its sweep of space broken only by two huge, round columns; with rough-finished walls of gray granite, accent stripes of dark green polished marble, a floor of white, black and dark green marble in a geometric pattern, and (in a detail that is striking, almost daring) a coffered ceiling of wood, this room is spectacular, even exuberant. Yet this lobby has all the sense of control that one expects from Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel's work: this magnificent room stands as proof, once and for all, that these architects have figured out how to be comfortable with bigness, and it is a splendid gift to the city.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
How to Snare Elusive Bargains From Airlines

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
"WITH the current bad economic climate," one travel agent said in New York, "the airlines are not going to offer any specials on any tickets they can sell at a regular price. What they are saying is, 'If you want to travel and you are willing to meet our terms on days and places, you can travel for a cut rate.' "
This column will outline steps to get the big discounts when they are available. It assumes that you do not have a ticket in hand yet, as "downgrading" an existing ticket to match an advertised promotional price is now the exception rather than the rule, said the agent, Joseph Vengersammy of Galo Travel. 
 The airlines are hustling. The mail is full of coupons and the ads full of specials: For example, British Airways sent out coupons for free round-trip companion tickets on one flight a day from New York to London or one a day to Manchester, England, between Jan. 15 and March 15; the return, valid until March 25 -- the Monday before Easter -- is good for one flight a day from each British city. If London is the choice, a ticket to travel Monday to Thursday, purchased 21 days ahead, would cost $632; for weekend travel it would be $685. (British Airways created an even cheaper deal a week later, and Pan Am, T.W.A., Continental and Virgin Atlantic matched it: $249 for a New York-London round trip, meaning that two people could travel to London for $498. The last departure date is March 17, the last return March 22. The disadvantage of this one is that reservations could not be made and nor tickets bought until 48 hours before the flight.)
Continental is sending a set of coupons to its frequent-flier members. A coupon is good for a discount of $35 on a ticket costing $100 to $250 or $50 on a ticket costing over $250. These are valid for flights between April 10 and June 15.
By the time an ad appears or a coupon arrives, the few promotional-fare seats on the most desirable flights may be gone. Everyone who flies is aware by now of yield management, the computerized technique that controls the number of seats offered at a certain fare and that keeps revising the number on the basis of demand and expectations of no-shows. Airlines do not usually advertise their specials until they apply for Government approval, but the line's agents begin selling it beforehand. This is what wipes out the good fares on the good flights on the day of the first ad.
One irate traveler said that he phoned Delta on Nov. 19, the day a $25 companion fare was advertised, to buy tickets from Hartford to Atlanta on Jan. 25 and back on Jan. 27, 66 days thence. He said the prime-time tickets were already gone and reported that he was told that only 15 seats on the flight he wanted had been available at the companion fare to start with. This traveler could have had the fare if he bought a ticket for midmorning departure and a late-evening return, but that was not what he wanted. Or, more correctly, he did not want the fare enough to adjust his hours of travel.
Flexibility Is the Key
So a "get that fare" manual for the consumer starts with the question of day of travel. Be flexible.
For most regular fares, the cheapest days for travel are usually Tuesday noon to Thursday noon. But the deeply discounted fares may have other rules, so the first question to ask the ticket or travel agent is, "What days of the week would qualify me for that bargain fare?"
If the fare has cut-rate fare available in midweek, it may save $25 or more each way. An illustration: On Jan. 17, Midway Airlines was quoting a midweek round trip from Midway Airport in Chicago to New Orleans in February after Mardi Gras at $227, including the $5 Chicago fuel surcharge; United and American were quoting the same price out of O'Hare. With a Friday departure and a Sunday return, the price rose to $270.50. Valerie Stringer of Travel Avenue said that there weren't many weekend seats available at that price.
New York-West Coast flights, which have been on a $298 special that expires Feb. 16, had different rules on travel days. United, Continental, American, Delta, USAir, Midway, America West, Northwest and T.W.A. all specified departures from New York Wednesday to Saturday and returns from California -- all the major airports were available on this special -- Sunday to Wednesday. As Mr. Vengersammy said, "These weekender fares are not designed to meet the traveler's needs, but to see if the traveler is willing to pay for the seat on the airline's terms."
If flexibility on day of the week produces no results, the alternative airport move is the next step. Unless you are really familiar with what your alternatives are, you should first do some research.
So the second big question for saving money is,"What if I leave from that airport instead of this?"
Here are two examples of big savings with alternative airports. In the middle of January, T.W.A. came out with a round-trip fare of $298 from Philadelphia to Albuquerque, N.M., valid until Feb. 20. The available days were Wednesday to Saturday outbound and Sunday to Wednesday return, and the maximum stay was eight days. From New York, the Albuquerque fare was $453, making the alternative a saving of $155, ample to cover a train trip to Philadelphia.
On Jan. 18, American, USAir, Midway, United and Northwest jumped in with a $138 round trip -- $5 fuel charge not included -- between Chicago and Bradley Airport, which serves Hartford and Springfield, Mass. It was for sale only until Jan. 31 but it was valid for travel until Feb. 28. Outbound travel could be Sunday to Friday, but the return could not be before Saturday, or the outbound trip could be Saturday, with a Saturday night stay required. For comparison, the nonrefundable fare between Chicago and Boston for this period on Northwest, Delta, T.W.A., USAir and Continental was $283, making Hartford a saving of $145.
Dial and Redial
There have been cases where bonanza fares are announced, with the sale to begin like a race, at 7 A.M. Eastern time on some later date. One strategy for this is available to people who have automatic redial devices on their telephones. One reader said she started dialing the number before the appointed hour and, when she got a busy signal, simply pressed the button to redial the number until she got an answer. This does not happen often, but redialing is probably worth trying.
It seems to me as the market gets crazier, it is silly to do without a travel agent. Travel agents are notified by the airlines about forthcoming coupons, or learn from one client that there are coupons in the mail and call to tell another. If the agent has been working with you for some time, she or he will keep you from buying a ticket for a trip where a forthcoming coupon may save you money. If there is lots of notice and the venture is worth the reward, the agent can become the equivalent of the redial device, checking the prices regularly.
The discount travel agency is another way of saving money. It charges you a flat fee for producing a ticket but rebates to you the discount it is given by the airlines for selling its wares. The more expensive the ticket, the more worthwhile this is. But a discount agency will not attend to vague ideas or shop around for several weeks. On domestic tickets, Travel Avenue (641 West Lake Street, Chicago, Ill. 60606; [800] 333-3335), formerly McTravel, rebates to you the airlines' discount of 7 to 10 percent of the price and charges $10 for writing the ticket. For a ticket over $100, the agency guarantees a saving of $5. The transaction is all by phone, with credit card charges. The ticket is sent by United Parcel.
The agency's clients know what they want when they call, although flexibility on days is a big key. The president of Travel Avenue, Richard Dickieson, said that the agency did not have a rule on how long agents could stay on the phone with one client. But it is clear that a salesperson cannot take a caller through every possibility and needs to close up a sale pretty quickly.

HEADLINE: Enshrining the Old South

BYLINE: By CAROLINE SEEBOHM; CAROLINE SEEBOHM is the author of five works of fiction and nonfiction, most recently "Private Landscapes" (Clarkson N. Potter).

 BODY:
PRESERVATION of the past is big business in America, but nowhere is it bigger business than in Natchez. I was brought up in England on the notion of the house as museum, but I was quite unprepared for the astonishingly determined re-creation of a bygone age that I saw in the many houses of Natchez during Pilgrimage Month.
Natchez is named for the Natchez Indians, who first settled there on the almost-mile-wide banks of the Mississippi, which now divides the state from Louisiana. Its tropical climate, fish, fruits and live oak and magnolia trees soon attracted white invaders, including French, Spanish and British, who ultimately dispatched the eponymous natives. By the 1800's, when the area became part of the Mississippi Territory, Natchez was a desirable little town, with prosperous trade generated from the Mississippi River and surrounding plantations. Its European heritage and successful economy encouraged fine architecture, and plantation owners vied with each other in building town houses to repair to when plantation life palled. 
 Unlike many parts of the South, Natchez escaped much of the pillage and burning that took place during the Civil War. Even the houses that were occupied by the opposing armies were treated with care except in a very few cases, and thus when the war was over the sense of continuity was comparatively easy to sustain.
A small oil boom in the 1970's infused the town with some much-needed new funds, most of which have dried up now, but which allowed the tourist industry to get a solid footing by restoring and promoting 30 or so antebellum houses out of the hundreds still extant in the town, attractions that are now the pride of Mississippi and a riveting experience for the first-time visitor.
Pilgrimage Month is actually almost two months, one in the spring and one in the fall. All 30 houses -- most privately owned, all restored to varying degrees -- are opened to the public on a kind of shift system, organized into morning and afternoon tours. It is impossible to see all the houses; you would go crazy in the attempt. Last April I visited 20 in four days, and by the end I felt if I was shown one more piece of baroque Victorian furniture by John Belter I would take a match to it; the idea of admiring one more portrait of a proud owner's granddaddy made my eyes fill with the wrong sort of tears. As with all such tourist bonanzas, discrimination is the key. My favorites, of course, indicate my own idiosyncracies, but these descriptions may give some idea of what to expect from the houses, which are scattered all over town.
Rosalie, built around 1820, is one of the most important houses in Natchez for both esthetic and historic reasons. It is situated on a small knoll overlooking the Mississippi, perfectly placed for admiring the view and for military occupation. With its sturdy brick facade and solid white columns, it looks ready for any invasion, even the hordes of tourists who now traipse through its noble, high-ceilinged rooms.
During the Civil War, the Union Army occupied Rosalie, treating it with respect. The only room to sustain damage was the dining room (a cracked mantel), which was used by the soldiers as a mess hall. (Two huge mirrors in the front parlor were taken down, wrapped in quilts and stored in a cave during hostilities, and were later rehung in perfect condition.) Rosalie's furnishings are typical of the mid-19th-century Southern houses one sees all over Natchez -- Belter or Belter-style furniture, rosewood pianos (all Southern belles learned to play), heavy damask fabrics (some original, most not) and finely-carved cornices and moldings. Six to eight acres of the 22-acre garden had been planned as a formal landscape, but is now rather spottily planted.
Lansdowne, built in 1852, appealed to me because, unlike some of the more monumental Greek Revival structures, it is one story of pale pink painted brick, giving it an Italianate feel. Jean Zuber contributed scenic wallpapers to the interior, which is also filled with rosewood and mahogany furniture, and Egyptian marble mantelpieces. The 140 acres of grounds are evocative -- trees hung with Spanish moss, streams, woodland. Inside, the wallpapers are particularly interesting, many of Italianate scenes in subtle monochromatic colors by Zuber.
Edgewood also has a very beautiful approach, including the fascinating sight of bayou-like lakes with trees growing out of the water. Its facade is dark pink stucco, unabashedly Italianate, with slim columns running the full length of the house.
High up on my must-see list is Montaigne, another stucco house painted in the subtle pinkish terra cotta of Edgewood, with gray shutters, enhanced by a supremely elegant portico and pediment. Built in 1855, the interior of Montaigne was destroyed by runaway slaves and white scalawags during the Civil War; chandeliers were smashed, silver and brass melted down, fine furniture and moldings cut down for firewood. But the original owner, a lawyer named William T. Martin, rebuilt it and today it houses Chippendale furniture, marble mantelpieces, Zuber wallpapers, and a lovely staircase. (Seeing the many period or original wallpapers in these houses was one of the most thrilling treats for me; I remember Chinese motifs and pineapples at Elms Court, English roses at Stanton Hall.) Perhaps the most exciting part of Montaigne, however, is the garden -- 23 acres of trees and shrubs, including live oaks, an azalea walk punctuated with double cherry trees and lined with camellias, and the most sensuous brick wall I have ever seen anywhere, looping and dipping with the grace of a suspension bridge, anchored with pedestals and finials, and revealing orchards and woodland beyond.
Most of the other houses on the tours have some elements of those described above, with fine antique furnishings, historical details and beautiful wallpapers. Like English country houses, the majority of them are lived in year-round by descendants of the original owners, thus exuding a loved and cherished feeling, with family photographs and heirlooms displayed everywhere. Many are designed round courtyards, with outbuildings that once housed laundry, kitchens and schoolrooms.
Stanton Hall, the Pilgrimage Garden Club showcase, is grand and well landscaped and has restaurants and overnight accommodation. Dunleith and Hawthorne have been glamorously modernized and thus have lost any period interior interest. Melrose has a lovely floor-through hallway, with doors opening to gardens at each end, like some English houses. Melrose also has hand-painted canvas-covered floors, originally to protect the wood, but very impractical and labor-intensive to us admiring them now.

 THE rest of my superlatives I save for a house called Longwood, an octagonal Oriental fantasy on the lines of Brighton Pavilion, built for Dr. Howard Nutt and his family by the Philadelphia architect Samuel Sloan. The drama about this house is that it was never finished. Eighteen months after it was begun in 1859, the Philadelphia masons and artisans imported by the architect rushed back North. Dr. Nutt, a Union sympathizer, lost all his money and died (aged 48) during the war, leaving his wife and eight children and their servants to live in the basement of the half-built house. At the end of the war the house was sold.
What is left is a symbol of the Old South so poignant that I doubt Margaret Mitchell herself could have come up with a better one. The exterior of Longwood is in perfect condition, down to its Byzantine arches and splendid onion dome. Inside, the house is a shell -- uncovered brick walls, bare supporting beams, naked niches for statuary and lighting. One can look up right up to the top of the dome's skeleton and admire the many wooden planks crisscrossing in a spiral of consummate carpentry. In one ground-floor corner of this echoing space is a stack of packing cases and open, wrecked, empty steamer trunks, all covered with a fine white dust, like archeological finds from a distant civilization. In fact, the whole effect reminded me overwhelmingly of Pompeii, with its ghostly rooms, its sense of life tragically interrupted.
Plans of the original house are on display, showing how the basement had been designated as a billiard room, game room and storage space, but became the hiding place where Mrs. Nutt and her family sat out the war. The basement is now filled with Nutt furniture and heirlooms. The gardens are mostly trees and ponds, no formal structure having been laid out before disaster struck.
Most of the surprisingly large estates of these Natchez houses are very rundown, which may disappoint critical gardeners (although not this one; I found them atmospheric and very touching). As a former owner of one of these houses remarked as we walked around Montaigne, "the biggest problem for people in this business is the upkeep of the gardens." I particularly enjoyed the five to seven acres of formal gardens at Elms Court, built, like most Natchez houses, on a knoll, as the owner, Grace McKittrick MacNeil, said, with terracing to control the rainwater runoff. "My father," she explained, "started using terraces for ornamental purposes." She also showed me a beautiful eglantine rosebush growing up her veranda in the middle of which a cardinal was sitting on its eggs. (Elms Court, unlike most other houses I visited, also has a plant list.) Another house with a lot of character is Elgin, a true plantation house dating from 1791, which also has a very interesting overgrown garden full of running-wild climbing roses, set in 50 acres of wilderness and woodland.
After a few days of exposure to these romantic settings, one certainly gets a powerful sense of what it was to live in the antebellum South, a sense fiercely promoted by the crinoline-clad women, many of them the owners themselves, who lead you through their precious mansions. (The religious connotation of the title "Pilgrimage" is no accident.) Actually, by the end I was desperately scurrying past the open doors of parlors and bedrooms to avoid the clutches of the eager belles in hooped skirts, who seemed never to grow weary of telling yet one more time about this beautiful four-poster bed or that crystal chandelier.
One night at dusk I took a restorative drive through the town of Natchez, away from the chic, manicured tourist areas toward the shabbier neighborhoods. Linton Avenue (on the way to the National Cemetery) seemed to me to express another side of the Natchez story -- antebellum homes as beautiful (although smaller) as the Pilgrimage tour houses, but neglected, unrestored, crumbling, with roses the size of cabbages blooming in the unkempt gardens.
This twilight trip stayed with me when I set out for the evening's entertainment. For the tourist's indoctrination doesn't end at sundown: I had the choice of the "Confederate Pageant," a star-spangled affair in the City Auditorium, presenting richly costumed tableaux of the South's finest moments, or "A Southern Road to Freedom," a musical show presented by the Holy Family Catholic Church Gospel Choir, which took place in a conference room of the Natchez Eola Hotel. I sprinted from one to the other on the same night, the juxtaposition affording a startling contrast. The "Confederate Pageant" made no reference to, nor indeed included performers from, the black population that my meager knowledge of American history tells me played a key role in the history of the area. The audience, jam-packed for this gala event, many dressed in sequins and silks, seemed not to have noticed this omission. The gospel singers, attended by a mixed, sparse audience, sang songs and told stories of their people from the slave days down to the present, and at the end we all sang "Amen," and shook hands. The implication of these concurrent happenings was hard to ignore.
"Before the War Between the States times were different," proclaimed the narrator at the "Confederate Pageant." "Before the war there were rustling silks, fluttering fans, and the perfume of lovely gardens. Romance, grandeur, chivalry, wealth -- all these are Natchez." The local real estate magnate in Natchez told me that several of the grand houses are up for sale (The Burn, $1.1 million; Linden, $900,000), and that buyers in search of silks and fluttering fans tend to come from Texas and California. Perhaps they bring some sense of reality with them to this stalwart corner of Dixieland. But Natchez may instead be gratefully recognized as the most precious living monument to the dreams of the Old South.
 
A VISITOR'S GUIDE TO ANTEBELLUM HOUSES

 
The Pilgrimages
In 1991, the Natchez Spring Pilgrimage runs from March 9 through April 7, and the Fall Pilgrimage from Oct. 5 through 25. At other times of year, 10 of the 30 houses remain open all day, including Rosalie, Lansdowne, Dunleith, Longwood, Melrose and Stanton Hall. For information, call Natchez Pilgrimage Tours at (800) 647-6742; it is at Canal at State Street, Post Office Box 347, Natchez, Miss. 39121.
During pilgrimage months, there are six tours, and each tour, consisting of up to five houses, goes from 9:30 A.M. to 1 P.M., and from 2 P.M. to 5:30 P.M. Thus, if you stay for three full days, you will cover every tour. Each house is open only on its tour day. The cost is $12 (three-house tour), $14 (four-house tour), or $16 (five-house tour). You must buy your tickets at the Natchez Pilgrimage Tours center.
Visitors can get around by car or a special bus, or with private guides ($50 for a half-day; $100 for a whole day).
There are good parking facilities everywhere in town and I did not see a parking meter in Natchez.
 
Where to Stay
For total saturation, you may actually stay the night in some of these houses, which offer a bed-and-breakfast service. These include Twin Oaks, Monmouth, D'Evereux, Linden, Melrose, Dunleith, Elgin, Stanton Hall, The Burn, Mount Repose and Hope Farm. For further information and room rates, call Natchez Pilgrimage Tours.
Another antebellum house converted into a guesthouse (seven rooms in the main house, plus six in cottages on the grounds) is The Briars, 31 Irving Lane, Post Office Box 1245, Natchez, Miss. 39120; (601) 446-9654 or (800) 634-1818, with the great advantage of a spectacular view over the Mississippi. Double room for two from $120, including breakfast.
Just below it, with more modern amenities is the Ramada Hilltop, 130 John R. Junkin Drive, Natchez, Miss. 39120; (601) 446-6311. Double room $58 in February, $64 starting March 1.
The other large modern chain-style hotel is the River Park Hotel, 645 South Canal Street, Natchez, Miss. 39120; (601) 446-6688. Double room $40 through February, then $65 from March 1 onward.
The best hotel in the center of town is the Natchez Eola, which has a handsome Victorian lobby with pillars, 110 North Pearl Street, Natchez, Miss. 39120; (800) 888-9140 outside Mississippi. Double room $60; $70 during Pilgrimage.
 
Where to Eat
Most restaurants are the paper-napkin-and-plastic-menu kind. Wherever I went I had good fried catfish, the local specialty, and anything with a spicy sauce was satisfactory.
The King's Tavern is the oldest building on the Natchez Trace (the dangerous 500-mile land route connecting Natchez with the rest of North America in the 18th and early 19th centuries), and shows its scars -- bullet holes, ancient wood beams, an interesting atmosphere in which to dine on steak and seafood; a three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine is about $50. The King's Tavern, 619 Jefferson, Natchez, Miss. 39120; (601) 446-8845.
The Cafe LaSalle and Juleps Restaurant, both in the Natchez Eola Hotel, (601) 445-6000, are well-designed and unusually pleasant for hotel restaurants. Juleps, open for lunch only, has a daily buffet for $4.95 ($7.95 on Sundays). Cafe LaSalle serves dinner, with an emphasis on seafood; a three-course dinner for two with wine is about $60.
The only restaurant with pretensions to serious cuisine has the off-putting name of The Pompous Palate. Don't be put off, however, for the menu is varied (quail, lobster, shrimp, crawfish enchiladas) and the cooking and service excellent. Address: Jefferson and Pearl; (601) 445-4946.
For a truly spectacular half-hour, I suggest a drink at the Natchez Landing or Cock of the Walk, where you can sip your mint julep while watching the sun set behind the huge bridge that arches across the Mississippi. Natchez Landing, 11 Silver Street; (601) 442-6639. Cock of the Walk, 15 Silver Street; (601) 446-8920. -- C. S.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 3; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 211 words

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: New Plant in Harlem;
Expanding a Doll House

 BODY:
Beatrice Behrman began making rag dolls in 1923 and by 1930 they had developed molded heads and limbs, eyelashes, fingers and the grand name their creator had assumed: Madame Alexander Dolls.
The famous little toys, always associated with a familiar story, important women or national costumes, still are produced in Harlem and many have become mother-to-daughter heirlooms.
Now the factory will be moving from 615 West 131th Street to a larger site on West 155th Street between Eighth Avenue and Macombs Place. No moving date has been set.
The New York State Urban Development Corporation is making a $33,500 grant to the New York City Public Development Corporation to help pay for preliminary environmental assessment at the 77,000-square-foot site.
The Alexander Doll Company plans to build a two-story, 121,425-square-foot plant to allow for the expansion of its workforce. The company, which was bought by outside investors in 1988, already employs 585 dollmakers, accounting for about a third of all light-manufacturing employment in Harlem, according to the Urban Development Corporation.
Mrs. Behrman died last year.
Most of the new site is city-owned and will be leased to the manufacturer, which will then buy the remainder from private owners.
