HEADLINE: The Rent Tug of War In Commercial Space

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
JEAN KAHN, a Manhattan baker, is a survivor of the real estate boom gone sour. The owner of Patisserie les Friandises, a croissant and cake shop on the Upper West Side, she has gone through four years of tenacious bargaining with her landlord.
She has threatened twice to move. As a result, she said, her rent, $60 a square foot when she signed a 10-year lease in 1986, has been cut almost in half to $32 a square foot.
And the tug of war continues. 
 "It's incredible how much vacant space is available," said Ms. Kahn, whose shop is on Amsterdam Avenue between 92d and 93d Streets. "I still might move."
Efforts like hers to bring down commercial rents are being made across New York City. Tenants, ranging from multinational corporations to tiny corner retailers, are demanding reductions, even before their current leases expire.
Legal skirmishes and financial brinksmanship abound. In a market where commercial leases normally run 5 to 25 years, with their crucial, long-term financial implications for business, experts say commercial tenants are approaching their landlords with an aggressiveness unlike anything in recent memory.
"Tenants see opportunities now that may not be available when the market gets out of the trough," said Steven A. Swerdlow, senior vice president of Coldwell Banker Commercial Real Estate Services, a New York brokerage.
One result is a new dynamic in commercial real estate.
During the mid-80's, owners of retail space demanded 50, 100 or even 200 percent increases on new leases, forcing many small enterprises to move or close, and making "gentrification" a dirty word in the New York vocabulary.
Now the shoe is on the other foot.
"In this market, any tenant who hasn't at least asked for a rent reduction is crazy," said Clark Wolf, a Manhattan consultant to retailers and restaurateurs.
Real estate executives point to many reasons for the shift. Vacancy rates of offices, stores and other commercial space are rising. Large corporations, particularly Wall Street firms, leased more space in the 80's than they needed -- and much more than they need in the current slump -- and are scrambling to sublet to other companies.
Some landlords are under additional pressure from their banks. Those who refinanced their properties in the early 80's, when interest rates plummeted from a peak of over 16 percent, typically did so with 10-year loans, and will soon seek extensions or new financing.
And since real estate lenders regard high vacancies as high risks, any landlord hoping for favorable treatment by his bank must do all he can to keep his tenants in place. All of which may be good for New York City.
"It has be positive," said Herbert Morse, senior managing partner at KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm. "The city remains an expensive place do business, but this should narrow the difference."
TWO major corporate tenants, Peat Marwick and the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, scrapped their existing leases on their Manhattan headquarters in January and negotiated long-term renewals. Although neither got a rent reduction, they did get commitments on their current space with little rent increase into the 21st century.
Peat Marwick's prior lease was not due to expire until 1994, but it signed a 15-year extension to 2006. Bristol-Myers's prior lease, not due to end until 1999, was extended to 2009.
Others have been unable to extricate themselves from leases on huge blocks of office space they no longer need and are trying to sublet to other companies, even if that means taking a loss.
One company with too much space is Merrill Lynch, which negotiated 25-year leases in the early 80's for 2.3 million square feet of offices in two new towers at the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan. Soon after the buildings were completed and Merrill Lynch began moving in 1985, it began looking for subtenants.
Merrill Lynch said it set aside $470 million from its its 1989 earnings, in part to cover the cost of its excess space.
In November, it said Nomura Securities International, a Japanese securities firm, had subleased 325,000 square of its space, but it is still trying to find tenants for 170,000 square feet more.
Some corporate tenants, meanwhile, have obtained steep rent reductions.
"For the first time I can remember, the cost is going down," said Bill Skellinger, vice president of Petry Television, which sells television advertising air time. After threatening to move, Petry renegotiated its lease in January on four floors of offices at 3 East 54th Street.
Although Mr. Skellinger declined to specify how much Petry is paying for its space, real estate executives close to the transaction said its rent was reduced more than 30 percent.
To be sure, the bargaining position of tenants is limited by their contractual obligations when they sign leases. Typically, tenants pay security deposits that equal one to two year's rent when they sign leases, an amount that would exceed $1 million for large corporations and over $100,000 for even small retailers. The deposit is immediately lost by those who break leases, and landlords can take legal action to hold tenants to other financial obligations.
Some tenants, particularly retailers and restaurateurs, also have large investments in the fixtures they install, which are normally sacrificed if they break their leases. Although rare, some also sign personal guarantees to landlords, meaning they pledge their personal assets -- as well as those of their business -- to guarantee that their leases will not be broken.
Still, business is business. Comparing what might be saved by breaking a lease to the cost of litigation, some have decided to take a walk.
"We've made a simple business decision," said Christopher Pine, head of real estate for Burke & Burke, a company with 15 Manhattan restaurants and gourmet food stores. Burke & Burke said last week that it had broken a 15-year lease for retail space in a Chemical Bank building at 95 Wall Street.
Chemical said it has sued, citing a $150,000 personal guarantee attached to the lease by Joe Burke, president of Burke & Burke. But Mr. Pine said the company was willing to pay the price of legal penalties.
"There is obviously a price affixed to walking away from a lease," he said. But because of layoffs and the weak economy in the financial district, the cost of operating a store on Wall Street would be higher. "We'll pay a settlement," he added.
SURVEYS indicate office vacancy rates, now over 16 percent throughout Manhattan, have been rising steadily since the mid-1980's. The Cushman & Wakefield brokerage said vacancies in modern, well located midtwon Manhattan buildings had risen to 17.2 percent in 1990 from 6.6 in 1984, and average rents had risen 9 percent to $40.26 a square foot.
Vacancies in the best office buildings in lower Manhattan reached a low of 9.8 percent in 1986, and rose to 16.1 percent last year, the company said. It said downturn rents fell 7 percent, to $32.99 a square foot.
Retail vacancies are also expanding. M & B Resources, a brokerage and consulting firm, said vacancies in Manhattan rose to 10.3 percent in 1990, after having between 9 percent and 9.5 percent in the 80's. It said the average price of retail space had more than doubled in the early 1980s, to a peak of $63.50 a square foot in 1986, but since then has fallen back slightly, to $59.25 a square foot last year.
Real estate executives say the result is clear to commercial tenants across the city. "Any tenant who signed a lease between 1981 and 1985 is now paying a lot more than the market, and any tenant who is at all sophisticated knows it," said Mitchell Steir, senior managing director of Julien J. Studley, a commercial brokerage in Manhattan.
He added that the disparity in rents on new or renegotiated leases now, and those signed in the early 80's, is even higher than the surveys suggest because of generous "escalator clauses" landlords obtained in the earlier transactions. Among these were "porter's wage" provisions, in which tenants agreed to cover wage increases for porters and other building employees.
Some of the provisions meant that the rent due on a lease signed in the early 80's has risen 50 percent, he said. And while tenants now negotiating leases immediately reject inflated escalator clauses, those who agreed to them years ago are demanding relief.
Indeed, not all negotiations have involved legal threats. "It's a double-edged sword," said Michael Hirschfeld, president of M & B Resources. "Landlords don't want their tenants to be forced out of business because they certainly don't want to be sitting on more vacant space in this market."
Stores, restaurants and other small businesses often abide by a formula that dictates spending no more than 10 percent of their gross income in rent. Mr. Hirschfeld said many of the tenant-landlord negotiations are based on the tenants simply demonstrating that their receipts have declined, and their rent has become too big a burden.
Large corporate tenants have a special advantage in dealing with their landlords, whose success rides partially on the prestige of the companies in their buildings.
"AT a time when both local and national economies are experiencing contraction, such leases provide an important expression of confidence in New YOrk City," said Mayor David Dinkins, who in January joined a press conference to announce the lease renewals by Peat Marwick and Bristol Myers. Both companies are headquartered at 345 Park Avenue, a 44 story building.
Although both companies declined to say what their rent bill will be, Lewis Rudin, their landlord, said the lease extensions give them "a firm fix" at what he termed "very reasonable rent."
"My crystal ball may not be any good, and maybe this space will be worth twice as much in five years," Mr. Rudin said. "But they put something on the table and so did we."
"There was no acrimony, no 11th hour threats," he added. "I think this is good testimony to cooperative tenant-landlord relations."
The case of Ms. Kahn, the Amsterdam Avenue baker, reflects how sharply business conditions have changed for many New York City tenants since the peak of the city's economic boom.
WHEN she opened her shop in 1986, paying $60 a square foot, Ms. Kahn said, her block was filled with book, furniture and stationery stores, and appeared to be emerging as a fashionable retailing center, drawing affluent costumers from among the young professionals who had flocked to the Upper West Side.
That began changing the year later, she said, when the stock market collapsed, the city turned a corner toward recession, drug dealers began appearing on the block, and her fellow retailers began going out of business. Now, she said, 40 percent of the stores, on her block are vacant.
James Goldstick, director of retail leasing for Mark Greenburg Real Estate, Ms. Kahn's landlord, said her situation was "a special one" because her block has gone through a "very difficult period."
Ms. Kahn said her business has survived mainly as a wholesale supplier of backed goods to hotels, delicatessens and restaurants elsewhere in the city. Even though her rent has been sharply reduced, she said she had not backed off from a tough bargaining position.
"I told my landlord if he wants me to stay, he better be nice," said Ms. Kahn, whose last round of negotiations with her landlord was in November. For now, she added, she has agreed to honor her lease only on a "month to month basis."

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Business Improvement Districts;
Banding Together for Local Betterment

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
FIRST they were called special assessment districts. Then, after the adoption of legislation by the New York State Legislature in 1982, they came to be known as business improvement districts. Sometimes the term is special services district.
By whatever name, they are commercial or industrial districts in which property owners assess themselves to provide funds to improve their environment. The assessments are mandatory and the money is collected by the municipality on the owners' behalf. 
 A district management association formed by the owners disburses it for purposes specified in a district's plan -- generally security and sanitation services, and street and sign improvements. There are 20 such districts in New York City already and 12 more in planning.
The largest one, the Grand Central Business Improvement District, is now on the verge of adding a new dimension to the concept. Its district management association, the Grand Central Partnership, plans to borrow $28 million to help finance an improvement program. The loan will be secured by the assessments that are paid by the 204 properties in the district to the city's Department of Finance, currently at a rate of 11.4 cents a square foot per year. The assessments are mandatory on owners.
With an inventory of 51 million square feet of space, roughly the same as downtown Los Angeles, the Grand Central district is hardly representative of business improvement districts generally. Most are on a much smaller scale. But the district is nevertheless a prime example of the ever more ambitious collaborative efforts among downtown property owners to improve and sustain the public environment, in their own interest and the municipality's.
And not just locally.
Richard Bradley, president of the International Downtown Association in Washington, says that there are about 1,000 such districts in the United States and they have been forming at an accelerating rate as states adopt the enabling legislation that gives the districts the power to tax their property owners. A total of 38 states have these laws so far.
In New Jersey, improvement districts have "taken off like a rocket" in the last three years, following the adoption of enabling legislation in 1984, said Lawrence Houstoun(cq), principal in the Atlantic Group, a consulting firm in Cranbury, N.J., and Philadelphia. Six are in operation -- in Engelwood, Cranford, New Brunswick, Elizabeth, Trenton and Somerville -- and at least two others are in formation, in Bayonne and, for industrial properties, Kearny.
Property owners in Newark are planning a major district, with about six million square feet of space and an initial budget of $1.2 million. And in Connecticut, where the term is "special services district," state officials estimate that there are 10 to 20, including two in New Haven and one in New Britain.
In New York City, a proposed improvement district for the 34th Street area would embrace 225 properties totaling 36 million square feet of space, with 140 owners. It is under review by community boards at present and could be in operation by next January. Other large districts are in planning stages for the Times Square area and for Metrotech, the large development undertaking in downtown Brooklyn.
Not everyone is sanguine about the growth of business improvement districts. The economist Robert B. Reich sees them as a further example of the "secession of the affluent" in American society, because they enable locations he describes as affluent to provide special services that are not available to the city generally. He cites the Grand Central district as an example.
HISTORICALLY, business associations have tried to assess their members on a voluntary basis to help meet mutual beneficial goals -- Christmas lighting displays in retail areas is a common kind of project. In the 70's, New York City began using community development funds to help local retail districts begin "community revitalization" programs, an effort that continues. The more successful of these have been transformed into true business improvement districts, making use of a 1982 law sponsored by Assemblyman John C. Dearie, a Bronx Democrat-Liberal. The law authorized the tax collection system.
In New York State, districts must have the support of at least 50 percent of the property owners, representing at least 50 percent of the property. In New York City, the district must win approvals from the community-board, the City Planning Commission and, since last year, the City Council. It is an arduous process that depends for success on committed business leadership.
The impetus for the Grand Central district came from the Grand Central Partnership, an association of property owners, at the suggestion of Kenneth Lipper, former Deputy Mayor for Economic Development in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, in 1985. The partnerships's chairman is Peter Malkin, general partner in the ownerships of the Lincoln Building at 60 East 42d Street and the Graybar Building at 420 Lexington Avenue. Among the large owners who signed on are Olympia & York Properties, Metropolitan Life and Manufacturers Hanover Trust. It took two and a half years to get owner and public approval through Community Boards 5 and 6, the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate.
In the district's first year, 1989, assessments of 9.2 cents a square foot produced $4.7 million. The district now collects $5.8 million at its 11.4-cent-a-square-foot rate. (Property taxes paid to the city typically run from $5 to $12 a square foot.) The Partnership's total budget is $8 million, which includes grants and contracts for social services, principally for a program to aid the homeless in the Grand Central area. About half the work force of 185 does street cleaning or security work. Security personnel wear uniforms, but carry no arms.
WHAT lies ahead is a $28 million borrowing through a public agency at tax-exempt rates that will pay for an ambitious program of improvements on city property. After consultations with community boards, the street improvements must be approved by the New York City Arts Commission or the Department of Transportation or the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The first $2.5 million will be spent on the floodlighting of Grand Central Terminal, said Daniel Biederman, president of the Partnership.
New street lights, trash receptacles, signs, plantings and possibly paving insets along 43d Street between Fifth and Vanderbilt Avenues and south to 42d Street are being planned. If approved, installed and successful, similar treatments will be extended throughout the district.
The beneficiaries, Mr. Biederman says, are not property owners, businesses and office tenants alone but, perhaps more conspicuously, average New Yorkers who use the streets. Services and benefits will be provided that would seem an unwarranted luxury if the city paid for them, and it wouldn't, he said.
The model -- the inspiration, it might be said -- for the Grand Central district is Rockefeller Center, whose remarkably well-tended environment covers 22 acres and two miles of underground concourses. The tending is done by almost 2,000 maintenance people, either on staff or under contract, said Lorian L. Marlantes, president of Rockefeller Center Management Corporation.
"Two nights a week we use steam devices to take the chewing gum off the sidewalks," said Mr. Marlantes.
It is at the small neighborhood level rather than in the central business district that most of the business improvement districts have been formed. The city's Office of Business Development and its predecessor agencies have helped 160 commercial districts establish revitalization programs since the 70's. Fourteen of these have "graduated" to self-subsidized business improvement districts, said Barbara Wolff, the assistant commissioner who has long directed the program.
Assessment methods differ. At the Hub in the Bronx -- Third Avenue from 148th to 153d Streets, established in 1988 -- owners pay $85 a front foot. The budget this year is $256,000. On Grand Street in Brooklyn's Williamsburg-Bushwick section, assessments are based on a formula combining front footage with assessed valuation. The budget is $65,000.
"We're encouraging more business improvement districts," said David A. Smith, commissioner in the Office of Business Development. "It's a marvelously flexible tool."

GRAPHIC: Map: "Business Improvement Districts," shows existing and planned districts in greater New York City (Source: New York city Office of Business Development)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: East Side Rehabilitation;
Creating New Roles For Art Deco Buildings

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
IF not alpha, there was at least omega, and many others besides: lambda, rho, delta, gamma, theta, zeta and pi. Hidden almost three decades behind a "modern" travertine facade, these deeply carved Greek letters came surprisingly to light during the renovation of the Beekman Tower Hotel.
They attest to the origins of the hotel, on the corner of First Avenue and 49th Street, as Panhellenic House, a 28-story residence for young women from out of town who belonged to Greek-letter sororities. 
 During the renovation, which is nearing completion, the letters were revealed, as were two panels with highly geometric, Art Deco-style fountains and the cornerstone, which reads "1928."
These features have now been restored or replicated. Although the owners and their architect did not set out on an archeological mission, their discoveries were of particular interest, since the all-suite Beekman Tower is being considered for landmark status.
It is one of several landmarks or landmark-caliber properties between First and Second Avenues that are being rehabilitated.
The former Beaux-Arts Institute of Design, 304 East 44th Street, is another vivid Art Deco building from 1928, enlivened by painted terra-cotta panels showing the architecture of Athens, Paris and Rome. It is being recreated as the headquarters of the American Federation of Musicians and Employers Pension Fund, a subsidiary of which owns the building, to designs by Milo Kleinberg Design Associates of Manhattan.
Two blocks south is the 21-story Tudor Hotel, 304 East 42d Street. It is on the western edge of Tudor City, which was completed in 1928 by the Fred F. French Company, and is part of the Tudor City Historic District. But unlike the apartment buildings, with their Tudor-style architectural embellishments, the hotel is a much purer, modernistic composition.
In 1989, a rehabilitation and restoration project began, in affiliation with Sarova Hotels of London. "We're hoping to have a four-star hotel operating by mid-spring," said Fred Dinerstein, general manager of the Tudor. There will be 303 room and 14 suites. The architect is Vijay Kale of Manhattan and the owner is Charles Goldberg of Queens.
One nearby building whose much-discussed renovation has gone nowhere is the former United Nations School at First Avenue and 51st Street. This 99-year-old structure was built as Public School 35 and is being used as a shelter for homeless women. Last Monday, 172 women were housed there.
Since 1983, the city has been trying to sell the building -- with a requirement that the Romanesque Revival facade be preserved -- in the hope that it would be redeveloped. But five prospective purchasers, most recently a Florida developer who could not get needed financing, have either walked away from the project or been eliminated.
Today, the city has no immediate plans for the building other than to keep using it as a shelter, said a spokesman for the General Services Department, given the cost of relocating the people who stay there, as well as the building's recent sales history. Eventually, the Public Development Corporation may offer the property again in a negotiated sale.
Meanwhile, work at the Beekman Tower is almost complete. It was undertaken by Manhattan East Suite Hotels, a nine-hotel chain owned by the Denihan family. The architect was Douglas F. Korves of Manhattan.
Benjamin Denihan and Arthur W. Bresciani bought the hotel in 1963. "We gutted the building and turned it into an apartment-hotel," said Daniel Denihan, Benjamin's nephew, who is a managing partner of Manhattan East, which is based in Manhattan.
The hotel drew much of its business from United Nations missions and from large corporations that needed rooms with kitchens for weeks at a time, to house employees who were being trained or relocated.
By the late 1980's, the 170-room hotel was showing its age. "The rooms needed a complete facelift," said Donald G. Denihan, Benjamin's son, who is also a managing partner. Guests had been loyal but the occupancy level dropped between 1987 and 1988. "It was starting to show in the numbers," said Robert Hansen, the general manager.
AS a result of the renovation, the lobby, a dark space with a heavy Victorian feeling to it, was lightened considerably. A giant settee in the form of a geometric sunburst became the centerpiece. The ground-floor restaurant -- Peartree's, for many years -- was rebuilt as the Zephyr Grill, with decoration inspired by the streamlined trains of that name. Upstairs, the guest rooms got new carpets, furniture and paint.
A one-bedroom suite, with a full bathroom, a powder room and a kitchen that includes a dishwasher and microwave oven, can run between $180 and $245 a night.
Panhellenic House was designed by John Mead Howells, who also won the famous competition for Tribune Tower in Chicago. The starkly powerful hotel has none of the Gothicism of Tribune Tower, however.
"In the huge, square monolith, one feels the vertical steel structure under the sheathing of concrete and brick," declared an article in The New York Times in 1928, which described the tower as "an outstanding example of American skyscraper architecture."
Although the building is not an official landmark, it has been proposed for landmark status. Therefore, the Buildings Department would not approve work without review by the staff of the landmarks commission. "We even had to get approval to take the travertine off to find out what was underneath," Mr. Korves said. "The landmarks staff was delighted to hear that we found the fountain panels and Greek letters."
IT happened that Mr. Korves had long admired the Beekman Tower and did not envision radical alterations. "When you work in a building as historic as this -- even if it isn't technically a landmark -- you have to do it with a light hand and respect the original architect," he said.
"The work that the architect is doing is very good design and very sympathetic to the building," said Tracie Rozhon, spokeswoman for the landmarks commission. "This is a wonderful example of why we encourage architects to work with us even before a building is designated."
As successful as the renovation may have been, the Beekman Tower is suffering from the effects of the recession, the war in the Persian Gulf and the collapse of Eastern Airlines. Its occupancy rate in January was 65 percent. But in general, Daniel Denihan said, occupancy had been "pretty strong" in the all-suite Manhattan East chain.

HEADLINE: Sludge: New Focus On Recycling

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE day is near, officials and environmentalists say, when the waste flushed down kitchen sinks, toilets and industrial drains will be filtered, processed, packaged and ultimately sold as fertilizer, ground cover and even decorative mulch to be spread around shrubs and flower beds.
Prompted by impending Federal and state bans on ocean dumping of sewage sludge, municipal utility authorities and sewage treatment plant officials across the state are reassessing their long-term plans for disposal of the solid wastes contained in sewage. 
 At the same time, faced with marked increases in costs no matter what alternative disposal method they choose, and aware of the public's opposition to incineration, officials are finding that beneficial uses for sludge are often economically and environmentally preferable to burning or burying it.
Notwithstanding the trend toward the recycling of sludge, however, officials of some of the state's largest sewage treatment plants say they may be forced to adopt incineration unless Federal regulators grant them more time to assess alternatives and to develop stringent pretreatment requirements for industrial sewage.
 
'No Longer the Nefarious Product'
 At the same time, state environmental officials have also expressed a change in attitude toward the burning of sludge, a method that had been previously considered acceptable. The officials are now establishing a task force to look into alternative methods for dealing with the estimated two million dry pounds of sludge that New Jersey residents and businesses produce every day.
 "Sludge is no longer the nefarious product that it has been publicized as over many years," said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Protection. "We feel that we can now treat it as a commodity instead of a waste."
Officials say that compost derived from sludge can be used as fertilizer and cover material on athletic fields, golf courses, highway roadsides and the almost half-million acres of harvested cropland in the state.
 Indeed, in a report issued by the department in last November, officials estimated that markets existed for 100 percent of the sludge now generated in New Jersey. Currently, only 10 percent of the state's sludge is being recycled through land application.
 
Destroying Harmful Organisms
 Dr. Karen J. Giroux, assistant director of the New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, said that sludge that was relatively clean to begin with -- free of heavy metals often found in industrial sewage -- could be composted and then used as a fertilizer or as a nutrient for non-food-chain crops. Composting is a natural process that destroys harmful organisms by biologically generating heat when wood chips are added.
With effective pretreatment to remove heavy metals, Dr. Giroux said, "the final product of composting is essentially pathogen-free and a useful product for improving soil fertility."
The Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority, for example, now sends all its sludge to a plant in Philadelphia to be composted and takes the compost back when it is finished. The county then uses it for the top layer of several landfills.
"Compost is licensed by the New Jersey Department of Agriculture as a specialty fertilizer," said Dennis W. Palmer, director of operations for the Camden authority. "Nurserymen can use it, and professionals can use it as top dressing around plants."
Camden County officials are so pleased with the results of their sludge composting program, Mr. Palmer said, that they are now designing their own composing plant, which will handle up to 250 wet tons of sludge each day.
But while most experts agree that recycling sludge is preferable to incinerating it, a large percentage of the state's sludge is still scheduled to be burned.
The Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission, for example, which processes almost a quarter of all the waste water in New Jersey, has applied for a permit to build a sludge incinerator for the estimated 500 dry tons of sludge that it produces each day.
"We've calculated that it would be less costly to the taxpayers to incinerate," said Carmine T. Perrapato, executive director of the commission. "But when you mention the word 'incineration,' unfortunately it's not very well received."
As a result, Mr. Perrapato said, though the commission is still going forward with its incinerator permit application, it is also hiring consultants to assess other potential methods of treating the sludge. "Right now," he said, "our aim is incineration until somebody comes to us and says, 'Here is a plan that will work.' "
 Passaic Valley is one of six New Jersey sewage treatment plants that have been dumping sludge in the Atlantic Ocean at a site 106 miles offshore. The five others -- the Bergen County Utilities Authority, the Joint Meeting of Essex and Union Counties, the Linden Roselle Sewerage Authority, the Middlesex County Utilities Authority and the Rahway Valley Sewerage Authority -- along with Passaic Valley, account for almost 58 percent of the total sludge produced in the state.
Several years ago the Federal Government ordered the offshore site closed to New Jersey dumpers as of Dec. 31, 1991. But the State Legislature, concerned that dumping contributed to the pollution that closed several beaches in the summers of 1987 and 1988, imposed its own deadline of March 17, 1991.
Lawsuits generated by the Federal closure order resulted in court-approved agreements among the six authorities, the Environmental Protection Agency and the State Department of Environmental Protection. Those agreements require the authorities to develop short-term and long-term sludge disposal plans by specific deadlines.
 Most of the short-term plans developed involve shipping the sludge to out-of-state landfills. And while almost all of the original long-term plans initially contemplated incineration, at least three of the authorities now plan to recycle their sludge.
Middlesex County, for example, will be converting its sludge into a soil product that will be used as cover at a county-operated landfill. The county currently has to purchase the cover material it uses.
Despite that savings, however, the change from ocean dumping will still be an expensive one for Middlesex. "It means about $10.6 million in additional costs," said Frederick Kurtz, executive director of the Middlesex County Utilities Authority. Ocean dumping costs Middlesex County about $4 million each year. Recycling the county's daily production of 120 dry tons of sludge will cost about $15 million a year.
 
Sludge Quality at Issue
 The Rahway Valley Sewerage Authority, which originally chose incineration as its long-term solution, recently modified its plans to allow for recycling of its sludge. And though the cost of recycling the sludge is three to four times more expensive than ocean dumping, said Richard Tokarski, executive director of the authority, officials found that it was less expensive than incineration.
 The ability to recycle, however, depends upon the quality of the sludge itself. The quality of a given area's sludge is often adversely affected by the presence of a large number of industrial contributors to the waste stream, whose sludge contains heavy metals like copper, cadmium and lead. The only way to improve sludge quality in such an area is to require pretreatment of the waste water at the point of emission and before it gets to the main treatment plant.
 And that, officials say, takes time and money.
The Bergen County Utilities Authority, for example, is required under its consent agreement to have long-term plans in place by September.
Anticipating that requirement, and proceeding in accordance with previous state policy, officials there developed plans for the construction of a sludge incinerator in Little Ferry.
 
Public Opposition Grows
 Over the last few years, however, public opposition to incineration has intensified while official support for the burning of sludge has dwindled. Indeed, state environmental officials are now encouraging the beneficial use of treated sludge and are discouraging incineration.
But that has left large sewerage authorities like those in Bergen County, Passaic County and the Joint Meeting of Essex and Union Counties with expensive incinerator projects still on the drawing board. And with the time constraints imposed by the consent agreements, those authorities have little choice but to go forward with their original plans unless the Federal Environmental Protection Agency agrees to extend their deadlines.
 Such an extension is needed in Bergen County, said Larry J. McClure, executive director of the Bergen County Municipal Utilities Authority, to give officials there time to improve sludge quality.
 
'Wasting Public Money'
 "We're talking about going out and monitoring all the industrial dischargers and forcing them to upgrade their pretreatment systems," Mr. McClure said. "We probably need at least another year. In the meantime, we are literally wasting public money having to pursue false avenues."
The State Department of Environmental Protection, in an effort to develop a comprehensive state policy for sludge disposal, is now assembling a task force to examine such issues and to propose new regulations.
And while incineration will not be expressly prohibited by the new regulations, greater emphasis will be directed at assessing pretreatment and beneficial-use options, said Judith A. Yaskin, Commissioner of Environmental Protection. Ms. Yaskin will be stepping down as Commissioner on Friday.
Anticipating the one issue that often arises with recycling, Ms. Yaskin said insuring a market for the recycled sludge would also be addressed.
But with 300 landfills throughout the state needing land cover, she said, and with millions of acres of agricultural land needing fertilizer, finding a market for treated sludge should not be a problem.
"We've got the supply, and we've got the demand," Ms. Yaskin said. "And we will never again have to resort to dumping in the ocean."

HEADLINE: Newcomer Creates a Stir in Corridors of Power

BYLINE: By States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
REPRESENTATIVE Robert E. Andrews has been in Washington only 100 days, but he has already begun causing a stir.
Pundits called Mr. Andrews, Democrat of Bellmawr, the "miracle child" for overcoming the anti-Democratic sentiment that almost unseated Senator Bill Bradley. New Jersey lawmakers have praised Mr. Andrews's instant popularity. And he has attracted attention throughout Congress as one of only two lawmakers to vote against war in the Persian Gulf under any circumstances. 
 "Rob Andrews has made more of an impact in a few weeks than I have seen many members make in a few months or even a few years," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood. "He has become known and established."
Mr. Andrews, 33 years old, is one of the youngest Democrats ever to have been chairman of the Camden County Board of Chosen Freeholders, and now he is the youngest Democrat in Congress. A Camden native with a bachelor's degree from Bucknell University and a law degree from Cornell, he is eager to share his ideas and plans.
He is confident of where the Democratic Party -- even Congress as a whole -- should be going. And he is having a great time.
 
'The Best Job in America'
 "It's the best job in America," Mr. Andrews said, sitting in his office in the House Longworth Building. The bookshelves are still bare; the desk is tidy and uncluttered.
Mr. Andrews is one of 44 new House members and one of two from New Jersey. The other, Representative Richard Zimmer, 47, a Republican, replaced James A. Courter in the 12th District.
Both New Jersey freshmen are lawyers, the class's most popular occupation. The newcomers' average age is 54, and they represent an eclectic mix, from Bernard Sanders of Vermont, a Socialist, to Gary Franks of Connecticut, the first black Republican in the House in 56 years.
But Mr. Andrews has got a jump on most of his classmates, taking over Gov. Jim Florio's former seat in the First District as soon as election results were certified on Nov. 10. Wiry and energetic, Mr. Andrews can hardly contain his excitement. He attends every Persian Gulf briefing, welcomes all lobbyists, returns every reporter's telephone call. The only thing like it that he can remember, he says, is waiting as a child for Christmas morning to arrive.
"I literally woke up one night at 4 o'clock in the morning when I was down here and couldn't go back to sleep, because I couldn't wait for the day to begin," he said. "I mean, all the things I was going to do."
 On a typical day, Mr. Andrews has plenty to keep him busy. One recent day began at 8 A.M. with a briefing on the Persian Gulf from Adm. William J. Crowe, retired, former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. For Mr. Andrews, the debate over the war has proved the greatest challenge of his first days in Congress.
"It's hard to imagine a more compelling decision that one would have to be a part of than the decision to send young Americans to die," he said. Like his colleagues, he had to choose between authorizing force in the gulf or calling on President Bush to exhaust diplomacy and sanctions before resorting to force.
 
Both Options Rejected
 After extensive meetings with constituents, who, he said, largely opposed military action, Mr. Andrews rejected both options. The only other member of Congress to do so was Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon. Mr. Andrews said that even the second resolution calling for sanctions and diplomacy did not ultimately rule out war.
"I was not against sanctions," he said. "I took the vote for reasons of clarity, and taking a definite stand. I did not want to be in a situation where I had authorized war, because I felt it was not the proper policy."
Democratic colleagues responded with respect. "It was a very thoughtful and conscientious decision and evoked a lot of admiration on my part," said Representative Thomas Foglietta, Democrat of Pennsylvania.
Mr. Andrews says that now that the United States is at war, however, he fully supports the President. And briefings like the one with Admiral Crowe have helped him explain the war to constituents back home, Mr. Andrews said.
At 9 A.M. Mr. Andrews returned to his office for a meeting with Stephen Minikes, a lobbyist for the City of Philadelphia. The topic: how to save the Philadelphia Naval Yard.
This is Mr. Andrews's top legislative priority this year. With base closings on the horizon, he is worried about the shipyard and the 3,000 people in his district who work there. He and Mr. Minikes agreed on a strategy that would highlight the shipyard's new role in the war. The aircraft carrier Saratoga, which was rehabilitated at the shipyard, has been sent to the gulf, Mr. Andrews pointed out.
"Part of the prior argument against the yard is that these kinds of ships were obsolete," he said. "What has happened in the last 30 days has really put the lie to that argument."
Next, Mr. Andrews headed to the Capitol Building for a meeting of the Democratic Steering and Policy Committee. Once there, he had no compunction about asking a guard where to find Room 114. His ego is not on the line, he said, as is the case with some freshmen who pretend to be experts and end up wandering the halls for hours.
"I'd rather get to the meeting and show a little humility," he said.
Mr. Andrews takes care at all times to wear the square gold pin that identifies him as a member of the 102d Congress. "I wear it so people don't think I'm a page, actually," he said.
 
Reviewing the Schedule
 After a pro forma vote to elect Representative Paul E. Kanjorski, Democrat of Pennsylvania, as regional Democrat whip, Mr. Andrews returned to his office for a 10:30 A.M. staff meeting. The first order of business was to review the day's schedule. "So everyone, especially me, knows what they're doing," said Mr. Andrews, who loves to joke with staff members, visitors and friends.
Mr. Andrews admitted to being somewhat scatterbrained about life's more practical details. Day-to-day domestic responsibilities are apparently not his forte. Fran Callanan, Mr. Andrews's scheduling secretary, has a lock on his schedule, and an accountant handles his finances.
But when it comes to discussing legislation with his staff, Mr. Andrews is in his element. One bill on his agenda was a measure, written by Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of Ocean City, that requires states to follow uniform beach testing standards. The bill has unanimous support from the New Jersey Congressional delegation, but Mr. Andrews had questions.
"Why do we need a Federal law telling us to do that?" he wanted to know. Characteristically, he was resistant to a law that would rob states of local control.
 
Concern for Middle Class
 "I would like to be known as someone who brought middle-class people back into public policy," Mr. Andrews said. "And this is a New Jersey concern, because we are such a middle-class state. But I think it's a concern that plays on the national stage as well."
Mr. Andrews also takes a hard line on protecting the flag. He and his skeptical staff began a debate on First Amendment rights, patriotism, the distinction between action and speech. This easy back- and-forth of ideas and arguments was his favorite part of the day.
But as the time for an appointment approached, Mr. Andrews sent away the staff and welcomed Susan J. Loomis, a lobbyist with the Associated General Contractors of America.
"I wanted to come by and welcome you," said Ms. Loomis, assuring Mr. Andrews that she knew they would not always agree, but that all she wanted was "an opportunity to be heard on the issues."
Ms. Loomis leaned forward to make sure Mr. Andrews understood the association's position. Among other things, the association fears that a new bill discouraging companies from hiring replacements for striking workers could tie employers' hands. Ken Holdsman, Mr. Andrews's legislat ive director, was sympathetic, but Mr. Andrews jumped in.
"I will tell you right up front that I am for that," he said of the bill. With Ms. Loomis, as with other lobbyists, Mr. Andrews made no promises.
 
A Ceremonial Duty
 Just before noon, Mr. Andrews headed back to the Capitol Building for a luncheon with Mr. Torricelli. But first he had a ceremonial duty on the Capitol steps. Michael Owen, a senior from West Deptford High School, was in Washington with the National Young Leaders Conference. Mr. Owen arrived at the Capitol wearing black earmuffs and a New Jersey pin, ready with his camera for a photograph with Mr. Andrews.
Friendly and chatty, Mr. Andrews asked Mr. Owen about his college plans. After smiles and clicks, Mr. Andrews ducked inside to meet Mr. Torricelli, whose advice helped Mr. Andrews land seats on committees with an economic emphasis: the House Education and Labor Committee and the Small Business Committee.
"Rob Andrews represents a lot of what I hope will come to prevail in the Democratic Party," Mr. Torricelli said. "He is idealistic, but he has a clear, practical understanding of how to get things done. Some of his instincts may be liberal, but he has a moderate approach."
The afternoon left Mr. Andrews time to telephone a long list of reporters. But in midsentence he was startled by a nasal, buzzing sound. "What do all those bells and buzzers mean?" he asked his staff, nervously pacing the office.
A quick call established that in 10 minutes, Mr. Andrews would have to vote on whether to condemn Iraq's attack of Israel, its treatment of prisoners of war and Soviet violence in the Baltics.
"We're voting 'yes' on all of these, in case anybody calls," he yelled, dashing out the door.
 
Shouts From Members
 At 3:45 P.M., the House floor was mayhem. Members stood in clusters and pairs, shouting at the top of their lungs while a chairman pounded vainly on the gavel. Mr. Andrews was there, almost indistinguishable from his colleagues in a charcoal gray suit, white shirt and gray tie.
By 5:45, after going through his mail and getting visits from more lobbyists, the office was empty. But for Mr. Andrews, the day was not yet over. Two receptions awaited him, given by important potential allies: the American Association of Retired Persons and the American Federation of Government Employees.
At both, Mr. Andrews was enthusiastically greeted by lobbyists who steered him to leading officials for warm handshakes, greetings and small talk. Mr. Andrews was courteous and attentive, ignoring the ample food and drink.
A quick cab ride took him back to Capitol Hill. Mr. Andrews had no social plans, no wife waiting with dinner on the stove. And so, at 8 P.M., he entered a fast-food place on Pennsylvania Avenue before heading back to his empty apartment.

HEADLINE: Free Acres Journal;
A Haven Where Residents Own the Houses but Not the Land

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: FREE ACRES

 BODY:
COMMUTERS cruising along Interstate 78 as it slices through the Watchung Mountains are likely to be unaware that they have just passed through one of the most unusual little communities in New Jersey.
Behind the trees that fill the gorge to the north of the superhighway, a 70-acre enclave known as Free Acres inches slowly into the 1990's while residents fondly stoke the embers of its quasi-utopian past. 
 Free Acres, not a municipality itself but a small sliver of Berkeley Heights, was established 81 years ago by the son of a Presbyterian minister who disdained the idea of individual ownership of property. The community, which now consists of 84 families, is something like a condominium, something like a cooperative and something like a miniature municipality.
But residents say it is nothing like anywhere else in the world.
"I feel like I'm protected in a little cocoon," said Geraldine Runfeldt, 65 years old, who has lived in Free Acres with her husband, Theodore, for 40 years. "I feel like we're all bound together here," she said.
Mrs. Runfeldt is Free Acres' town clerk. She organizes the monthly meetings, keeps track of residents' suggestions and complaints, and records the births and deaths that make any community a changing thing.
"There's just a feeling of family here," Mrs. Runfeldt said. "I know that if something ever happened to me or my husband, there would be a lot of people around who care. It's a very protected feeling."
 Free Acres was founded on the philosophy of Henry George, a 19th-century journalist and economist who believed that land should be owned by the community rather than by individuals. Residents can build houses on lots they lease, but they can never actually own the land. A single annual tax is charged to cover public services like road repair and maintenance of common buildings.
 
Run by Three Elected Trustees
 In 1910, Bolton Hall, a devotee of George, deeded about 68 acres of land he owned in Berkeley Heights and New Providence to the Free Acres Association, a corporation organized to manage the community. The association, now run by three elected trustees, sets policy, enforces rules, keeps track of finances and collects the annual tax from each resident. The association then pays a single tax on the land to Berkeley Heights; residents pay taxes only on their houses.
Leases, which run for 99 years, are automatically renewed for another 99 years each time a property is "sold," and when a leaseholder dies and passes his or her interest to heirs.
"If you really want to get picky about it, we're a combination between a condominium and a co-op," said Joseph Romano, a Free Acres resident. "But if you read the lease, you'll go crazy. If you just sign it and live here and have a good time, you'll be fine."
In Free Acres, it is not considered a bad investment to build a $300,000 home next to a tiny summer bungalow, nor is it odd to buy a small summer bungalow and then put a $200,000 addition onto the back. But it would be quite startling to see someone chopping down a tree.
The association prohibits cutting down trees more than four feet high and three inches in diameter.
The community represents all levels of occupational achievement. It attracts lawyers and laborers, students and scholars, successful architects and, sometimes, starving artists.
"We rented Jimmy Cagney's cottage," said Dr. Fanny Stoll, 88, a physician who bought a home in Free Acres in 1939 after spending a few summers renting from the actor. "The houses were mainly little shacks then. Now they're a little more elegant."
Laurel Hessing, Dr. Stoll's daughter and the unofficial historian of Free Acres, said the community was originally an artists' colony with "a lot of left-wingers" spending the summer in tents and unheated shacks. Over the years, she said, cottages were built on the tent platforms, additions were built onto the shacks and Free Acres began to take on its eclectic but charming hodgepodge appearance.
"Every house has a distinct character," Mrs. Hessing said.
Indeed, no two houses even remotely resemble each other, in style, age or value. Aside from that, it seems to be anyone's guess as to what makes the place special.
"One of the things that makes Free Acres so unique is simply that it has lasted so long," said Martin Bierbaum, a 45-year-old resident who is a lawyer with a doctorate in urban planning. "This community has remained intact for six generations," Mr. Bierbaum said. "Part of the reason is because the community was never static; it was able to bend. And you can't underestimate the nature of the landholding arrangement either."
Jean Brodgesell, 35, who moved to Free Acres nine years ago, said that part of what made the tiny community different was that residents had a greater sense of control than they would in a larger municipality.
"We get to decide how our money is spent," Mrs. Brodgesell said. "We decide what roads need to be paved, and how we want to deal with our forest and our trees."
Donald Heerens, a financial consultant who moved here in 1974, said that being part of such an intimate community drew people together on issues of common interest.
"When you meet your neighbors once a month, you get to know them pretty quickly," he said, referring to the monthly meetings to discuss issues of interest to the community.
Another thing that brings residents of Free Acres together is its children.
"Before I had kids, I didn't know who anybody was," said Laure Holsten, 27, at a recent meeting of the children's play group. "We were ready to move out, and then there was this major population explosion."
That explosion, Ms. Holsten said, accounts for the more than 20 children who now attend the play group weekly at a community-owned farmhouse, parents in tow. And that has an advantage for the parents as well.
"You can't believe how many people I'm friendly with now," Mrs. Holsten said.
But the Free Acres philosophy is perhaps best expressed by Zelda Benjamin, 92, a former actress who moved here with her husband, an artist, in 1937.
"Children form relationships for life here," Mrs. Benjamin said. "Friendships stay very strong, and anybody who goes away always tries to come back."
She looked out the window and through the trees at the dozens of backyards connected to one another by trails that meander randomly through the heart of Free Acres. "See, there are no fences here," she said. "And we wouldn't want it to be otherwise."

HEADLINE: Campus Life: U.C.L.A.;
Upgraded Status Urged For Chicano Studies

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The Mexican-American com munity of Southern California last week pressured the University of California at Los Angeles to recognize the region's close cultural ties with Mexico by establishing a full-fledged academic department devoted to Chicano studies.
At a news conference on Olvera Street -- the historic heart of the Mexican community in Los Angeles -- a community coalition called the United Community and Labor Alliance formally joined a U.C.L.A. student group, Movimiento Estudiantil Chicano de Aztlan, in advocating the elevation of what is currently an undergraduate interdisciplinary major -- and a troubled one at that. 
 U.C.L.A. granted $150,000 for this academic year to buttress the program, which lacked office space, a counselor and, according to one Faculty Senate committee, a viable curriculum structure.
University officials said Chicano studies enrolls between 11 and 15 majors and graduates 3 or 4 each year.
But advocates say that Chicano studies is troubled precisely because it does not have department status.
"A department would help train teachers and social workers who could then serve the Los Angeles Chicano community," said John Fernandez, who is on the board of directors of the teachers union, the United Teachers of Los Angeles.
 
 Suspending Admissions
 Campus debate over a Chicano studies department began last February when a Faculty Senate committee recommended that the university suspend new admissions to the major until the program was strengthened.
Since then, students have been meeting regularly with members of the Los Angeles Mexican-American community, including the alliance, which comprises about 40 labor organizations, merchants and political groups, to muster support for a department devoted to the study of the social, cultural, economic and historical development of people of Mexican descent, both in the United States and Mexico.
Citing their frustrations with U.C.L.A.'s bureaucracy, students have also tried cutting through the red tape by writing letters to administrators and politicians, drawing up proposals, attending meetings of various university committees and organizing rallies, including a candlelight vigil at the campus residence of Charles Young, U.C.L.A.'s chancellor.
While several faculty members support creating the department, administrators question whether it is in the university's best interest. Questions like "Is a department the best use of our resources?" need to be answered first, Raymund Paredes, the associate vice chancellor, said in a telephone interview last week.
 
Hard to Recruit Faculty
 He also said it would be difficult for U.C.L.A. to recruit enough faculty members to begin a department because most professors would rather be in conventional departments, Mr. Paredes said. Mr. Paredes himself occasionally teaches Chicano literature courses in the English department.
Chancellor Young has opposed establishing a department for what he considers to be an unconventional discipline, but he is waiting for recommendations from a faculty committee on what to do next.
Vilma Ortiz, a sociology professor who favors establishing a department, said the large volume of work produced in the last 20 years makes Chicano studies a legitimate field of study.
Proponents also say that many interests would be served by establishing a department. "It is important politically for the Mexican community of Los Angeles to point out to U.C.L.A. that for 20 years they have been requesting this kind of education for our youth," said Marcos Aguilar, a junior history major. Mr. Aguilar is one of the almost 3,000 Mexican-American students who make up nearly 9 percent of U.C.L.A.'s 36,000 undergraduate and graduate students.
But Ms. Ortiz, who is working to develop a strong curriculum for the program, said, "Faculty never had time to devote a lot of energy to better the curriculum, which is important. It needs to be institutionalized in a way that will make it stable."

HEADLINE: Commercial Paper Has Troubles, Too

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Banks are not the only lenders tightening credit in these hard times. Some borrowers are having trouble tapping another source of short-term cash -- the commercial paper market, which some analysts had hoped would give a few companies refuge from the credit crunch.
The $740 billion worldwide commercial paper market is in the throes of a shakeout, as the recession, a series of defaults and a proposed regulation force buyers to keep a stricter eye on quality. Although it grew 500 percent in the expansive 80's by serving as a cheaper alternative to bank financing for large companies, the market has recently grown finicky. 
 Today, investors are shying away from all but the highest-rated issues -- a position being encouraged by the Securities and Exchange Commission. On Wednesday, the commission is scheduled to vote on whether to restrict money market funds, the largest buyers of commercial paper, from investing in almost all but the top-rated issues.
For instance, Chrysler Financial, the finance arm of the Chrysler Corporation, has been all but frozen out of the commercial paper market in the last year, significantly adding to its borrowing costs. Last June, its commercial paper credit rating was cut by Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Services, two of the major rating agencies, to the third and lowest investment-grade level. Then, last week, the company withdrew its rating to avoid being formally lowered to noninvestment grade by Standard & Poor's.
"It became more difficult to find buyers so we changed our funding strategy to rely less on commerical paper," said Dennis M. Cantwell, vice president for corporate finance and development.
Indeed, at the end of 1990, Chrysler had just $1.1 billion in commercial credit outstanding, down sharply from $10.1 billion a year earlier. To fill the gap, it has sold some of its automobile loans in the secondary market and, like other troubled issuers, turned to its banks for cash -- $6.2 billion by the end of 1990.
But borrowing from banks costs more than issuing commercial paper -- a short-term I.O.U. that provides cash for up to 270 days to cover costs like inventories. Going to the bank increased Chrysler's costs, for instance, by about $25 million in 1990.
But even better-rated companies are having trouble. Companies that carry the second-highest rating from Moody's and S.& P. -- like CSX, the Marriott Corporation, American Brands and Union Oil of California -- have also been knocked off the buy list of many money market funds, which purchase 35 percent to 40 percent of the commercial paper issued in the United States. Marriott, which slashed its borrowing to $100 million in the last quarter of 1990, from $1.5 billion at the end of September, has been forced to secure new bank loans as a backup.
The banks themselves are having a hard time finding buyers for their paper. The major money-center banks have all had their credit downgraded recently, but had already begun to move to reduce their reliance on commercial paper.
 "Right now all you hear is quality, quality, quality," said John Wetzler, sales manager for short-term products at Citicorp Securities Markets Inc.
Still, the group being squeezed is relatively small. Top-rated companies have always accounted for the bulk of the market -- constituting about 84 percent of the total issues worldwide today, according to Moody's. These companies, with A-1 ratings from S.& P. and P-1 from Moody's, include General Electric Capital, General Motors Acceptance, Ford Motor Credit, Sears Roebuck Acceptance and American Express Credit.
Despite the drop in demand for lower-rated issues, the growth of the overall market has only levelled off because the appetite for top-rated paper remains strong.
Companies with A-2 ratings from S.& P. and P-2 from Moody's account for only about 13 percent of the more than 1,000 companies that borrow in the commercial paper market. And companies in the lowest investment grade levels, A-3 and P-3, account for only 2 percent of the market. Unrated companies or those rated below investment grade make up about 1 percent of the market. According to Moody's, there were about 75 unrated issuers with $5 billion in paper outstanding at the beginning of 1990, up from $3 billion in September of 1989.
That growth came from the burst in new issues in the expansive 80's, when credit concerns were less worrisome, lower-grade and unrated issues, like the paper market in general, grew by leaps and bounds. By 1990, the important measure of risk,the spreads in interest rates on top-rated and lesser-rated paper, narrowed to 10 basis points (100 basis points equal 1 percentage point).
But the boom ended abruptly last year after several companies defaulted on their paper, some of which was held by money market funds. Since June 1989, 11 companies have defaulted on a total of $1.1 billion in paper, marking the first defaults in the market since the Manville Corporation's in 1982.
What followed was a period in late 1990 that John Ward, who is responsible for the origination of commercial paper at Citicorp Securities Markets Inc., called the "height of schizophrenia." People worried about whether even quality issuers could fund themselves through the end of the year. Spreads shot up to as high as 100 basis points.
Seven of the 11 defaults were in the newer commercial paper markets in London, Japan and France, which account for the one-fourth of the paper not issued in the United States.
The defaults, and the prospects that a recession would decrease company earnings and bring on more defaults, led the S.E.C. last July to propose a new regulation to limit commercial paper purchases by money market funds. Under the S.E.C. proposal, no more than 5 percent of a fund's assets could be invested in paper without a top grade from the major rating agencies. And that 5 percent would have to be in paper with the second-highest rating.
The recession is not the only force that could disrupt the market. In an article this month, James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, harks back to the first commercial paper default, that of the Penn Central Transportation Company in 1970. While he does not suggest that the market faces the turmoil that the Penn Central default caused, he is worried about the market's backup -- the commercial banks. Most commercial paper is backed by bank loans that issuers can use to pay off the paper when it comes due if they do not have the cash.
"In the days of Penn Central, the banking system was upright and solvent," Mr. Grant said in an interview. "This vast market is undergirded by the promise of bankers to lend and not all of those banks are going to be solvent at the end of the year."
And banks are not eager to honor credit lines to companies issuing commercial paper because they are leary of any loan with any risk. Given the opportunity, they might back out.In fact, after the credit downgradings of Integrated Resources Inc. and the Mortgage and Realty Trust, banks suddenly withdrew their backing, causing Integrated to default in June of 1989 and Mortgage, in March of last year.
Jerome S. Fons and Andrew E. Kimball of Moody's noted that credit quality standards have tightened since then, reducing investors' exposure to these problems. But, they still conclude, "there are clouds on the horizon." They note that in this recessionary environment there can be quick downgradings of company paper that could lead to the withdrawal of backing from banks.
Many traders, dealers and money market fund managers talk much more optimistically about commercial paper's outlook. The market has settled some in the last few months and spreads have fallen back to the 30 basis point range.
Still, money managers are exerting caution. Jay Mueller, portfolio manager at R. Meeder & Associates in Dublin, Ohio, which manages the Flex Fund money market fund, insists that the commercial paper market is not in disarry. But he has not owned any paper below A-1/P-2 for nine months and is not buying any paper from a company backed by a Japanese bank. John Todd, the portfolio manager for Fidelity's Cash Reserve and Spartan Money Market Fund, has also gotten rid of all paper that is not top-rated.
Joseph DiMartino, president of the Dreyfus Corporation, has been less severe, reducing his exposure in the second-tier to about 2 percent of the Dreyfas Worldwide Dollar Money Market Fund.
Chuck Mayer, co-head of the commercial paper department at Goldman Sachs & Company, sums up the state of the market with this slightly backhanded optimism: "I don't see that there has been much change in the acceptance of commercial paper. But it has not gotten worse."
 
 
 
DUCKING THE CREDIT CRUNCH
 For some analysts, the rise in the volume of commercial paper even after recessionary signs multiplied late last year was a worry. Assuming additional debt means more companies are likely to have trouble meeting interest payments if a recovery proves to be late in coming, said Nancy Lazar, senior vice president at C.J. Lawrence Inc.
But other analysts have been less concerned by the continuing volume. In fact, George J. Iwanicki, an economist at Kidder, Peabody, has argued that the commercial paper increase is good because it is helping to fill some of the credit gap left by the decline in lending by banks.
"While some analysts are disturbed by the increase in commercial paper financing, we are encouraged," he said. "This is one piece of evidence that whatever credit gap is being created by commercial bank lending restraint is being at least partially filled by alternative sources of credit."
At the same time, he is not sure if this gap filling will play a significant role in turning the economy around.
James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, does not think the commercial paper market is making the bank credit squeeze any easier. He argues that the top-rated companies are still in a position to borrow in the market and possibly from their banks. But, he said, the lower-rated companies that are being frozen out of the market are also having trouble at their banks.
There is logic to this argument. But the fact that the Marriott Corporation has just secured a $150 million loan commitment from a group of banks shows that some companies pushed out of the commercial paper market can still get some help.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Yin-Yang of Rates and Earnings

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Stock markets around the world rallied last week and several analysts declared that the bear market was over. It will take some time for these bulls to be proved right. In the meantime, the markets are likely to move up and down in response to a tug of war between falling interest rates and falling company earnings.
Falling rates represent all that is positive in the markets and the hope for a growing, rather than a slowing, world economy in the near future. 
 Falling earnings reflect all that is wrong right now. Recessions in the United States and Britain. Sharply slowing growth throughout Europe, except for Germany. Banking problems in the United States and Japan. Political and economic deterioration in the Soviet Union. And the Persian Gulf war, playing more in the background these days but ready with a surprise to shock the markets. With the season for reporting earnings upon us, the reminders of all that is wrong could be quite insistent.
"It is the case of whether the glass is half empty or half full," said Roger Palmer, the overall strategist at Kleinwort Benson Securities in London. As for himself, he has joined the analysts who have happily waved goodbye to the bear market much sooner than they might have expected.
At the heart of this bullish view are several factors and assumptions. One assumption is that interest rates peaked in Germany at the end of last month when the Bundesbank raised two key rates by half of a percentage point. A report on factory orders for December, which was released Friday, shows that the German economy is slowing down, although it is not anywhere near a recession, meaning that there is no reason to raise rates further, Mr. Palmer said.
For the 12 months ending in December, the rate of increase in the orders fell to 1.8 percent, compared with a gain of 11.3 percent for the 12 months ending in October. And because of the sharp rise in the German mark and the decline of the dollar -- which continued last week despite heavy coordinated dollar buying by central banks from the United States and its allies -- orders for German factory exports fell 9.8 percent over the year ending in December.
Another factor supporting the bullish view is the apparent change in the psyche of the markets, a metamorphosis that began with the optimistic rally at the outset of the gulf war in mid-January. Before the war, when analysts thought stock markets would drop sharply at the outbreak of fighting, it was wise to be risk averse. Stay out of equities was the message.
Now the risk is not being in equities. Cash positions grew enormously because of the cautious prewar strategy. With the buying spigot fully turned on, that cash hoard is making the rush back into the market even more dramatic. Of course, that means there could be some slowing as institutions and mutual funds get closer to their normal cash positions.
One of the stock markets that has rallied the most during this transition is Sweden's, which has been among the best performers in the world this year. Since the beginning of 1991, the market's Affarsvarlden General Index is up just over 12 percent. But like other markets, Sweden's will feel the tug of falling earnings.
Until the end of 1990, this small market had been off most analysts' lists. Interest rates had soared last fall to defend the krona. Inflation remained a problem, as did Government spending in the heavily subsidized society.
But even before the war began, the market had begun to turn. Interest rates were declining and the Government's budget package, crammed with spending cuts, was positively received. And as was the case elsewhere, large investors were flush with cash and started to pour money back into stocks.
The war gave the market another boost. Then the friendly takeover of Alfa-Laval, one of the world's largest manufacturers of dairy machinery, by Sweden's Tetra Pak pushed the market even higher. The Wallenberg family, which has major stakes in many top Swedish companies, including Alfa-Laval, needs to raise cash to reduce its debt burden. And the 16.25 billion kronor purchase by Tetra Pak, Europe's dominant maker of juice and dairy packaging, raised speculation that other companies might be sold. Investors also hoped that some of the cash from the sale would be plowed back into the market.
Now earnings reports are coming out in Sweden. As expected, the 1990 earnings for one major company, Ericsson, rose 30 percent. But when the telecommunications concern released its numbers on Thursday, it also forecast that 1991 earnings would not keep pace -- and that sent the market down 2 percent. It regained about half that decline on Friday.
"It will be the testing period now," said Sven Hagstromer, head of his own brokerage firm in Stockholm. "In the next month we have the reports from the companies and we expect the results to be under current forecasts."
He also expects the extra cash that was on the sidelines to run out soon. "Then we will see what kind of real strength there is in the market," he said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Wall Street's Steadfast Faith In the Airlines

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Markets can be so inconvenient. No sooner did George Bush point to the stock market rally as evidence that the recession will be short and shallow than the rally began to sputter.
"The market," Mr. Bush told the upper tier of the New York financial establishment, gathered for a meeting of the Economic Club of New York, "seems to be saying there is good reason to be less pessimistic and more optimistic." The next day, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 20 points. 
 Nonetheless, Mr. Bush is right about what the market clearly believes. The explosive rally that began after the bombs began falling shows no sign of letting up. It has swept along stocks good and bad, and even on Thursday, when the Dow fell, there were a few more stocks rising than falling on the New York Stock Exchange.
 The Dow made back those 20 points on Friday, and ended the week with a gain of an even 100 points, or 3.7 percent, to 2,830.69. It is now just 68.57 points, or 2.4 percent, below its level of Aug. 1, just before Iraq invaded Kuwait.
Unfortunately, the stock market's confident forecast of the future is not yet confirmed by reports of business activity. Sales are bad at department stores, worse at automobile showrooms and all but nonexistent at airline counters.
The airlines, and their shareholders, celebrated last month when the start of the Persian Gulf war brought on lower oil prices and when, soon after, Eastern Air Lines finally gave up and stopped flying. The big airlines responded to the disappearance of Eastern with a sigh of relief and a determination to charge customers more. American Airlines says that its average discount fare is now about 5 percent higher than a year ago, when there was no recession.
Most of what has been written on the drastic downturn in air travel has focused on fears of terrorism brought on by the war. No doubt that explanation has some validity, but fare levels have also played an important role.
As last week ended, it appears there was a rush to buy tickets as travelers scrambled to take advantage of a brief two-for-one sale offered by America West, an airline with mounting losses and so burdened with debt that Donald Trump once called it overleveraged.
Now the big question is whether a new round of fare cutting will begin, or whether the damage to profits will be contained as airlines do no more than match America West on competitive routes. It is no coincidence that Trans World Airlines, which is defaulting on its bonds, took the lead in extending, through today, the deadline for buying half-price tickets. Airlines that are desperate for cash find it difficult to take the long view.
For now, the stock market seems to think that a new era of profitability is on the horizon for the air carriers, propelled by falling fuel prices and interest rates. Since the war began, AMR, UAL and Delta, three airlines that everyone expects to be survivors, are all up 20 percent or so. But so are America West and Continental. Optimism does run deep.
