LENGTH: 1571 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/February 3-8

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Help From Washington for America's Humbled Banks
 
Laws passed decades ago to restrict the big American banks might now be rewritten to help save them. What a change in the bankers' image: from heartless oppressors, vilified in American literature and film, to bumbling spendthrifts and lenders to hopeless causes. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady presented a plan on Tuesday for the first overhaul of the banking system since the Depression. While the laws have remained fixed, the banking world has changed. Foreign banks, once cowed by their American rivals, now account for 29 of the 30 largest in the world. Markets as small as a city or state, once dependable, now are too limited and volatile for consistent profits. Restrictions on underwriting securities and a ban on bank ownership by other industries, once essential limits on banks' influence and risk, now are accelerating their decline. Congressional opposition to several features of the plan is inevitable. Many lawmakers come from states that have restricted the ability of banks to branch out even across county lines. But as Federal officials scramble to bail out the bank insurance fund and loosen bank credit, they recognize that the financing of the nation's businesses and consumers is at stake.

Stripping the F.D.I.C. of Power
 
If you can't hit the soldier, shoot at his horse: the Administration's proposed banking laws would strip L. William Seidman's Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation of its regulatory powers. The plan would split the F.D.I.C.'s authority over banks between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury, leaving Mr. Seidman to meekly watch over his dwindling bank insurance fund. Fast as a House Budget Committee microphone could be switched on, he was ready to denounce the plan as "an invitation to regulatory civil war." In a skirmish last year, the Bush Administration tried to topple Mr. Seidman from his post; his term runs until October.
 
 An Optimistic Budget
 
The din of war and the plaints of recession echo only faintly through the 1992 Bush budget. The $1.45 billion budget he submitted to Congress on Monday counts on an end to the recession by mid-year and allied aid so generous that the Persian Gulf war will cost the nation only $12.8 billion. Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said the Administration will probably have to ask for more war money in a few months. The President, painted by the Democrats as the protector of the undeserving rich, hopes to maneuver them into defending some breaks for the wealthy. He wants to limit subsidies to the rich for agriculture, Medicare, school lunches and student aid -- programs dear to many Democratic politicians.
 
 Productivity Gains - at a Cost
 
If American factories have truly become more efficient, why all the dismal, shuttered Youngstowns and Flints? The Commerce Department said last week that manufacturing productivity climbed at a record 3.6 percent annual rate in the 1980's, matching trading partners' gains. A service economy it may be, but as productivity among white-collar workers stagnates, manufacturing accounts for an increasing, 23.3 percent share of the nation's output. But the decade's improvements in plant efficiency have come with the loss of two million jobs. Industries like textiles have reversed their fortunes by automating, but far lower employment is the result. Nobody would comfort a small, failing farmer by saying that the success of the vast, mechanized spread next-door was all for the good. Manufacturing productivity likewise comes at a cost.
 
 California Runs Dry
 
You farm where there's no rain from April through November, build cities hundreds of miles from the needed water supplies, and sooner or later you're going to run dry. After five years of drought, California's state water project has cut off supplies to Central Valley farmers. Rationing is already the rule in southern California. Several economists estimate that losses to the state's farmers, food processors and factories that depend on inexpensive water will reach $3 billion. This in the nation's most populous and agriculturally productive state.
 
 A Whole New Computer Game
 
A powerful group of companies aims to redesign the personal computer from the chip up. Microsoft, Compaq and Digital are nearing an agreement to produce computers and software based on chips designed by MIPS Computer Systems. The group's main targets appear to be International Business Machines and Apple, which have their own personal computer standards, and Sun Microsystems, which makes competing chips.

 
 
COMPANIES


 Bitter Medicine at G.M.
 
While stock market investors rejoiced at the anticipated return of flush times, General Motors prepared for a long recession. The company announced reductions in capital spending and white-collar staffing last week, and cut its dividend almost in half, the first cut in more than a decade. Scott F. Merlis, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, blessed the actions as "creative destruction," explaining, "Excesses will be purged. You're going to end up with a much more efficient industry." Next to cut their dividends, say many analysts, are Chrysler and Ford.
 
The day after G.M. imposed new economies, sales figures demonstrated that consumers are economizing, too. Sales of vehicles made in America dropped 31.5 percent during Jan. 21 to 31 from the same period last year.
 
 Chrysler's Accounting Gain
 
Chrysler managed to recover in the accounting offices what it lost in the factories and showrooms. The company eked out a $31 million profit in the fourth quarter on a bookkeeping change, as expected losses for plant closings and layoffs were reduced. But borrowing will not be among the costs that auto makers like Chrysler can easily cut. Standard & Poor's reduced the credit ratings of all of auto's Big Three, tossing Chrysler into a category reserved for "junk bonds."
 
 An Energy (Production) Policy
 
The White House wants to rely on increased production more than reduced consumption to slake the nation's thirst for imported fuels. A draft of its new energy policy includes tax breaks and deregulation to increase production of coal, oil and natural gas. Many obstacles that have halted construction of nuclear power plants would be removed.
 
 Sony Wants Orion Pictures
 
Orion needs a sugar daddy, and Sony stands ready to fill the role. Sony, which already owns the Columbia studio, wants to buy Orion Pictures as well. For perhaps $500 million, Sony could acquire the rights to Woody Allen's neuroses and probably Kevin Costner's sensitive machismo. Several elaborately produced flops (anyone see "Valmont"?) have left Orion with low earnings and high debts. John Werner Kluge's 70 percent stake in Orion is only a sliver of his multi-billion-dollar investment portfolio. When Orion ran short of money to complete "Mermaids," starring Cher, last fall, Mr. Kluge kicked in $23 million. Now, he seems willing to let someone else provide the sugar.
 
 McCabe Looks to Fill His Ark
 
The first product any advertising professional must promote is himself. In this sense, Ed (It takes a tough man to make a tender chicken) McCabe is off to a grand start. Comparing his opening of a new agency last week to the Second Coming would have been too obvious. Instead, in full-page newspaper ads, he settled for posing as Noah, at an agency deluged with job-seekers, vendors and potential clients all trying to clamber aboard his ark. Only two accounts are on board so far.

INTERNATIONAL

 
 Japan's Designer Scouts
 
More than 300,000 Japanese beaver scouts, cub scouts, boy scouts, senior scouts and troop leaders can confidently dress in gentrified, all-natural fibers, courtesy of Ralph Lauren. At the urging of Akio Morita, the former chief executive of Sony, Mr. Lauren designed new uniforms for everyone. "Just a gesture of goodwill," with no profits to the designer, said Peter Strom, vice chairman of the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation. The colorations include an earthy khaki with forest green trim, olive with red and royal blue with gold. Plenty of pleats, plackets and pockets to set a rugged but refined tone; no pony insignia, though. American styles are far more popular in Japan than American cars. In an agreement with the Seibu chain, Ralph Lauren sells his other fashions at 11 free-standing shops and the nation's major retailers, with revenues of $700 million a year. Uniform sales have been strong since his designs came out late last year.Next, the scouts will want Philip Johnson to design their tents.
 
 Outfoxing the Supply Lines
 
Just as some Soviets are trying to learn American ways of business, Americans are learning the Soviet ways. An undersand economy has flourished among the troops in Saudi Arabia. Same problem as in Russia: plenty of goods, but a clogged distribution system. Written requisitions, the currency of military supply, have plummeted in value as piles of unfilled orders accumulate. The best-stocked units boast supply officers who are the most conniving. They think nothing of stockpiling camouflage fatigues to swap for some help from forklift operators, or jumping into empty trucks and simply driving them away. "Most people go to prison for this," said one sergeant. "I get promoted."

PUB-DATE: February 10, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2977 words

HEADLINE: An Aging Dancer Fights to Keep Up

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Does Silicon Valley have a future?
For the first time in its adult life, this storied crucible of research and development in northern California is experiencing a crisis of confidence, questioning whether it can remain the world center for technical innovation. 
 Causing the jitters is a growing fear that companies here are falling behind the Japanese in the race to develop the next generation of computers: one-pound palmtop marvels so portable that they can transmit and receive data from anywhere and so user-friendly that they will dispense with keyboards and take orders from even the most cramped handwritten instructions.
The first of the new machines could arrive within a year and mark the end of the era of deskbound computers.
If the palmtops come with a Japanese name on the box, they could also mark the end of an era for this region, the fertile source for the past two decades of nearly all of the world's most important home and business microelectronic innovations, including videocassette recorders, video games and personal computers.
Although dozens of Valley companies are scrambling to design the software and hardware for the new machines -- and one may yet come from behind to emerge the winner -- the race may already have been lost, many experts say.
"Japan has sensed a lot quicker than anyone else what's going on with these products," said John Sculley, chairman of Apple Computer Inc., one of the Valley's first citizens. "The only chance that we have is to leverage our software technology with some of their hardware."
A failure to be first with what many believe will be the next blockbuster technology could consign the Valley to second-class status, forcing companies here either to follow the Japanese lead in product development or to concentrate on niches that the Japanese don't care about.
The Valley is on the verge of becoming a "techno-colony," dependent on innovation from Japan, said one Valley pioneer, Andrew S. Grove, co-founder of the Intel Corporation, at a recent industry dinner in San Jose, Calif.
And since the Valley is seen by many as the archetype of American competitiveness -- as well as one of the key engines of the country's economy -- a decline in its status would produce ripples throughout the nation, affecting everything from factory automation to weapons development.
<> <> A second-place finish in the palmtop derby would also greatly accelerate the pace of investment here by the Japanese, who are eager to tap into the Valley's still-strong stores of software expertise. Many of the most innovative Valley companies are already in partnership with the Japanese and more will have to do that to survive, executives, engineers and computer scientists say.
The growing importance of the Japanese -- and, to a lesser extent, high-tech companies from other countries like Korea -- could actually result in more jobs for the Valley, just as the opening of factories in Kentucky and Ohio by Japanese auto makers has buoyed those areas.
But there are dreadful dangers as well, some Valley veterans say. As the Japanese presence becomes more pervasive, they say, the research effort here could be redirected, captive to a foreign agenda geared to foreign products and priorities.
Indeed, a victory for the Japanese in developing palmtop machines could speed the shift of economic power to Asia, said Jacques Attali, a French writer and theorist who heads the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
With so much on the line, it is not surprising that the Valley seems obsessed these days with checking its pulse. For example, a recent issue of the California Management Review, a publication of the University of California at Berkeley, was largely devoted to the growing debate over the Valley's future.
The pessimists believe that the next generation of computers, referred to as nomadic devices because of their full-service portability, will particularly favor Japanese designers because of that nation's long experience with microelectronic miniaturization. Fully 40 percent of all personal computers in Japan are portables, a number that is expected to soar to 60 percent by the end of next year. In this country, the Japanese already dominate the market for pocket computers -- simple low-end calendars and notetakers like the Sharp Wizard and Casio B.O.S.S.
What's more, the Japanese several years ago wrested away from the Valley large parts of the computer hardware market and they are now the undisputed leaders in the manufacture of semiconductors, the heart and brains of all computerized equipment, as well as most consumer electronics products.
But not everyone in the Valley is prepared to throw in the towel, even if the Japanese win the first round of what will ultimately be a decade-long race to perfect the palmtops.
"I wouldn't count Silicon Valley out yet," said Apple's Mr. Sculley. "If start-ups are going to have a role, then Silicon Valley will continue to be important."
The creativity of the Valley will persist, its boosters say, because no other region in the world can duplicate the hundreds of informal research networks that sprouted here.
"There is such a huge critical mass of very talented engineers here who don't think the same," said Sheridan Tatsuno, a consultant at Neoconcepts, a market research firm in Fremont, Calif. "They're independent-minded and on the leading edge. In Japan there is still a herd mentality: If Sony does it, everyone follows."
Among the optimists is the economist George Gilder, who has argued that each new generation of semiconductor technology spontaneously generates start-up companies, thereby insuring the vitality of the United States microelectronics industry.
But critics counter that while Valley companies are still ahead of the Japanese on the software front, the growing Japanese lead in hardware could cost the Americans their edge in product development and ultimately contribute to the demise of high-tech industry in the United States.
"The United States has developed a system of making technological breakthroughs, but in fact we're falling behind other countries in learning how to manufacture the stuff," said Richard Florida, a management professor at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh. The separation of manufacturing from product design, which is particularly evident in the Valley, is a potentially fatal weakness, he added.
 
Inevitable Rendezvous
 In a sense, the Valley has spent a generation preparing for its date with the palmtops. Indeed, for almost two decades, the vision of a portable supercomputer dubbed the "Dynabook" has served as the Holy Grail for the best computer designers here.
First proposed in the 1970's by the computer scientist Alan Kay and a small band of associates at the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center, the Dynabook has long been envisioned as a notebook-sized device that would be less like today's portable computers and more of a savvy electronic assistant. Unlike current computers, which have to be told exactly what to do, a Dynabook would come with a dollop of intelligence of its own, making it possible to perform certain filing chores and search functions with a degree of flexibility.
When the Xerox researchers built their first prototype of the Dynabook in the late 70's, it was the size of a hefty sewing machine. And at $50,000 each, it could not be manufactured at a reasonable cost. What got developed instead, a few years later, were the first commercial portables from Valley stalwarts like the Osborne Computer Company and Morrow Designs.
In the ensuing decade, portables became increasingly smaller and more powerful. Current state-of-the-art machines, like the American-designed model from the Poqet Computer Corporation, package the functions of a desktop computer in a box the size of a notepad. Now the Sony Corporation and some American companies are introducing pocket-size computers designed to be controlled with a stylus rather than a keyboard.
These tiny powerhouses still do not have the software to act as an electronic assistant; nor are they yet able to communicate through radio and satellite links. Moreover, their ability to "read" handwriting entered by stylus is quite rudimentary.
 
Coming Soon
 But clearly, the Dynabook will soon become a reality, and Sony, Toshiba and Sharp are all thought to be ahead of anyone in the Valley in designing the hardware for it.
Why are even the Valley's most successful companies behind Japan? The answer, at least in part, may have less to do with the Valley than with the very nature of innovation in the computer industry. New companies may sprout with each technological advance, as Mr. Gilder says. But something else also happens: the companies responsible for the previous generation of machines usually are not able to recast themselves to design the next one.
In an effort to reinvent the creativity that characterized the small group of engineers who designed the Macintosh computer -- the machine that marked the last big advance with its ease of use -- Apple recently spun off a small start-up company called General Magic Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif.
The new company, led by veterans of the Macintosh design team, is working on a stylus-based palmtop connected to the world by a wireless radio system.
Apple's engineers were jolted into action last year shortly after the company introduced its first portable model, which weighed a hefty 18 pounds. Another American company, the Houston-based Compaq Computer Corporation, then offered its own 6-pound notebook machine. Compaq had designed it in partnership with Citizen, a Japanese consumer electronics and watch manufacturer.
 
'We Were Stunned'
 "We took it apart and we were stunned because we realized that Apple couldn't make anything similar," said one Apple executive.
Now Apple is planning a lighter portable, but this time many in the industry believe the company, based in Cupertino, Calif., intends to enter the market either by licensing its Macintosh technology to a competitor or working with a Japanese partner. Likely candidates include Sony and Toshiba, which have expertise, unlike the Americans, in making flat-panel display screens, a key component of the tiny machines.
Apple is not the only Valley company struggling with the challenges presented by miniaturization. The Go Corporation, which has designed a new software system for stylus-based computers, recently surprised many in the industry when it announced that it had no plans to build the hardware for such a machine. Instead, it formed an alliance with the International Business Machines Corporation to finish the development of the software, which it would then license to both Japanese and American palmtop makers.
"Today the computer hardware industry is desperately competitive," said Gerrold Kaplan, Go's founder, referring to the great difficulties smaller Valley companies have had in turning a profit in hardware.
By contrast, software can be quite profitable, said Mr. Kaplan, because operating systems have become a larger and larger component of a product's total cost with each new generation of computers. And software is where the Valley is still ahead of the Japanese.
American software that controls the display and manipulation of data on computer screens -- systems pioneered by Xerox and then commercialized by many companies, including Apple, Metaphor Computer Systems, Next and Sun Microsystems -- is simply unrivaled by any Japanese computer maker.
Known as interfaces, these systems will be critically important to the development of a palmtop and its ability to read handwriting -- and they could prove to be the missing ingredient that could revive the Valley's chances.
Some start-ups are betting on that possibility. The Japanese may dominate portable computers with models compatible with the standard MS-DOS desktop operating system, but they will be very cautious about committing themselves to an interface for palmtops, Valley executives say.
 
Memories of Beta
 The reason, they say, is the painful memory of Sony's failure with videocassette recorders a decade ago. Sony latched on to the Beta video format only to see the rest of the industry choose VHS, a mistake that cost it hundreds of millions of dollars.
The Japanese tentativeness is underscored, some Valley executives say, by Sony's reluctance to market its existing stylus-equipped portable in the United States, a signal that it is holding back until it feels more secure about its software choices.
"The Japanese have been real scared to introduce products in the United States that are nonstandard," said Kamran Elahian, founder of the Momenta Corporation, a Sunnyvale, Calif., start-up. "When they've done so in the past, they've paid a heavy price."
And that could be just the opening that the Valley needs.
At Momenta's offices, for instance, a plaque on the wall announces a company goal: "1,000 days to immortality." The vehicle to fame and fortune is a stylus-based portable that Momenta is designing. Down the hall, a calendar indicates there are less than 600 days to complete the design and make a machine.
Momenta is just one of many startups working feverishly to create new standards for stylus machines. Taken together, Valley supporters say, they are the best evidence that the crisis of confidence afflicting some of the older companies is simply self-inflicted.
"My sense is that there is still a lot of optimism in the Valley," said AnnaLee Saxenian, a researcher in economic development at the University of California at Berkeley.
Indeed, the number of new start-ups backed by venture capital rose sharply in 1989, to 853. Despite the decline of traditional semiconductor manufacturers in the Valley, chip makers generated 25,000 new jobs and more than $2 billion in additional annual sales in the past decade by creating new markets. And the total number of high-technology jobs in Santa Clara County, the center of the Valley, reached a new peak of almost 340,000 in 1989, Ms. Saxenian said.
"The Valley still looks really good to me," said Harry Vertelney, a designer in Apple Computer's advanced-technology group. "This is still the center of the computational universe."
The question, though, is whose universe? In a sense, that universe increasingly is going to be controlled by the Japanese, even if the Valley somehow pulls a palmtop out of its hat, many experts say.
Japanese giants like Fujitsu, Hitachi and Sony are already expanding their operations here, and others are expected to follow soon.
They have no choice, said Mr. Tatsuno, the consultant at Neoconcepts. Software is Silicon Valley's strength -- and Japan's Achilles heel. A similar imbalance has been drawing Japanese consumer electronics companies, including Sony, to southern California and the special "software" that Hollywood produces.
"The Japanese have to be here," Mr. Tatsuno said.
 
A DUBIOUS FORMULA?
 For years, communities and industries all over the United States have tried to copy Silicon Valley's formula for high-tech development. But in a recently published book, two economists question the wisdom of that approach.
In "The Breakthrough Illusion: Corporate America's Failure to Move From Innovation to Mass Production" (Basic Books), Richard Florida and Martin Kenney argue that the "start-up mania" that has characterized Silicon Valley has contributed to the demise of the American economy's competitiveness as much as it has bolstered it.
Mr. Florida and Mr. Kenney particularly fault the pattern of dozens of "me too" start-ups rushing after each new technology fad. The inevitable result, they say, is a shakeout with huge losses and layoffs.
Me-too start-ups weaken the development of the entire industry by dividing market share and engineering talent among too many companies, the authors contend. The resulting fragmentation leaves American companies vulnerable to more integrated international competitors, they say.
Moreover, even the best parts of the Valley's economic model -- innovation and flexibility in technological and industrial organization -- have done little to transform basic manufacturing industries in the United States, they argue.
"It is as though high technology start-ups and large industrial companies are operating on entirely different planets," they say.
 
CAN THEY REKINDLE THE MAGIC?
 During the heady days seven years ago when they were racing to finish the design of the Macintosh computer, engineers at Apple Computer Inc. wore T-shirts that read, "Working 90 hours a week and loving it."
If Silicon Valley retains its technological edge, many believe it will be because new start-up companies are able to duplicate the passion and intensity of that Macintosh team. By all accounts that is what 14 Apple veterans are trying to do at General Magic Inc., a Mountain View, Calif., start-up that was founded last year.
General Magic is attempting to design what it calls "personal information communicators" -- palmtop machines that permit users to take a powerful personal computer with them wherever they go.
So far, General Magic's founders are saying little about their planned product or which major companies besides Apple they are hoping will back their venture. But according to several people close to the company, General Magic has recaptured much of the enthusiasm that characterized the Macintosh effort.
One of the company's three founders, Bill Atkinson, helped develop the Macintosh and then gained a reputation as Apple's best programmer after he designed an innovative computer language called Hypercard.
Now, at General Magic, Mr. Atkinson is said to be working for as long as three or four days at a stretch without sleep.

HEADLINE: All About/Oil Services;
A Lean, High-Tech Industry Poised for Postwar Growth

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
During the oil boom of the early 1980's, most companies spent more than $10, some more than $20, to find and produce a barrel of oil in the United States. Since then, the service companies that provide equipment and crews to drill for oil, and for the natural gas often found with it, have improved the process vastly. They have introduced supercomputers to spot drilling sites and sophisticated equipment that can even drill sideways (box).
For the three years that ended in 1989, the average cost to produce one barrel of oil in the United States was just $4.82, according to John S. Herrold Inc., an oil research firm based in Greenwich, Conn. 
 That still doesn't match the $2 a barrel cost in Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf nations, where huge deposits lie relatively near the surface. But achieving the decline in the United States, where most of the remaining petroleum lies deep indeed, demonstrates the service industry's technological leadership.
The high-tech pioneers -- the major international service companies like Schlumberger, Halliburton, Dresser Industries and Baker Hughes -- have steadily improved their profits over the three years through 1990. By slashing their payrolls and curtailing operations, they survived an unprecedented collapse in oil drilling activity from 1986 through 1989 that ruined or crippled many of their debt-laden rivals.
 
The Rig Count
Boomlet Follows Bust in the U.S.
The fortunes of the oil field service industry can be tracked by the rig count. As oil prices soared in the early 1980's, the number of operating rigs in the United States rose to more than 4,500. The count fell to a post-World War II low of 869 in 1989, but rebounded last year to 1,010, according to Baker Hughes Inc. Outside the United States, the rig count has been far less volatile. The international average, excluding Canada, was 907 rigs in 1990 -- the first year since 1985 that the United States has beaten that average.
Many analysts expect higher oil prices, more drilling and higher revenues for the service companies by the mid-1990's, as oil prices rise from the current $20 a barrel or so to more than $25. The analysts assume that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will again restrict output after the current war ends. They say that the United States rig count will gradually increase to an average of 1,200 in 1993, with 2,400 worldwide.
The service companies provide drill bits, drill pipe, special muds and fluids, offshore equipment, geological mapping software and the personnel to deploy it all. A huge source of new orders for them might be the rebuilding of Middle Eastern facilities. The extent of damage to oil fields, refineries and petrochemical plants will known for certain only when the war in the Persian Gulf ends. But some analysts estimate that just repairing the damage to Kuwaiti facilities so far is likely to cost $40 billion. The Kuwaiti Government, with investments estimated at $100 billion, has more than enough to bankroll postwar reconstruction. "At some point, there will be an enormous rebuilding plan required there," said John J. Murphy, Dresser's chairman and chief executive.
Meanwhile, the industry's main customers, the major oil companies, plan to increase their worldwide drilling budgets this year by nearly 14 percent, according to James D. Crandell, a Salomon Brothers analyst. And Government-controlled oil enterprises, which have been increasing their purchases by more than 30 percent a year, according to Suzanne L. Cook, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, contributed 40 percent of industry revenues last year. These national oil organizations, in places like Mexico, Indonesia and Venezuela, accounted for only about 10 percent of business in 1980, she said.
 
Where the Work Is
Postwar Rebuilding In the Middle East
 Although the long-term prospects are reassuring, until recently the outlook for oil service companies was dreary. When Saudi Arabia and other OPEC members quickly stepped in to make up for the Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil supplies lost to war, fears of scarcity promptly turned to fears of glut. Some analysts felt crude prices might plunge below $15 a barrel after the war ended.
Investors quickly showed their disenchantment with OPEC members' production increases. The shares of 25 representative oil service companies fell an average of 34 percent from an early August peak through Jan. 17, according to Mr. Crandell. For 19 months before the peak, the sector had led the market, as worldwide energy demand appeared to be rising.
Since the first bombing raids over Baghdad, shares in the oil service sector have bounced back up by about 12 percent. Aside from the implications of damage to oil production equipment in Iraq and Kuwait, year-end earnings reports have improved investors' confidence somewhat that the industry's recovery will continue.
One still urgent, and palpable, problem is the collapse of natural-gas prices, which developed independently of Middle East politics. The price of natural gas depends heavily on demand for heating. "Warm weather has overwhelmed the market with problems," said James L. Carroll, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., in New York.
High temperatures, especially in the Northeast, have restricted demand in the last three months. February prices in the spot market have ranged between $1.10 and $1.40 per 1,000 cubic feet. The price had averaged $1.71 in 1990 and nearly $1.80 the year before.
In the Gulf of Mexico, which produces mostly natural gas, offshore drilling specialists including Marine Drilling, Cliffs Offshore and Oceaneering International have suffered, said Mr. Carroll of PaineWebber. Lease rates for modest rigs operating in 250 feet of water or less off the coasts of Texas and Louisiana have fallen in the last month by $2,000, to as low as $10,000 a day. So rig operators are pulling up their equipment and hauling it to areas with more oil -- including Venezuela, West Africa and the North Sea.
 
The Technology
More Precision At Greater Depths
New technologies are helping oil companies to recover more oil and gas from deeper, more precisely drilled holes even as lower costs have increased the demand for rigs.
In the last few years, supercomputers using sophisticated software have sharpened many a driller's aim, locating and mapping reservoir sites by analyzing sound waves sent speeding through layers of rock. The Halliburton Company has installed a version of this technology on a ship launched last year to pinpoint offshore drilling sites.
Innovative equipment is also allowing oil companies to drill in deeper water. Traditional rig supports, built from the sea floor up, allow drilling in no more than 1,300 feet of water. But Conoco Inc. has pumped oil and natural gas for more than a year from a rig tethered to the Gulf of Mexico seabed by giant cables in water 1,700 feet deep. Shell Oil has ordered rigs with the same technology to operate in depths exceeding 3,000 feet.
Schlumberger Ltd. and Halliburton have each introduced foaming compounds that act like timed-release medications. Deep in a well, they can unlock trapped oil and promote its flow from a reservoir toward the bottom of a well shaft, where it can be reached for pumping to the surface.
 
 
THE HORIZONTAL BOOM
 Years of declines in Texas oil production apparently ended in 1990 for one reason: the high amounts of crude pumped from horizontally drilled wells. Texas oil production, which peaked at 3.6 million barrels a day in 1972, had fallen to 1.68 million in 1989 as the fields were depleted. By last November, the lastest figures available, it was up to 1.8 million barrels a day.
Since the 1940's, a few oilmen have dabbled with the technique of drilling a well straight down, then trying to tap more oil by angling the drill bit until it moved laterally. But broken drill bits and pipe frustrated them.
Several technologies have combined to make horizontal drilling more practical. Modern drill bits -- driven by motors in the bits instead of above ground -- can be precisely directed with the help of computers and precision mapping. They have minimized the frustrations of dry holes and damage to equipment.
Drillers usually employ these techniques in aging fields where geologists think earlier explorers missed oil trapped in narrow, vertical rock formations. With horizonal drilling, a single bore can tap several vertical deposits. Some companies have used the technique to search for new discoveries in North Dakota, Wyoming and Colorado where rock layers are similar to ones in Texas fields. But for now, most drillers are confining their efforts to a proven source: Texas itself.
The nation's largest independent oil producer, the Oryx Energy Company, recovered 58 million barrels of oil and barrel-equivalents of natural gas last year by drilling 68 horizontal wells in Texas fields southwest of San Antonio. Oryx plans to drill 70 more wells this year.
"Texas has had a turnaround and that has come clearly because of horizontal drilling," said Robert Krueger, a member of the Texas Railroad Commission, which regulates oil fields. The agency granted 1,098 permits for horizontal wells in 1990, up from 127 in 1989.
Baker Hughes Inc., which sold about half the equipment and services used in the nation's horizontal wells last year, estimated that as many as 5,000 horizontal wells will be drilled worldwide by the year 2000. Sales of horizontal-well equipment by its subsidiary, Eastman Christensen, are growing 40 percent a year. Eastman provided $100 million of Baker Hughes's total revenues of $2.6 billion in 1990.

HEADLINE: Bringing Haiti's Shattered Economy Back From the Brink

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU -PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
When Jacques Auguste returned here in 1960 armed with an engineering degree and visions of founding his own building materials company, he quickly discovered how little of what he had learned at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute prepared him for the rigors of doing business in his native Haiti.
Not long after opening a small cinder-block factory in 1961, Mr. Auguste found his workers besieged by the Tontons Macoute, the militia of the recently enthroned dictator, Francois Duvalier. 
 Looking back now, Mr. Auguste, a vigorous, deep-voiced 62-year-old, describes the repeated run-ins with the gun-toting thugs without alarm. Their monthly visits to extort payroll money, he says, were merely the most egregious of many bad encounters with agents of the Haitian Government. Eventually, the episodes of official harassment and theft forced him to flee the country for five years in the late 1960's, he adds, and they have discouraged legions of other investors from taking more interest in Haiti.
"The problem has been that nobody in Government considers you a taxpayer to whom they owe a service," said Mr. Auguste, whose company, Prefab, has since expanded handsomely, despite all the obstacles. "Being in business often seems like living under an occupation army. They owe you nothing. You owe them everything."
Now, Mr. Auguste and many other local entrepreneurs have their fingers crossed. The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a left-leaning Roman Catholic priest and political neophyte, was sworn in as President last Thursday. The hope is that Father Aristide will somehow overcome his inexperience and the country's seemingly intractable problems and rebuild the shattered economy of a nation that has grown accustomed to chaos.
Few details are known about the economic plans of the 37-year-old Father Aristide. In his speeches and writings before entering politics, he urged land redistribution for peasants and higher wages for industrial workers. Since then, however, he has made a war against corruption the centerpiece of his economic statements, while repeatedly stressing that his Government will welcome private investment.
It will also welcome more aid from the United States -- and American diplomats say they are eager to provide a substantial increase in assistance, both as a show of goodwill to a new democracy and to help resuscitate its anemic economy.
Haiti received about $55 million of United States aid in 1990, according to the State Department, just a bit more than half of what was given before elections were aborted in violence in 1987. Before assistance can return to its former levels, however, Father Aristide's Government must adopt "macroeconomic policies that are sound," American officials say privately.
That would be a stark change for Haiti, the hemisphere's poorest country, with a per capita gross domestic product of less than $400. A rush of local and foreign investments made Haiti's fast-growing industrial sector the envy of the region in the late 70's, and a model for the development strategy pushed by the United States through its Caribbean Basin Initiative. But instability, corruption and decay have long since regained the upper hand.
Haitian leaders began falling in dizzying succession amid the coups d'etat and popular uprisings that began with the flight into exile of Jean-Claude Duvalier, Francois's son, in 1986. Since then, the Government has refined its corrupt practices somewhat, becoming less crudely menacing, if more insidious, Mr. Auguste and other businessmen here say.
Where they once faced what amounted to armed holdups, entrepreneurs in Haiti's scrappy indigenous industrial sector now labor instead under a heavily overstaffed bureaucracy. For many businessmen, that bureaucracy seems organized to do little other than enrich itself, albeit by manipulating rules and perquisites instead of weapons. Although long incapable of functions like seeing to the cleaning or policing of the streets, the civil service has shown a gift for organizing wholesale smuggling and elaborating ever more arcane codes to extract "favors" from businesses, many here say.
"When I returned to the country in 1985, I opened a new branch of my business and decided I would try and see if I could do everything strictly according to the books, so that I could avoid having to pay bribes," said one businessman who, like many when discussing details of Government corruption, asked to remain anonymous. "Pretty soon auditors were coming at me with apprenticeship taxes for my workers -- all kinds of things that have been forgotten for 100 years. Finally I had to bribe them."
Similar tales of Government-induced sloth and corruption pour forth from Mr. Auguste as he describes each step of the relatively simple production processes he uses at Prefab, which now makes concrete flagstones, terra cotta roof tiles and bars of laundry soap in addition to cinder blocks.
HE lays much of the blame for this waste at the feet of the highly unpopular military governments that have run the country since 1986. Seeking to placate a population eager for democratic rule, the generals began padding the payrolls of already sluggish state-owned enterprises, from the national cement factory and flour mill to the port and electricity and telephone companies, Mr. Auguste and other businessmen said. Hundreds of unnecessary workers were added, and significant wage increases were granted as well, Government critics charge.
"This is why our cement costs us so much," Mr. Auguste said, his voice booming over the groans and belches of a large rock-crushing machine that churned out sand and clouds of white dust in the yard of his sprawling complex. Mr. Auguste pays $6.40 for a 94-pound cement bag, which sells for $2.50 elsewhere in the Caribbean. "If we are going to be socialists, fine, but if we want to reduce the cost of living for the people, this is ridiculous," he said.
The story of the tallow he imports from Florida to manufacture soap has a similar ring. Government regulations, he said, require that once dockers begin an unloading job, they must complete it the same day, even if it means that long overtime hours, which kick in at 4 P.M., must be paid.
Even without its costly overtime rules, Haiti's port is one of the world's most expensive, economists here say, with 1,100 workers doing a job that about 150 could handle.
As bad as the reputation of Haiti's port has become, the state corporation that has fallen the furthest into ill repute, many feel, is Electricite d'Haiti. The utility monopolizes electricity generation, or degeneration, as one wry joke has put it since the number of hours without power has begun to outstrip the number of hours with electricity for many customers.
In recent weeks, Haiti's newspapers have been filled with reports of workers at the electric company denouncing their superiors for taking under-the-table payments from affluent customers and quietly sweeping their large bills off the books.
While these corporate officers, several of whom were forced to resign, were reportedly enriching themselves, the company, which many see as a metaphor for the entire country's infrastructure, has simply abandoned many basic maintenance tasks. In one instance, poor land management around the basin that feeds the country's major hydroelectric dam has led to a severe silting problem that frequently knocks the dam's turbines out of service. Backup generators have also been poorly maintained and the company frequently lacks money to buy the oil that fuels them.
"For the last 15 years they have known about the problem of soil erosion at the dam, but nobody has bothered to do anything about it," said Leslie Delatour, a free-market economist who served briefly as a reformist finance minister in the mid-80's. "There is no sanction for failure in the civil service."
FOR businesses like Mr. Auguste's, where profit margins for a product like soap are measured in pennies, the failure to produce more than eight hours of electricity each day has meant critical production losses. "We will have problems as long as the electricity is in the hands of the Government," Mr. Auguste said. "Everything has to be privatized or we will remain lost."
While foreign investors and local businessmen are largely united in their desire to see Father Aristide brake the country's freefall, and privatize or somehow streamline the wasteful state monopolies, their visions of an ideal business environment veer off in near-opposite directions beyond that point.
For many of those who produce for the local market, like Mr. Auguste, the classic International Monetary Fund advice -- eliminate tariff barriers and devalue the currency to make export industries more competitive -- amounts to little more than devices intended to allow foreign interests to take over their fragile market.
These entrepreneurs hope that Father Aristide, whose message is strongly nationalistic, will heed their call to resist changes they see as hurting their interests.
"The Americans, the I.M.F. and everyone else want us to push our doors wide open, to lower the barriers, even encourage smuggling, if necessary, to lower prices," said Mr. Auguste, who advocates continued protectionism for many products. "Well, that is just nuts to think that you can solve all of our problems just by opening our doors."
Others, however, insist that as long as Haiti resists efforts to liberalize its trade, foreign investors will shy away from the country while local producers will hold on to their small, sure shares of what will remain a stunted market. "The first thing an elected Government will have to do is decide whether encouraging investment is a good thing," said Mr. Delatour, the former finance minister. "As for the domestic producers, I am sorry, but there are a lot of businesses they have no business being in."
 
 
THE UNSETTLING EXODUS OF FOREIGN INVESTMENT
 For foreign investors, Haiti's costly inefficiencies and political turmoil have so tarnished the country's reputation that the nation has fallen in the space of a decade from leading the pack of industrializing Caribbean islands to a stagnant backwater.
Despite the $3 minimum daily wage that makes industrial labor among the least expensive in the hemisphere, production by Haiti's manufacturing sector, traditionally concentrated in textiles, toys, electronics and sporting goods, shrunk in eight of the last nine years through 1989, the last year for which complete data were available, according to the Inter-American Development Bank.
In recent months, as this slide has continued, several large American companies have pulled up stakes, citing concerns about instability. Among those leaving: the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company, whose operations in the country's industrial zone made Haiti the world's largest producer of baseballs.
"There is an unfortunate perception among customers that because of the chaos they won't get their orders filled on time," one Western diplomat who has sought to promote foreign investment in the country said of companies like K Mart that have begun canceling orders for Haitian-produced clothing. "The fact is that even with all of the changes of Government and strikes and everything else, most of the producers somehow manage to get their goods out."
That has been the case with the Inter-American Leisure Products Company, according to its American owner, Morton Karten. "We have had very few instances of not being able to get our shipments out on time," said Mr. Karten, a 20-year resident of the country whose company, based in Port-au-Prince, makes fishing tackle, embroidered rugs, pillows and tapestries.
"Our customers come here very infrequently nowadays, but happily, they continue to send us their orders," Mr. Karten said, explaining that one result of Haiti's image of violence and instability is that he must travel regularly to the United States and elsewhere to meet with clients who in other times would have made the trip to Haiti themselves.
Like many in the business community in Haiti, Mr. Karten expressed cautious optimism that President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's new Government will be able to turn the country around. "Things could not get much worse than in the last five years," Mr. Karten said. "Even people who favored another candidate for President will tell you it is better to have someone who was elected and is popular than the unelected people we had been having."

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Why Rich New York Is So Poor

BYLINE: By EDWIN S. RUBENSTEIN; Edwin S. Rubenstein, an adjunct fellow of the Manhattan Institute, writes on economics for National Review.

 BODY:
In his latest budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York proposes sizable cuts in Medicaid, local aid and the state payroll, which fiscal conservatives have been urging for years. Yet even after these cuts are in place, New York will still be spending more per capita and relative to income than most other states. And the Governor's tax increases insure New York's standing as one of the highest taxed states in the nation. Mr. Cuomo has to do better.
The last eight years saw a historic resurgence of New York's economy. Real personal income rebounded from no growth to average annual increases of more than 3 percent. Per capita income in the state zoomed to 20 percent above the national average in 1989, up from 12 percent above in 1983. Despite the current recession, there are nearly one million more New Yorkers working today than eight years ago. The state's unemployment rate edged to 5.5 percent in December; when Mr. Cuomo delivered his first State of the State message, it was 9 percent. 
 The economic expansion pushed tax revenues up a startling 89 percent since 1983. This represents a tax hike of $760 per capita, a figure larger than the total tax collections of some states. While the recession has reduced revenues below prior projections, so far revenues are ahead of last year.
Had state spending merely kept pace with personal income, Albany would have a surplus today, recession or no recession. But the opportunity was squandered. Spending has consistently outpaced the incomes of New Yorkers, even in boom years.
Department of Commerce data show that from 1983 to 1988 (the latest years for which data on all states are available) total New York State spending rose from $31.9 billion to $50.4 billion, or from 14.7 percent of state personal income to 15.7 percent. The other 49 states managed to cut spending relative to income over this period.
The fiscal crisis in Albany clearly stems from too much spending rather than too little revenue. New Yorkers can be excused for not understanding this, however. As State Comptroller Edward Regan has repeatedly pointed out, the state budget conceals the true size and growth of spending with a bewildering array of special funds.
Albany can claim to "cut" tax-supported general-fund spending with creative accounting. Since 1983, for example, many state agencies long considered general-fund expenses have been switched off-budget, to special-revenue funds. The Public Service Commission, the Banking Department, the Consumer Protection Board, parts of the Departments of Agriculture and Social Services have all disappeared from the state budget.
While the Comptroller has criticized this practice in official reports, it has become standard operating procedure. Over the past eight years, off-budget spending has risen nearly five times faster than the general fund.
The off-budget trick can be dismissed as simply another game politicians play. But the massive use of one-shot revenue gimmicks to sustain a spending level far beyond the state's fiscal means is a recipe for future disaster. The 1991 budget is "balanced" with $1.8 billion worth of these Rube Goldberg revenue raisers, including the sale of a highway to the State Thruway Authority, the use of the teachers' pension fund contributions to support current operations and the siphoning off of reserved funds that were set up to support future debt service. Each one provides temporary budget relief at the cost of a larger future liability.
Many New Yorkers believe these heroic revenue-raising measures are justified in light of the vast array of unmet social needs. This view ignores waste and abuse.
Medicaid, for example, Albany's most uncontrollable spending program, costs twice as much per recipient in New York as it does in the rest of the nation. Again, despite extensive advice from the Comptroller on how Medicaid costs could be cut, Albany has resisted meaningful reforms.
New York's welfare spending ranks first in the nation as a percentage of personal income, though New York ranks only eighth nationally in the percentage of the population living in poverty. Administrative costs are partly to blame. In 1988, it cost about $1,118 to administer one case through Aid to Families with Dependent Children, compared with an average of $628 nationally.
Social pathology, an aging population and crumbling infrastructure have each been cited as a reason why New York must spend more than other states. Yet disinterested scholars have found that even when needs and local costs are accounted for, New York stands alone.
The best-known of these studies on state spending was developed by Robert W. Rafuse Jr. of the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, a nonpartisan research group supported by New York and other states. Mr. Rafuse's analysis adjusts actual spending levels for such factors as population characteristics, crime rates and even the number of miles residents drive on state roads.
Data for fiscal 1987, the latest available, show that even after adjusting for the state's extraordinary needs and higher costs, Albany and the local governments still spend 52.4 percent more than the national average.
Although the Governor has blamed the recession, the cutback in Federal aid and even the Senate Republicans for the fiscal imbalance, he in fact wields both a line-item veto and broad impoundment powers for spending control. It's time these measures were put to use.

HEADLINE: Sunday Dinner;
For Francophiles, La Cuisine at Its Best

 BODY:
This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some French restaurants in Manhattan.
 
Cafe Un, Deux, Trois
 123 West 44th Street, (212) 354-4148 -- One of the better bets for Broadway theater-district dining, this cavernous brasserie can be loud at peak hours before and after theater, as the din amplifies off the bare walls and tile floor. But it's a great spot to argue about a play or movie you have just seen -- and you can even illustrate your points on the paper tablecloths with crayons set out in a glass.
The vast open dining room is a visual pun of sorts, with its faux marble columns, mustard-colored walls painted to look as if they are peeling, sky murals wrapped in trompe l'oeil frames, deliberately chipped moldings and playful mismatched colors. Waiters and waitresses are extremely well-poised and diction-conscious -- they even sing "Happy Birthday" in five-part harmony.
The service is snappy and efficient under fervid conditions. The short regular menu is supplemented by many daily specials. Among appetizers are the house pork-based terrine, crab cakes with tartar sauce, homemade gravlax, and Caesar salad. Entrees include shrimp in a creamy peppercorn sauce, chicken florentine with spinach in a Dijon mustard sauce, half a roasted duck stuffed with wild rice and served with an orange-Cognac sauce, and a competently prepared steak tartare.
Desserts are straightforward and satisfying. Among them are profiteroles, tarte Tatin and a walnut basket filled with ice cream and fresh fruit, topped with a raspberry sauce and set in a pool of chocolate sauce. Appetizers range from $4.50 to $6.95; entree,s $10.50 to $18.50; desserts, $5.25 to $5.50. Sunday dinner is from 4 to 11 P.M. (Article, Oct. 19, 1990.)
 
Ferrier
 29 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9000 -- This gleaming little bistro just east of Madison Avenue is owned by Alain Chevreaux, who also has Chez Ma Tante in Greenwich Village. Ferrier has a lively little bar up front and a neighborly rectangular dining room in the back with colorful French prints on the walls and a bank of mirrors to minimize claustrophobia.
At peak lunch and dinner hours, the mob here can make Ferrier's chic neighbor, Le Cirque, look underbooked. Early or late reservations are recommended. On the current menu, you might start with baked tomato with mild goat cheese and warm vinaigrette; tuna tartare; snails with eggplant, tomato and garlic butter nested in pastry crust; and terrine of goose foie gras.
For main courses there are chicken breast sauteed and served with a Champagne sauce, artichokes and mushrooms; pan-fried shell steak with crushed peppercorns and a Cognac cream sauce; roasted salmon with a fennel-citrus vinaigrette; and medallions of veal accompanied with a lemon-tarragon sauce and sauteed endives. Desserts include chocolate Charlotte, creme brulee and tarte Tatin.
A $19.95 prix-fixe pre-theater menu is offered featured on Sunday evenings from 5:30 to 6:30 P.M.
Appetizers range from $5.95 to $9.95; entrees, $15.95 to $19.95; desserts, $4.50 to $6. Sunday dinner is served from 6:30 P.M. to midnight. (Diner's Journal, Dec. 1, 1989.)
 
Restaurant Florent
 69 Gansevoort Street, a half block west of Greenwich Street, (212) 989-5779 -- It's an Edward Hopper painting come to life, this World War II coffee shop turned French bistro in the heart of the gritty West Side meat-market area. Formerly the R & L Restaurant, a stainless-steel-and-Formica hash house that catered to butchers and truck drivers in the market's heyday, it was taken over by a genial young Frenchman, Florent Morellet. The new owner changed the name to Restaurant Florent but left the period decor largely intact.
The menu has abandoned "Adam and Eve on a raft" (poached eggs on toast) for French onion soup gratinee, duck mousse, couscous, sweetbreads, grilled calf's liver and other homey Gallic fare. Not only is much of the food surprisingly well prepared, it's also a bargain. On Sunday nights Florent is offering a "menu recession" at two different prices: $14.95 from 6 to 7:30 P.M., and $16.95 from 7:30 to 11:30 P.M. The a la carte menu is also available.
For starters, duck liver mousse is freshly made, creamy and well seasoned; and rillettes of pork are appropriately rough-textured and peppery. Other dishes include the inky and oniony boudin noir; steak au poivre; and choucroute garnie, which is a Sunday special. A vegetarian plate is also offered every night, according to fresh produce availability. For desserts there are sour-cream chocolate cake, apple tart and creme caramel. Appetizers range from $3.95 to $6.95; entrees, $8.50 to $16.75; desserts, $4 to $5. Cash only. Open 24 hours a day; Sunday dinner menu served from 6 to 11:30 P.M. (Article, March 24, 1989.)

HEADLINE: How to Teach Arithmetic So That It Stimulates Young Minds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Jan. 14 article on the effect of proposed budget cuts on one north Bronx school displays vividly a principal cause for the low levels of interest and attainment in mathematics and science by American students. The photograph shows a blackboard on which five arithmetic problems have been worked. As far as can be checked from the partly obscured writing, only one of the five was done correctly. But the mistakes don't indicate what's wrong in that schoolroom; for that you have to think about the exercises. They are all multiplications of four-digit numbers by three-digit or four-digit numbers. Nobody in his or her right mind would undertake such an exercise outside the schoolroom, or expect to get the right answer. The calculator has banished such tedious tasks. Why subject students to them in the classroom?
The standard answer is: To teach the principles of arithmetic. Hogwash! Tedious exercises can't teach principles. What they teach is that arithmetic, and by extension mathematics, and by further extension most other school subjects, is stultifying drudgery. The only escapes are to close your mind, play hooky or drop out. Students resort to all three. 
 There are alternatives to teaching by drudgery, and they don't strain scant resources. What goes on inside the calculator can be conveyed perfectly well by two digit times two digit examples without burying the logic in mounds of rote operations.
And there are more important and more stimulating things to be taught in the arithmetic class. The most important is a sense of proportion and a feeling for magnitude. The significant thing in multiplying 6,158 X 387 (the exercise shown most clearly on the blackboard) is to see that the result must be about 6,000 X 400 or 24,000 X 100 or 2.4 million, so that the answer on the blackboard is at a glance implausibly low. The person who did that multiplication got the last three digits right, precisely the ones that aren't worth computing.
So the art of estimation should be emphasized: staying awake and using common sense instead of applying memorized rules mindlessly. That's how the scientist or mathematician does his or her arithmetic, and it is fun rather than drudgery. It would not drive the students out of the classroom. Some of them might even find that approach challenging and interesting.
 
ROBERT DORFMAN
Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 28, 1991
 
 
The writer retired as the David A. Wells Professor of Political Economy at Harvard University.

HEADLINE: Using Borrowed Money to Defend Foreign Economies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the Business Diary on Jan. 20, the headline on the lead item read, "Why Can't America Make a VCR to Match Its F-117?" The article cited the manifest technological superiority of American weapons and asked: Why can't America "make the world's best VCR's? Or compact cars?"
The answer is very simple. We put our best brains and much of our research money into designing high-technology weapons of destruction. Our competitors, in contrast, put theirs to work to develop computer technology and consumer goods. And they do that while we are spending money to defend their oil sources -- and having to borrow the money from them to do it.
 
NIELS H. NIELSEN
New York, N.Y., Jan. 21

HEADLINE: Hindu Party in India Seeks a Governing Image

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Feb. 9

 BODY:
In a move that could strengthen its image as an alternative government for India, the conservative Bharatiya Janata Party has named a shadow cabinet in preparation for the opening of a crucial session of Parliament later this month.
Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, whose party commands only 56 seats in a lower house of 517 members, is expected to face strong challenges on domestic and foreign issues, including the decision to allow the refueling of American planes bound for the Persian Gulf. The Government could easily topple ifthe Congress Party withdraws the support that gives Mr. Shekhar its ruling majority in Parliament. 
 Bharatiya Janata, a Hindu party, leads the opposition in Parliament to Mr. Shekhar's minority Government. L. K. Advani, the party's legislative leader, has already upstaged two former Prime Ministers, Rajiv Gandhi and V. P. Singh, on the floor of the lower house.
Mr. Singh's National Front Government fell in November after Bharatiya Janata withdrew its support on issues of affirmative action for lower castes and of Mr. Singh's opposition to the campaign by militant Hindus to build atemple on the site of a Muslim mosque in northern India. Mr. Shekhar defected from Mr. Singh's party and claimed the prime ministership with the backing of the Congress Party, which did not want to contest an election.
Atal Behari Vajpayee, a Bharatiya Janata leader, said that the fielding of an organized alternative cabinet in the tradition of the British Parliament will be an innovation in Indian politics, where Parliament debate has lately degenerated into chaos.
The opposition's shadow ministers -- or spokesmen -- will be backed by expert panels in various areas of government like foreign policy, domestic affairs, the economy, and law and justice.
"Debates do require some preparation and some expertise," Mr. Vajpayee, the party's leader in the upper house and a former Foreign Minister, said in an interview.
The party just concluded a national convention, during which it made an effort to project itself as the first national alternative to the dominant Congress Party.
The Bharatiya Janata Party -- its name in English means Indian People's Party -- considers itself liberal, in favor of private enterprise and reformist in social policy, Mr. Vajpayee said. The party also supports a nuclear weapons program for India.
Indian political analysts, even those who fear that religious harmony and secular democracy are threatened bythe growth of the Bharatiya Janata Party, concede that the party appeals to many voters, including young people, because of its reputation for discipline and incorruptibility.
But its involvement in the campaign to build a temple to the god Rama in the northern city of Ayodhya, while popular among militant Hindus, dampened enthusiasm among other voters.
With another national election expected, the party is working to temper its image. A physics professor at Allahabad University, Murli Manohar Joshi, has been elected party president.
Mr. Vajpayee, the Bharatiya Janata Party leader in the upper house, said: "We are not a religious party; we have never been a religious party. But we do take note of the changing Hindu psyche."
"There is a feeling that Hindus aretaken for granted," he went on, "and there is now a reaction to this." More than 80 percent of Indians are Hindus.
With Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party consumed by internal disagreements and Mr. Singh's Janata Dal split after the defections that brought down his Government in November, the disciplined Bharatiya Janata Party is confident. It controls the governments of three states -- Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Himachal Pradesh -- and is organizing down to the local level in most others.
Mr. Singh and his allies among the Communist parties are not counted out by political analysts, however. Last week, the Communist-led state government of Kerala swept local elections with the help of Mr. Singh's campaign appearances. The Congress Party lost nearly everywhere.

HEADLINE: Assault Charge Sends Pickets to Queens Grocery

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A group of black Queens residents called for a boycott of a Korean-owned grocery store in Elmhurst yesterday after a Korean employee was arrested and charged with assaulting an 11-year-old black boy. The police said the store worker said he thought the boy was shoplifting.
The store owner acknowledged yesterday that his worker may have overstepped his bounds, but said the boy had caused trouble in the store and shoplifted for several months and had just splattered detergent all over one of the aisles. 
 About 25 people, including a dozen children, marched in front of the C-Town Supermarket, at 57th Avenue and 97th Street near the Lefrak City housing complex yesterday afternoon, yelling "Boycott C-Town." They carried signs and urged people not to enter the store.
Earlier yesterday, about 40 demonstrators led by the Rev. Herbert Daughtry rallied in front of the store. "If anything else like this happens again, they should either close it down or let us take it over," said Mr. Daughtry, pastor of the House of the Lord Pentacostal Church in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn.
 
Calls for Calm
 But several prominent blacks from the Queens area called for calm, saying they met with the store's owner, Francis Ahn, on Friday and were satisfied that he was working to remedy the problems that caused the incident. They said they hoped to avoid a boycott like the one of a small Korean grocery in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
"The people don't want to see what happened in Brooklyn happen here," said Assemblywoman Helen M. Marshall, a Democratic representing the 35th District, which includes Elmhurtst. "We feel we don't have to do a massive demonstration. We can work with him."
But she added, "If the man doesn't cooperate, he might have to close his store down."
Throughout the protest, customers -- many of them black and Hispanic -- continued to shop at the store as the protesters were kept behind police barricades.
Residents said the protest sprang from the same bitter roots of cultural misunderstanding and economic envy that fed the long, bitter boycott of the Red Apple Grocery at 1823 Church Avenue in Flatbush. That yearlong conflict, which began after a Korean employee was accused of assaulting a black patron, came to symbolize racial tensions between blacks and the Korean immigrants who have become proprietors of many stores in black neighborhoods. It drew national attention and put pressure on Mayor David N. Dinkins, who was criticized for not settling the dispute quickly.
 
Employee Spoke Little English

On Jan. 31, Pong Ok Jang, the 32-year-old manager of the Red Apple, was aquitted of misdemeanor assault charges. He had been accused a year earlier of slapping Gieslaine Felissaint, a 47-year-old home-care worker born in Haiti.
The police said the confrontation in Queens started about 4:45 P.M. on Tuesday after the boy, Bobby Yates, went to the store with his mother, Cynthia Yates. The boy wandered away from his mother in the full-size supermarket and became embroiled in a dispute with a 53-year-old employee who spoke little English, the police said.
The employee, Kim Yon Cha, cuffed the boy on the left ear, accused him of shoplifting and then took him to a back room. The police said he kept him there for nearly a half-hour until his mother was located.
After Ms. Yates discovered what had happened, she took her son to Elmhurst General Hospital, where he was treated for a minor cut, the police said. Mr. Kim, of 79-11 41st Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, was arrested on misdemeanor assault charges and released on his own recognizance.
Ms. Yates said yesterday that Mr. Kim came up behind her son, grabbed him by the hair, twisted his arm behind him and threw him into a rack of shelves, causing bottles to fall on his head. She also said Mr. Kim locked the boy in a freezer for a half-hour.
"I believe it's part of a racist thing that goes on in there," Ms. Yates said. "He is very traumatized. He was badly beaten."
The owner of the store, Francis Ahn, 46, gave a different account. He said Mr. Kim chased Bobby and grabbed him after the boy ran down an aisle, knocking things down, and spilled a large plastic bottle of detergent on the floor. He said the boy was well-known to employees as a trouble-maker who ran through the aisles and sometimes stole small things.
"This kid is extraordinary," Mr. Ahn said. "Every time he comes in he does aggravating things."
He said Mr. Kim caught Bobby after he slipped and fell in the soap, and pushed him into a back room "for a talk." The clerk told the boy he would call his parents and the police if he kept running through the aisles, he said. But Bobby burst into tears, and Mr. Kim's resolve melted, and he let him go after two or three minutes, he said.
"It was just a simple talk," Mr. Ahn said. "We never locked him in the freezer as they are claiming." He refused to say anything about whether Mr. Kim had hit the boy because he did not see it, he said.
Mr. Ahn said that, under American standards, his employees may have done something wrong, but in Korea, his actions would have been acceptable. There, he said, adults often scold or punish other people's children, he said. "We treat all the kids as our own son," he said. "We can say something. Here it is against the law."
 
Suit is Planned
 A spokesman for the police, Officer Kim Royster, said there was no evidence the boy had been put in a freezer or seriously hurt.
Ms. Yates said she planned to sue the store, an independently owned outlet of the C-Town chain, and she declined to discuss what evidence she had that her son had been locked up and mistreated.
Several leaders of community organizations said there was growing animosity among black residents toward Korean store owners in the area because in the last five years many black business owners in the area have suffered economic setbacks and have been forced to sell their establishments. At the same time, Korean families have bought many businesses along 57th Avenue that serve the huge Lefrak housing complex. There is a widespread perception, the leaders said, that Korean entreprenuers have an easier time getting business loans than blacks.
"It's our community and everything is owned by people other than blacks," said Albert Blake, a paralegal who is a member of the Lefrak tenants' council. "There are no stores in the community owned by blacks any more."
 
Differences in Customs
 Mr. Ahn said he had 60 employees. Twelve are Korean; the rest are black or Hispanic, he said.
Mr. Blake and other residents said that some blacks are frustrated because few Korean merchants speak English and several have customs the Americans do not understand. For example, Koreans consider it impolite to smile during a business transaction.
Mr. Blake and others said such cultural gaps were raised at a meeting on Friday between Mr. Ahn and LeFrak tenant leaders.
"We had to explain to him that 'this is not your country; this is not your culture,' " Mr. Blake said. "When you can't communicate with people you're spending money with, it creates problems."
A group of 12 tenant leaders, local politicians and members of the clergy are to meet with Mr. Ahn on Wednesday to discuss ways to improve relations. Several said Mr. Ahn has cooperated in the past.
"There have been complaints of people going into this store and not being treated the way they should," Ms. Marshall, the assemblywoman, said. "But he's been very responsive. He's fired people on the spot."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bobby Yates, foreground, demonstrating with friends in front of a Korean-owned store in Elmhurst, Queens, where the police said he was assaulted last week by an employee who accused him of shoplifting. (Photographs by Eddie Hausner/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: RHODE ISLAND GETS BANK BAILOUT LAW

BYLINE: AP
LP>Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun has signed into law a measure aimed at resolving the state's banking and credit union crisis and putting refund checks into the hands of depositors at 14 failed state-chartered institutions within two months.
The legislation was signed by the Governor on Friday, 30 minutes after it had cleared the State Senate on a vote of 31 to 17, and a day after the House had passed it by 60 to 30.

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 9

 BODY:
 The new law creates a bailout agency, the Depositors Economic Protection Corporation, which will take over and then liquidate the assets of the 14 failed institutions and provide refunds to their depositors, whose money has been frozen for the last month.
Depositors with accounts of $100,000 or less will get all their money back. For each increment of $100,000 above that, a depositor will lose 10 percent. This incremental scale has a floor of 50 percent, which will apply to that portion of an account above $500,000.
 
$150 Million Bond Issue
 The bailout will be financed by a $150 million bond issue that the state will pay off by keeping the state sales tax at 7 percent instead of rolling it back to 6.5 percent next July, as had been planned.
Mr. Sundlun, a Democrat who defeated the Republican incumbent, Edward D. DiPrete, in November, said he would appoint a board for the new agency on Monday or Tuesday. The takeover and the liquidation of assets are to begin immediately afterward.
The Governor said depositors with accounts in institutions that voluntarily go into receivership with the Depositors Economic Protection Corporation could expect checks within 45 days. Accounts in institutions involuntarily taken over will be refunded within 60 days, he said.
The state's crisis dates from Jan. 1, when Mr. Sundlun, a few hours after being sworn in as Governor, closed 45 banks and credit unions because of the collapse of their private insurer, the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corporation.
Of the 31 institutions not addressed by the new law, 27 have since reopened with insurance coverage by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or the National Credit Union Adminisitration, and the four others have either gone out of business or become rechartered as loan origination offices, which accept no deposits.
The 14 institutions addressed by the new law were all rejected for Federal insurance, largely because the proportion of real estate holdings among their assets was deemed too high. Their deposits total $1.3 billion.
