HEADLINE: AIRLINE NEAR PACT WITH PILOTS' UNION

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 9

 BODY:
American Airlines and the union representing its 8,900 pilots said today that they had tentatively resolved a 16-month contract dispute in which many pilots were prepared to strike if demands for higher pay and other terms were not met.
Details of the new pact were unclear, but people close to the talks, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said both sides agreed to take to Government-sponsored arbitration their continuing differences over whether the pilots should pay part of their medical insurance costs. 
 American's negotiators offered the pay increase just hours after talks appeared to break down early Thursday, in a shift that appeared to move the two sides toward the tentative agreement. The deal was completed this morning at 8:45 in Washington, after the talks went through the night, both sides said in a statement.
A strike by pilots would have inflicted heavy losses on American, which like other airlines has lost money from higher jet fuel costs, the recession and a decline in passengers on its international routes since the Persian Gulf war started on Jan. 17.
 
Flights Had Been Trimmed

"We're pleased to have this agreement," Al Becker, a company spokesman, said. "We want to put this whole period behind us and move forward."
American trimmed the number of its daily flights by 250, to 2,050, last month, after accusing pilots of disrupting hundreds of flights over the Christmas holidays through delays on runways, absences that the pilots attributed to illness, and other actions.
The airline had planned to continue flying in the event of a walkout, using those who crossed picket lines as well as newly hired pilots to replace those on strike.
Final terms of the pact are to be completed next week. The 20 pilots who are directors of the Allied Pilots Association, the in-house union representing the American pilots, are to vote on the pact after a final, legal draft is completed later next week, said Wally Pitts, a union spokesman.
The outcome of the vote by the 20 pilots did not appear to be in doubt. Approval by them would make the contract final, since it does not have to be approved by the pilots' association.
In their joint statement, Fred Vogel, the union president, and Ralph Craviso, American's head of employee relations, said they were satisfied "that a long and difficult period of negotiations had been successfully concluded with a mutually beneficial contract." Details of the pact should be made public soon, they added.
 
Wanted to Match Delta

The pilots were seeking a pay scale to match one obtained last July by pilots at Delta Airlines making them the highest paid in the airline industry. Under that plan, high-ranking captains on wide-body aircraft, like Boeing 747's or McDonnell Douglas DC-10's, are paid $176,130 a year after 12 years.
American had proposed a pay scale last November offering similar captains $165,569. American raised the offer to about $170,000 when the talks moved to Washington on Jan. 7 under the supervision of a Federal mediator.
The November plan matched the pay for pilots at Northwest Airlines. American is the nation's largest airline, ranked by revenue, followed in descending order by United, Delta, Northwest and USAir.
American said last month that the higher, revised offer would have added more than $1 billion to salaries for the pilots over five years, with the average pilot's salary rising to $105,000.
 
Bonus Formula Offered

American also offered a bonus formula based on the airline's yearly profits that, in its view, could have given pilots more money than Delta's pilots in years when American was highly profitable.
American described the offer as its final position, but negotiatiors for the pilots rejected it on Jan. 30. At that point, Harry Bickford, the Federal mediator, recessed the talks for four days and, according to the airline-union statement today, "greatly facilitated" discussions this week that led to the accord today.
Mr. Bickford, who entered the talks in March 1990, could have advised the National Mediation Board to declare an impasse after the stalemate on Jan. 30 and begin a 30-day "cooling off" period that could have resulted in a pilot walkout early in March.
The dispute over medical insurance, which the airline and union have handed to binding arbitration, should be resolved within 90 days after an agreement on other issues is signed, said Mr. Pitts, the union spokesman.
American wants the pilots to make payments, starting at an average of less than $300 a year, toward rising insurance costs. The union opposes making any medical payments.

HEADLINE: Environmental Tax Urged for Some Products

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The Worldwatch Institute, a leading environmental research group, said today that governments should impose heavy taxes on "products and activities that pollute, deplete or otherwise degrade natural systems."
By taxing products like the carbon in coal and oil and activities like dumping hazardous wastes, the United States could raise more than $130 billion a year while protecting the air, water and other natural systems that support life, the institute said in its 1991 "State of the World" report.The report acknowledged that such taxes would be passed along to consumers in the form of higher prices for things like gasoline, paper, waste disposal, drinking water, farm produce and electricity. To offset the effect on low-income families, it said, income taxes could be reduced. 
 It identified eight potential "green" taxes: $100 a ton on the carbon content of fossil fuels like coal and oil; $100 a ton on hazardous wastes; $64 a ton on paper from virgin pulp; a tax of 50 percent of total sales of pesticides; $150 a ton on sulfur dioxide emissions; $100 a ton on nitrous oxides emissions; $5.83 a kilogram on chloroflurocarbon sales, atax already in effect in the United States, and $50 per acre-foot of water for depletion of water under the ground.
 
'Correcting Market's Failure'
 "Taxes are appealing because they offer an efficient way of correcting for the market's failure to value environmental services," the report said. "Taxing products and activities that pollute, deplete or otherwise degrade natural systems is a way of insuring that environmental costs are taken into account in private decisions -- whether to commute by car or bicycle, for example, or to generate electricity fromcoal or sunlight."
The report said a tax on the carbon content of fossil fuels was "urgently needed" to slow the onset of global warming caused by the carbon dioxide that results from burning them.
A study by the Congressional Budget Office last year found that although such a tax could be effective in reducing carbon dioxide emissions, it would be "hazardous for the economy if imposed too rapidly."
But the budget office said that phased in gradually over the next 10 years and reaching $100 a ton by the year 2000, such taxes would reduce the gross national product growth by as little as 1 percent and no more than 2 percent over that period. The $100 a ton charge maintained over the longer run would hold the G.N.P. 1 percent below what it would have been annually, thebudget office estimated.
Congress is not considering environmental taxes, and the draft energy plan being circulated by the Bush Administration pointedly omits any new taes on fuels like gasoline.
 
One Environmental Tax Working

There is relatively little experience with environmental taxes in this country. The Federal Government did impose a $5.83 a kilogram tax on chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, two years ago as incentive to industry to find substitutes for these widely used industrial chemicals that endanger the earth's protective ozone layer. The tax is expected to raise about $5 billion over five years.
Kevin Fay, executive director of the Alliance for Responsible CFC Policy, an industry lobbying group, said that the tax was effective at raising revenue but was probably not needed to force producers to make less harmful substitutes. Production of CFC's is "way down," Mr. Fay said, adding that the chief reasons were the slack economy and the pressure from scientists and environmentalists to find substitute chemicals, as well as an international treaty requiring that use of the chemicals be ended by the year 2000.
A variety of environmental taxes have been introduced by Western European countries in recent years. A report by the Commission of the European Communities last year found that many of them had achieved their purposes. For example, an 8 percent tax on leaded gasoline, introduced in Britain in 1989, led to an increase in the market share of unleaded gasoline to 30 percent from 4 percent in one year.

HEADLINE: Calling Bank Supervision Archaic, Greenspan Seeks Major Change

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 9

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, called today for major changes in the way Federal bank examiners supervise lending practices at commercial banks. He said that by often failing to recognize banking's true nature, the examiners had played a significant role in making banks reluctant to lend.
"They are responding inappropriately," Mr. Greenspan said. "Even if we did not have a credit crunch, it would be wise to look at this process because the very structure is an archaic one." 
Mr. Greenspan said he had "never been interested in bank supervision as a technical issue until" it restricted bank lending and affected the economy.
In a luncheon speech at the semiannual meeting of the directors of the National Association of Manufacturers, and in a brief interview afterwards, Mr. Greenspan offered an endorsement of banking's special role in society that he had not made so explicitly in the past.
Although bank supervision was the main thrust of his speech, he said a lack of demand for new loans was the most important reason for the cutback in lending that has hit the economy in the past eight or nine months. Consumers and companies, in effect, are intensifying the recession because they do not want to borrow for spending and investment. "We do not see any evidence that lending is opening up," he said. He noted that the Federal Reverse's recent interest rate reductions were aimed at encouraging lending, and his concern that lending has not picked up left open the possibility of more interest rate cuts.
 
Example of Real Estate
 Aside for the weak demand for loans, the Federal examination process plays a significant role in limiting credit, a role best illustrated in real estate lending, Mr. Greenspan said. The examiners have encouraged loan appraisals that can miss the point of a bank's role in society.
"There is an increasing tendency to look at deposit institutions and say we should mark to market the loan portfolios, meaning trying to regain the values -- in real estate, for example -- that the loans represent if we sold them in the market tomorrow," Mr. Greenspan said.
This tendency produces two problems, the Federal Reserve chairman said. One is that just as bank appraisers overvalued real estate in the mid-1980's, expecting prices to keep rising, they are "low balling" a property's value because of expectations that prices will continue to fall. Partly as a result, banks are offering inadequate loans.
 
The Nature of Banking
 The entire procedure, in the mid-1980's and now, conflicts with the true nature of banking, Mr. Greenspan said. Banks should not be treating long portfolios as if they believed that they "have to be out of business tomorrow," he said.
"This is fundamentally wrong because commercial banking, and savings and loan activities as well, are a very special form of activity," Mr. Greenspan said. "Commercial banking is the practice by which you make illiquid loans."
Bankers should determine the profitability of a loan over its lifetime, even 20 years, and not the day-to-day value of the underlying real estate and, when borrowers get into trouble, the banks should work with them to solve the problem, Mr. Greenspan said. The bank examination process should reflect this role of banking.
 
Long-Term View
 "The basic process is not to get paid back immediately or to sell the loan," but to carry the loan for its full life, Mr. Greenspan said. Accounting practices, as well as the examination process, should reflect this, he added.
The Federal regulators and the Treasury "are trying to figure out what types of regulatory changes should be instituted," Mr. Greenspan said. "We are trying to get some sense of how what we conceive of as a mistaken process is adding to the credit crunch."
In his remarks to more than 140 top executives of manufacturing companies, Mr. Greenspan made no references to the economic outlook, to how soon the recession might end or to the impact of the Persian Gulf war on the economy. In the past, he has blamed the recession primarily on the Gulf crisis and the damage it has done to consumer confidence.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Washington's Plan To Funnel City Aid Through the States Enrages the Mayors

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the Depression year of 1933, when people were starving in the streets, three mayors came to Washington, met with President Franklin D. Roosevelt and asked for emergency assistance. Over the objections of governors, who argued that aid should be funneled exclusively through the states, Congress in 1933 earmarked 25 percent of each state's road funds for municipal projects.
The perennial tension between governors and mayors exploded again last week in their responses to President Bush's proposal to turn over $15 billion of Federal programs to the states. In a move to celebrate the "innovative power of states as laboratories," Mr. Bush proposed to strip away Federal restrictions on use of the money, a relatively small portion of the $171 billion that the Federal Government expects to distribute in grants to state and local governments for an immense array of programs next year. 
 Many governors expressed interest in the proposal. The idea of gaining more flexibility in the use of Federal money is "very attractive to the states," said Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington, chairman of the National Governors Association.
But mayors complained that it was, in the words of Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, another salvo in Washington's "10-year steady assault on America's cities."
 
Tapping the Pipeline
 Mayors now fear that Mr. Bush's proposal would permit the states to siphon money from the pipeline that carries cash from the United States Treasury directly to hundreds of cities.
Mayors were apoplectic last week when they learned, for instance, that Mr. Bush's budget proposal included the Community Development Block Grants on a list of the programs that might be turned over to the states. The program provides $3.1 billion a year for housing, street repairs, parks and playgrounds, child care, shelters for battered women and other public services to benefit people with low or moderate income. Cities and urban counties now get two-thirds of the money; states get the remainder.
In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 29, President Bush said transferring such programs to the states would move "power and decision-making closer to the people." But Mayor Robert M. Isaac of Colorado Springs, president of the United States Conference of Mayors, said that under the proposal power would actually be further removed from the people because decisions about how to spend community development funds would be made by state officials, rather than at the local level.
For their part, states, in fiscal distress themselves, need every dollar they can find. Even as Mr. Bush proposed devolution of Federal programs to the state level, governors were begging Washington to pay more of the cost of Medicaid, the fast-growing health program for poor people.
Apart from the tensions between governors and mayors, the outlook for Mr. Bush's proposal is fraught with other problems.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said last week that the Administration wanted to negotiate with the governors and with the National Conference of State Legislatures on which Federal programs should be turned over to the states. Surely, he implied, they should be able to agree on a package.
After all, there are 478 Federal grant programs that distribute more than $100 billion a year for specific activities narrowly defined by law. Each "categorical grant" program is a separate spigot. There are 17 for highways, 22 for pollution control, 65 for health services and 98 for education.
Some might think it would be easy to consolidate the six Federal grant programs for urban mass transit, or the 16 for education of handicapped children. But such an expectation ignores the political reality: Behind each grant is at least one member of Congress, zealously interested in the program and responding to hundreds of thousands of people who benefit from it.
Another obstacle will be the committees of Congress, which are unlikely to approve Mr. Bush's proposal to turn over $15 billion worth of programs to the states "in a single consolidated grant." Nearly every committee has some grants within its purview and would fight to retain control of the money.
But it is conceivable that Congress might revise Mr. Bush's proposal by merging some of the smaller grant programs into a new or expanded block grant for a broad purpose like mental health, highways or elementary education. At the very least, Congress could give states more leeway to shift money between similar grant programs.
Whether the proposal survives in its current form or not, Ralph Tabor, a lobbyist for the National Association of Counties, commented: "If you put all this money together into one pot and the governors can transfer funds from one program to another, there is no assurance the original purposes of the current grants will be met."
The unanswered questions already being raised about Mr. Bush's block grant proposal suggest that it was hastily devised to put flesh on the bones of his domestic policy. White House officials said the aid formula could be written so that each state would receive a lump sum roughly equal to the total amount it now receives from all the separate grants being consolidated. But many details have yet to be worked out. It is impossible to say whether any particular city or state would be a winner or a loser.
President Bush said that if he transfers Federal programs to the states, they would be "fully funded" for five years. His vow was meant to pacify state and local officials who know that Washington likes to give them new responsibilities with no new money.
But what did Mr. Bush mean?
There would be $15 billion a year for five years, without any allowance for inflation. In promising this amount, the Administration assumed that costs would soar in some categories while spending would be slashed in others. Thus, states are asked to take full responsibility for the cost of administering welfare, food stamps and Medicaid, and the Administration asssumes those costs will grow 62 percent, to $8.3 billion, in 1996. Over the same period, it assumes that states can get along with a 56 percent cut in Federal grants for construction of sewage treatment plants and an 83 percent cut in Federal money to help poor people heat their homes.
City residents might well notice a difference.
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research group, notes that 80 percent of the program funds suggested for consolidation into a block grant are now used to help people with low incomes.
"The Administration's proposal thus could pose a significant risk to poor families" because they have historically had less political influence at the state level than at the Federal level, he said.
"State legislatures tend to be dominated by suburban and rural interests," said Mayor William J. Althaus of York, Pa., a Republican. Calling Mr. Bush's block grant proposal "very ill-conceived," Mr. Althaus spoke for many mayors when he said at a news conference last week that he thought there was no reason to tamper with a system that was working.
States, of course, are repeatedly mentioned in the Constitution. Cities and counties are not; they exist as agencies of the states. Presidents have given differing degrees of recognition to the cities. Some mayors say they never had a better friend in the White House than Richard M. Nixon, who promoted revenue sharing, community development grants and operating subsidies for mass transit. By contrast, President Ronald Reagan, a former governor, preferred to do business with the governors. He often acted as if he believed that no one, not even the Federal Government, should tell sovereign states how to behave.
In his new budget, Mr. Bush likewise celebrates that sovereignty.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1937 words

HEADLINE: Adding It All Up;
Battle Plans Are Deadly Simple; The Strategic Weapon Is Politics

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FROM the chain of command, all the way up to George Bush, the word to the public last week was that the war in the Persian Gulf was going according to plan -- as if the Bush Administration had subverted the military maxim first uttered by Count Helmuth von Moltke the Elder, the Prussian Chief of Staff who said no battle plan survives contact with the enemy.
In fact, though, the first three weeks of the war had illustrated the ability of combat to surprise those who plan it -- from the need to divert air power to hunt down mobile Scud missile launchers, to the ability of Saddam Hussein's Republican Guards to dig in and resist, to the chanting of mobs in the streets of Morocco, Jordan and Yemen. 
 All of these developments reflected the extent to which this has been a war in which political imperatives, both in the United States and abroad, have played an extraordinary role in shaping strategy. And that only promised to continue this week, when President Bush is to sit down with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and General Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to confront the tough decision of when to initiate a ground campaign against the world's fourth largest army.
Part of that decision would be determining what kind of ground campaign would stand the best chance of ending the war with the fewest American casualties. Mr. Cheney, on the ground in Saudi Arabia, already was hinting at strategies to put allied forces on the flanks of Iraq's army to draw the enemy out of its fortifications into the killing fields of allied air power. Other military officials said allied forces would wage a ground war on the margins of Iraq's brute dug-in power, nibbling away from a safe distance and following a ground strategy called "destruction in detail."
So far, this has been a very different kind of war: the first over-the-horizon war, fought by two military giants of completely different form, and fought in heavily scheduled phases; one party, the United States and its allies, has controlled the pace and the timing of destruction by virtue of its control of the airspace over the theater of operations.
Of the two powers, one, Iraq, is comparatively low-tech, ground-based and completely dependent on a strategy of damage absorption, attrition against the attacking force, perseverance without resupply and the use of unconventional weapons to incite political terror. Ultimately, it is in this ability to absorb punishment and survive that Iraq's leader places his hopes for victory -- not the military victory of prevailing on the battlefield, but the political victory that might be wrung from outlasting an onslaught from the world's greatest military powers.
The other giant, the American-led coalition, relies on a technology-based strategy of stand-off destruction with precision weapons to protect its manpower base, to which it attaches the highest premium. For it, too, the definition of success is in large part political: The allies are prosecuting a war under a political imperative of casualty limitation as great or greater than in any previous American conflict.
The closing phase of the war still lies in the murky distance. But with the continued destruction of Iraq's national infrastructure -- roads, bridges, power plants, refineries and basic industries, much of which have served military as well as civilian purposes -- some important voices inside and outside the coalition have begun to question the scale of the allied bombing strategy beyond the Kuwaiti border.
If the Bush Administration has begun to address such questions as how Iraq will feed itself the morning after the war ends, it is not apparent in the President's public diplomacy. This remains narrowly focused on the villainy of Saddam Hussein, a tenacious adversary who many experts believe is likely to survive, firmly in control of his power base, still sitting on the world's second largest pool of oil and still rampant on the Arab political landscape.
Last week's offer by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to assist any postwar Iraqi regime so long as it is not headed by Mr. Hussein appeared more as a political ploy to undermine the Iraqi leader than a genuine offer of help, telegraphing as it did an assumption of punitive treatment of Iraq in the event that Mr. Hussein survives.
In a strictly military sense, the strategy unfolding in the Persian Gulf is not surprising to people who have watched military doctrine evolve at the Pentagon over the last decade. Mr. Bush's generals are peeling back the layers of a "relentlessly simple, almost pedestrian" blueprint, as one White House official called it, to murder the body of Iraqi military power with a thousand well-aimed cuts.
The plan was on the shelf in the text of the Pentagon's Air-Land Doctrine, 40 linear feet of strategy and tactics written over the last decade as technology, complexity and Congress all forced the services to operate jointly on the battlefield, with all the services arms of each other under a unified theater command.
On the Arabian Peninsula, the classical rules of warfare have been adapted to microchip weapons, desert geography and the peculiar mismatch of strengths and weaknesses between the adversaries. Even General Powell's bumper-sticker description betrayed the simplicity of the concept when he described the plan for defeating Iraq's 30-division force around Kuwait: "First we're going to cut it off and then we're going to kill it."
But radiating out from this simple strategy is the real tension of this war, and the basis for the observation by one former Pentagon intelligence official that General Powell may be winning the war he is fighting while Saddam Hussein may also be winning the war he is fighting.
Unquestionably, Mr. Hussein is pursuing a political-military strategy, seeking to make his place in history as an indefatigable Arab warrior holding out against the greatest military onslaught that could be served up by the superpowers. He intends to stand as the leader of an Arab Sparta, a personification of third-world aspirations who, in his own dangerous way, dared to be great.
He has not hidden his battle strategy from the West, but has gloried in its strength and simplicity.
"They will tell you that America is developed in terms of missiles, developed in aircraft, and developed in its ability to jam the Iraqis," Mr. Hussein told an Islamic conference five days before war broke out.
"They have weapons that strike from afar," he said, but added that "under all circumstances, one who wants to evict a fighter from the land will eventually depend on a soldier who walks on the ground and comes with a hand grenade, rifle and bayonet to fight the soldier in the battle trench.
"If you go to the theater of operations now," Mr. Hussein said, "you will not see the thousands of tanks and the millions of people. You may see traffic on public roads; the rest are all well fortified under the ground so that when they direct fire towards them to allow their tanks and infantry to advance, the fighters will emerge safe and able to fight.
"All this technological superiority, which is on paper," he said, "will eventually be tested in the theater of operations. We are not people who speak on the basis of books; we are people with experience in fighting."
As he holds out in his bunker, Mr. Hussein has not left the briefings to his generals, as Mr. Bush has done. The Iraqi leader uses no pointer, no charts; he briefs with rhetoric, distortion and his own social mythology about the subjugation of the have-nots by the haves -- all of it designed to inflame Arab and other third-world sensibilities about the return of the colonial powers to visit destruction on Arab lands and Islamic shrines.
In the ground war ahead, Mr. Hussein has promised the "Mother of All Battles," an Islamic Armageddon to join all Arab grievances into one holy war. He has wrapped his defiance in Kuwait in the mantle of Palestinian nationalism; his struggle has thus fused his cause with the plight of a people who feel the United Nations has left them in the torpor of resolutions unenforced and expectations unfulfilled. In addition, he has joined to the Palestinian struggle his own paranoid view that the West was out to bring Iraq low after his "victory" over Iran, to unleash Israel against his arms industries and to undermine his economy in league with the "corrupt" oil sheiks in Kuwait.
If the bearish American field commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, has come as Hector with lasers and cruise missiles to smite Iraq, then Saddam Hussein has set himself up as Saladin, the Muslim avenger resisting a Western crusade to re-enslave Islam.
Military officers hate it when their achievements are judged against political yardsticks. But political factors intrude on all wars, and that is especially evident in this one. Mr. Cheney told an audience of mining executives last week that he does not buy the argument that the Iraqi leader is winning by losing, even though there is precedent for such an outcome in the Arab-Israeli wars.
"Our plan is mathematical and it has its schedule," a White House official said last week, "and Saddam Hussein has his battle plan with its schedule.
"There are two curves," the official continued. "On one you measure how long he can hold out and on the other you measure our campaign to go after the skeletal structure of his military, and then the muscle and flesh. At some point those curves intersect and I just don't see how he can keep on his schedule."
The Scud attacks may have been the first attempt to change the schedule of the war for political gain. This is the reason General Powell altered the course of the air war when Israel started taking incoming missiles that threatened to bring it into the conflict, followed perhaps by Jordan and the implosion of the Arab alliance against Iraq.
To military officers, the Scud threat was militarily insignificant, because random explosions in residential neighborhoods cannot defeat an army. "We've never been worried about Scuds," one military commander said. "They are so inaccurate that if you get hit with a Scud, you were going to have a bad day anyway."
But General Powell, with the political acuity gained in two tours at the White House, has reinforced to his field command the inexorable Realpolitik of warfare by coalition.
The same military insignificance attended Iraq's ill-fated assault on Khafji, but for Mr. Hussein the battle had some effect nevertheless: It rattled the allied military, left 11 American marines dead, taught Mr. Hussein something about the allied front lines and showed the Arab world that he was fighting.
A measure of its impact on Washington was the speed with which the allied commander, General Schwarzkopf, bolted from his war room into the studios of every American television network and major news organizations to press the military view that the world had witnessed a mosquito bite on an elephant.
 The ultimate test for the political cohesion of the coalition may come if -- or when -- Iraq introduces chemical warfare as a final spasm of defiance.
So far, the military has had an answer for everything, except how and where the campaign will end. To be sure, the United States and its allies fully expect that their victory will come with the strangulation of Iraq's war machine, the military outcome that seems the most likely; meanwhile, the possibility that Iraq will be able to claim its own dark victory, even in the event of military defeat, is seeking form in the murky distance.

HEADLINE: The Region;
Dinkins Is Running a Deficit In His Credibility Account

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
IF Credibility Gap were a place, David N. Dinkins might be its mayor.
As it is, Mr. Dinkins is the Mayor of New York City, which is as much a state of mind as a political jurisdiction. And, beginning last summer, the avuncular Mayor whom many New Yorkers had been inclined to give the benefit of the doubt seemed, to some, to be generating more doubts than benefits. Mr. Dinkins had entered higher office with a credibility deficit. However irrelevant, it was rooted, in part, in his personal affairs -- his income tax filing lapses decades ago and a questionable stock transfer to his son that reverberated again last month when an independent investigator's failure to find evidence of criminality was hailed by the Mayor as vindication. Moreover, Mr. Dinkins's previous government experience had been largely unremarkable. 
 Trust is a fragile commodity. The public is fickle; the first scent of blood can send the press into a feeding frenzy. By summer, Mr. Dinkins was starting to hemorrhage.
The undercurrent of skepticism surfaced with his failure to bring to a timely conclusion the boycott by a group of blacks of a Brooklyn grocery store owned by Korean immigrants -- a failure that was magnified because it contrasted with the promise that his city would be more harmonious than his predecessor's. Mr. Dinkins's maddeningly deliberate response to surging crime underscored earlier concerns about indecisiveness and even about his compassion. Last October, three mayoral announcements instantly elevated one roller-coaster week to legend in the annals of governance: A contract settlement with the teachers union that some outside monitors considered imprudent; an ambitious but expensive public safety program, and the prospect of as many as 15,000 layoffs to close a growing budget gap.
Mr. Dinkins seemed no more irresolute than President Bush had been about his budget, no more disbelieved by some people in and out of government than many other elected officials had been. But confusion was compounded by several subsequent events. One was the disclosure that the Dinkins administration, the City Council and the state Legislature had, perhaps unwittingly, not fully disclosed that a proposed extension of the city's personal income tax surcharge to pay for the public safety program might produce more revenue than necessary. Another was that property taxes might have to be increased by more than had been stated explicitly. Still another was that the city had negotiated a relatively modest agreement with two more municipal unions -- relatively modest in less austere times, at least -- at the same time that it was contemplating budget cuts that could result in, among other economies, the closing of 41 firehouses.
To a great extent, what the Dinkins administration seemed guiltier of than deliberate deception was poor timing, inattention to detail, attempted cover-ups when it apparently had little to hide and, primarily, miscommunication. It seemed unable to place in context positions that might be intellectually defensible individually, but which, collectively, seemed contradictory. That Mr. Dinkins himself is circumspect and believes the media cannot be trusted didn't help.
"Much of it is a bad rap," Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, said of the credibility gap. "The problem is the arrogance of his staff and the inability to communicate. I can't believe that the Mayor personally knows what's going on." The last remark seems a back-handed compliment.
Last fall, Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, declared that the city was facing not another fiscal crisis but a crisis of confidence.
"There's been a 180-degree change since then," Mr. Proctor said last week. "The issue in the fall was, do they have a handle on what their problems are and what would make them better? I think that's not an issue any more. If there's someone who's worrying, it's a different worry: Does the city have the management capacity and the governance capacity to achieve what it announced?"
The layoff debate was "a sideshow," Mr. Proctor said, since the city's goals were clear even as it debated how much could be achieved by attrition. Similarly, the income-tax-surcharge question "comes to the issue of tactics rather than substance," he said, and "reflects incompleteness." "As to what the implications of incompleteness are, people can differ." (Or, as Philip R. Michael, the city budget director, said: "We're not such clods that we attempted to hide it and we hid it badly. If anything, it was just the opposite.")
"They're not perfect," Mr. Proctor said, "but I'm not sure they need to be perfect."
Their blundering in last October's surprises prompted Standard & Poor's Corporation to place the city on a credit watch. Last week, in a vote of confidence, the rating agency revoked its caveat, while cautioning that the long-term outlook remained negative.
"I think he's learned a lot from the October experience," Hyman C. Grossman, a Standard & Poor's managing director, said of Mr. Dinkins. "He's better briefed, more confident and understands much more than he did 6 months ago or 12 months ago. I give anybody at least two years to get the complete range and scope of understanding the ramifications of being chief executive of the City of New York."
Last week, in fact, seemed nearly as triumphal for the Mayor as the week last October was catastrophic. The Standard & Poor's verdict was followed by a tentative agreement in Albany on Mr. Dinkins's public safety program, which, if it is finally hatched, might well erase memories of a difficult incubation.
Lingering perceptions can shape reality, though, even for a Mayor whose perceived decency often mitigated nagging doubts about his performance. Bridging gaps in credibility, whatever their cause, may be more challenging than the budget gaps that Mr. Dinkins must hurdle over the next several months. Belatedly and begrudgingly, he has been taking tentative steps to prevent his administration from being defined by default. One such step was acknowledging the role of the press in shaping the image of public officials. "Sometimes," Mr. Dinkins said, "we are what you say we are."

HEADLINE: The World;
As Soviet Borders Open, the West Braces for an Economic Exodus

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
THE withering of the Soviet empire and the economic strains that accompany it may produce the largest migration since World War II, demographers say, and that will present Western governments that have long pressed Moscow to open its frontiers with the uncomfortable problem of what to do about a flood of would-be immigrants.
Most are in search of work, food, a better life, sometimes safety. They include Soviet Jews heading for Israel, Germany and the United States, Armenians going to France, German-speaking Poles and Hungarians entering unified Germany, Albanians scrambling into Greece. 
 The exodus has been manageable so far, but barely. From a maximum of 100,000 a year in the 1970's and middle 1980's, immigration from the Warsaw Pact countries to the West jumped to 1.3 million in 1989, the last year for which figures are available, and it was probably higher in 1990.
But now Western countries fear an even larger exodus as the Soviet Union starts lifting travel restrictions just when economic hardship and ethnic tensions are on the rise.
 
Specters of Famine and War <>
Last month Vladimir Scherbakov, chairman of the Soviet state Committee on Labor and Social Services, told West European governments that 1.5 million to 2 million Soviet citizens are likely to move west in search of work in the next few years. This is well below the more extreme estimates of 25 million to 30 million immigrants that some experts in the United Nations High Commission for Refugees have warned could head west if famine combines with civil war.
Those who believe the migration from the East can be absorbed say most of those leaving come from finite ethnic groups -- the roughly 2 million Germans in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, the 2 million or so Soviet Jews, the million Armenians living outside Armenia, an estimated 3 million displaced Hungarians and some 3 million gypsies. The great mass of the Soviet people, according to this theory, have no tradition of migration and remain attached to the soil. But some 25 million ethnic Russians already live in other Soviet republics -- including 9 million in predominantly Moslem Central Asia and Azerbaijan, where they are often considered unwelcome foreigners -- and they might decide to flee.
Other experts warn of a steady stream of Easterners taking advantage of their new freedom to travel and study abroad, overstaying their visas and joining the underground economy.
Bimal Ghosh, an expert with the Geneva-based International Organization for Migration, warns that the switch to a market economy could put 14 million people out of work in Eastern Europe and 30 million to 40 million people in the Soviet Union by 1994.
The prospect of rising migration creates a dilemma for Western European governments and for the United States, Canada and Australia, the countries that have absorbed most recent migrations. With the cold war over, immigrants are unlikely to qualify for political asylum as refugees facing "well-founded fear of persecution." But it is equally difficult for Western governments to keep them out after telling the Soviet bloc for decades to open its frontiers.
More Western countries, however, are closing the door to potential migrants from the East, requiring visas, return tickets and a minimum amount of cash. And Austria, a traditional haven for refugees in cold war days, has sent 4,000 soldiers to seal its borders.
Many argue the real answer is for the West to do more to help the east make a success of capitalism quickly so its people stay home.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Nature Humbles a State of Mind;
5-Year Drought Is Only the Latest Trouble in Paradise

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
CALIFORNIANS yet again have cause to ponder the consequences of the profligacy, recklessness and greed that have long dulled the California dream of hope, renewal and optimism. In what the historian Kevin Starr has called "the intensified pursuit of human happiness" that marks the energetic history of California, insult after insult has been inflicted on this earthly paradise. The great Gold Rush left the mountains scarred like a battlefield. Lumbermen denuded the magnificent stands of redwood to the point that the few remaining trees are tourist curiosities. Automobiles have exhausted the air of Southern California. And now, it seems, the water is nearly all gone.
It did not have to be this way. For four dry years, water officials gambled that the rain and snow would resume soon, treating drought as a temporary inconvenience. To maintain near-normal deliveries, they drew down reservoirs to dangerously low levels. Even as drought tightened its grip in 1990, California farmers racked up record receipts and income. California remained the nation's second largest grower of rice, a monsoon crop that can be grown here only with cheap subsidized water and Federal crop supports. And there seemed plenty of water for Angelenos to fill their pools and wash their sidewalks. 
 Only now, well into the fifth dry year, when it may be too late, has concerted reaction set in with panicky attempts to conserve water and find additional sources. A few days ago, the Napa Valley wine town of St. Helena, with only a 125-day supply left in its reservoir, imposed rationing for the first time in history. In the San Joaquin Valley, the city of Merced adopted an odd-even outdoor watering rule on Monday, the same day the State Water Project cut off supplies to all farmers. Cities throughout Southern California last week were preparing rationing plans.
The state government's response so far has been hesitant and confused. The Water Resources Control Board twice set dates to impose statewide restrictions and twice postponed them amid doubts about its authority, ultimately deferring to Gov. Pete Wilson, who has appointed a special water panel to make emergency recommendations by Friday. His short-term options are limited, the long-term ones painful.
Few places on earth offer a more improbable setting for vast industrialized cities and prosperous farms than this mostly desertified state. Even as the American settlement of the Pacific frontier was gathering momentum a century and a half ago, a United States naval officer, Lieut. Henry Augustus Wise, pronounced California's future bleak. "Under no contingency," he wrote in 1849, "does the natural face of Upper California appear susceptible of supporting a very large population; the country is hilly and mountainous; great dryness prevails during the summers, and occasionally excessive droughts parch up the soil for periods of 12 or 18 months."
With great disdain for such negativism, Californians rearranged the environment to get the water they needed. Dams and reservoirs snatched water from the snows of the Sierra of Northern California and funneled it into thick aortas, the mighty aqueducts that course through the deserts, making rich farms out of the malarial bogs of the Central Valley and sprouting powerful cities where none were naturally meant to be. Not even mountains stood in the way of the engineers. Huge pumps, like throbbing heart muscles, throw the water over the Tehachapi Mountains and down into that arid tract known as the Los Angeles Basin, land of car washes, swimming pools and now home to 15 million. The result is perhaps the most problematic and vulnerable urban conglomeration in America today, threatened by the twin terrors of earthquake and drought.
"There is something disturbing about this corner of America, a sinister suggestion of transience," wrote the British author J. B. Priestly. "There is a quality, hostile to men in the very earth and air here. As if we were not meant to make our homes in this oddly enervating sunshine." He went on: "California will be a silent desert again. It is all as impermanent and brittle as a reel of film."
That may or not be true. But the means by which the water problem is solved will speak volumes about whether California, in its maturity, will learn from its youth or repeat its mistakes.
"In Iowa there is a humility about the farmer's reliance on nature -- he embraces nature and allows himself to be embraced by its generosity," J. S. Holliday, historian of California's rambunctious Gold Rush past, said in an interview. "But here there is an entirely different attitude. The miners brought the attitude that nature had to be cracked open, that nature is a bounteous force from which we will take whatever we can get however we can get it. We were so flagrant, so arrogant, so profligate."
Already, history is repeating itself. Five years of water profligacy in the face of drought have taken an environmental toll. According to the Natural Resources Defense Council in San Francisco, striped bass counts in the Sacramento Delta and San Francisco Bay are at their lowest levels in history, and numerous birds, sea animals and plants have become candidates for the endangered species list because reduced fresh water flows to estuarine waters have raised salinity.
 But the solution that is so obvious to conservationsists -- to change the outdated system of water rights and impose new incentives for more efficient agriculture -- may not be the most politically feasible outcome. It is sobering to realize that even if every household in California, population 30 million, cut its annual water use by 25 percent that would reduce overall use by only 2 percent; agriculture consumes 85 percent of all available water.
"It is an empty exercise to put cities through elaborate conservation exercises," argues William L. Kahrl, author of "Water and Power," the definitive chronicle of California's water wars. "That picks the course that causes the maximum inconvenience to the largest number of people, rather than looking at the reality of the deliveries. The lesson is they are very likely going to say: 'I don't care about the Sacramento Delta. That's a long way away. Give me more water.' "
Southern California, with the bulk of the population and political power, has long coveted the water of the north. The largest new potential for water would come from building the long-delayed peripheral canal that would channel more water to the south from the Sacramento Delta, water that would otherwise flow into San Francisco Bay. Talk about tapping the rivers of rural far-northern California has also been revived, a course that would please the farmers as much as urban leaders, but that would rearrange the environment even more than it has been.
"I do not have any thought of giving up water -- it's a matter of how we get it," said Carl Boronkay, the general manager of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California. His is the largest and most politically powerful of the state's 2,000 water districts, supplying half the water used by 15 million people in the fast-growing region from Ventura to the Mexican border. Mr. Boronkay talks of taking water away from rice farmers, of voluntary transfers between regions -- easier said than done because water cannot be transferred like money between accounts. Reclamation, rationing and conservation are fine, he said, but "we need wet water."
The water crisis gives Californians one more reason to contemplate the state's failure to prepare for uncertainty and for growth that seems as inevitable as it is unwanted. Schools, social programs, freeways, bridges, prisons -- none has kept pace with the exploding population. "There are a full raft of problems we have failed adequately to plan for," said Bill Bradley, author of the forthcoming book "The United States of California." "California is the quintessence of the American dream," he said. "Its history has been based on betting on the prospect of things going one's way. There is a lot of strength in being optimistic. But the down side is what we are confronting now."
 
THE FIGHT FOR MORE WATER
 WITH the announcement last week that irrigation authorities were cutting off all water to farmers, including those in the huge Central Valley, and with Southern California cities preparing rationing plans, the drought that is now in its fifth year has exposed more starkly than ever the precarious assumption on which California's civilization is built: that even in a desert an endless stream of water is an inalienable right.
Even in the wettest times, providing water for California's agriculture industry and its growing megalopolises is a heroic (some would say hubristic) act involving hydrology, geography and power politics that sometimes seems to border on civil war. Northern California may have been born in the Gold Rush but the resource that has become the most coveted is the water that falls on its mountaintops. But while three-fourths of the state's rain and snow falls north of Sacramento, three-fourths of the population is in the southern part of the state. In a mammoth feat of civil engineering, water is funneled by a labyrinth of dams and reservoirs into aqueducts that lead to the politically powerful south.
The Northerners ask why they should make such a sacrifice for the Southerners, whom they like to stereotype as water-guzzling users of swimming pools and car washes. And both the Northerners and the Southerners resent having to share water with the farmers, who have long insisted on growing cotton, alfalfa, rice and other crops requiring huge amounts of water. About 85 percent of the water in California is, or rather was, used by farmers, who produce half the fruits and vegetables in the United States.
And so the effects of the drought ripple beyond California. Halfway through the so-called rainy season, the snowpack in the Sierra Nevada stands at 13 percent of normal, making hopes of a spring runoff seem an elusive dream.

HEADLINE: Baseball Notebook;
Cubs Favored, and Frey Is Relieved

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Some of the early -- foolhardy? -- prognostications are out, and the Chicago Cubs are among the teams touted for a division championship. Jim Frey, their no-nonsense general manager, is sort of relieved.
 "If you spend $26 million and it doesn't make you a contender, there's something wrong," Frey said. "We ought to be called a contender because we think we helped our ball club and we should have as good a chance as anyone." 
 The Cubs, in the space of four weeks, signed Danny Jackson, George Bell and Dave Smith as free agents for a total of $25.2 million guaranteed. The total comes to $30 million if option years are included.
 Their foray into such stratospheric economic territory was uncharacteristic for the Cubs. This is an organization, after all, that had to be embarrassed into signing Andre Dawson as a free agent four years ago, and then filled in a paltry $500,000 when he signed a blank contract. This is an organization that had been more accustomed to signing free agents on the level of Paul Moskau and Wayne Nordhagen.
 "The public seems surprised that we did what we did to the extent that we did it," Frey said. "There was always a perception on the part of many people that the Tribune wouldn't do that with free agency. I think the people were a little bit surprised not only that we went into the free-agent market but that we came out with three quality guys."
 Authorization by the Tribune Company, owner of the Cubs, for the large expenditure was surprising. Credit for the stunning departure should go to Frey, the 59-year-old executive, who can be more persuasive than most.
 (In 1984, for example, the Cubs plodded through a horrendous spring and whenever Manager Frey was asked what he was going to do, he said, "I have a plan." He sounded convincing, but he admitted after the team's championship season, their first since 1945, that he had had no plan; it was all he could think of saying that would satisfy people and keep them off his back.)
 "We talked about it," Frey said, discussing the evolution of the Cubs' off-season expenditures, "and after going through all the possible trade scenarios and trying to upgrade everything the best we could, we found out if you upgrade the pitching, you're probably taking away from the offense and vice versa.
 "I started to campaign a little bit to add a couple of free agent pitchers. I felt we had to improve our pitching with a quality left-handed starter and a right-hander to stabilize the bullpen. I thought if we didn't have to give up any of our position players to acquire them, we'd be one of the teams to beat. Then we went beyond that and got the left fielder, Bell."
 
They Need a Healthy Jackson
 The additions to a questionable pitching staff and an already solid offense have put the Cubs in position to compete with the defending champion Pittsburgh Pirates and the always-contending Mets. For the newcomers to help, however, Jackson has to remain healthy (he has missed significant parts of the past two seasons), Smith and Mitch Williams have to coexist peacefully in the bullpen and Bell has to avoid incurring the wrath of Wrigley Field's Bleacher Bums by playing better defense than he did recently for Toronto.
 Frey, who scoffs at much of what fans and reporters perceive or believe, could not offer a guarantee on Jackson's health, but he adderessed the other two matters.
 On the possibility of ego problems with the Smith-Williams relief tandem: "The only problem will be from guys coming into the clubhouse and asking Williams if he's teed off. Keep asking and one night he will be. The notion that everybody has to be completely happy all the time is a new idea. Everybody has to be happy and contented. It's not very often the case where everybody on a ball club is happy with their lot. The young guys always are trying to be in a better position, trying to be recognized and make more money, and the older guys are trying to hold on."
 On Bell's defense: "I'm not concerned about that. I don't think what some people say is accurate. I don't know that he's as bad as his image has developed in the last couple years. Baseball people I talk to don't see it the same way as writers and fans. Anyway, we haven't exactly had Joe DiMaggios running around in left field since I've been in town."
Will Frey's job, in effect, be on the line because he convinced his employers they should spend all of that money?
 "I haven't given that a whole lot of consideration," Frey said. "I don't feel that that's the natural consequence of spending money. If that was the case, there would be 25 clubs at the end of the year where the general manager should probably feel uncomfortable."
 
The Durability of Morris
 With a stretch of 235 or more innings pitched in 9 of the past 10 seasons (excluding strike-shortened 1981), Jack Morris has proved himself to be one of the most durable pitchers of his time. How does he account for his durability?
 "Training, clean living," Morris said. "I love the game. I want to play. I have goals and idols and heroes like every kid. My heroes are guys who pitched more innings than I have."
 Who might his heroes be? He named Phil Niekro, Nolan Ryan, Steve Carlton, Jim Palmer and Tom Seaver. All had remarkable records for durability and, in most cases, longevity:
 Niekro -- Pitched more than 200 innings for 19 successive seasons (excluding 1981), including four of 300 or more innings and seven others over 250; averaged 262 innings per season in that period.
 Ryan -- Has pitched more than 200 innings 14 times, surpassing 300 twice and 250 four other times; averaged 266 2/3 innings in a 10-year stretch and 240 2/3 the last 18 years (excluding 1981).
 Carlton -- Pitched 229 or more innings for 16 consecutive seasons (excluding 1981), including more than 250 innings 12 times; averaged 270 innings in the 16-season stretch.
 Palmer -- Pitched 274 or more innings in eight years of a nine-year span, exceeding 300 four times, including three seasons in a row; averaged 287 2/3 innings during that time and 266 1/3 over a 12-year stretch.
 Seaver -- Pitched 236 or more innings in 12 successive seasons, surpassing 250 the first 7 of those seasons and 11 of the 12; averaged 270 innings in that time.
 Morris added one pitcher to his personal hall of fame: Frank Tanana. "He's one of my heroes," Morris said of his former teammate. "I love him like a brother. He'd be embarrassed to hear me say that. He's a power pitcher turned into a finesse pitcher. His conditioning program is great. He's a survivor."
 
Santiago Joins $1-Million-a-Year Club
 When Benito Santiago's salary arbitration case was decided Friday, he became the 200th player to have a salary of $1 million or more for this year.
 With more to come, Oakland leads with 13 such players and the Mets, Los Angeles and San Francisco each have 12. The Yankees, the Cubs and Boston have 11 each. Baltimore has only two while Cleveland, Seattle and Houston have three each. The Red Sox have the most players at $2 million or more, nine, one more than the Mets and the Dodgers.
 The Athletics, the Dodgers and the Red Sox have watched their payrolls soar past the $30 million mark, with the first two clubs approaching $32 million. And Oakland faces a possible $3.3 million loss to Mark McGwire in salary arbitration.
 
Clemens and the $6 Million Plateau
 In the right set of circumstances, Roger Clemens could become baseball's Lee Majors: the $6 million man.
 That's the salary Clemens could earn in 1996 if the Boston Red Sox don't exercise their option for a fifth year in his contract, but he does, which would be his right if they don't and, in 1994 or '95, he pitches 220 innings or places in the top three in the Cy Young Award voting.
 But even if Clemens does become baseball's $6 million man, would he be the first to reach that plateau? Very likely not if the current contract escalation continues.
 When Jose Canseco signed a contract last June for an average of $4.7 million a year, baseball executives figured no one would top that number. It took nearly seven months, but Clemens has done it, catapulting past Canseco by more than $600,000.
 Now those executives will wait with dread, wondering when the next challenger will come along and topple Clemens as king of the money hill.
 Maybe it will be somebody already high on the salary charts, Will Clark, for example, whose $3.75-million-a-year contract expires after the 1993 season. Clark has a $4.25 million salary in that last year, and it wouldn't be too far a jump to reach $6 million in 1995, a year before Clemens could get there. Clark also plays for the right team. San Francisco pays its players exceedingly well, especially to keep them from straying.
 Perhaps it'll be Eric Davis, whose contract expires after the 1992 season. Davis, like his friend Darryl Strawberry, has had eyes for Los Angeles, and the Dodgers may not be able to resist having the two in the same outfield. A five-year contract, at mid-'90s numbers, could put Davis at $6 million by 1995.
 One last guess: Nolan Ryan, the first $1-million-a-year player. The remarkable Ryan will be only 48 years old in 1995 and a mere kid of 47 in 1994. His salary this year is $3.3 million, and it wouldn't be an unthinkable leap for him to get to $6 million one of those years.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Clemens Gives Mets Dilemma

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Craig Fenech, agent for Frank Viola, considered the record contract signed by Roger Clemens on Friday and said, "I'm probably having a better weekend than Al."
 Fenech referred to Al Harazin, the man charged with negotiating the Mets' contracts. The day after Clemens and the Boston Red Sox agreed to a four-year deal worth $21,521,000, or more than $5 million a year, Harazin was at home in Scarsdale yesterday wondering where the Mets should go with Dwight Gooden and Frank Viola. 
 The pitchers each have one year remaining on their contracts, and the Mets have begun negotiations with their agents. They have made one offer to Viola and they mailed a second offer to Gooden last Thursday. No one has disclosed details of the offers, but they are undoubtedly for three years each and fall more than $1.5 million a year short of the $5.38 million Clemens will average in his contract extension.
 
Position to Be Determined
 The problem for the Mets, as they enter the once-again new world of baseball economics, is not just the amount of money they should offer Gooden and Viola but the length of the extensions.
 "I haven't had a chance to talk to Frank extensively to determine what our bargaining position is going to be," Harazin said, referring to Frank Cashen, the general manager. But the Mets face a dilemma in determining the length because of Darryl Strawberry.
When Strawberry became a free agent last fall, the Mets steadfastly held to their so-called policy of not having anyone, even their star players, under contract for more than four years. They offered Strawberry $15.5 million for four years, and he instantly bolted to Los Angeles for five years and $20.25 million with the Dodgers.
 
An Obvious Problem
 Now, if the Mets hold to their four-year policy and offer Gooden and Viola no more than a three-year extension, they risk losing them as free agents after the 1991 season. If, on the other hand, they abandon their "policy" and offer the pitchers four years on top of the one each has left, they risk incurring the wrath of fans who would be critical for not having offered Strawberry five years just three months earlier.
 "We've been very consistent not wanting to offer more than four years at a time," Harazin said. "The problem is an obvious one. It's a dilemma."
 The Mets had hoped to avoid the dilemma, crossing their fingers that the Red Sox would not sign Clemens until they had completed their negotiations with Gooden and Viola. But the Red Sox went about their business while the Mets took their time with theirs.
 
Market Is Volatile
 "They wanted a counterproposal from us," Fenech said. "I held off because in a market this volatile, to make a proposal before Clemens and Gooden signed would have been premature. I would have had to put numbers together that they would have scoffed at."
 The Mets can agonize over the Clemens numbers -- "I'm sure it's a great thing for Roger Clemens," Harazin said. "I'm not sure it's good for the rest of baseball" -- but they cannot scoff at whatever Gooden and Viola might now propose.

HEADLINE: Topics of the Times;
More Than a Token of Love

 BODY:
If, despite the recession and the war, anyone is still throwing money around the way they did in the 1980's, the American Greetings Corporation has the perfect valentine. Before the economy slid and before Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, the company commissioned 2,000 oil paintings of roses by artists in the Far East, which it is offering to moonstruck Americans for $100 apiece.
For $100, you get a 17-inch-by-21-inch painting in a gold-colored frame with a fold-out generic greeting in rhyme on the back, ready for hanging. The rhymes are all the same, but the pictures are different, and thus each one is designated as a "Treasured Original"; the artists' instructions were only that the works should focus on red or pink roses in a vase. 
 Valentines are typically priced higher than other cards, but not that high. The average for paper valentines, of which American Greetings has more than 1,000 different designs this year, is just under $2. The average for its non-valentine cards is $1.40.
Sales figures for the $100 specials aren't out yet, but one customer in Cleveland bought three. That's real love.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Sununu vs. Scientists

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
The answer: John Sununu, White House chief of staff.
 The question: Why are Administration officials like Secretary of State Baker and William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, afraid to speak their minds about the greenhouse effect -- those gases widely believed by scientists to be trapping heat and dangerously raising global temperatures? 
 And why are they all so quiet just when 130 nations are meeting near Washington on how to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, principally carbon dioxide?
 The curtain on these matters lifts slightly with the following piece of high liturgy issued in Mr. Baker's behalf:
 "Even though officials with oil and gas interests are not as a rule required to recuse themselves from general policy actions that may have a financial impact on those interests, Secretary Baker has removed himself generally from global climate change questions out of an abundance of caution, on a case-by-case basis, to avoid the appearance of any impropriety."
 This remarkable "abundance of caution" comes from the very former Texas oil man who actively and sensibly participates in framing Persian Gulf policy and national energy strategy, who himself placed global warming among his top diplomatic priorities two years ago and who serves a President remembered for his greenhouse oratory during the last Presidential campaign.
 Mr. Baker, like most pros (and in this case like Mr. Reilly and a host of Administration environmentalists and scientists), backed away from the greenhouse cause when he saw Mr. Sununu's ferocity. John Sununu showed he would take no prisoners here when he ordered the dismissal of a State Department official foolish enough to take seriously the Bush- Baker pledges on global warming.
 Mr. Sununu seems to find most specialists in energy and environmental policy to be hysterics, bolstered by bad scientists and unreliable economists. Regarding global warming in particular, he believes that scientists have failed to prove that there is a warming trend, that the recent increase in temperatures is being fueled by greenhouse gases or that temperature rises of 1 to 3 degrees centigrade would badly damage the global climate. He is also convinced that available solutions to the problem are far too costly, and that cheaper ones will appear in time to prevent calamity.
 Perhaps Mr. Sununu, who has installed a global warming computer model in his personal computer, is right in his skepticism. He and others argued that the dangers of acid rain were greatly exaggerated, and recent findings suggest they were correct. But such skeptics initially waved aside the ozone problem, and two years ago the perils of increasing ultraviolet light became so palpable that the world community mandated deep cuts in chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, to reduce holes in the ozone layer.
 Arrayed against Mr. Sununu are people like Margaret Thatcher, solid professionals like those in the World Resources Institute in Washington and most of the scientific establishment. The hard-nosed chief of staff has held them all at bay and threatens to stymie the nations gathered in Chantilly, Va., with a transparent gimmick.
 The Administration began the conference last week with a pledge to stabilize its production of greenhouse gases. But as everyone at the meeting well understood, that could be accomplished simply by keeping a prior commitment to reduce CFC's. The Administration proposes to do nothing about the burning of fossil fuels like oil and coal, the main sources of carbon dioxide. In fact, U.S. production of carbon dioxide will signficantly increase in the coming years, more so because of the new energy policy. By contrast, Western European nations have already promised steep cuts in fossil fuel burning.
 What is disturbing here is not Mr. Sununu's public relations ploy, but his lack of practicality. He can retain all his skepticism about global warming, but the point remains that the very steps needed to reduce the supposed greenhouse effect are justifiable in their own right: carbon dioxide fouls the air. An oil-burning economy means continued dependence on imports. Destruction of forests harms life itself.
 Has Mr. Sununu been enforcing Administration silence about such considerations on his own tack or in behalf of Mr. Bush? If Mr. Bush has interest in global warming besides campaign bluster, he might go to the Chantilly conference and hear how the alarm bells sound for himself.

HEADLINE: Kids at Risk in Mr. Bush's Budget

 BODY:
In memory and in the occasional novel, the 1980's are seen as an Age of Affluence. But for America's children, they were the Age of Indifference. And if President Bush's budget message is any guide, more years of official neglect lie ahead.
A nationwide survey just released by the Center for the Study of Social Policy contains a few shreds of good news. The infant mortality rate went down several points. So did the child death rate. And more kids are graduating from high school. But every other important indicator of children's well-being tells a sad story. 
 The percentage of low-birth-weight babies is up. So is the percentage of babies born out of wedlock to adolescent mothers. The percentage of babies living with both parents went down. Moreover, life improved little as the children grew older. The violent death rate for teen-agers rose 12 percent from 1984 to 1988. And the juvenile incarceration rate rose 41 percent from 1979 to 1987.
Over all, the percentage of American children in poverty rose 26 percent between 1979 and 1989, and whites suffered along with blacks. Although black and Hispanic children are far more likely to be poor, the percentage of white children living in poverty rose 36 percent.
There's little reason to believe that these figures will soon improve. With one big exception, Mr. Bush's budgetary proposals involve more sleight-of-hand than substance. The exception is his proposal for generous increases in the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC) and smaller increases for childhood immunization. Both proposals could further reduce the childhood death rate.
Mr. Bush also proposed to lower the tragically high infant mortality rate in 10 American cities. But to achieve that result he may put poor infants in other parts of the country at risk. That's because the money for the cities initiative will be siphoned away from some community health centers -- specifically the centers' year-old rural outreach program -- as well as from the Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant. Mr. Bush thus flouts the recommendations of his own Task Force on Infant Mortality, which last fall urged increased funding for both.
Although he has been extravagant in his praise for Head Start, the President is reluctant to put money where his mouth is. The suggested increase for the program is more than enough to stay ahead of inflation but nowhere near enough to realize Congress's goal for Head Start -- enrolling every eligible child in America by 1994.
And the proposed 16 percent cut in foster care will have a cruel effect on the kind of preplacement services that make it possible for a child to stay out of foster care, like counseling for families and various prevention activities.
What is truly sad about this aspect of the President's budget is that the money is coming out of programs that work. If America is still not certain about how to help its troubled teen-agers, it has more than a few good ideas about how to help the very young. Help them today, and there'll be fewer poor and desperate kids tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Is Victory Over Iraq Really a Sure Thing?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Most of the skepticism on the outcome of the war in the Persian Gulf has focused on its political and economic consequences. There seems widespread disagreement whether in the long-term these will be beneficial or harmful to United States interests. 
 But the result of the military campaign against Iraq is taken as a fait accompli. There are, however, reasons for questioning whether or not a military victory is a sure thing.
Perhaps the most obvious of these is the possible use by the Iraqis of decoys for their tanks and artillery. Decoys are a lot cheaper than smart weapons, and it is within the technological capabilities of the Iraqis to make them in large number. When I asked a well-known defense expert about this possibility soon after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, he said the Bush Administration doesn't believe the Iraqis have the technical sophistication to make decoys that can fool our synthetic aperture radars.
As it has turned out, though, the Iraqis do have the technical sophistication to hide their mobile missile launchers in a way to make them almost impossible to detect with our radars or any other means, and have successfully deployed missile decoys. We cannot assume that the Iraqis are incapable of hiding their real tanks and artillery, and of producing realistic decoys. If the Iraqis make extensive use of decoys, the war will be very expensive to pursue, and a complete victory may cost more than most Americans are willing to pay.
An even more worrisome reason to doubt the military outcome is the possible use by Iraq of nuclear weapons. Although the possession by the Iraqis of usable nuclear weapons is widely discounted, I don't think it can be ruled out. In late 1989, the Iraqis were caught trying to acquire detonators that can be used in nuclear weapons. One might wonder why they were interested in acquiring detonators if they didn't have, or weren't soon to acquire, sufficient quantities of the nuclear materials to make nuclear bombs. I think it can be assumed that the Iraqis are frantically working to produce nuclear weapons.
What the actual state of affairs is may be known at the highest levels of government, but I doubt that the Bush Administration is willing to divulge what is known. The public statements by the President that the Iraqi nuclear capability has been almost eliminated strains credulity. It seems to me more likely that the Iraqi centrifuges for producing enriched uranium are whirring away inside deep bunkers or mines.
If the Iraqis start to lose the conventional war, they may well be inclined to use whatever nuclear weapons they have on hand.
The United States military action can be viewed as a bet that we can defeat Iraq and impose some kind of mandatory inspection condition before Iraq can use nuclear weapons against the coalition forces and possibly Saudi Arabia. I hope we win this bet but the expected doesn't always happen.
 
GEORGE CHAPLINE
Livermore, Calif., Jan. 31, 1991
 
The writer is a senior scientist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
