HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Offbeat Settings Enhance Winter Show

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
When the 37th annual Winter Antiques Show ended last Sunday, most participants were relieved, and some were jubilant. Business, while down from a year ago, was better than many dealers had expected, considering the war and the recession. Although the East Side House Settlement, the sponsor of the 10-day bazaar at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, reported fewer tickets were sold than last year, the decline was less than had been projected. Even the new floor plan, with its wider aisles and shallower booths, was praised more than condemned.
Not everyone felt upbeat about the show. Critics focused primarily on the 66 dealers' stock, which, they said, was short on variety and memorable artworks. 
 "There should be fewer things and more significant objects," said Michael Ward, a Manhattan antiquities dealer, after visiting the fair. "There's too much stuff -- it's like a shopping mall."
Said Herve Aaron, a former exhibitor at the Winter Antiques Show who heads the Manhattan gallery of the furniture dealers Didier Aaron of Paris: "If they want to make it a great show, they have to get more dealers who have great things to show."
Yet most vistors were enthusiastic. "This show looks the best I've seen in the 11 or 12 years I've been coming here," said Brian Haughton, a London ceramics dealer. Mr. Haughton and his wife, Anna, organize the International Antique Show each October at the armory, on Park Avenue -- the biggest competitor of the more glamorous and commercially successful Winter Antiques Show.
"All the dealers seem to have paid more attention this year to the design of their booths," said W. Graham Arader 3d, a New York print dealer at the show. Why? "They had to pay double or triple the booth rent. There is nothing like pain to sharpen one's attention to details."
Several of the show's 17 new dealers devised offbeat settings. At Bauman Rare Books, a Philadelphia dealer, a mahogany library wall invited browsing and buying. The proprietors, David and Natalie Bauman, sold numerous leather-bound books, an Abraham Lincoln legal manuscript and a copy of the lavishly illustrated 15th-century "Nuremberg Chronicle," a gilded volume bound in pigskin, which was bought for about $60,000.
An aisle away, at the booth shared by two San Francisco silver dealers -- Argentum and the Leopard's Head -- warm gray walls heightened the ambiance of polished shimmer.
Leighton Longhi, at the show for the first time, exploited the six-foot depth of his booth, the shallowest at the fair. He hung a stunning pair of gilded 17th-century Japanese screens wall to wall at the back, placing a few choice Japanese art objects, including 30-inch-tall carved dragons, in front. The screens sold swiftly to a Japanese collector for about $800,000.
The most spectacular piece of furniture at the fair -- a boldly carved 18th-century English library table with gilded embellishments -- was the centerpiece of Carlton Hobbs's booth. Mr. Hobbs, a London dealer, kept things simple and curiously somber, curtaining the walls in dark green glazed chintz and installing a pair of marble busts of Roman emperors on either side of the seven-foot-long library table; the table was made for Charles Jennens, one of Handel's librettists, around 1750. The price of the table was the highest at the fair -- $2.8 million. It did not sell.
Americana dominated the booths of 21 dealers and accounted for many major sales. Two paintings by Edward Hicks -- a "Peaceable Kingdom" at Marguerite Riordan and "Penn's Treaty" at Hirschl & Adler Folk -- were bought for more than $1 million each. Thomas K. Woodard's prize objects -- an imposing life-size zinc elk from the 1870's, at $75,000, and a 1920's Amish quilt of brightly colored squares, at $40,000 -- were sold at the opening-night preview.
"It's been our best show to date," Mr. Woodard said. "We had no idea what to expect with the world situation. I think it proves our business is a fluke."
Mr. Arader said he sold at least four prints by John James Audubon at $15,000 to $32,000 each. "There is no question that there is a recession," he said. "Everyone wants to know what the wholesale value at auction is of what they look at."
Arie L. Kopelman, an East Side House board member who is president and chief executive officer of Chanel, said the show is due for changes. In addition to selecting a successor to Mario Buatta, who resigned as chairman this year, a system has to be set to vet each item for authenticity at next year's show.
Another top priority, Mr. Kopelman said, is to increase the amount of money raised by the Winter Antiques Show, the charity's most important vehicle for financing its activities in the South Bronx. According to East Side House, ticket sales at the show declined for the third year in a row. This year, the revenue from tickets to the previews, which were $500 and $250 each, totaled $435,000, down from $515,250 last year. Tickets for the event, at $10 each, also dipped, bringing $245,960; this compares to $268,000 in 1990.
"There will always be ups and downs," Mr. Kopelman said, "and some disagreements."

HEADLINE: Plantation Mansions on the Mississippi

BYLINE: By CAROL von PRESSENTIN WRIGHT; CAROL von PRESSENTIN WRIGHT is the author of "The Blue Guide to New York," the second edition of which will be published this spring (W. W. Norton).

 BODY:
ALONG the stretch of the Mississippi between Baton Rouge and New Orleans runs an old two-lane highway known as the River Road, until the ascendancy of the steamboat in the early 1800's an important route between the two cities and the plantations marshalled along the river. The highway, actually two roads on the two banks of the river, reflects the errant ways of the Mississippi, meandering to follow the levees, changing its name and its number as it winds past isolated villages, towering chemical plants and occasional stands of sugar cane.
Here and there flourish groves of aged live oaks, planted to shadow the manor houses of the plantations that the road originally served. Here and there remain the great mansions themselves, once the focal point of Louisiana's social and economic life. Although you can travel more swiftly on the 80 miles of Interstate between Baton Rouge and New Orleans, a trip on the River Road, which snakes for about 115 miles along a parallel route, has its own rewards. 
 On trips in August and December, I visited five major houses in two days, a good pace that allowed time for dawdling. Don't expect to travel fast: although the homeward-bound factory workers who are conversant with every dip and bend drive with intolerant haste, traffic often moves slowly. Don't expect to see the Mississippi: the levees that contain its flood waters also obscure it from sight. Occasionally you may glimpse the superstructure of a freighter looming above you, but you can see the water only by climbing the levee.
Finally, do not expect the River Road to look like an antebellum theme park, where everything is repainted every year and there is plenty of money to invest in artifice. Heavy industry has replaced the former agrarian economy; gargantuan refineries and chemical plants now stand beside the old mansions, which often seem stranded in unsympathetic environments. While the remaining antebellum homes are without exception beautiful in their forms and proportions, they are not all in good condition; some have been restored, but others seem to be barely hanging on as the economy changes around them. And yet each house has something individual to offer -- distinctive architecture, history, fine furniture, or insight into a past about which it is difficult not to feel ambivalent.
The oldest house in the lower Mississippi Valley is Destrehan, in the town of the same name, about eight miles from the New Orleans airport. Begun in 1787, Destrehan exemplifies the raised cottage or Creole style; it is a two-story house with a wide hipped roof and large shady galleries to protect against the heat, a living floor raised above ground to protect against moisture (including floods), and dormers to ventilate the attic. The Spanish in the Caribbean developed the style and transported it to Louisiana where it was supremely suited to the tribulations of the climate. A later owner updated the house with Greek Revival refinements, encasing the columns, adding the capitals, and the moldings, mantels and door surrounds that have been restored today.
The small flanking garconnieres were probably built for Jean Noel Destrehan de Beaupre, who married the granddaughter of the original builder and fathered 14 children. When the boys of a family reached adolescence, they moved from the main house to their own quarters, where they were provided with personal servants, and, sometimes, mistresses .
Destrehan's economy, based first on indigo, later on sugar cane, and finally on oil refining, epitomizes that of southern Louisiana as a whole. After serving a succession of oil companies in the 20th century, the house remained vacant for 12 years, while vandals stripped it of everything remotely portable, sparing only the one-ton marble bathtub. Today the River Road Historical Society owns Destrehan and has restored it with scholarly scrupulousness, furnishing it with handsome period antiques and replicas.
If Destrehan is the oldest, San Francisco, in Garyville, about 22 miles upriver from Destrehan, is the most decorative of the plantation manors. Begun in 1853 or 1854, it is built of plastered brick and topped off with a massive roof. Although the Greek Revival style had supplanted the Creole by 1853, the San Francisco's builder clung to the old ways for the interior floor plan, while garnishing the outside of his house with copious ornamentation and Gothic Revival windows that were right up to the minute. The house is still described as Steamboat Gothic.
The name has a French derivation; according to one story, the builder's son, Valsin Marmillion, inherited a modest house and decided to do it up right, lavishing money on the interior decoration and thus finding himself, in the vernacular of the period, sans fruscins, without a penny. A later owner corrupted the name to San Francisco.
Outside stand two cypress cisterns with fanciful copper roofs that provided running water to the end rooms of the house. While startling to some visitors, the exterior colors -- peach or ocher and cerulean blue -- are historically accurate, determined by careful scraping to the original layer of paint.
The interior is famous for its five painted ceilings and for its false marbling and false wood-graining, now carefully restored. The ceiling paintings were executed around 1860 on the cypress-board ceilings in a variety of designs -- medallions, architectural motifs, fleurs-de-lis.
Because plantations were businesses, their owners frequently treated the manor houses as parts thereof, carefully tracking expenditures and assets. The Marmillion household inventories, for example, noted the location of every piece of furniture each time the family held a significant social event; while this may suggest a mistrust of the guests, it has helped the San Francisco Foundation.
At one time, San Francisco looked at the Mississippi across an expanse of formal garden, but successive setbacks have brought the levees closer to the front door. When the plantation houses were built, each owner was responsible for the levees on his own property, a system ensuring that one's own engineering failures would wreak havoc with one's neighbors; as early as 1879 construction and maintenance of the system was assigned to the Army Corps of Engineers and the levees were standardized.

 HOUMAS House, in Burnside, about 29 miles upriver from San Francisco, was built a decade earlier and better conforms to the popular notion of the white, columned, antebellum mansion. Its unusual name harks back to the Houmas Indians, who lived here before one Alexandre Latil purchased land from them. Latil built himself a small dwelling in about 1790, while Louisiana was still under Spanish domination; later owners built the Greek Revival mansion (1840) and joined the old dwelling to it.
Just before the Civil War, the plantation grew to 20,000 acres and became the nation's premier sugar producer. Because the owner was a British subject and apparently a persuasive man, Houmas House was spared occupation by the Union forces and remained intact and profitable until the turn of the century. In 1940 Dr. George B. Crozat, a New Orleans orthodontist, bought Houmas House.
Dr. Crozat enjoyed gardens, maps and antique furniture -- especially armoires and trunks -- all of which are in evidence at Houmas House, from the four ancient live oaks and the formal gardens, to the antique maps in the upstairs hall (some of which show land grants from Louis XIV to a Monsieur Antoine Crozat), to the collection of armoires. It is not surprising that so beautiful a house should have been the setting for several movies, including "Hush Hush, Sweet Charlotte," whose star, Bette Davis, presented Dr. Crozat with a handsome chandelier for his trouble.
In far less happy condition, though of significant interest if you don't mind a certain amount of upheaval, is Ashland, also known as Belle Helene. It is situated between Darrow and Geismar, about 10 miles upriver from Houmas House. Designed by a notable New Orleans architect, James Gallier Sr., for a notable citizen, Duncan Kenner -- lawyer, statesman, cane planter, and horse breeder -- Ashland with its haunted, vacant beauty has enthralled more than one photographer and served as the site of such movies as "The Foxes of Harrow," "The Long, Hot Summer" and "Fletch Lives," where it played the decrepit plantation Chevy Chase inherits.
As this casting suggests, Ashland's beauties are largely unrestored. Outside are wide galleries on all four sides supported by a colonnade of 28 square columns that rise to a six-foot parapet concealing the pitched roof. Inside, a central hall on both the first and second floors opens onto spacious rooms. At the rear an elliptical staircase of cypress wood with a walnut balustrade ascends through the second floor and to the attic.
While no costumed guides will lead you through a series of perfectly appointed rooms, you may take a self-guided tour aided by a floor plan, wall placards and a pamphlet. You will learn that Spanish moss belongs to the pineapple family and was used to stuff mattresses and that Duncan Kenner named Ashland for Henry Clay's plantation as tribute to a man he admired. You will also discover that the second owner renamed it Belle Helene in honor of his first granddaughter, whose heirs still own the home.
If you are interested in how mansions were built, Ashland is the place to find out, since it is in the midst of a slow, privately financed restoration, its downstairs floors taken up and its foundations exposed. You can see the brick footings set 15 feet into the ground; you can see the mortar crumbling and discover that it was made of river silt, horsehair and some form of lime -- probably burnt clam shells.
If you prefer undimmed elegance and spectacular interiors, Nottoway, on the west bank of the Mississippi near the town of White Castle, will be more to your taste. (To get there you will have to cross the river, either at Baton Rouge or downstream at the Sunshine Bridge near Donaldsonville.) Built by John Hampden Randolph in 1859, Nottoway, the largest plantation house in the South, was once the centerpiece of a 7,000-acre sugar cane plantation. Randolph, who had moved to the Deep South from the Nottoway River area of Virginia, at first farmed cotton on a smaller inland plantation, but turned to sugar, a riskier but potentially more profitable crop, before he bought the acreage on which Nottoway stands.
Today Nottoway's property has been broken up and sold off, but its setting, in a flat, sparsely populated rural area, still suggests its former expanse and isolation. The house was designed by New Orleans's other great society architect, Henry Howard, in the Greek Revival and Italianate styles -- the latter the newest comer in the parade of changing fashion. Outside and in, from its large semicircular wing and 22 immense square columns, to its coal-burning fireplaces, indoor plumbing and gas lights, Nottoway manifests its owner's wealth and success and indeed Randolph seems to have been inspired by nearby Belle Grove (completed three years earlier but gutted by fire in 1952) to build a bigger and better house than his neighbor. Like other successful planters, Randolph was an exquisite record keeper and left detailed instructions as to the mansion's construction. We know, for example, that Nottoway was finished with four coats of paint, that the windows and blinds were finished in a color called Paris-Green.

 THIS attachment to detail, along with the refurnishing, makes the interior of Nottoway a special pleasure. There are 4,200 yards of plastering, with 140 feet of scroll ornaments in the parlors alone, as well as eight medallions and friezes in the parlors, the main hall and at the stair landing. The original crystal and brass chandelier hangs in the entrance hall (it cost Randolph $138).
The jewel of the house, however, is the white ballroom in the oval wing of the house, adorned with hand-carved cypress columns and ceiling medallions. The original gas fixtures and chandeliers still provide light, just as the silver pulls for the servants still hang by the fireplaces with their original white marble mantels. Randolph had eight daughters to marry off and six of them were wed in the ballroom.
Randolph died at Nottoway in 1883, successful again after devastating losses during the Civil War, leaving his wife to run the plantation, which she did for six years before finally auctioning the property. She is said to have been seen on her last day in the house moving from room to room in her black dress, closing each of its 200 windows before she left.
 
GETTING AROUND THE AREA

 
Plantation Houses
Ashland/Belle Helene is on the River Road (State Route 75) between Darrow and Geismar. It is open 9 to 5 daily, except Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. The admission fee is $4.50. Information: 7497 Ashland Road, Geismar, La. 70734; telephone (504) 473-1328.
Destrehan Plantation, at 9999 River Road (State Route 48) in Destrehan west of Kenner, is about eight miles from New Orleans International Airport. It is open daily 9:30 to 4 except major holidays. Admission $5.50. Information: Post Office Box 5, Destrehan, La. 70047; (504) 764-9345.
Houmas House is on the River Road (State Route 942) in Burnside, just beyond the intersection of Route 44. It is open daily February through October 10 to 5, November through January 10 to 4. Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. Admission $4.50. Information: Route 1, Box 181, Convent, La. 70723; (504) 473-7841 or, in New Orleans, (504) 522-2262.
Nottoway is on the River Road (State Route 1) just north of White Castle. Open 9 to 5 daily. Closed Christmas Day. Admission $8, $3 for children under 12. Information: Post Office Box 160, White Castle, La. 70788; (504) 545-2730. In Baton Rouge telephone 346-8263.
San Francisco is on the River Road (State Route 44) in Garyville, between LaPlace and Gramercy. Open daily 10 to 4. Closed Easter, Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year's and Mardi Gras Day. Admission $6. Information: Post Office Drawer AX, Reserve, La. 70084; (504) 535-2341.
Several of the River Road plantations offer overnight accommodations and breakfast, either in the main house or in other buildings on the property; rates range from $75 to $250 for two, depending on the accommodation.
 
Where to Eat
The restaurant at Nottoway is open seven days: lunch 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.; dinner 6 P.M. to 8:30 P.M. For reservations call (504) 545-2730. The menu offers Creole and Cajun specialties and is moderately priced.
The Cabin Restaurant is at the intersection of Routes 22 and 44 between Burnside and Gonzales. Open daily, with varying hours. Cajun and Creole specialties as well as sandwiches, gumbo and salads. (504) 473-3007.
Somewhat more formal is Lafitte's Landing at the foot of the Sunshine Bridge in Donaldsonville. The legendary Jean Lafitte -- pirate, smuggler and gentleman rover -- is said to have used Donaldsonville as a base for his operations upriver and on Bayou Lafourche; his son, legend says, was married to Marie Emma Viala in the building. Open daily. Regional specialties as well as po' boys, gumbo and crawfish bisque, and seafood. (504) 473-1232. -- C. v. P. W.

HEADLINE: The Last Stalinist

BYLINE: By Clifford Krauss; Clifford Krauss, who covers the State Department for The New York Times, is the author of the forthcoming "Inside Central America."

 BODY:

GUERRILLA PRINCE
The Untold Story of Fidel Castro.
By Georgie Anne Geyer.
Illustrated. 445 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company.
$22.95. 
 Georgie Anne Geyer closes her provocative biography of Fidel Castro with a dire prediction: "Some kind of terrible striking out lay ahead -- an attack on the United States, a mass suicide within, a bitter war within the military between the generations, something rightfully commensurate with the greatness and drama of Fidel Castro." Borrowing from Wagner, she writes that unless Mr. Castro dies suddenly in his sleep, "his would be a Gotterdammerung end."
As Communism collapses around the world, and Cuba competes with North Korea for the dubious honor of being the last Stalinist state, no one can predict what Mr. Castro's future will be -- only that it will probably not be a long one. Cuba's economy is cracking, and with it Mr. Castro's mystique and popularity. A series of foreign-policy reversals has forced him to bring home his troops and advisers from Africa and Central America. Show trials involving important military figures and a sweeping shake-up of his security apparatus in 1989 suggest that Mr. Castro is not confident of his power base and that a coup is possible.
The time has come to analyze the Castro legacy, for surely he reached his peak about 10 years ago and he is now fading fast. "Guerrilla Prince" is a good beginning, but Ms. Geyer, a syndicated columnist, falls into the trap of many biographers by overestimating the importance of her subject. According to Ms. Geyer, Mr. Castro was responsible for revolutions in Nicaragua, El Salvador, Angola, Mozambique and Ethiopia. Had it not been for him, she maintains, military dictators would not have destroyed democracy in South America's southern cone and the United States would not have invaded Grenada. And there would have been no "supernational 'drug state' " protected by Cuban-trained guerrillas.
There is a grain of truth to this argument. Mr. Castro did transform his small island nation into a world power. A beacon to two generations of third world revolutionaries, he sent 57,000 troops and military advisers to Angola and tens of thousands more to Ethiopia, South Yemen, Libya, Mozambique, Syria, Equatorial Guinea, Tanzania, Guinea-Bissau, North Korea, Algeria, Uganda -- and the list goes on. He served as a mediator between Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega and the Medellin drug cartel, and he may even have had a hand in the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. But Ms. Geyer's claim that since 1959 "wherever the United States had a watershed foreign policy crisis, Castro's formative hand could be found" is clearly overstated.
Stretching her argument leads Ms. Geyer to stretch some of her facts. The red and black colors of the Sandinista party flag were not copied from Mr. Castro's 26th of July Movement, as she claims, but were adopted from the banner of Spanish anarchism. Indeed they are the same colors Augusto Cesar Sandino flew in the 1920's and 1930's when he and his band of guerrillas challenged the United States Marines occupying Nicaragua. The matter of a flag's colors would be inconsequential if they weren't reflective of the deep roots of the Nicaraguan revolution. Nicaragua, like El Salvador and much of the rest of the third world, was in conflict long before Mr. Castro came to power.
Still, this is a book worth reading. Ms. Geyer is an experienced observer of Latin America, and the best passages of "Guerrilla Prince" portray a nuanced understanding of Cuba's political culture. She sheds her great-man theory of history long enough to describe artfully the social milieu that created the anti-Yankee dictator. Since its days as the colonial center of Spain's Caribbean domain, Cuba has long aspired to a great destiny. But Cubans were cheated on the eve of their independence from Spain by the United States, which first occupied the island and then made it a dependency for half a century. Mr. Castro's personification of Cuba's frustrated nationalism was only heightened by the fact that his father was born and grew up in the proud Spanish province of Galicia, where the Spanish-American War is still refered to as "el desastre."
Ms. Geyer is sketchy on recent developments in Cuba, but she is exhaustive in describing the tawdry details of Mr. Castro's womanizing and treachery. Much of her account is new and surprising: as a youthful rebel, Mr. Castro reportedly admired Hitler's tactics and faked at least one police beating to get attention. He furtively fed his infant son three times the recommended amount of formula to make him stronger faster. Before he succeeded in overthrowing the Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista, he once asked a Costa Rican labor leader he suspected of receiving Central Intelligence Agency financing how he might get on the agency's payroll. Unwilling to share the spotlight after taking power, he sent Ernesto (Che) Guevara off to Bolivia and then cut off his supplies.
Above all else, Mr. Castro hates the United States with a passion and would destroy it in a second if he could. Fortunately for Washington, his time is running out.

HEADLINE: The State of the Governor

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Kolbert; Elizabeth Kolbert is Albany bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
It is the last day of the year, and Albany, living up to its cheerless reputation, is gray and frigid. Nevertheless, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has decided to walk to his swearing-in ceremony. He marches down the hill from the State Capitol, a powerful figure in a shapeless fedora, his aides trailing behind him, hugging themselves against the cold.
In deference to the state's bare treasury, Cuomo has forsworn the traditional inauguration party, opting instead for a modest ceremony at the State Court of Appeals building. The whole exercise lasts less than 10 minutes. After it is over, Cuomo is about to plunge out into the cold again when a group of reporters blocks his way, and he stops to talk to them under the courthouse dome. 
 The scene seems, at first, much like an ordinary news conference, with the Governor in the center and a throng of reporters stretching microphones toward his lips. But for Cuomo, it is clearly something more. He is standing in the building where he began his career 35 years ago as a law clerk, and now he is about to embark on his third term in New York State's highest office. When he is asked to reflect on the challenges facing him as the state goes through a dizzying financial decline, his tone is elegiac.
"This state has overcome fire and floods and depression and wars, always bringing us to a higher ground," he says. "Sixty years ago this state showed the whole nation the way out of the Depression. So if you remember your history and if you remember the people who came before you, it gets a little easier to look forward to the challenges you have to face."
Cuomo is not a man to draw casually on history, and so this answer, like so many of his remarks, invites speculation. "If you remember the people who came before you. . . ." Are these people like Theodore Roosevelt and Franklin D. Roosevelt, whom historians consider to have been unexceptional governors, but who went on to be great Presidents? Or are they people like Alfred E. Smith and Thomas E. Dewey, who imposed their vision on New York State but then lost their bids for higher office?
Since the day of his first inauguration, Cuomo has seemed destined to make his mark according to one of these two models. His tremendous eloquence made him almost immediately a national figure, and within two years of becoming Governor, he was invested with the aura of a potential President. At home in New York, he enjoyed an equally exalted stature -- his political sovereignty uncontested, his popularity unmatched.
But now, after eight years in office, Cuomo's destiny no longer seems so clear, and his relation to his predecessors has a poignant, almost morbid quality. As he begins his third term, Cuomo, the "Hamlet" of American politics, seems oddly suspended at the edge of history.

CUOMO'S UNEASY RELATIONSHIP TO higher office has been well documented by a national press corps that has tracked his moves with open fascination. When the Governor has traveled around the nation denouncing the Republican administration in Washington, reporters have happily spied signs of a nascent campaign. When he has drawn back, there has been speculation about secreted skeletons and weak knees.
Far less attention has been devoted to the equally curious record of Cuomo's governorship. But it is a record that reveals many of the same themes: an unusual set of opportunities, a mysterious hesitancy to seize them and a genius for confounding popular expectations.
Some of these opportunities have been created by Cuomo himself; others have been handed to him by good fortune. When Cuomo took office in January 1983, the state was in the final stages of one of its periodic fiscal emergencies. Within a year, however, there were clear signs of economic improvement, and as the 1980's wore on, the recovery turned into a boom. Personal income rose at a startling rate, and state revenues grew apace. In the first five years of the Cuomo administration, the state budget, in constant dollars, increased by almost 20 percent.
For the Governor, this rare economic windfall was matched by unusual political security. Throughout his tenure, Cuomo has maintained phenomenally high ratings in the polls, and in 1986, he was re-elected by the largest majority in New York State history. In contrast to Cuomo's robustness, New York's Republican Party has for more than a decade been slowly dying of internal injuries. Last year, the party could barely even muster a gubernatorial candidate; at least 19 Republicans turned down the nomination before Pierre A. Rinfret, an economist and political oddball, finally agreed to take Cuomo on. Politically bedridden, the Republicans have allowed Cuomo to monopolize media attention in the state while raising only a quavering voice in opposition.
Presiding over a time of affluence and lacking a serious rival, Cuomo was well positioned to confront a new generation of needs that accompanied the lavish economic growth of the mid-1980's: AIDS, crack, homelessness. So devastating were these problems that they seemed to demand responses more inventive, and more risky, than traditional government solutions.
Yet Cuomo's response to these problems has been largely incremental, largely business as usual. He has failed to draw on his immense popularity to make New York a leader in new and experimental programs, nor has he undertaken the kind of ambitious capital projects that characterized the administration of Nelson A. Rockefeller in the 60's. Instead, he has chosen to build cautiously on what was already in place, acting as a conservator of the state's extensive network of social services and its aging infrastructure.
"You have a state that's a perfect laboratory to do something visionary," says Russell Sykes, a senior policy associate with the State Communities Aid Association, a nonprofit advocacy group. "But we have just been taking baby steps."
In the late 1980's and now the early 1990's, New York's economy has been contracting almost as fast as it had earlier expanded, presenting Cuomo with a new opportunity to leave his stamp on the state. Tax collections in New York, as in most Northeastern states, have been dropping precipitously over the last few years, leaving gaping holes between the cost of existing programs and the sum of existing taxes. The impetus for re-examination and reorganization of government services in the state has rarely been greater.
But Cuomo's response to the contraction has been as modulated and circumspect as his response to the years of growth. When money was plentiful, Cuomo distributed it generously and evenhandedly, increasing spending on liberal-minded social programs like welfare, and also on more conservative, law-and-order programs like prison construction. Then he cut income-tax rates and took steps to reduce the state's chronic borrowing.
Now with revenues
shrinking, Cuomo is meting out the pain just as broadly. He has cut programs for the poor, like Medicaid, and programs for the middle class, like aid to private colleges. He has raised a battery of taxes and then, for good measure, he has raided reserve funds and racked up record deficits.
Perhaps as a result of Cuomo's guarded handling of the state's purse strings, New York has managed to maintain a sense of equanimity in the face of hard times, while many of its neighbors, like New Jersey and Massachusetts, have fallen to bitter squabbling. Cuomo himself has remained remarkably popular despite the pains of retrenchment, and in a period when other governors have been felled, he is still standing. He has retained his power, but some would ask: for what?
"He's holding his political capital tight to him," says Eve Brooks, executive director of Statewide Youth Advocacy, a nonprofit group that keeps a watchful eye on Cuomo. "He's trying to speak to a lot of constituencies and create as few enemies as possible. But the question is, where is he going with all this?"

FOR HIS ENTIRE tenure as Governor, Cuomo has had to cope with a divided State Legislature: Democrats in the Assembly, Republicans in the Senate. To hear Cuomo tell it, this one fact explains most of the limitations attributed to his record. If he has not been as daring as some would have liked, the Republican Senate is to blame. " 'The Senate wouldn't do it,' " says Richard C. Wade, a professor of urban history at the City University of New York and a longtime Cuomo associate. "That's his first response to everything."
That the divided Legislature is an impediment to innovation in New York is indisputable. Indeed, many officials in Albany would argue that the sole aim of the Republican Senate is to gum up the gears of state government. But there are many who argue that Cuomo, too, is responsible for the standstill.
Cuomo has always spoken ardently of his desire to win control of the State Senate for the Democrats. But his actions on behalf of Democratic candidates have often seemed to fall short of such passion. In 1986, for example, a year when many Republican seats seemed vulnerable, Cuomo's efforts were so anemic that many in his own party accused him of bad faith. In 1990, the Democrats' last chance to seize the Senate before redistricting, Cuomo played a more active role in the campaign. But when it came to contributing money from his own swollen campaign treasury, he held back, saying the money had not been donated for him to give away.
When it comes to pushing legislation through the Republican Senate, Cuomo's efforts have been similarly tentative. As anyone who has dealt with the State Legislature knows, it is not enough to lay out your case for a bill and then hope for the best. You have to exert constant pressure, to wheedle and threaten and then, finally, make deals. You have to be willing to take risks and alienate some of your supporters to achieve your objectives. This Cuomo has rarely done.
At the start of the year, when he unveils his legislative agenda, Cuomo resubmits the same bills that the Senate rejected the year before: legislation to redistribute school aid, to overhaul the state's election laws, to introduce a system of public campaign financing. Each year, he proclaims that this year will be different. The tide has turned, he proclaims, a new day is dawning, the bills will finally pass. But by the time the Legislature recesses in July, these bills have, once again, been unceremoniously killed off.

THE GOVERNOR LAYS out his agenda each year in the State of the State Message, presented to a joint session of the Legislature in early January. The message outlines the Governor's hopes and aspirations for the coming year. In 1982, the last year of Gov. Hugh L. Carey's administration, the State of the State Message ran to 24 pages. By 1986, the message had grown to 137 pages, reaching a high of 178 pages last year before dropping back to 121 pages last month.
The expanding State of the State Message is a remarkably apt illustration of Cuomo's style of leadership. Enlarged almost every year, the message has become a statement of inclusivity. Like the Governor's mythic "family of New York," which is supposed to enfold all groups, the elastic State of the State insures that no one will feel left out. But while the appeal of the message has been broadened, its effectiveness as a statement of the Governor's aims has been dissipated. By the hundredth page, it becomes almost impossible to figure out which of the proposals represent serious policy goals and which are merely wishes that will dissolve on contact with the brutal realities of politics.
Even when pressed on the matter, Cuomo shies away from laying out clear priorities. Shortly after Cuomo delivered one of his State of the State Messages, his staff, responding to reporters' calls on the subject, tried to come up with a list of the Governor's top 10 goals for the year. But the task proved too daunting; the Governor's staff could not limit its priorities to just 10. "Under No. 1," a former aide to the Governor recalls, "there was 1a, 1b, 1c."
Cuomo entered politics through the side door, first attracting attention as a negotiator in a vicious battle over low-income housing in Forest Hills, Queens. It is a role that he has never entirely abandoned. Assailed by interest groups on all sides, Cuomo often portrays himself as the referee in the great game of government. If one group is unhappy with a call this time, next time it will be the other group. All of the groups have a claim on his attention, and none of them particularly deserve to win.
"One of the failures of our politics is that it has been simplistic," Cuomo said in a recent interview. "So when you have a struggle over the air in the city of New York and it comes down to environment versus economic development, the politicians more often than not will choose one of the sides, and one will be an environmentalist who says, 'The clean air is more important than the jobs,' and the other will be an economic development person who says, 'No, the jobs in the Hudson Valley are more important than the trees,' and both are wrong. Trees are important and the economic development is important."
Cuomo dismisses the idea that his inclusive style of government has liabilities. The press corps's demands for clear priorities is, he charges, simply self-serving. "Reporters have to summarize you at one point," he said. "They have to define you and it's easier if you're in one area and they can call you 'the Education Governor' or the person who failed to be the Education Governor." As far as Cuomo is concerned, it seems, the only result of having no well-defined priorities is that his public relations are not as good as they might be. "We have a very long list of accomplishments that I think have not been properly noted, because I have never focused on just one issue," he said.
But others see more serious consequences flowing from the absence of priorities. They look at state government, with its tricky politics and its bureaucratic inertia and its many competing interests, and they say coaxing this vast machinery to accomplish anything substantial requires a crystalline goal and a steely single-mindedness.
"The political system doesn't have the capacity to address a lot of important issues simultaneously," says Gerald Benjamin, a professor of political science at the State University of New York at New Paltz who is active in Republican politics. "What is necessary is to make a dramatic commitment to something and to focus the energy. You have to choose something and be measured by it."
The costs and the benefits of Cuomo's style are clear from his handling of virtually every major issue of the last eight years. Take, for example, the state's fiscal problems, which first emerged in the spring of 1988. Almost immediately, financial analysts urged Cuomo to make systematic, long-term spending cuts to prepare for even harder times to come. But the Governor, hesitant to antagonize the municipal governments, school districts and other vast constituencies that depend on state dollars, demurred. Instead, he made temporary cuts that left the long-term problems unaddressed. Then he dipped into reserve funds and allowed the state to spend its way into enormous deficits.
It was not until late last year, with a national recession well under way and half the states in the country awash in red ink, that the Governor proposed the kind of budget cuts that others around the state had called for from the start. (Late last month the Governor proposed an additional $4.5 billion in spending cuts.) The price of waiting was high: New York's credit rating dropped to its lowest level ever and became the third-lowest of any state in the nation after Massachusetts and Louisiana. But by waiting, the Governor effectively minimized opposition to the cuts: the problems had become so enormous that the cuts were unavoidable, and everyone, liberal or conservative, Republican or Democrat, acknowledged it.
This tactic -- delaying until a consensus finally presents itself -- is typical of the Governor's response to controversy. While other governors, like Jim Florio of New Jersey, simply try to overpower their opponents, Cuomo attempts to win them over, no matter what the cost. "What he really likes to do," Wade says, "is defang the opposition."
One of the Governor's favorite strategies for "defanging" his opponents is to appoint a commission to advise him on a controversial issue. At their best, these commissions provide a forum for all sides to vent their anger, and they lay the groundwork for compromise. But too often, critics of the Governor complain, the commissions become a substitute for doing anything at all.
Such was the case with the Governor's commission on the Adirondack Park, a collection of private and public lands that together make up the largest wilderness area east of the Mississippi. Under heavy pressure from environmentalists, Cuomo appointed a commission in early 1989 to suggest ways to preserve the park from what he called "an era of unbridled land speculation and unwarranted development." Last May, the commission issued a set of sweeping recommendations, including a yearlong moratorium on new construc-tion in the park and permanent changes in its zoning. Adirondack residents, wary about the impact of the proposals on the local economy, tied up traffic in Albany in protest. Cuomo not only backed away from the recommendations, but even questioned the very premise on which the commission had been founded.
"I didn't assume the park was in trouble," he said. "I said I wanted to know if the park was in trouble." To pacify those who lived in the park, Cuomo turned to a second group, which recommended ways to water down the original commission's plan. It is now two years since the initial commission was appointed, and nothing has been done.
CUOMO IS extremely sensitive to charges that he has not imposed a clear vision on the state or lived up to the high standards of achievement set by some of his predecessors. Such criticism, he claims, is an unfortunate consequence of speaking up for what he believes.
Nearly seven years ago, Cuomo delivered the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco. The speech, a ringing condemnation of the Reagan era, not only transformed Cuomo, then a new and relatively untested Governor, into a national figure; it furnished him with what seems to be a perpetual spot on the list of potential Democratic Presidential candidates. Now, Cuomo claims, he regrets ever having made the speech. "Frankly," he says, "I'm sorry I went."
The 1984 keynote address, Cuomo asserts, made him the target of a terrible form of injustice, which he has labeled the "dumb blonde syndrome." Like the proverbial "dumb blonde," the Governor says, he is the victim of an insidious prejudice that works like this: if she's beautiful, she can't type; if he gives great speeches, he must be a lousy Governor. "I think once I made a speech at the keynote that was well received, that became a problem for us," he says. People began to criticize his record, according to Cuomo, saying that it fell short of the rhetoric. "They said, 'See, he gives a speech, what else can he do?' "
Cuomo certainly is right about being treated more critically than your run-of-the-mill Governor. What he seems unwilling to accept is that such criticism follows inevitably from his position as a national leader and potential President. Or it may be that he chooses not to realize it to make a point.
Treating criticism as a fault of the critic is one of Cuomo's favorite tactics. It puts the critic on the defensive ("Gosh, I didn't realize I was prejudiced against great orators"), and it blurs the issue under debate. But the tactic has been only half-effective: Cuomo continues to feel harassed by criticism of his record -- and to take offense at such criticism. When pressed on the issue, Cuomo can become defensive, measuring himself against some of his more illustrious predecessors -- Dewey, for example, or Rockefeller -- and suggesting that they have been overrated. (Dewey is credited with building the state's thruway, Rockefeller the state university system.)
"If I had wanted to be the guy with the edifice complex and never mentioned children and never mentioned prisons and never mentioned the environment, I could have talked only about the state university building I've rebuilt and the roads and bridges I've rebuilt," Cuomo said in an interview last year about his record. "Fifty billion dollars worth. You look it up. Where in the Rockefeller years did they do that much in eight years? Dewey didn't do that much."
To further confound his critics, Cuomo has recently taken to chronicling his accomplishments in long, encyclopedic lists. These lists include everything from the significant -- "unprecedented prison expansion" (Cuomo has presided over the largest prison construction program in state history) -- to the justifiably obscure -- "Quebec license reciprocity."
The irony of these lists is that Cuomo rarely takes credit for what is perhaps his greatest accomplishment. When he became Governor, Cuomo inherited a state that was already a hothouse for urban problems: crime, drugs, relentless poverty. During his administration, these problems have grown dramatically. Crack arrived and decimated whole neighborhoods. AIDS exacted a ravaging toll. Reagonomics helped push the state's vast legions of poor further into misfortune.
Much of Cuomo's energies over the last eight years have been devoted to preserving the fabric of New York society in the face of these new threats, a task that has not been easy. AIDS and crack strained the state's safety net; racial tensions grew; the gulf between rich and poor widened. Yet at a time when, in Washington, government was being portrayed as the problem, Cuomo maintained in New York that government was part of the solution.
This message is perhaps Cuomo's greatest legacy to New York State. In a period when the social contract seemed constantly threatened with annulment, Cuomo continued to press for a society in which everyone had a stake and no one was abandoned. He set the tone for the state. When it was easy to sow division, he preached caring and compassion. This achievement is more abstract than most that history records. It is a rhetorical victory, but nonetheless one with real consequences.
Mel Miller, the State Assembly Speaker, is, next to the Governor, the most powerful Democrat in New York. Miller has often battled with Cuomo, but he expresses a grudging respect for him and his ability to sustain a benevolent vision of government in troubled times.
"Cuomo has a traditional Democratic viewpoint that the basic role of government is to help people who need help," Miller says. "His real talent is that he can articulate these issues in a 1990's way. At a time when a lot of people have started to walk from this, he has said that New York is still committed to its progressive tradition, even though times have changed, and this has created a kind of hopefulness."
WHEN CUOMO TOOK office in 1983, he did away with the standard pyramidal model of executive authority and replaced it with a more egalitarian wheel. "I want myself in the center of the wheel," he said, "and a lot of spokes out to the agencies."
The metaphor was a good one for a state government as vast and far-flung as New York's. It stressed co-operation over hierarchy, and it suggested that Cuomo would grant his commissioners the automony to exercise their own judgment. But as anyone who has ever had sustained dealings with the Cuomo administration will attest, the reality has never lived up to the metaphor. In the Cuomo administration, "there are no real players," one former administration official says. "There's just him."
Under Cuomo, power has been consolidated to an almost unprecedented extent in the executive offices on the second floor of the State Capitol. No major decision is made by the head of a state agency without Cuomo's clearance, and even many mid-level decisions must await the approval of the Governor or one of his top staff members, a group referred to collectively as "the second floor."
This is a narrow circle, one totally under the Governor's control. Most of its members are able and committed public servants, but their ability to stand up to someone of Cuomo's stature and temperament is limited. Perhaps the highest compliment that can be paid in Albany is to say of a Cuomo staff member: "He argues with the Governor."
One of the few administration officials with enough clout to wrangle with Cuomo -- and to speak for him -- is Gerald C. Crotty, the Secretary to the Governor, who functions as a chief of staff. Evan A. Davis, until recently Cuomo's counsel, was viewed in Albany as a talented and thoughtful lawyer, but in discussions with the Legislature he was perceived as little more than a mouthpiece for the Governor's position. Many of those who have left the administration over the years look back at the 16-hour days they worked for the Governor and question whether he ever took notice of all the effort they put in.
To call Cuomo a "hands on" manager is to grossly understate his role in running state government. Cuomo is his own chief negotiator (in a recent fight with the state's public-employee unions, he went head to head directly with the union leaders), and he often serves as his own press secretary (he has been known to talk on the telephone with the same reporter two or three times in one day). He calls his aides dozens of times to remind them about one thing or another and asks: "How come I'm the only one who's thinking of these things?"
Cuomo is not fond of internal dissent, and that which exists in his administration is kept under wraps. Criticism emanating from officials outside the administration is harder to silence, but Cuomo is not averse to trying. Recently, for instance, a reporter from Time magazine confronted him with a disparaging remark attributed to Assembly Speaker Miller. With the reporter in his office, Cuomo phoned the Speaker and asked him point-blank if he had made the remark, which pointed to a gulf between the Governor's rhetoric and his performance. (Miller reluctantly had to acknowledge that he had.) On days when critical comments appear in the press, legislators, lobbyists and civic leaders have all come to expect threatening phone calls from the second floor.
The contrast between Cuomo's domineering, closed-off style and his open, expansive vision of government is one of the great contradictions of his administration. There is the public Cuomo, pushing a family style of politics that is embracing and compassionate, and then there is Cuomo in private, isolated and unforgiving.
It is the contradictions of his tenure -- the record vs. the rhetoric, the politics vs. the personality -- that have left Cuomo, after eight years in New York State's most visible office, still with an aura of mystery about him. Attempts to categorize him become entangled in his own internal conflicts, and even those who have watched Cuomo over many years can only shake their heads and conclude that nothing about him is simple or straightforward.
As Governor of New York and the leader of the state's Democratic Party, Cuomo is frequently asked to comment on the political implications of a particular event -- an election, a demonstration, an indictment. Just as frequently, he declines. "I'm not good at politics," he says, shaking his head regretfully. "It's not my strength."
This is the not the kind of ordinary prevarication that politicians often use to duck tough questions; it is a grandiose lie so patently false that it can hardly even be considered deceitful. Cuomo is a master at such magnificent deceptions. His response to the most direct question is usually not an answer, it is more a form of entertainment, a kind of performance art for the press.
OVER THE LAST FEW months, the speculation about a Cuomo candidacy has been resurrected, providing the Governor once again with a national audience for his circumlocutions. The war in the Persian Gulf has called attention to the Governor's major Presidential weakness -- his inexperience in foreign affairs -- and remarks Cuomo made in the fall advocating a negotiated settlement to the conflict struck some experts as dangerously naive. But the war has also created new vulnerabilities for President Bush and made a Cuomo candidacy seem, under certain circumstances, that much more plausible.
Cuomo has been playing the part of the candidate-in-spite-of-himself with characteristic elan. In a recent interview with the author William Kennedy, a friend of his, Cuomo said he couldn't rule out the Presidency even if he wanted to, and he didn't want to: "If I did say convincingly that under no circumstances would I ever run, that would be so unreasonable a position that people would say, 'There must be something in his closet.' Now I wouldn't mind if they said it was a 28-year-old blonde, but they don't say that. They say, 'His uncle is Mafia.' "
Cuomo is acutely sensitive to the peculiar slights suffered by Italian-Americans in public life; indeed, there are few politicians who take their ethical standing more seriously than he does. Cuomo and his wife, Matilda, attend church every Sunday morning, and, according to one of the ushers, the Governor always deposits a $10 bill in the collection basket. The Governor speaks reverentially -- and often -- about the homespun virtues that his immigrant parents, Andrea and Immaculata, taught him behind the counter of their Queens grocery store.
Nothing, in fact, infuriates Cuomo more than the suggestion that there is a chink in his integrity, or that of his family. Last year, for example, several newspapers reported that the Governor's youngest daughter, Madeline, had been tooling around -- and had managed to get into a car accident -- with a lapsed driver's license. The Governor's ire was so all-encompassing that even reporters who had not covered the story were told that he would not be answering their phone calls for a few days.
To Cuomo's credit, and immense satisfaction, little damaging evidence about his personal dealings has ever been discovered, despite the best efforts of many in the press. As Cuomo likes to point out, a team of Newsday reporters once spent several months trying to uncover corruption in his administration, poring over state contracts and expense records and conducting lengthy interrogations of his aides. The team came up essentially empty-handed. Reporters who investigated rumors about Mafia connections in the Governor's family were similarly disappointed.
These repeated failures have diminished one mystery only to open up another. Cuomo's Presidential hesitancy does not, it seems, have the easy logic of Gothic concealment. Like the disparity between his public vision of government and his private style, Cuomo's relation to the Presidency appears to be wrapped in some strangely personal enigma.
As Cuomo himself notes, enigmas are usually effaced by history, which is remorseless in its demand for decisiveness. Thus, history portrays great leaders as unwavering in their pursuits, when, on closer look, one finds that many were consumed by doubt.
Cuomo is eloquent when he describes his heroes, men like Abraham Lincoln and St. Thomas More, who at the crucial moment, he says, were forced by events to transcend their uncertainties: "One of the reasons I enjoy knowing Lincoln and Thomas More is that they were both terribly human, even to the point of suffering fits of ambiguity, ambivalence. Lincoln on the subject of slavery was often perceived as less than totally committed to the idea of the destruction of slavery in this nation. Indeed, he was perfectly prepared to allow it to continue in parts of the U.S., as we all know.
"The thing about Lincoln and More that makes them appealing to other human beings is that they are like all human beings, capable of not being totally lucid, totally clear, totally in control intellectually of their position on a given issue at all times. Sometimes it evolves, sometimes they slip and slide, sometimes they go sideways."
As 1992 draws close, and as New York enters a time of crisis, it may be that Cuomo will encounter events that will force him to resolve his own ambivalences -- and take his place in history. Or it may be that he won't. Events may prove too kind to him, or too cruel.

HEADLINE: BROWN U. RECEIVES GIFT OF $25 MILLION

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Thomas J. Watson Jr., the 77-year-old chairman emeritus of the International Business Machines Corporation and former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, gave $25 million yesterday to Brown University, where a dean once told him, "It doesn't look promising for you in college."
The gift, $10 million in cash and the rest in bequests, is the largest contribution in the 227-year history of the Providence, R.I., university. 
 Vartan Gregorian, the president of Brown, said that to acknowledge Mr. Watson's generosity and his 45-year involvement with the university, during which he has served as trustee, adviser and vice chancellor, the Brown Corporation voted yesterday to rename the university's Institute for International Studies the Thomas J. Watson Jr. Institute for International Studies.
The institute was established in 1986 and consists of 13 affiliated centers and programs, including the Center for Foreign Policy Development, which researches ways to improve relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.
 
A Most Generous Donor

Mr. Watson, who graduated from Brown in 1937, has been the university's most generous donor.
His first contribution to Brown was $750 in 1946, when he was named a trustee, Mr. Watson said in a telephone interview Friday from his office at I.B.M.'s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y.
His donations have continued and grown since then and, with this latest gift, now total more than $42 million.
"The reason for this gift is that they're having a major drive," Mr. Watson said. "I have great respect for the new man, Gregorian. I thought he deserved a good start."
 
$500 Million Endowment Drive

Dr. Gregorian, who headed the New York Public Library from 1981 to 1988, when he took over at Brown, said the $25 million gift would help start a campaign to raise as much as $500 million for the university's endowment.
That would more than double Brown's current endowment, estimated at $400 million. The university's endowment fund is the smallest of any of the eight colleges or universities in the Ivy League.
The endowment at Yale University, for example, is $2.3 billion. Yale has nearly 11,000 graduate and undergraduate students, as against Brown's total enrollment of 7,000. Harvard, with a total enrollment of about 18,000, has the largest endowment in the Ivy League, and in the nation, with $5 billion.
The size of its endowment means Brown faces more difficulties than other similar institutions in this time of rising costs. Other universities can rely on substantial interest income from their endowments to balance their budgets; Brown must generate most of its revenue through tuition and fees.
 
$2.7 Million Budget Deficit

The cost of an undergraduate year at Brown, including tuition, room and board, and fees, is slightly more than $20,000.
Dr. Gregorian said the university faces a $2.7 million budget deficit this year. So far, he has applied $1.3 million from the president's contingency fund toward the deficit and has imposed a hiring freeze that is expected to result in savings of up to $900,000. The remaining $500,000 will come from cuts in funds for nonacademic areas, he said.
"Private sector higher education cannot survive without enlightened support from civic leaders such as Tom Watson," Dr. Gregorian said.
Mr. Watson, the son of a founder of I.B.M., ran the company from 1956 to 1971. In his memoirs, "Father, Son & Co." (Bantam), published last year, he describes four years at Brown unfettered by the rigors of academic life or the economic hardships of the Depression.
"At Brown, I spent so much time flying airplanes and fooling around that I barely graduated," he wrote in the book's introduction.
After his first semester he was upbraided by Samuel T. Arnold, the dean of undergraduates. For the remainder of Mr. Watson's college career Dean Arnold continued to both reprimand and encourage him.
"In his wise old way he would say, 'You've got to do less of this and more of that,' " Mr. Watson said. "My getting through Brown was due as much to Dean Arnold as anyone else."
In memory of the dean, Mr. Watson has financed a program of Arnold Fellowships, which support students who are studying abroad.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas J. Watson Jr. has been Brown's most generous donor. (John Foraste/Brown University)

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
All Paths Led to Las Vegas

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
Larry Johnson stood in a parking lot outside the Thomas and Mack Center where an hour before he scored 23 points to lead Nevada-Las Vegas to another lopsided victory. This time it was by 40 points over Fresno State.
In the chilly night desert air, away from the glare of cameras and crowded interview rooms, Johnson reflected on the circuitous path that had brought him from an area in south Dallas he once called "the baddest part of town you ever saw," to Odessa College in Texas to Las Vegas.
 
 Had someone told him when he was 13 years old that 9 years later he would be the star player on a national championship team, and that he would be projected as a lottery pick in the National Basketball Association's draft and that he would be graduating with a degree in communications, Johnson said he wouldn't have believed it.
"Did you ever watch the movie 'A Raisin in the Sun?' " he asked referring to the 1961 adaptation of Lorraine Hansberry's play about a black family living in cramped quarters on the South Side of Chicago. The movie centered on the struggle of a mother to keep her family together in the face of economic hardship and social pressures.
 "That lady was my mom, she was the spitting image of my mom," Johnson said. "I saw that movie a couple weeks ago in Santa Barbara at 3:30 in the morning. I went and got on a pay phone and called my mama. I ask her about stuff like that: 'When I was 12, 13, did you ever think I'd be in this position?' "
"I usually tell him no, I didn't think so," Dortha Johnson said. "That's what makes me so proud of him. All of a sudden he decided he wanted something, and straightened up and tried to get it."
 The paths that have carried Johnson's teammates to Las Vegas have been equally oblique. Two of the six players in the starting rotation -- Greg Anthony and Elmore Spencer -- began their careers at four-year colleges. Johnson and George Ackles attended junior college, and Stacey Augmon and Anderson Hunt came directly from high school.
 They have come here from Pasadena, Calif.; Manteo, N.C.; Detroit, Atlanta and Portland to form what some think -- pending the outcome of this afternoon's game with Arkansas -- may be one of the best college basketball teams in the last 15 years.
 It is also one of the most controversial because of its image as an outlaw school and its battles with the National Collegiate Athletic Association over the last decade. It is currently on probation for violations in the program.
The players, however, view themselves and their program in a more positive light.
"Coach Tarkanian has brought in hardworking, blue-collar type players," said Spencer, the 6-foot-10-inch junior from Atlanta. "Not your prima donnas, not your all athletic, naturally gifted athletes. Inner-city kids with problems who have struggled. There have been success stories to come out of this program: people who have gotten their degrees, and there have been successful stories with people who haven't gotten their degrees.
"When things go well on campus, on the court, little things like N.C.A.A. probation, illegal recruitment, illegal payment, all of that stuff seems trivial because the things that are bringing me joy don't even apply to the N.C.A.A. rules."
In many ways, who they are and where they come from helps explain their amazing success through hard work and making the most of an opportunity and overcoming adversity to achieve a common goal. Here's a closer look at the men of U.N.L.V.
 
LARRY JOHNSON, 6-7 forward

"I play basketball because I like it, but the most important thing I want to do is help my family," he said. "I get $700 a month for a scholarship check. I'm living good. The thing I'm worrying about is my family living good. No more working for my mom or my aunt.
 "When I was 15, 16, it was all about having fun and trying to survive in my neighborhood, day to day. I used to run the streets, my mom used to be crying all the time, coming to get me out of the police station all the time. Sports took me off the street."
After his junior year in high school, his mother hand-delivered him to Skyline, the largest high school in Dallas, and entrusted him to Coach J. D. Mayo. Mayo said that Johnson was "rough around the edges, like most 14-year-olds. But he was one of the most incredibly focused young people I'd ever met. He'd take one thing and work on it and work on it until he got it right. People don't realize it, but Larry was an overachiever."
Although Johnson, an all-American, promised that he would stay in school after leading the Runnin' Rebels to their first national championship last April, a number of people were surprised when he did return.
"One of my goals is to get my degree, get my education and stay healthy," he said. "I'm trying to please my family, keep my mom happy, make sure she's proud of me. I just don't want to do anything to make my team look bad, make me look bad, make my family look bad."
 
STACEY AUGMON, 6-8 forward
 While Pasadena is only 280 miles from Las Vegas, those who knew Augmon as a gangly, introverted 14-year-old say he has traveled as far as any of his teammates to reach this point in his life.
 "Basketball has opened doors for Stacey that he would not have even come close to, much less gone through," said Eddie Newman, an assistant principal at Muir High School who has known Augmon since his freshman year there. "He was a nice, quiet, even-tempered young man. He wasn't strong academically when he came in, but he got through because he worked hard and he listened."
Augmon was raised in northwest Pasadena, a predominantly black, poor section. "Coming up, I was very shy, I stayed at home a lot because of my shyness," he said. Augmon was raised by his mother, but he credits his older sister, his oldest brother and basketball with keeping him from getting caught up in neighborhood street life.
"It's really unbelievable the success I've had on this team," Augmon said. "I would have never thought that this would have happened when I came to college."
 
GREG ANTHONY, 6-1 guard
 Anthony is the antithesis of the world-class athlete: bright, politically active, socially conscious. He is vice chairman of the Young Republicans of Nevada, has his real-estate license and owns his own company. He interned in 1989 in the Washington office of Representative Barbara Vucanovich and served as an aide at the World Economic Summit in Houston last summer.
Yet, in a more fundamental way, Anthony is a hungry athlete who is driven to succeed by a fear of failing and falling back into the directionless life of North Las Vegas.
 The search for something new and different is what took Anthony from Rancho High in Las Vegas to the University of Portland. He played shooting guard and earned freshman-of-the-year honors. But he knew he would never receive visibility and publicity there, so he transferred to U.N.L.V.
"I think there's too much emphasis on just getting that piece of paper, instead of enhancing the person as an individual, instead of learning more about life, which is what the college environment should be all about," he said.
 
GEORGE ACKLES, 6-11 center
 "I thought I'd be working right now, doing a 9-to-5 job," said Ackles. "I never thought I'd be able to play basketball, to tell you the truth, because I didn't start playing until my junior year in high school."
The summer that Ackles turned 15 his mother moved him and his twin sisters from a Pittsburgh suburb to Virginia, where she had found work as a cook at the Calvary Pentecostal Camp. Not only did Ackles not share his mother's religious commitment, he was somewhat miffed that just when he was developing a feel for basketball she moved to a place where the game wasn't played. When Ackles made friends with someone from Manteo, N.C., he convinced his mother that Manteo was where he needed to be.
 "I cried for two days after he left," Marva Ackles said. "It's hard to cut those apron strings, but I knew if I didn't let him go, he'd rebel."
 Ackles played two seasons at Manteo High School and then shocked his mother again by announcing that he was going to Garden City Community College in Kansas.
 At U.N.L.V., Ackles started in 1988-89 season and set a school single-season record for blocks with 64. He suffered a broken wrist the following summer and sat out as the Rebels won the national championship.
 
ANDERSON HUNT, 6-1 1/2 guard
 Although he's the youngest starter, Hunt is probably the oldest and truest Rebel at heart. In fact, he knew as early as his freshman year at Southwestern High School in Detroit that he wanted to come to U.N.L.V. Hunt grew up as the youngest of three children in a stable, working-class neighborhood. His father died when he was 9. That was the last major trauma until his senior year in high school when Southwestern, with a 27-1 record, was upset in the championship game.
Then Hunt took the Scholastic Aptitude Test a day after his senior prom and failed to make the 700 score to be eligible to play as a freshman. Meanwhile, all of his Detroit buddies played. "Seeing Mark Macon play and Doug Smith, Steve Smith all having great freshman years, that hurt a lot," he said. "But I bounced back and studied harder and I'm here today."
When U.N.L.V. played Duke for the national title, Hunt made 12 of 16 shots, had 30 points and was the most valuable player of the Final Four.
 
ELMORE SPENCER, 7-0 center
 Elmore Spencer grew to be 6-10 by his senior year when he led Washington High School in Atlanta to the state title and an impressive victory over Skyline, led by Larry Johnson.
 During the previous summer, his mother suffered a fatal heart attack while talking on the phone to a college recruiter. Suddenly it was Spencer and his younger sister.
 "As soon as she died it was an abrupt maturation process, overnight," he said. "I know that I could still have humor and live a happy life, but I also knew that when she died I was a young man with responsibilities."
 Spencer made a commitment to attend Georgia, but the summer before he was to report he was diagnosed as being manic depressive and spent 36 days in the psychiatric ward of a hospital. He enrolled at Georgia sat out the first year, played the following year but then suffered a broken foot. Spencer enrolled at Connors State Junior College in Warner, Okla.
Spencer, who is married, said he had found peace in the desert. "I'm content," he said. "I'm happy with my classes here. The teachers are very coperative. Athletically I play with a group of ballplayers who love each other, love playing the game at a fast pace. We jive well off the court, we help each other in time of need. It probably exceeded my expectations."
