HEADLINE: Businesses' Enthusiasm For the State Said to Drop

BYLINE: By BARBARA STURKEN

 BODY:
AFTER a decadelong boom in the state's economy, New Jersey's business associations say they are detecting a new streak of pessimism in the private sector. Although the economic picture is generally bleak throughout the nation, some businesses say that conditions in New Jersey are worse than in other states, prompting them to reassess their commitment to remaining here.
What seems to worry many business leaders is the growing perception that New Jersey is not a good place to do business anymore, and that this perception in itself could drive companies away. And while state officials argue that this view is not supported by any hard evidence, several recent polls of businesses have revealed a sharp increase in dissatisfaction with their treatment by the state. 
 "The bloom is off the rose," said Elissa McCrary, vice president for communications of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, which surveys its 13,000 members at least once a year.
In a recent poll, which drew the most negative results in years, she said, 71 percent of the 3,100 companies responding said that conditions were worse in New Jersey than in the rest of the nation, up from only 27 percent a year ago. The state did not fare any better in another survey, by the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce and Price Waterhouse, which found that 87 percent of the 500 companies polled thought that actions by the state's government would hurt their business over the next five years. Some critics argue that New Jersey is already losing its competitive edge, pointing to the decision by several large employers to leave the state.
Maxwell House, a division of Kraft General Foods, for example, is planning to close its Hoboken plant and transfer some of its operations to Jacksonville, Fla., a move that affects 600 jobs. The company avoided any direct criticism of New Jersey in its announcement, but it did cite lower labor costs elsewhere as a factor.
"There is no question that there are businesses leaving the state and that manufacturing has dropped in New Jersey more than in other states," said Frederick Westphal, president of the State Chamber of Commerce. Although 70 percent of the businesses polled by the chamber said they were satisfied with their New Jersey locations, about a third of that group said they had considered moving.
And the Business and Industry Association, in a survey it did in mid-1990, asked a similar question and found that 88 percent said they were unlikely to expand in the state. Asked whether they would cease operations in New Jersey, 14 percent said they would. The group said a number of its members were reacting to what they felt was an "antibusiness" attitude in state government.
State officials answer these complaints by pointing out that even if some companies are leaving or putting on hold expansion plans, others are moving in. BASF, a German chemical company, for example, is building its North American headquarters in Mount Olive, and Pepsico said it would construct a bottling plant in Piscataway. But while most businesses are not about to pull up stakes, many say that their displeasure goes beyond the normal complaining in an economic downturn.
Mr. Westphal of the Chamber of Commerce said that what New Jersey businesses objected to were a rise in state and local taxes, increased health insurance costs and what has been perceived as an onslaught of costly environmental regulations.
He singled out some elements of Gov. Jim Florio's tax package as particularly damaging, like the new 7 percent telecommunications tax. "That makes us a locker room ballplayer," Mr. Westphal said. "We can't compete with surrounding states."
 
Concern Over Negative Thinking
 Yet at the same time the Chamber of Commerce is concerned that this sort of negative thinking not get out of control, Mr. Westphal said. "A perception can become reality, and that certainly is not what we're trying to do," he said. "We're trying to put a positive spin on it."
He said the chamber was also working to promote the very things that have drawn record numbers of companies to the state in recent years, like foreign trade zones and its being in the densely populated Northeast corridor, which provides a ready market for goods and services.
Dennis Marco, Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Commerce, Energy and Economic Development, said he believed that the surveys might be picking up businesses' traditional suspicion of government, rather than any new anti-New Jersey sentiment. The Governor's budget actions have given the state a triple-A bond rating, which should help accelerate economic recovery, he said.
"This administration came into a situation where we were left with an enormous deficit," Mr. Marco said. "We have now taken care of our fiscal house, and we haven't proposed raising taxes this year, unlike other states."
Many business officials do give Governor Florio credit for getting the tax issue behind him quickly, no matter how unpalatable it seemed at the time. Now the spotlight is shifting to New York, Connecticut and other nearby states, which are agonizing over the same unpopular revenue-raising measures that brought the business community's wrath down on Mr. Florio more than a year ago.
 
Disagreement With Pessimism
 Beatrice D'Agostino, president of the New Jersey Savings Bank in Somerville, said she did not share the bearish outlook of many of her colleagues.
"I don't hold with these dim economic forecasts," she said. "The economic situation in the whole Northeast reflects a deepening recession, but we have weathered these storms in the past."
Some of the pessimism may be due to the inevitable contraction that follows a boom, she added. "Many businesses came here for the tax benefits and a great employee base," she said. "But businesses expanded so quickly and what they are really doing is purging the excesses of that expansion, and that is not necessarily saying that they don't want to be in New Jersey."
The severity of the state's economic slowdown was confirmed in the Chamber of Commerce survey, in which 70 percent of the respondents said their business was down, with 41 percent estimating that things would not improve until 1992. And 42 percent said they were likely to reduce their staffs this year.
One commonly voiced concern is that New Jersey may be losing its status as a state that companies would move to, rather than flee. New York City, for example, has seen a sizable number of businesses move across the river to take advantage of tax breaks and lower costs. But the amount of negative publicity over New Jersey's tax increases may have damaged the state's image as a more friendly environment for business than some of its neighbors.
 
'Our Tax Advantage Is Gone'
 Joseph Hoffman, a partner in the Roseland law firm of Hannoch Weisman, said that "our tax advantage is gone" and that "our tax structure is now pretty much like New York's, and not as good as Pennsylvania's."
Even worse than the increased taxes are the environmental laws that are now on the books, said Mr. Hoffman, a formerNew Jersey Commissioner of Labor. Among the laws he and other critics mention are the Clean Water Enforcement Act and the universal labeling law, which recently went into effect after being held up by legal appeals for a number of years.
"These laws have one by one tightened the noose around New Jersey's businesses," he said.
 But even if New Jersey is seen as being less advantageous for business, state officials say statistics contradict any suggestion that companies are departing in droves. The Commerce Department's most recent figures show that New York-based businesses are continuing to move to New Jersey, and, in fact, that the number rose 30 percent last year, with 51 New York companies announcing moves or expansion to New Jersey.
Mr. Marco said New Jersey would fight to keep jobs in the state by giving companies an incentive to stay. As an example, he cited the negotiations that preceded Maxwell House's decision to close its New Jersey plant.
"The region came together to save the facility," he said, with a plan that involved the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and state and local governments. Mr. Marco said that terminal operators had agreed to give favorable terms to the company and that an arrangement had been made to bring coffee beans to the plant by barge from Brooklyn.
 
Views on Maxwell House Move
 Although Kraft General Foods, which is based in White Plains, did not comment on the specifics of the Maxwell House negotiations, Mr. Marco said New Jersey lost out because Florida had lower labor costs and had less stringent rules on air quality than New Jersey.
"The bottom line is that they can pay $3 less an hour," he said, "but I think they are being very shortsighted to move out of the biggest market in the country for their product."
Nan Redmond, Kraft's director of corporate affairs, said that while the company did take labor costs into account, "a whole lot of other things were involved; it was not a one-dimensional decision."
A recent New Jersey Labor Department report on the state's economic indicators also noted the decision of several companies to move plants to other states. The Ciba-Geigy Corporation, the chemical and pharmaceutical giant, is moving one of its Toms River divisions to California and Alabama.
Another example provided by the Business and Industry Association is the decision of the Clorox Company to close its household products manufacturing operation in Jersey City by the fall of 1993, the same time it is opening an expanded production center in Perryman, Md. The move affects 160 employees.
The report noted that New Jersey had already been losing manufacturing jobs to other states, citing New Jersey Department of Labor statistics showing that the state has lost about 43,000 manufacturing jobs since the end of 1988. But until 1990 service industries had more than made up the difference, it said.
With the recession now spreading nationwide, New Jersey businesses should look to other markets, particularly overseas, Mr. Westphal of the Chamber of Commerce said. The Business and Industry Association,for its part, has urged closer communication between the state officials regulating business and the companies' executives. If this occurs, both groups say, perhaps the results of their annual surveys will not be so unflattering to New Jersey next year.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Another Opening, at a New Address

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: ELMSFORD

 BODY:
WHEN times are hard, have a theater built. That appears to be the credo of William B. Stutler and Robert J. Funking, the producers of An Evening Dinner Theater, which opened here in 1974, the beleaguered year of an energy shortage, a bear market and multiple monetary crises.
Now, in a new decade that financial analysts are already referring to as the "economically lean 90's," Mr. Stutler and Mr. Funking are about to open a new, enlarged showplace. 
 In a burst of assertiveness, they have named it Westchester Broadway Theater. Moreover, they are changing the address, from 75 Clearbrook Road, one block north of the theater they are leaving, to 1 Broadway Plaza. There, preview performances of "A Chorus Line" are scheduled to begin on Wednesday, in preparation of a formal opening night party on Friday and a run through June 2.
 
Success and Risk in Westchester
 During a tour of the new 449-seat theater last weekend, Mr. Stutler and Mr. Funking were surrounded by about 60 carpenters, painters, woodworkers and plumbers. (The cast and crew of "A Chorus Line," meanwhile, were rehearsing in the old space.) They talked about the formula of their success and the risk of a new theater operation in Westchester where, they said their research indicated, 27 professional theater companies "have come and gone" in the 16 years since An Evening opened.
"Westchester is not a county that experiments," said Mr. Stutler, who has lived in Croton-on-Hudson for 27 years. "And it doesn't have a strong theater history. Our audiences want to know what they're going to see, and that it's been successful."
Mr. Funking, a Scarborough resident for 16 years, added: "We give them what they want: a great service that's pleasant, easy and convenient, with no parking problems. People don't want hassles. And they resent the prices -- and the fear -- of going to Broadway. So even though we're using the cachet of Broadway for professionalism and glamour, we're different."
 
A 15-Year Lease
 Mr. Stutler and Mr. Funking hold a 15-year lease on the new building, which is owned and was built by the Robert Martin Company of Elmsford. The cost was $4.5 million, $1 million of which was raised by the producers.
"In reality we couldn't build it ourselves -- banks don't lend money to theaters and restaurants," Mr. Stutler said. "But we have the largest commercial landlord in the county, and we've been their tenant for 16 years. We felt a need to improve, and all businesses have to be recycled, redesigned, jazzed up."
The new theater, at 32,000 square feet, is almost twice as large as the old one and has a stage that is four feet wider and twice as high. The lobby is three times the size of the one at An Evening. There is an expanded orchestra pit below stage level, an electrical grid for more than 500 lighting instruments, and a "floating" stairway as well as an elevator. The rehearsal room will no longer double as a lounge or a place for private parties, and there are plentiful restrooms.
"The interior is painted dark red, which has been found by restaurant magazines to be the most appetizing and flattering color," Mr. Stutler said.
When An Evening opened, the top ticket price was $11.95; the current top price of $50 on Saturday nights ($41.24 on weeknights) will continue at the new theater. But now five private boxes, named after famous composers, will be available with what the theater is calling an "enhanced menu" for $88 a ticket.
 
Fewer Shows, Longer Runs
 "We started with short runs -- 'Kiss Me, Kate' for six weeks, 'Barefoot in the Park' for five," Mr. Funking recalled. "But the comedies were not supported. People wanted only musicals. Now fewer new ones are available, and they're running longer."
This has been the case since 1985, when "Evita" ran at An Evening for 21 weeks. Since then "La Cage aux Folles" and "My One and Only" each lasted 24 weeks. The current "Me and My Girl" will have run 26 weeks when it closes today.
The musicals play Wednesday through Saturday evenings with matinees on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. On Mondays and Tuesdays, special shows will continue to be offered: Big Band concerts, comedy nights and outside productions of usually light plays.
The producers declined to reveal recent figures about audience demographics or disclose the monthly cost of running the new theater. "It's very high and double the rent we've been paying," Mr. Stutler said, who added that there was "a yearly gross of $6 million, and we're profitable -- 1989 was more so than 1990."
"But our profit margins are small and getting tighter. The rising cost of insurance and health plans and pension and welfare for actors can add 30 percent to the Equity minimum, which is now $323 a week for chorus members. But 'A Chorus Line' has only four cast members who are on a chorus contract. The rest are principals and our pre-production costs will come to $200,000."
 
Whence the Audience
 Mr. Stutler said the theater's audiences "come mostly from Westchester," but he added: "There's the tri-state area, groups from fire departments, bowling leagues and various corporations; and busloads from the Bronx and Philadelphia and Dutchess County."
Addressing the theatrical status of dinner theater, Mr. Funking said: "We're a theater that serves food, not a restaurant that puts on a show. There's a lot of snobbery about that and it's been hard to overcome. But now we're accepted in the theater world and agents send us the same people they send Hal Prince -- and that took years to accomplish."
Performers who have appeared at An Evening include Kevin Gray, who has the title role in "Phantom of the Opera" on Broadway and played one of the leads in "Kiss of the Spider Woman" when it was produced by New Musicals last year at the State University of New York at Purchase -- both productions directed by Mr. Prince.
"When we started planning three years ago, times were terrible." Mr. Funking said. "If we had to start that all over again now, we probably wouldn't. But our timing was good before. If you ever want to know a recession is on the way, just have us open a theater."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Design for a Post-Cold War Company

BYLINE: By RICHARD FLORIDA and MARTIN KENNEY; Richard Florida and Martin Kenney are authors of "The Breakthrough Illusion: Corporate America's Failure to Move From Innovation to Mass Production."

 BODY:
Japan's leading microelectronics companies are opening state-of-the-art research and development laboratories in the United States and are trying to steal away America's best scientists. Is the American computer industry -- the last bastion of American technological superiority -- about to succumb to the Japanese threat? A number of analysts think so. But it is not the Japanese we should be afraid of. We are our own worst enemy.
American companies, held hostage by the illusion that breakthroughs are the key to technological superiority and industrial competitiveness, have failed to employ a winning formula. To be competitive, big new ideas must be turned into products and that requires an ability to follow through. This is where we, as an industrial nation, fail. And this is where the Japanese succeed. 
 To address our competitiveness problems, we must make changes in three fundamental areas:
First, we must tap the collective intelligence of all our workers, from research and development scientists to factory workers. This is absolutely essential for success in an age of rapid technological change and perpetual innovation.
There can no longer be a one-way flow of information from "all-knowing" scientists, engineers and managers to the "know-nothings" on the factory floor. The shop floor must become an extension of the lab, and the lab an extension of the shop floor.
Second, American companies must realize that workers will continue to resist corporate efforts to tap into their brains if they do not have real guarantees that their jobs are safe. Many companies sold off their labs and moved their factories to the third world, resulting in massive layoffs and disaffection among those who remained.
Third, even with the success of the high-technology weapons used in the Persian Gulf war, America must transform itself from a military to a civilian economy. We must mobilize all the resources we can muster to build a more effective technology system and economy.
This means dismantling the old cold war military research, development and manufacturing system and embarking on a comprehensive effort to rebuild our industrial plant.
Huge amounts of government money and generations of our best engineers and scientists have been devoted to developing military breakthroughs. The Pentagon has created a technological welfare state, the most expensive industrial subsidy program in all of human history. This has enabled American corporations to prosper, while avoiding the restructuring they need to make them globally competitive.
The real reason Japanese companies are opening labs in the United States is not to steal our breakthroughs, but to incorporate them into their already well-established manufacturing plants. We have the opportunity to do the same.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Rally's Continuation Is Questioned

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
With long-term interest rates at their lowest levels in more than a year, some credit market analysts are beginning to wonder whether the bond market rally that began in mid-January has run its course.
Bond yields have fallen by more than half a percentage point in scarcely a month's time, and since much of the $11 billion worth of new 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds sold at last week's Treasury refunding auctions remain in Wall Street's hands, dealers are watching to see whether retail investors will step up and buy the securities. 
 "The Street has a very real interest in keeping the rally going," said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. "But at the moment there does not seem to be any clear sign of overwhelming retail demand. Do investors believe that this is about the end of the decline, and that rates could turn around?"
 
Lower Yields Expected
 Despite the seeming lack of enthusiasm by investors, Mr. Griggs and other analysts said the recession and an anticipated sharp slowdown in inflation this year would probably push bond yields lower.
"The bullish posture of the dealer community is absolutely appropriate," said James M. Benham, chairman of Benham Capital Management Group, a Mountain View, Calif., firm with a fixed-income portfolio of $7.5 billion, most of it in Government securities. "The bond market rally is real. The weakness in the economy is clearly evident, and talk about a turnaround this spring looks like a hope to me, not reality. I think bond yields are destined to fall to 7.75 percent at least and possibly as low as 7 percent by year-end, depending on what the economy does and how the Fed responds."
Because the drop in short-term rates has been so much more pronounced than in bond yields, Mr. Benham said more and more investors in his funds were lengthening the maturity of their holdings to capture additional yield.
 
Salomon Assessment
 "The most compelling argument in favor of lower yields stems from the forces that are undercutting inflation," Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, noted in the firm's weekly newsletter Comments on Credit.
Because of the recession, wage pressures are easing, Mr. DiClemente said. And a slowdown in other industrial economies, many of them crucial American export markets, will impede a quick recovery in the United States.
Still, there are signs that investors, who grew increasingly conscious of credit quality as 1990 progressed, are now willing to take on more risk in exchange for yields that are much higher than those offered on AAA-rated Treasury securities.
Despite the recession, prices of a wide variety of corporate bonds have been rising for much of the last month, from high-yield "junk bonds," to medium- to high-quality corporate issues.
 
Corporate Yields at a Low
 Corporate bond indexes compiled by Merrill Lynch show that yields on high-quality corporate bonds with maturities of 10 years or more are now at 52-week lows, at just over 9 percent. So, too, are yields on riskier investment-grade corporate debt, securities rated A to Baa. At the end of last week, Merrill Lynch's index showed those issues were yielding about 9.80 percent.
The improvement in the corporate market has much to do with the overall decline in interest rates. But analysts said the declines in many corporate issues in the fourth quarter turned them into bargains.
"In the fourth quarter the whole corporate market got cheap, too cheap relative to the economic fundamentals," said Thomas J. Sowanick, senior fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch.
"With the general level of bond yields down, and the fact that long Treasuries are now yielding under 8 percent, investors have been given a reason to take on incremental yield."
 
Views on Corporate Market
 Given the economic outlook, participants in the corporate market said prices would probably improve further.
"For the first time probably since 1982, people think they should buy corporates because the Fed is lowering rates and, while credit quality looks bad now, it will improve in six or seven months," said one corporate bond trader. "Prices in this market are not the equivalent of being 6 percent or so from their all-time peak, as they are in the stock market."
Analysts said that upcoming economic reports this week should be favorable to prices in almost all fixed-income markets.
"We are looking for a whole string of weak numbers, from industrial production to retail sales to producer prices," said Steven Slifer, a senior vice president and financial market economist at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "If we get that string, the market might begin building an expectation that the Fed will ease again before the end of February."
 
Possible Stumbling Block
 The producer price report that Mr. Slifer referred to might prove a stumbling block.
Most analysts, including Mr. Slifer, anticipate that the Producer Price Index for January, which is expected to be released on Friday, will show that prices fell last month, in large part because of a decline in energy prices.
Some analysts noted, however, that much of that decline occurred after the onset of fighting in the Middle East. In early January, the period when data for the report were collected, wholesale gasoline prices actually rose, they said.
As a consequence, Brian Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers, is estimating that producer prices probably rose by two-tenths of a percentage point last month, after a decline of six-tenths of a point in December.
Excluding food and energy, however, the core inflation rate probably increased by a mere one-tenth of a percentage point, Mr. Jones said, compared with an increase of three-tenths of a point in December.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Washington;
Baker and Dole Disagreeing On Warning by Gorbachev

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today brushed aside Soviet complaints that the United States was on the verge of exceeding United Nations resolutions by destroying Iraq and not just liberating Kuwait, but a top Republican Senator said the Soviet position might be correct.
The conflicting assessments by Mr. Baker and the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, reflect what is likely to be growing debate in the anti-Iraq coalition about exactly what are Washington's war aims, as long it continues to depend on air power to wear down Iraq's military without any movement on the ground to liberate Kuwait. 
 President Mikhail S. Gorbachev added fuel to that debate on Saturday when he declared in Moscow that the air war against Iraq was assuming "an ever more alarming and dramatic scope" and that the "logic" of American military operations threatened to exceed the limited United Nations mandate of liberating Kuwait.
"I would disagree with that," Mr. Baker said when asked on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" about Mr. Gorbachev's complaint regarding the United Nations mandate. "The language calls for the use of all necessary means to implement the U.N. resolutions, which call for Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait and restoration of the leadership. So by taking on primarily military targets in Iraq, we are moving in that direction, and we're doing so in a manner that's going to reduce coalition casualties."
 
Domestic Audience Seen
 Asked whether he was worried that Mr. Gorbachev might be drifting away from the anti-Iraq coalition, Mr. Baker indicated that this was not a concern and that Mr. Gorbachev appeared to speaking more to some of his domestic constituencies than signaling any major policy change.
"The Soviet Union gave us prior notice of this statement," Mr. Baker said. "It is true that the position, the principled position, they have taken alongside the United States has not been popular with many segments of Soviet society. So there is a significant amount of public opinion in the Soviet Union, particularly in some of the Muslim republics, with some of the military, that are very much opposed to the position they're taking, but they're sticking with that position."
Mr. Baker said Washington did not object to a planned visit to Baghdad by the Soviet Middle East envoy, Yevgeny M. Primakov, to try to persuade President Saddam Hussein to withdraw fully from Kuwait. If the Soviet envoy succeeds, Mr. Baker said, "more power to them."
While Administration officials publicly have to welcome any diplomatic efforts by the Soviet Union, privately they are more ambivalent. Although they never admit it publicly, Administration officials acknowledge in private that American interests will be served if Kuwait is not only liberated but Iraq's armed forces are sharply cut down in size, its ability to produce weapons of mass destruction is eliminated and Mr. Hussein is removed from power.
If Mr. Hussein survives this war, officials say, no matter how badly his army is mauled or driven out of Kuwait, he will still pose a threat to his neighbors and therefore victory will be incomplete until he is toppled.
 
Four Stated Goals
 Given these private sentiments, the current American military strategy of using weeks of aerial bombardments to sap the strength of Iraq's military before moving on Kuwait is ideal from the Administration's perspective, since it can accomplish its stated objectives while also accomplishing its unstated objectives. The Administration's four stated objectives are liberating Kuwait, restoring its legitimate Government, safeguarding Americans in the Persian Gulf and stabilizing the region.
Senator Dole, speaking on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," virtually confirmed this distinction between the Administration's explicit and implicit goals when he remarked: "I think, to some extent, when we say in addition to the four objectives set out by President Bush, we're going to, in effect, destroy Iraq militarily, that was not one of the original objectives. So there is a bit of truth to what Gorbachev says."
Mr. Dole went on to say that he did not think that Mr. Bush had formally expanded any of his initial goals, but that "just by happenstance, to get them out of Kuwait, we've had to repeatedly go after targets in Iraq, because he is not moving out of Kuwait."
"I don't see anything wrong with it," he added.
Judging from Mr. Gorbachev's remarks, the Soviet Union is ready to play along to a certain degree with Washington's explicit and implicit objectives, since at this stage it is virtually impossible to distinguish between a military strategy designed simply to liberate Kuwait and one that involves a wider objective of destroying Iraq's armed forces.
But Mr. Gorbachev's complaint, if it picks up more international support in the coming days, could force the United States into a ground campaign sooner rather than later, to maintain international support for the war to liberate Kuwawit. Mr. Gorbachev seemed to be saying to Washington that Moscow could not tolerate weeks more of devastating Iraq without any apparent movement on the ground to free Kuwait.
 
Hoping for Hussein's Ouster
 Mr. Gorbachev's warning aside, Mr. Baker did not shy away from sending yet another signal to the Iraqi people that although Washington did not have the explicit objective of removing President Hussein, postwar Iraq would benefit enormously if the Iraqis themselves deposed him.
Mr. Baker said that "as President Bush says, 'Nobody would shed any tears' " if Mr. Hussein was ousted.
"And it's going to be important in terms of what can and cannot be done in that area in the aftermath, whether it's economic reconstruction or what it is, but I do not believe that we should amend our war aims or our war goals to make that a war aim of the United States," he said.

HEADLINE: BRAZIL SKEPTICAL OVER PRICE FREEZE

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Last March, Brazilians thrilled to hear their dynamic new President announce that he had "one bullet to kill the inflationary tiger."
Almost one year later, a cartoon in the Rio daily Jornal do Brasil last week reflected a diminished public assessment: President Fernando Collor de Mello taking aim with a popgun, the barrel plugged with a cork on a string. 
 As Brazilians embark on their fifth experience in five years with wage and price controls, the political byword is credibilidade -- credibility.
"Collor II is working only in the land of make-believe," Brazil's most influential newsweekly, Veja, wrote last week of the President's second major economic shock plan since taking office on March 15.
 
Skepticism Is Rampant
 In January, only eight months since the end of the last freeze, prices jumped 20 percent. Today, only 10 days after the freeze was imposed, shortages are spreading through markets and shopkeepers are charging under-the-table commissions to sell hoarded goods in short supply. Among Brazilians who have lived through this cycle before, skepticism is rampant.
"There will be a short-term drop in inflation, but then it will return to be worse than before," predicted Roberto Campos, an economist and a conservative member of Congress. "The problem is that the plan attacks the effects and not the causes of inflation. The cause is excessive monetary expansion."
In a DataFolha poll made public on Saturday, 49 percent of the respondents said the price freeze was not working. Another large group, 60 perccent, predicted that unemployment would increase.
In a Gallup poll made public on Thursday, 56 percent of respondents predicted that the plan would not reduce inflation.
Indeed, with high monthly inflation and a sharp recession, Latin America's largest economy had already slipped into what economists here call stagflation -- inflation and economic stagnation. Last year, industrial activity in Sao Paulo fell 11.2 percent, the worst performance in the 15 years that the Sao Paulo Federation of Industries has charted industrial performance.
Factory owners, long accustomed to creative mathematics from Brasilia, are now struggling to discover how they can absorb gasoline and electricity increases of 50 percent, pay mandated salary raises at the end of February, maintain prices frozen at the levels of last Thursday and make money.
 
The Orthodox View
 Orthodox economists say Brazil's inflation persists because Mr. Collor did not follow through on vows to shrink government.
"They did not make the serious cuts in spending that they said they would," Norman Gall, executive director of the Fernand Braudel Institute of World Economy, said in a telephone interview from Sao Paulo. "They bailed out state banks that were going to close, and there was a 58 percent explosion of money supply in December."
In New York, Brazil's foreign creditors did not give the plan a warm welcome when debt talks resumed on Thursday. The private bankers seek payment of $8 billion in interest arrears. Brazil's foreign currency reserves are almost $9 billion, but the economic team says domestic priorities should come first.
One priority is to sell gold on the local market to artificially repress the local value of the dollar as money floods out of money market accounts now crippled by negative interest rates.
Last week, 81 tons of gold traded hands in Sao Paulo's market as the Central Bank sought to prevent a surge in the dollar. The dollar held steady, and Sao Paulo's stock exchange index soared.
Next Wednesday, after Brazil's four-day Carnival holiday, Brazil's Congress is to address the economic plan.
 
Inflation's Biggest Cause
 Looking beyond approval of wage and price controls, it is unclear whether Mr. Collor will be able to win congressional approval for measures to attack what is viewed as inflation's biggest cause -- the need to privatize money-losing state companies and to dismiss federal employees who now are guaranteed lifetime employment after five years of service.
In the 584-seat Congress, Mr. Collor's National Reconstruction Party controls only 45 seats, or 8 percent. But a recent survey of the new Congress indicated that in the presidential runoff vote in December 1989, 53 percent of Congress voted for Mr. Collor and 31 percent for Luis Inacio da Silva, his socialist opponent.
With foreign private creditors unwilling to lend money and the Government technically broke, the President's only remedies may be to print more money or to increase domestic borrowing, which pushed inflation in 1990 to 1,795 percent.
Facing a new Congress, Mr. Collor appears to be mapping out an aggressive strategy that will draw on his residual personal popularity.
"In public opinion polls about credibility, politicians generally come in last," the 41-year-old President asserted in the Jornal do Brasil interview. "The President of the republic comes in third, after the church and radio. There is an enormous distance in popular perception between policies made by the President and policies made by Congress."

HEADLINE: Japan Pressed to Buy More U.S. Awacs Jets

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Heating up another front in the continuing trade disputes with Japan, 70 members of Congress complained last week that Tokyo has dragged its feet in assuming responsibility for the defense of its air space and sea lanes.
At issue is whether Japan needs the radar surveillance plane built by the Boeing Company -- the Airborne Early Warning and Control System, or Awacs -- and if it does, how many it needs. 
 Japan's budget for the next fiscal year is expected to provide for the purchase of four Awacs planes. But Boeing has said that unless it receives authority by March 31 to begin work on at least 14 more Awacs planes or the supporting tanker aircraft that use the same body, it will shut its production line. It now has no orders in hand.
Boeing, based in Seattle, has more than 105,000 workers in that area and smaller operations in Kansas and elsewhere. The Awacs operation is a small part of its business, and its construction of commerical airliners is doing extremely well. Last year, the company reported a $1 billion profit.
The 70 legislators first pressed their point in a letter in September to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in which they asserted: "Defense experts on both sides of the Pacific agree that comprehensive coverage of the vast area Japan has agreed to defend requires between 12 to 14 Awacs planes and at least 20 tankers."
Last week, those same legislators introduced a bill to press the case for more Awacs. It urges the State Department to start negotiations with Japan "leading to the successful assumption by Japan of the 1,000-mile defense mission."
At Japan's Embassy in Washington, Hideaki Ueda, the minister for public affairs, strongly denied that Japan was not meeting its commitment. "We can't increase our defense capability at once to cover everything," he said, adding, "I don't think we have enough money to buy more."
The Bush Administration is playing down the issue. A State Department official who insisted on anonymity pointed to Japan's "steady progress" in fulfilling the military role it has set for itself, and other officials have noted that Japan's military budget calls for the purchase of two Aegis missile-firing cruisers in addition to the Awacs planes.
 
No Fight Wanted
 Bush officials made clear they had little inclination to pick a fight with Japan on this issue at a time when Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is battling antiwar protesters as he seeks to send an additional $9 billion to support the war against Iraq.
"There are some major sensitivities here," one Administration official acknowledged.
Yet Washington has not been shy about criticizing Tokyo on other fronts, including what it says are Japan's delays in fulfilling agreements to open its construction and semiconductor markets and to fight Japanese antimonopoly practices more aggressively.
Largely because of resentments against Japan, some members of Congress last month introduced a Trade Agreement Compliance Act, mandating sanctions against countries that do not meet their military commitments. It has won the support of a majority of the members of the Senate Finance Committee.
 
10-Year-Old Commitment
 Japan's commitment for self-defense stems from May 1981, when Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki, responding to demands from Washington that Japan assume part of the cost of its defense, said his country would assume responsibility for defending its sea lanes and airspace out to 1,000 nautical miles from its shores.
The Reagan and Bush Administrations attached great importance to the commitment, calling it hard evidence of Japan's willingness to share the burden of defending the Pacific. And Tokyo's pledge has never been modified or abandoned.
Japan has steadily increased its military spending in the last decade and now spends about $30 billion a year. That is about one-tenth the size of the American military budget.
 
13 Radar Aircraft
 While Japan has never ordered an Awacs aircraft, it has 13 of the E2-C Hawkeye short-range radar aircaft, as well as 2 Aegis missile systems.
Many military analysts say the Hawkeye planes are adequate for patrolling Japan but not for monitoring the sea lanes out to 1,000 miles. Citing studies made by the United States Fifth Air Force, which is based in Japan, these analysts say the duties Tokyo assumed 10 years ago cannot be adequately met without the longer-range Awacs planes.
The Japanese commitment did not specify that it would buy Awacs aircraft, nor did it establish a timetable for specific purchases.
 
Meeting 'Full' Responsibility
 The Center for Security Policy, a Washington-based military policy research organization, said the purchase of only four Awacs means that Japan would be unable to meet its "full responsibilities until after the turn of the century."
The center's director, Frank J. Gaffney Jr., a former senior Pentagon official, said that Japan is continuing to balk at acquiring military hardware from the United States that is essential not only to meet Prime Minister Suzuki's commitment but also to "backstop U.S. forces and allow them to be deployed far more flexibly in future contingencies."
Four Awacs cost about $1 billion. The entire package cited as necessary by the military experts would cost about $5 billion.
 
Gaining Commercial Advantage?
 But many members of Congress see this as another case where Japan, which in the last two decades has developed the world's second most powerful economy and which is running a trade surplus of $50 billion a year with the United States, is shirking responsibilities in order to gain commercial advantage.
Backers of the bill introduced last week say they are worried in part by the possible demise of an aircraft regarded as a stunning performer for airborne surveillance and command, control and communications functions.
The plane's ability to detect and track hostile aircraft and to identify and control friendly aircraft, for example, has made it invaluable in the war against Iraq.
 
Affecting the Agenda
 "I hope the legislation importunes our Government to put this issue higher on the agenda, and that it shows the Japanese how important these issues are to Congress and the American people," said the leading sponsor, Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn.
Sixty-eight Awacs have been sold since 1977. The customers have been the air forces of the United States, the other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Saudi Arabia, Britain and France.
Discussing the plans to shut the Awacs production line, Donald B. Brannon, a Boeing spokesman, said the company "is not pointing any fingers at anybody," adding: "It's just a matter of timing. We have run out of work."
 
Orders From Saudia Arabia
 Saudi Arabia has put in a request for four Awacs and seven tankers as part of a military package worth an estimated $12 billion to $14 billion. Those 11 planes and the 4 that Japan is expected to order would be one more than the number Boeing says it needs to keep the production line open.
But the State Department has notified Congress that the Saudi deal will be delayed until after the gulf war, when there will be a reassessment of the region's military needs. One reason for deferral is the strong opposition of Israel.
A Pentagon official declined to comment on whether Japan's expected order of Awacs was adequate. He said Boeing had been in touch with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who "obviously hopes the line doesn't go down."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Boeing Company says it needs more orders for Awacs planes or it will shut down production of the high-technology surveillance jets. Some in Congress say Japan's reluctance to order more Awacs is a breach of the country's commitment to provide defense for the western Pacific region. (Pool photo via Associated Press) (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Does Government Have the Stuff to End a Recession?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Many analysts fear that a legacy of chronic budget deficits, insolvent banks and dependence on foreign capital has undermined Washington's ability to keep economic growth on track. "We're in a recession with no tools to get out," said Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics.
A pickup in business and consumer demand, modestly augmented by Pentagon spending on the Persian Gulf war, will probably carry the economy out of the current recession. But most economists are worried that the Government's ability to cope with economic shocks is more limited than in the past, and that the margin for error has narrowed. 
 This new-found humility is reflected in President Bush's 1992 budget, which offers no policy initiatives for fighting the recession and may actually retard the recovery. And it lies behind the warning last week by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that an extended gulf war would probably tip the economy into a nasty decline. Tracing the sources of the situation, however, is easier than figuring a way out.
 
Managing the Economy
 The idea that Washington could prevent ups and downs in the economy first gained popular credibility in 1962, when a tax cut engineered by the Kennedy Administration brought a recession to a speedy end. Since then, policy makers have made frequent use of two very different approaches to keeping total buying power roughly equal to the economy's productive capacity.
Congress and the White House could change tax rates or Government outlays, altering the incomes of businesses and individuals and inducing them to change their spending. Or the Federal Reserve could change the quantity of money to induce changes in interest rates, indirectly influencing everything from factory inventories to housing construction.
Schools of economic thought have come and gone, and with them have come changes in the Government's reliance on fiscal and monetary tools. Plenty of mistakes were made. "The record of discretionary fiscal policy is not very impressive," noted Lawrence Summers, chief economist of the World Bank.
 
An Integrated Economy
 But a near consensus prevailed in both Government and academia that Government could and should take steps to prevent unemployment or temper inflation. As President Richard M. Nixon said in 1969, "We are all Keynesians now."
But even as the interventionists celebrated their ascendency, forces were at work that would greatly complicate the task of doctoring a sick economy. Integration of the world economy made it as easy for Shell Oil, or for that matter the United States Treasury, to borrow in London or Tokyo as in New York, weakening the Federal Reserve's grip on the money supply. Equally important, spectacular expansion in world trade allowed a good chunk of purchasing power to spill beyond national borders.
Some analysts worried that the big economies would no longer be manageable without hand-in-glove coordination with other industrial powers -- an elusive goal, even among the closest of allies. At the very least, economists contended, the apparent redundancy of fiscal and monetary tools had been lost.
A clear division of labor was needed: those who drew up the Federal budget would fine-tune demand with taxing and spending policies; the Federal Reserve would focus on the international economy, changing interest rates to control the dollar's exchange rate, and with it, trade and capital flows.
 
Reagan Did Not Go Along
 But President Ronald Reagan never signed on. Big tax cuts without complementary reductions in spending generated enormous deficits, locking the fiscal tap at the full-on position. For the last decade, said Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution, "we've been relying on the Fed to regulate the economy alone."
The Fed, effectively forced to choose between stable exchange rates and a stable domestic economy, tilted toward the latter. There followed seven years of economic growth, a success that Robert Hall, an economist at Stanford University, attributes to the Fed's abandoning purist doctrines in favor of a pragmatic search for a balance between low inflation and steady economic growth.
But with most eyes focused on the domestic economy, the dollar ballooned in value in the mid-1980's, weakening American exports and attracting a flood of competitive imports. America was transformed from the world's largest creditor to the largest debtor.
 
Trap for Monetary Officials
 But the Fed's domestic luck ran out last year and the economy sagged into recession. Many economists, notably those who advise President Bush, believe the Fed waited too long to ease credit, and then acted with excessive caution. But as Mr. Bergsten points out, monetary officials were trapped. "Large cuts in interest rates could put in jeopardy the huge capital inflow that remains essential to fund the trade deficit," he said.
In recent months, the Fed's room for maneuver was narrowed still further by the banking crisis. Its primary method for reducing interest rates is buying Government securities for cash, thereby expanding the deposits that banks have on hand to lend.
But with many banks struggling to stay afloat in a sea of delinquent real estate loans, and most of the rest under pressure from regulators to raise private capital before expanding their loan portfolios, the response was less than impressive.
Many analysts assume that the disruption in the money mechanism is temporary. But temporary may translate into quite a while. Could fiscal policy take up the slack?
Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, notes that Congress and the President have discretion to cut taxes or raise spending in economic emergencies. Indeed, last year's budget agreement requires Congress to vote on a resolution suspending budget restrictions whenever it is formally notified of a downturn in the economy. But that is apparently not the Bush Administration's plan.
While its budget forecasts a whopping $280 billion deficit for the 1992 fiscal year, Charles Schulze of the Brookings Institution says it is actually more restrictive than the budget now in place. By Congressional Budget Office estimates, $98 billion of the new budget will go to pay off insured depositors at failing savings and loans. That money will not make anyone richer -- insured depositors never thought they had lost the money in the first place -- and will thus not spur demand.
 
Best Policy: Neglect?
 It is possible, perhaps likely, that neglect will prove the best policy. The Administration and the Congressional Budget Office are forecasting a quick rebound of private demand, ending the recession before prospective fiscal or monetary actions would have any effect. And Isabel Sawhill of the Urban Institute says added spending for the gulf war plus continuing downward pressure on oil prices will probably have a modest expansionary effect in the months ahead.
But Mr. Greenspan is making no secret of his nightmare that a lingering conflict will lengthen and deepen the recession. The war, he fears, will drive up oil prices and slam consumer confidence, more than offsetting the beneficial effect of Pentagon orders for supplies. And with the banks in terrible shape, a fresh injection of cash may have little immediate effect on private investment.
Even if the economy negotiates the recession in good form, Mr. Bosworth wonders whether the Federal Reserve chairman's troubles will be over. Once the recovery is complete, the Fed's primary worry will switch from unemployment to inflation. Will Washington be able to tighten credit, Mr. Bosworth asks, when the fate of hundreds of banks is tied to the hope of rising prices for houses and commercial real estate?

HEADLINE: The Talk of Teterboro;
Tax Haven in New Jersey, In Bind, Plans to Drop Police

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TETERBORO, N.J., Feb. 7

 BODY:
All was tranquil in this square-mile tax haven until Borough Manager Michael W. Tedesco proposed disbanding the eight-member police force.
Home to 55 businesses, 10,000 jobs, 7 houses and 23 residents, as well as one of the lowest property-tax rates in the state, the borough had hummed along serenely for many years, whizzing traffic on Route 46 and roaring airplanes at Teterboro Airport notwithstanding. 
 But Mr. Tedesco has stirred things by proposing to eliminate the $465,000-a-year Police Department. Just like officials in New Jersey's other communities, Mr. Tedesco said, he is trying to watch dollars and keep down taxes in sour economic times.
Much as they love low taxes, some of the borough's smaller businesses seem to love local police protection more.
"We're saying, 'Raise our taxes, we don't care,' " said George Green, owner of Club 80, a bar and restaurant. "I pay less taxes here than on my house." The Club 80 tax bill is $1,900.80, according to tax records.
The police are not objecting to the plan. The Bergen County Police Department would absorb four of the officers. Teterboro would pay their salaries and benefits, and the county would patrol here on weeknights and weekends. The savings for the borough would come from allowing the other four officers, who would patrol on weekdays, to retire by the middle of the decade, Mr. Te desco said. For now the plan is in limbo. A budget squeeze is forcing the county to lay off seven of its own officers, leaving no room for those from Teterboro. Mr. Tedesco said he was willing to talk with other towns.
The complaints come from executives without private security forces. They are grumbling about a closed and indifferent government and wondering whether friction between Mr. Tedesco and Police Chief Otto Flaig, and not cost-cutting, has doomed the department.
The executives also fret that eliminating the force could revive a move from the 1960's to dismember Teterboro and parcel its industry to four surrounding towns to reduce their tax rates. Those rates are at least two times Teterboro's.
"We're very sensitive to our police," said Thomas W. Marschall, the loudest critic and president of the Marschall Warehouse Company, a grocery wholesaler. "We regard local response as essential."
Eliminating the police could snowball into a municipal doomsday, Mr. Marschall said.
"You could then farm out the magistrate and the tax collector and other officials," he said. "Essentially you'd be dissolving yourself. Teterboro is a very attractive target."
Mr. Green of Club 80 wants more say at Borough Hall. "There's not a taxpayer in town who has a vote," he said, referring to the fact that all the residents are renters. "They're making decisions on our security and saying, 'We can do what we want.' "
Mr. Tedesco dismissed the dissenters as a minority and said most businesses were quiet about disbanding the police. "I guess they trust we're going to keep the tax rate stabilized," he said.
He also scoffed at the notion of dismembering Teterboro. "The trend is for consolidation and sharing of municipal services," he said. "Annexing towns is out."
The police cost of $465,000 is the largest item in the $2.3 million budget. Prudence is required now, Mr. Tedesco said.
Times are bleaker than the 80's. Several businesses, including Sylvania-GTE and the Wella Corporation, a cosmetics manufacturer, have left. Seven others, including the Great Bear Spring Company, which bottles water here, have appealed their new assessments.
And the six old water pumps near West Riser Ditch need replacing, at a cost of $1.5 million. They prevent flooding in the southern half of borough and the airport by draining marshes during heavy rains.
 
Huckleberries to Jets
 The airport, the town landmark, was created by Walter Teter, its namesake, in aviation's infancy about 1917. It was built on 715 acres of farms and huckleberry brush he bought from neighboring Little Ferry, Moonachie and Hasbrouck Heights. Charles A. Lindbergh and Amelia Earhart were early fixtures.
Now the field is a hub of corporate jets, recreational aircraft and courier planes that carry billions of dollars worth of canceled checks each night for banks and the Federal Reserve System.
After World War II, another developer, Alexander Summer, forged the industrial zoning that all but prohibited housing and, consequently, children. The few that grew up here were educated in neighboring towns. School taxes have always been a pittance. The total education budget for this school year is $8,665.
Although the airport takes up half the land, the owner, the tax-exempt Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pays the borough $13,500 a year in lieu of taxes.
Mr. Tedesco said that he often asked the authority for more money and that "they just keep putting you off."
Last year, the agency said, flights dropped 11 percent, to 160,370, apparently because of the recession. The authority estimates that the airport lost $410,000 for the year before depreciation and interest payments.
 
Big Fish in Small Pond
 The Bendix division of Allied-Signal Inc., which manufactures electronics for the aviation industry, is the town colossus.
It pays the most taxes, $370,000, and is the biggest employer, with 2,700 workers. Its realty arm, Realdix, owns the five one-family houses, whose taxes are $864 each, and two duplexes, whose taxes are $1,728 each, and rents them to Mayor Delmar E. Watt, the four Council members, Town Clerk Margaret J. Cahill and James E. Hall, who is both tax assessor and Board of Education secretary.
Traditionally, a Bendix retiree becomes town manager. Mr. Tedesco is one.
Bendix says it is neutral on the police issue.
"We have our own security force, and we're pretty self-sufficient," a spokesman, Armand DeLuca, said. "They're not getting any pressure from us."
 
A Lonely Dissenter
 Edith Lillo, who also rents from Realdix, is the political gadfly. She has challenged incumbents for a Council seat two times.
"I'd like to be part of the town because I'm the only one who isn't a job holder," she said. "But I only get four votes, six really, with our own."
The other Council members capture all the others, usually between 12 and 15 each election.

HEADLINE: A Lot of Big Names At a Collector's Event

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Presidents' Day is a week away, and Brian Kathenes is ready. He has a tie clip engraved with Richard M. Nixon's signature. He has an envelope with Millard Fillmore's signature where the stamp should have been. He has a form that Woodrow Wilson signed when he was a college president, which he was before he was that other kind of President.
What Mr. Kathenes does not have anymore are his two favorites, a letter from Gerald R. Ford and a baseball autographed by the Detroit Tigers in 1968, the year they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals in the World Series. 
 "I sold them to pay the rent," said Mr. Kathenes, whose first few months after quitting the cosmetics industry to become an autograph dealer did not make him a millionaire, as he had hoped.
Yesterday, with the prosperous confidence of someone who knows the difference between a John Hancock on a piece of parchment and a John Hancock on an insurance policy, Mr. Kathenes was once again all sell, sell, sell. There he was at the New York Autograph Show at the Sheraton City Squire Hotel, at Seventh Avenue at52d Street, showing would-be buyers everything from the check President Warren G. Harding wrote to pay his 1921 income taxes to such nonpresidential items as a photograph of Louis Armstrong and an aviator's license signed by Orville Wright.
Everything is relative, even among the 35 dealers and several hundred collectors who attended the daylong show. One Marilyn Monroe is worth 10 George Bushes. A letter from Giacomo Puccini ("Bravo," it begins) is worth two Elvis Presley photographs. A bona fide Elvis impersonator's signature might be worth $10, said Thomas E. Platt Jr., a coordinator of the show.
 
$1 to $10,000
 "The attitude we want to create is that autographs are not expensive," he said.
There were boxes of autographs priced at $1 or $5. But one person's idea of expensive was another's idea of unaffordable. Mr. Platt, for example, was selling everything from an original sketch of the television cartoon character Bart Simpson for $375 to an Indian adoption document for $10,000 ("signed by the chief who's on the Pontiac emblem").
At the lower end of the scale, collectors could get a Tommy Kirk for $6, with the ink still wet. Mr. Kirk was a child actor in Walt Disney films like "Old Yeller," "The Shaggy Dog," "The Absent-Minded Professor" and "The Swiss Family Robinson." Then he grew up, made B movies and became a waiter, a chauffeur and a carpet-cleaning-service owner. The Universal Autograph Collectors Club, the nonprofit group that sponsored the show, invited him to come and autograph pictures of himself.
Mr. Kirk was asked how many autograph requests he gets on a normal day. "Not that many," he said.
"One reason we have him is he is obscure," said Al Wittnebert, the club's treasurer.
 
More Fillmore-abilia
 The value of an autograph is usually determined by supply and demand -- the more there are, the less they tend to be worth. But there are exceptions, like Millard Fillmore. Mr. Kathenes was selling a Fillmore letter for $250. "He had a tendency to abuse the franking privilege," Mr. Kathenes said, which might drive the value down. But "the fact that a President of the United States would do something that's not on the up and up" seems to have bolstered its value.
Some collectors buy widely -- Presidents, gangsters, opera composers. Not William Randel, a retired New York City Housing Authority employee. He said he had 390 of the 583 generals who fought in the Union Army in the Civil War. "The Confederacy, I couldn't afford," he said, "and since I'm a Northerner, I'm not missing anything."
 
Spotting the Fakes
 Fakes and forgeries are a concern, though Mr. Platt said that most established dealers can spot the obvious ones and back what they sell with guarantees of authenticity.
The dealers seemed divided on whether the recession had thinned out the crowd at the show. "The recession is not affecting quality items at all," said Herman Darvick, a third-grade teacher at Public School 188 in Brooklyn and an autograph collector and auctioneer in his spare time. "I had an auction last week where every quality item went for 50 to 100 percent above the estimate."
Grace Weitman, another dealer, said the atmosphere was different from past shows because this time there was a $2 admission charge.
"It used to be that there were Damon Runyon types with the knitted caps exchanging these scraps of paper," she said. "Guys who stand at stage doors and get autographs. And then they'd come in here and shout, 'Hey, have you got Sally Rand?' And somebody else would say, 'No, but I've got Buster Keaton.' "

HEADLINE: Must Whistling Skyscraper Change Tune? Hearing to Decide

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
For 48 years, Frank Siegfried played the violin professionally, from the Artie Shaw and Radio City Music Hall orchestras to the pit band of "Jesus Christ Superstar." Mr. Siegfried loves music, but even he has had to draw the line at a building that whistles, generally an octave above middle C.
"It is horrendous," he said, sounding a complaint made by hundreds of midtown residents in recent months. 
 Mr. Siegfried, of 357 West 55th Street, lives two blocks west of Cityspire, a 72-story tower on West 56th Street off Seventh Avenue. Last December the building was cited by the city's Department of Environmental Protection for producing an annoying, loud whistle. Inspectors suspect the whistle is made by wind blowing over louvers on the building's green, eight-sided dome, 800 feet above ground.
The building's owner, Ian Bruce Eichner, plans to contest the citation today at an Environmental Control Board hearing at 1250 Broadway, at 32d Street. He faces an $880 penalty and an order to stop the noise if the hearing officer rules against him.
Mr. Siegfried and others who live near Citispire plan to pack the room as Mr. Eichner's representatives argue that the reputed violation -- unnecessary noise -- is unfounded.
 
'Not Unnecessary Noise'
 "It's not unnecessary noise," Howard Hornstein, a lawyer for Mr. Eichner, said without elaboration. "I don't think the city can justify the violation from a legal point of view."
Tell that to the agitated members of the West 56th Street Block Association.
"I think you can drive New Yorkers just so far," said Portia Clark, the group's secretary-treasurer. "There are people who can't sleep. They've called me, near to tears."
Mr. Siegfried has kept a detailed log since Dec. 9 of what he says are Cityspire's whistling sessions.
"I was really beside myself for three or four nights and days," he said. He counted 13 days during which he heard the piercing sound, including 20 consecutive hours on Jan. 31. The pitch of the whistle, he said, is most often the note sounded on a piano one octave above middle C. But occasionally, he said, the building also hits B and C sharp.
The Department of Environment Protection has said it received hundreds of complaints about the sound. After several visits to the midtown area last fall, department inspectors zeroed in on Cityspire.
In an interview last month, Mr. Hornstein said complaints about the noise were exaggerated.
"The project has a number of economic problems, and it would be silly to spend money on amelioration," said Mr. Hornstein, who did not detail what work might be needed to dampen the sound.
The Environmental Control Board adjudicates civil violations of air, noise, sanitation and building codes, and a decision in such cases usually comes within a week, said Anne McCarthy, the board's deputy director. Both sides can appeal a decision within 30 days.
Alex Larys of 120 West 58th Street did not wait for the hearing. On Jan. 22 he sued Cityspire's management in Small Claims Court, seeking payment for apartment soundproofing. That hearing is scheduled for Feb. 27.
Meantime Mr. Larys said he had employed an electric air freshener for the hum it produces.
To muffle the Cityspire noise, he said, "I have to sleep with white noise."
 
A Building's Song
 
Neignbors of Cityspire, a 72-story building east of Seventh Avenue between 55th and 56th Street, have complained that the building whistles, mostly one octave above middle C.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PUBLISHING;
Seeking Stars, Hollywood Is Spending Freely on Books

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
Forget about book advances. After rising sharply in the 1980's, they are now stagnant or even slipping. But options are hot.
All around New York's publishing world, idea-starved producers, directors, actors and actresses are on an extensive prowl, looking for books, manuscripts and even the first glimmerings of an author's idea that they might be able to "option." 
 "I never really felt this hunger on the part of movie producers that we feel today for books," said Gail Hochman, a literary agent at Brandt & Brandt. "They need ideas and characters, and they want the story line even before it's out of the author's brain."
For authors, options represent another means to stave off poverty. The options provide money in exchange for reserving the right to make a movie of a book.
An option is generally valid for a year and is usually renewable. It can be worth from $5,000 to more than $100,000. If all goes well -- and it rarely does -- this first payment will be followed by an outright sale of the film rights worth several times the option price. But because of the complexity of getting a movie into production, an option, even a costly one, is more likely to yield nothing -- except the cash in the author's pocket.
Where options were once the exception rather than the rule, now "you get the feeling there is a frenzy for good material, and just about everything is optioned," said Maria Campbell, a New York literary scout who finds material for the director Steven Spielberg's company, Amblin Entertainment.
For example, Irene Webb, a vice president of the William Morris Agency in Los Angeles, said she had just optioned "See Jane Run" by Joyce Fielding to Sally Field and the MGM-Pathe Communications Company. Although the book will not be published by William Morrow until the fall, the option was a six-figure sum.
"The movie business is cyclical, and we're in a heavy book cycle," Ms. Webb said.
Even first books can now command big options. Last year, Dennis McFarland's "The Music Room," a well-reviewed novel that did not get onto best-seller lists, was optioned by the Guber-Peters Entertainment Company for close to $100,000. And "Friday Night Lights," H. G. Bissinger's best-selling study of a high-school football season in Odessa, Tex., was optioned to the director Alan J. Pakula for more than $50,000.
The sudden hunger for manuscripts reflects two important factors: a change in Hollywood's mood and increased competition.
The mood is swinging away from the so-called high-concept movies, which rely on the presence of a big star and a story so simple it can be summed up in a single line. An example of such movies is "Top Gun," starring Tom Cruise. These were movies for the flashy decade of the 80's, which put a premium on simple thrills.
In their place, said David Lonner, a motion picture literary agent at International Creative Management in Los Angeles, movie makers are looking for solid story telling, strong characterization and a powerful plot. Life, after all, has turned complex in the 90's. "Presumed Innocent," Scott Turow's best-selling novel and a successful movie last year, illustrates the trend.
At the same time, the number of people in the market to option manuscripts or books has soared. A decade ago, there were just the seven or eight major studios. But now, said Amanda Urban, a literary agent at International Creative Management in New York, "there is more demand because there are more outlets."
These outlets include the movie-of-the-week market, the mini-series market, movie studios, independent producers, actors, Home Box Office, Showtime and foreign companies like Canal Plus of France, all of which are becoming increasingly aggressive.
Moreover, in tight economic times, these potential buyers often feel happier with a book manuscript than mere story lines from screen writers because they have a surer idea of what they might end up with. "Producers are realizing that a popular book tells you something about what movies people want to see," said Morton Janklow, a literary agent.
As a result of this interest, New York agents are working more and more closely with co-agents in Los Angeles to sell options. Many work with the agent Michael Ovitz's company, Creative Artists Agency. Even if no film materializes, an option can be useful for a publisher in promoting a book. And when the option is taken early, it can help an agent sell a manuscript to a publisher.
When the appetite for a book is really hot, authors can sometimes do even better. They manage to skip the option stage entirely and sell a book outright. Although still rare, this is happening more.
For example, Kim Wozencraft's "Rush," a novel about a woman working as an undercover narcotics cop who becomes addicted to drugs herself, was sold last year through International Creative Management to the Zanuck Company for $1 million several months before the book was published. In fact, the book did not even do particularly well. And Dominick Dunne's novel, "An Inconvenient Woman," was sold through William Morris to ABC Television for $500,000 without ever being optioned.
Of course, such a big and direct sale does not always mean a big and successful movie. Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel "The Bonfire of the Vanities" was a seven-figure direct sale, but the movie has been a box-office disaster.
"There is a frenetic feel now to getting your hands on good material," said Jean Naggar, a literary agent, "but that does not mean more good movies are being made or even more movies.".

HEADLINE: Seeking a Place on Santa's List

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Hide this newspaper, Mom and Dad, and blindfold the children. Here is what Santa Claus is bringing next Christmas, or at least that is what the toy industry hopes.
Formally, the 88th Annual American International Toy Fair, which opens this morning, is a 10-day exhibition of the hottest new toys by nearly 1,400 toy makers for more than 20,000 buyers from retailers like Toys "R" Us, Wal-Mart and Macy's. 
 In reality, the toy fair is a giant schmooze-fest of worried adults trying to figure out what is happening to their industry and why 10-year-olds around the country did not want their toys at Christmas. The biggest buyers have already peeked at the lines of toys from the major toy companies and may have already signed orders, so they do not need to see most of the exhibits.
Notably, the fair is off-limits for exactly the people the products are meant for. "Absolutely no one under the age of 18 will be admitted to the toy fair," warn the materials supplied to visitors.
As the nation's toy makers gather today at the Toy Center of the World, at 200 Fifth Avenue, at 23d Street, and nearby 1107 Broadway, as well as at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center at 11th Avenue and 34th Street, the industry is having its troubles. Christmas was sluggish for most toy makers and retailers, and disastrous for some. The industry's consolidation continues apace.
Child World, the second-largest toy retailer after Toys "R" Us, said last week it was close to finding a buyer for the company. Last month, the Tonka Corporation, the nation's third-largest toy maker, agreed to be acquired for $516 million by Hasbro Inc., a deal that would make Hasbro the nation's largest toy company.
At a news conference this morning, the Toy Manufacturers of America, an industry trade group, will disclose just how bad the Christmas season was, and whether sales exceeded the $14 billion posted in 1989.
While the toy industry bends metal, cuts paper and molds plastic, it is hardly a traditional manufacturing business. It is more like advertising in that it depends on catchy ideas and imaginative marketing. But like manufacturing, the industry needs repeatable products to lower production costs and fatten profits. That is why a perennial like G.I. Joe or Barbie is worth 10 flashes-in-the-pan like Teddy Ruxpin or Masters of the Universe.
Mattel Inc. last year had revenues of nearly $1.5 billion, almost half from Barbie dolls -- a toy that is 32 years old. This year, Mattel is bringing out Lights and Lace Barbie, a hip version of the doll, which is being promoted with a doll of the rap music star M. C. Hammer. Mattel is also coming out with Shani, a black doll with a Barbie-like fondness for fashion, albeit African-influenced. Shani means marvelous in Swahili, Mattel says.
Inexpensive is also a byword at this year's recession-conscious toy fair, as companies try to introduce toys that are smaller and usually sell for less than $15.
Mattel has a whole line of toys smaller than a youngster's hand and built around the cult film, "Attack of the Killer Tomatoes," in which crazed fruit wreak havoc on San Diego. Hasbro is also introducing Tell Me Tots, tiny talking dolls less than 5 inches tall that use microchip technology.
 
'What We Will Take'
 "Toy Fair is an opportunity for Charles Lazarus to say, 'Here's what we will take and here's what we won't,' " said Sean P. McGowan, a toy industry analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company, referring to the chairman of Toys "R" Us.
Children and parents, speaking through the sales rung up on computerized inventory systems, will make the real decisions for toy retailers later in the year.
"The smart buyers will get a little bit of this and a little bit of that," Mr. McGowan said, "and then let their checkout scanners determine what they'll buy a lot of."
Topic A at the fair is likely to be how Hasbro's acquisition of Tonka will affect the competitive position of other toy makers.
Tonka's Parker Brothers game-board business, with popular perennials including Monopoly, is expected to fit well with Hasbro's Milton Bradley subsidiary, which has had strong recent hits like Shark Attack. One new Milton Bradley game will be Splat!, The Bug Squishin' Race Game, in which hapless arachnids are dispatched with glee.
Judging by past fairs, these annual get-togethers are not particularly accurate indicators of what will be the hot toys and which toy companies will come out ahead.
Neither Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles nor Slap Wraps, the wraparound bracelets, were products from major exhibitors, yet both were sensations in 1990.
And the biggest toy company of all does not even have an exhibit at the fair. Nintendo of America had 7 of the 20 best-selling toys in the country last month. The subsidiary of the Japanese company, the world's largest maker of computers and video games, and its licensees posted 1990 sales of $3.4 billion, or more than the combined total of Mattel and Hasbro, the top two United States toy companies. Nintendo showed its wares at a consumer electronics show in Las Vegas last month.
