HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Mr. Bush Hires a Writer

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To a sailor, a telltale is a strip of cloth attached to the mast to indicate the wind's direction; to a railroader, a telltale is a ribbon hung over a track before a tunnel to warn trainmen off the roofs of cars; to a pundit, a telltale is some seemingly insignificant sign that is a portent of a change in political emphasis -- as when a President hires a new chief speechwriter.
 Last Halloween, as Chriss Winston prepared to take her 2-year-old out trick-or-treating, the White House reached her with a hurry-up assignment. Little Ian, dressed in his bunny suit, fell asleep on the couch as his mother cranked out a statement. That was it; early this year, Ms. Winston let her bosses know that her immediate future would be as mother and freelancer. 
 Chief of staff John Sununu and the pollster Robert Teeter seized the opportunity to search for a writer with a harder edge. The half-dozen other writers were passed over -- one, Mark Davis, was leaving to be word-smith to Gov. Pete Wilson of California -- because the President's men were looking ahead to 1992.
 In six months the war will be over and the sky-high Bush ratings will begin to sink; unemployment will be up, whether or not the recession bottoms out as soon as hoped; and Democrats will be taking pot-shots at "the first President to lead us into both a war and a recession." Partisanship time.
 Needed: not a heavy hitter with a big reputation and a lot of baggage, but a hard hitter not known for speechwriting, relatively young, and with independent right-wing credentials.
 Mr. Sununu's choice, not yet announced but who was introduced to the man in the Oval Office last week: Anthony Snow, 35, a Cincinnatian who worked at The Detroit News and for the past three years has been editorial page editor and columnist at the conservative Washington Times.
 Articulate enough for TV opinionfests, Mr. Snow has already begun to clam up: the F.B.I. is now visiting his kindergarten teachers, and Mr. Sununu would be proud of the way his choice parries press queries, even from certified bigfeet. Apparently Peggy Noonan's irreverent memoirs have set insiders' teeth on edge, and the new man is expected to revert to what F.D.R.'s Louis Brownlow called "a passion for anonymity."
 Most members of the Judson Welliver Society, the club of former Presidential speechwriters, would go along with that, even as we wince at the thought of a polemicist who has never written a speech -- and who doesn't know the principal's thinking intimately -- starting at the top. I hope op-editors seek out my colleagues (Clifford, Sorensen, Valenti, Cater, Schlesinger, Price, Herzberg, Elliot, etc.) for their guidance, but here is one old hand's advice to the new superspook:
 1. Don't look for a hot new phrase: stick with the New World Order. Of course it's vulnerable -- every time some plan falls apart or some tinpot hollers at Washington, critics will hoot, "You call this a new world order?" -- but it's Bush's baby, even if he shares its popularization with Gorbachev. Forget the Hitler "new order" root; F.D.R. used the phrase earlier.
 2. Fight for the Union. Up to now, the most pellucid prose to come out of Mr. Bush's mouth has been by the National Security Council's Richard Haass, in a news-conference statement of war aims; he also drafted the powerful letter to Saddam Hussein. But Professor Haass is merely a policymaker, not a card-carrying speechwriter; insist that N.S.C. stuff be routed through the writing shop, lest you wind up in a domestic backwater.
 3. Discover the Bush domestic design and lay it out in a series of speeches. Under all those Pinkerton paradigms and Darmanesque ditherings must be some pattern of decisions: find that gestalt, give it a Weltanschauung, and push it with some passion. Even moderates stand for something; the rhetorical trick is in divining the drift and declaiming the direction.
 4. Don't be haunted by Reagan's Ghost. Mr. Bush is fearful of comparison with Reagan speechifying, and instead shows off his ad-libbing advantage over his predecessor -- perversely boasting of his inadequate speech delivery. Enough of that; you've been brought aboard not for sound bites and snippets, but for serious red meat and potatoes.
 As the Ides of March approach, in prime time the President will solemnly come before us to explain this war's endgame. He has the sense of history in his head but not on the tip of his tongue. It's your enviable job to help him make weapons out of his words.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Is It Our Leaders, or Is It Us?

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: HONOLULU

 BODY:
Hawaii is, and feels, remote from mainland America. But for all its exotic quality, the concerns on people's minds are not so different from those in Boston or New York or Los Angeles. People worry about the war, about the recession, about racial tension.
In three days at and around the University of Hawaii, I found conversations coming back to one puzzling question. Why is it that the United States can rise so quickly to challenges abroad but seems utterly unable or unwilling to meet challenges at home? 
 Whatever one thinks of the policies that have led us to war in the Persian Gulf, the speed and energy of the American commitment have been remarkable. In six months the United States has sent a force of more than 400,000 and a vast array of modern weapons halfway around the world.
But in six months or six years we have made no progress on a host of domestic problems. Indeed, we have made no real commitment to address them -- no commitment of mind or resources.
* American public education is a scandal. In a world where learned skills are increasingly important, our children leave school far less educated than those in France or Korea or a dozen other countries.
* Our system of medical care -- our non-system -- is the most expensive in the world yet leaves millions with no assurance of care. Alone among the industrialized nations of the West, we have no universal medical insurance. Medical costs are breaking state and national budgets, and we do nothing but tinker here and there.
* In the richest country on earth, poverty is a mass phenomenon. We have so many poor families that the infant mortality rate, related to poverty, is higher than in less affluent countries. The Bush Administration wants to experiment with a program to reduce infant mortality -- by taking money away from programs to help poor pregnant women and children.
* Homelessness is another result of poverty and inadequate social programs. In cities across the country we are met by the sight of the homeless. Private and public efforts have provided, at best, palliatives.
* Two decades after the death of Martin Luther King Jr. our major cities have black ghettos that are centers of hopelessness and social disorder. A powerful United States Senator can be re-elected by appealing bluntly to anti-black feelings.
* Investment in our industry is at a low level, and we are falling way behind other countries in research and development of domestic products. We can make smart bombs and Patriot missiles, but we no longer make video cassette recorders.
All of those problems, and more, have been festering for years. None is a secret. But where is there any sign that we are about to tackle them? Why not?
Leadership is one possible answer. Most Presidents find foreign affairs a more congenial place to invest their energy. President Bush is more candid than most, saying openly that he finds foreign challenges more exhilarating than the often frustrating political struggle of domestic policy-making.
But on the whole we get the leaders we deserve. We voted for Ronald Reagan because we wanted to believe that greed was good, that cutting taxes and disabling government would make us all richer. We cheered even as he did lasting damage to this country.
Perhaps we have concluded, most of us, that the problems are just too daunting to face. Perhaps we have decided to deal with them by closing our eyes. Existential blindness, a Roman Catholic bishop in South Africa once called it: blindness because seeing is too painful.
Or perhaps the problems at home are too long and slow to awaken energetic response from us. If there is an invasion abroad and the President tells us that it is a defining moment, the country responds. Perhaps it will take a domestic trauma to waken us, as the Depression did in the 1930's.
Still, leadership matters. We have seen how Mr. Bush has been able to rally the country to the cause of fighting Iraq and freeing Kuwait. Whether his policy proves wise in the end or not, there is no doubt that he cared.
Someday we may again have a President who cares about the country's economic decline, about its stricken schools, about poverty and sickness. Someday we may have a President who will rally us to care, by saying something like what Franklin Roosevelt said in 1937:
"I see one-third of a nation ill-housed, ill-clad, ill-nourished."

HEADLINE: Polish Debt: Don't Even Ask

 BODY:
Poland's overnight leap from centralized economic control to markets has been painful. By stripping away price controls and Government subsidies, prices soared, unemployment rose and living standards dropped at least 10 percent. But Polish endurance is paying off. Export earnings are rising, the currency and inflation have now stabilized, and Poland is about to launch a radical plan to privatize factories and farms.
One big hurdle remains: $45 billion of foreign debt, largely loans by foreign governments to the former Communist regime. Polish debt payments are enormous, even compared to other heavily indebted countries. The Poles cannot afford to pay back these loans. If they try, their economic reform will be destroyed. 
 The U.S. -- prodded by Congressman David Obey of Wisconsin -- has been fighting for a substantial write-off of Poland's debt, perhaps as high as the 80 percent figure requested by the Poles. The Europeans, who hold most of the loans, are balking. The French are considering write-offs under 40 percent; the Japanese argue for zero. The Europeans say they are reluctant to establish a regrettable precedent for third world debtors.
Regrettable? The West ought to be deliriously happy if other debtor nations junked their centralized control and leaped to capitalism. Debt relief would be a trivial price for drawing the third world toward capitalism.
Without large debt write-off -- probably close to 80 percent -- Poland will face large outflows of capital. Foreign investors will stay away as long as Poland's resources are pledged to foreign governments rather than private investors. And the huge debt will also discourage domestic savers; why invest if the profits will be taxed and sent abroad?
For a few billion dollars, the West can insure that the brave Poles succeed and set an enviable model for the rest of Eastern Europe, and beyond. The Poles cannot afford to repay most of their foreign loans; it would be tragic to ask them to try.

HEADLINE: National Health Insurance Benefits Everyone

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Health Care a Growing Burden" (Business Day, Jan. 29) finds that annual health-care costs for each worker in 1990 were more than $3,200, a 17.1 percent increase from 1989. Employer-based health care has become increasingly inadequate for containing costs and providing coverage for the 31 million people who are uninsured. Health-care expenditures only add to the cost of labor, thus increasing unemployment. Increased labor costs also make it more difficult for American companies to compete with foreign corporations.
In addition, employers who would like to offer health insurance are sometimes denied that opportunity by insurance companies. For instance, many insurers who fear enrolling individuals with acquired immune deficiency syndrome or the human immunodeficiency virus will not enroll such groups as professional dancers, florists and AIDS activists. And some insurers offering group plans to employers try to discourage high-risk people from enrolling by offering skimpy benefits -- such as paying no more than $2,000 a year for pharmaceuticals or hospitalization.
Moreover, those who are unemployed, self-employed, between jobs or unable to work are seen as poor risks by insurers. They are able to get insurance, if at all, at prohibitively high rates, excessively high out-of-pocket expense or without coverage of pre-existing conditions.
Ultimately, employer-based health insurance must be eliminated to insure efficient and equitable health insurance financing.
The Dutch Government plans to eliminate employer-based health insurance in the 1990's. Under the Dutch health insurance system, each individual will select a health plan from competing insurance organizations during an open-enrollment period. The Government will require insurers to offer a basic minimum benefits package. This will prevent insurers from offering skimpy benefit packages that cater to the healthy.
Individuals will be required to pay a premium into a central fund based on income, as well as an additional premium to the plan of their choice. Those who are unemployed will be required to pay only a modest premium, but will still be covered by the basic benefits package.
The incentives in this system encourage quality and efficiency. Plans that can deliver services most efficiently and with the highest quality will enroll larger numbers. Insurers will not be allowed to deny coverage, but those who disproportionately enroll high-risk individuals will be compensated by the central fund. Cost containment will thus come from competition among health insurers, as well as limits on the use of the most expensive technology.
The elimination of employer-based health insurance and compensation for insurers who take added risks should mean competition by insurers to control costs, rather than to avoid high-risk individuals. This may be just the dose of efficiency and equity the United States health-care system and American business desperately need.
 
WARREN GREENBERG
Professor of Health Economics
Department of Health Services
Management and Policy
George Washington University
Kensington, Md., Jan. 30, 1991

HEADLINE: National Health Insurance Benefits Everyone;
The Elderly Victimized

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Once again, the elderly, and ultimately all of us, fall victim to the lack of a cohesive and rational health-care policy. The news coming from Washington regarding President Bush's proposed budget (front page, Feb. 5) threatens a generation of Americans who do not know what to expect next on health care. Medicare, a program established to provide for the health of the elderly, is again being singled out by the Bush Administration for disproportionate cuts.
Health care is not an economic commodity. Health care is a social good. Every citizen has a legitimate expectation of access to health care, and physicians and hospitals have legitimate expectations to be properly compensated for providing that care. Our nation must develop a system that responds to the health-care needs of the elderly and the millions of others who lack health care.
It will be interesting to see what Congress does with the latest proposals, especially since these proposals actually rehash proposals previously rejected. Let's hope Congress does its job in holding the President accountable.
 
JOHN E. CURLEY JR.
President, Catholic Health
Association of the United States
St. Louis, Feb. 5, 1991

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Campaign Hopes to Promote Bronx Zoo and Its Mission

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
HEEDING Darwin's lesson -- adapt to survive -- the Bronx Zoo will soon begin its first big image campaign. With safari-like commercials promoting the zoo's naturalistic settings, the zoo hopes to use the call of the wild to attract visitors and additional donations.
The New York Zoological Society, which operates the Bronz Zoo, the New York Aquarium and the zoo in Central Park, last week hired Geer, Dubois, a New York agency, to create an advertising and marketing campaign that will promote the zoo and remind people of the society's role as a wildlife conservation organization. 
 "The Bronx Zoo hadn't bothered to advertise itself," said Peter Glankoff, director of marketing and communications for the society. "It simply relied on its reputation."
But that is not enough any more, he said. Financing from traditional sources like donations is hard to come by in tough economic times. The society hopes to raise revenues by bolstering annual attendance, now about two million.
The zoo hopes to stir up the kind of interest the San Diego Zoo did when it began a splashy advertising campaign several years ago. Some commercials showed exotic animals cavorting to classical music, and one award-winning billboard sported a giant flamingo.
The campaign is widely credited with helping to make the San Diego Zoo one of the best-known attractions in California. And while attendance at some zoos dropped in the last decade, San Diego's rose to 3.3 million in 1989, from 3 million in 1980.
No longer able to rely on tax revenue and contributions as their primary sources of money, zoos have increasingly turned to aggressive marketing programs. In the past year, a number of zoos, including those in Minneapolis and Toronto, hired agencies to give themselves a high profile.
The Bronx Zoo's biggest problem is overcoming public misconceptions. "Research showed that many people thought it was still an old-fashioned kind of zoo where animals are kept behind bars," said John Hayes, the president of Geer, Dubois.
Mr. Glankoff of the Zoological Society said that many people believe the zoo is situated in an unpleasant neighborhood and he said the society would publicize the availability of express bus service to the zoo, which is off Southern Boulevard in the Fordham section of the Bronx.
The agency is also going to develop marketing programs to emphasize the zoological society's primary mission, wildlife preservation.
Rodney Underhill, executive vice president and creative director of Geer, Dubois, said the agency was working on exhibits for some of the zoo's leading attractions. "We might put a big electronic sign at the exit of Jungle World that continually ticks off the steady depletion of the rain forests," he said. "At that point we've already got a sympathetic audience, so maybe we can get them to join the society."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 12, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising Column in Business Day yesterday about campaign plans for the Bronx Zoo misstated the surname and title of an executive at the zoo's agency, Geer, Dubois. He is Rodney Underwood, not Underhill; he is the agency's vice chairman and creative director, not executive vice president.

HEADLINE: Waiting and Waiting on Tables for Her Big Break

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The face is familiar: she was Tom Hanks's mother in "Big," a furiously jealous Mafia wife in "Married to the Mob," and a smart, savvy and sexy Wall Street lawyer Off Broadway in "Other People's Money."
But to those who see Mercedes Ruehl on stage or screen and think they recognize her from a completely different context, the answer is simple: they probably do. 
 Success was not an overnight phenomenon for Ms. Ruehl. It took so long, she says, that she almost gave up. When she was not auditioning she spent a good deal of time in restaurants.
"I must have worked in at least a dozen places in New York as a waitress," Ms. Ruehl says, relaxing after a performance at the National Theater here of Neil Simon's new play, "Lost in Yonkers," in which she stars as Aunt Bella, a 35-year-old woman with the mind and emotions of a 13-year-old. "I was a milkmaid in the ice cream corner of the Plaza Hotel. I worked at Teachers on the Upper West Side, at the Buffalo Roadhouse in Greenwich Village, and I did a memorable summer at the White Horse Cafe. I was terrible when I started, but after about five or six years I became dangerously good at it, maybe even better at that time than I was as an actress."
 
Previews Start Tomorrow
 Ms. Ruehl is receiving very favorable advance comment for her portrayal of Bella, a character who, as one of her relatives says, is permanently "closed for repairs." "Lost in Yonkers," a comedy with serious overtones -- not unlike Mr. Simon's highly successful Brighton Beach trilogy but not as overtly autobiographical -- is set in the summer of 1942 in a two-bedroom apartment over Kurnitz's Kandy Store in Yonkers. The play, directed by Gene Saks, begins previews tomorrow on Broadway at the Richard Rodgers Theater, where it opens Feb. 21.
It tells the story of two teen-age brothers who have been forced for economic reasons to move in with their grandmother (Irene Worth), a stern, distant and iron-willed German-Jewish refugee whose overpowering personality has stunted the adulthood of her children. In addition to Bella, those children include a somewhat lovable mobster played by Kevin Spacey.
Ms. Ruehl, her long, dark hair piled atop her head and her slim, jeans-encased legs crossed at the ankles, is leaning forward, puffing a cigarette (only her second of the day; she is trying to quit) and talking about her new role, her career and the years it took to achieve her goals. She clearly loves to talk, and when she is asked a question, almost any question, her answers are unhesitating and rapid. The only thing she is reticent about is her age. She will, however, acknowledge that it is similar to Bella's.
 
Adult Awareness
 When she first started studying the role, she says, she had a lot of trouble getting a handle on it. Yes, Bella is childlike, but the character is also mature enough to understand and talk about her need for love and her desire for a husband and children. "Maybe I'm a child," Bella says, "but there's just enough woman in me now to make me really miserable."
Finally, Ms. Ruehl thought of a movie she had made, in which she played the mother of a 13-year-old who suddenly takes on adult form.
"I thought -- ding dong -- Tom Hanks in 'Big,' " she says. "He didn't talk cute or act cute. He just went about his business, and there were times when he even seemed naively, charmingly fresh. And then Bella started to come to life in my mind, because there are moments when she is very close to being a bit wise."
 
Peripatetic Childhood
 Ms. Ruehl, the daughter of a former F.B.I. agent, was born in Jackson Heights, Queens, but lived there for only two weeks. The next eight years were spent moving around: first to the Bronx, then to Lafayette, Ind., Scranton, Pa., and Hackensack, N.J. Finally, the family moved to Silver Spring, Md., where she stayed through high school.
After graduating from the College of New Rochelle, she moved to Manhattan, where, she says, she "started a career of waiting tables and studying drama."
The studying was done at the HB Studios, with William Hickey and Uta Hagen. She performed in workshops, an occasional Off Off Broadway showcase and a few other acting jobs every once in a while. But that was pretty much it. "I couldn't punch through that membrane," she says.
She went on a yearlong tour with "The Miracle Worker" and "Come Blow Your Horn," playing high schools and colleges all over the country, doing 90-minute versions of the two plays 14 to 16 times a week for a salary of $126. Then, after another period of mostly waiting on tables, she worked for two years in repertory at the Denver Center for the Performing Arts and began making the rounds of regional theaters.
 
Time to Grow Up
 By the time she looked up, it was Thanksgiving 1984. And, she says, she almost decided to drop it all: "I started to think: 'O.K., so this is it? Five hundred dollars a week and a reasonably nice apartment in the actors' transient building in every big city. Do I want to live like this indefinitely?' And I thought, 'I don't want this.' I always believed I was going to have this destiny in the theater, but now I figured: 'Maybe I'm not. And it's time to think about living like a grown-up.' "
One evening, she sat down with her father and talked about her problem. "He had just retired from the bureau," she says, "and he knew of a fellow retiree who was working for Baltimore Gas and Electric. And his friend knew this gal -- this was when I discovered that they're all 'gals' in business, and I knew I was looking ahead to 'galhood,' which filled me with feelings of utter ambivalence -- anyway, he knew this gal who had been an actress who was now directing industrial and promotional films for Baltimore Gas and Electric. And I said without a lot of conviction that it sounded wonderful, maybe I should meet her after Christmas."
But before she could make the appointment, she received a phone call from the playwright Albert Innaurato, for whom she had done some readings and who was having trouble with a play he was presenting at the Public Theater. The play was "Coming of Age in SoHo"; performances had been suspended, and Mr. Innaurato was busy rewriting.
"Albert called and said: 'No audition. Just come in. I've convinced them you're the one to do this. We've got 12 days.' Now, I'd been trying to get a foot in the door of the Public Theater since the beginning of time and couldn't. And suddenly here it was -- Off Broadway. So I said, 'Yes, yes, I'll do it.' "
 
'It Was Terrifying'
 But it was rough going. "There was a big chair on the set," she says, "and I would make my entrance, and I would realize that this was not just a regional stage. It was the Public. It was New York. And it was like jumping into a cold pool. It was terrifying.
"I would run to that chair every night and hold on to it. It was like a shield between me and the audience. And both Joe Papp and Albert had to persuade me to get out from behind the chair. And finally, on opening night, I got these lovely flowers from Joe with a note. It said: 'You finally got out from behind the chair. Anything goes now.' And it was a prophecy, because after that, I never stopped working."
"Coming of Age in SoHo" led almost immediately to Christopher Durang's "Marriage of Bette and Boo." And that led to a small movie role in "Heartburn." And 13 months as Judd Hirsch's daughter on Broadway in "I'm Not Rappaport." And "Big." And "Married to the Mob," for which she won the National Society of Film Critics' award as best supporting actress of 1988. And "Other People's Money." And two forthcoming movies, "Another You" with Richard Pryor and Gene Wilder, and "The Fisher King" with Robin Williams and Jeff Bridges. And now "Lost in Yonkers."
"And I never went to meet them at Baltimore Gas and Electric," Ms. Ruehl says, and laughs. "I never became a gal."

LENGTH: 1629 words

HEADLINE: Political Pressure Dismantles East German Sports Machine

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEIPZIG, Germany

 BODY:
The big bronze statue of the javelin hurler identifies the building as a sports school, but half the javelin is snapped off and the marble base is crumbling. Inside the building that was once the premier academy of the powerful East German sports machine, glass trophy cases gape emptily, and a tax consultant, one of thousands of private businesses sprouting in eastern Germany's dash to the market, has taken up rooms on the ground floor.
"Just one of those measures to help pay the upkeep," sighed Helmut Kirchgassner, a former middleweight boxer and professor of the theory and practice of training who is the school's new dean. 
 Officially dubbed the German College for Physical Culture, the school produced the coaches, trainers and sports medicine personnel who were responsible for East Germany's remarkable success at the highest levels of international sports. That success was demonstrated at the 1980 Games in Moscow -- after Western nations, led by the United States, stayed away to protest the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan -- the East Germans won 47 gold, 37 silver and 42 bronze medals, second only to the Soviet Union.
 
Struggling for Upkeep
 The school is now in limbo, its status unsure, staff cuts looming, its coaches either discredited for doping practices or leaving for more lucrative jobs in the old West Germany and farther West, and its financing unreliable.
In fact, these days, struggling to pay the upkeep is what takes up most of the time of athletes and sports officials on the eastern edge of a reunited Germany.
Eighteen months ago, they were still the heroes of the nation, standing triumphantly above the world of international sport that made their Communist state, politically and economically a dwarf, an athletic giant. Now they lie among the flotsam and jetsam of the discredited system, the athletes heckled for the privileges they enjoyed and their clubs threatened with closure.
As an abundance of coaches and trainers struggle for the few jobs available, a dog-eat-dog atmosphere has set in, with charges flying fast and furiously that so-and-so either used drugs or helped athletes do so, or belonged to the now-defunct Communist Party, or worse, the secret police, whose goons laced the sports establishment.
Harsh debate focuses on the so-called Child and Youth Sport Schools, a network of 25 prep schools whose pupils were picked by intricate tests and measurements from among first-grade youngsters. Parents were required to sign contracts permitting the children to withdraw only after consultation with state authorities, and many top East German athletes were graduates. Debate focuses on demands by Germans in the west that the schools be liberalized, a process some Germans in the east say will destroy the schools' effectiveness as training centers.
In a small apartment on the outskirts of Leipzig, Thomas Munkelt, an Olympic gold medal winner in the 110-meter hurdles in 1980, recalled the days of gold and glory. Munkelt, who attended a prep school for three years, described how sports had enabled him to climb out of a gritty home town near Buna to the practice of dentistry in a state clinic. But by Western standards, he admitted, the rewards were slim.
As a student, he and his wife and daughter shared two small dormitory rooms, until a small apartment became available. Every four years there was a new car, a stodgy Soviet-built Lada in his case, and small things, like fresh fruit, that few other East Germans saw much of, brightened an otherwise simple life.
Now, with Communism collapsed, he and a fellow hurdler-turned-dentist are seeking loans for a private practice. He laments what he views as the gradual demise of the old sports machinery.
"The basic problem is the training of young athletes, which in principle is being destroyed," he said. "Maybe in 5, 10 years' time it'll be back again. But for now, the money's just not there.
"According to our papers, we were always fulfilling our economic goals," Munkelt added bitterly. "But our stores were still always empty. We ran our sports by the performance principle, but not our economy."
The former hurdler has no excuses for East Germany's doping record. "You cannot force anyone to take tablets," he said, "but I don't think it was good the way it was done, with central lists and central organization and all that. The most important thing is that, with better testing, the use of drugs is being pushed back further and further."
The exact extent of drug use in East Germany remains a murky matter.
The German weekly Der Spiegel has published details of East Germany's centralized doping program, with two high-powered research institutes, one at the college in Leipzig and another in the hilltop village of Kreischa, south of Dresden, reporting to a doping headquarters at the Sports Medicine Service in Berlin.
A former swimming coach at a Potsdam sports club, Michael Regner, described how club physicians had initiated him in the distribution of anabolics to team swimmers, who included Kristin Otto and Silke Horner, both gold medalists at the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. Regner, who fled East Germany in August 1988, through Hungary and now coaches in New Zealand, described how a drug called Oral-Turinabol, manufactured by an East German company in Jena, was given to 13-year-old swimmers.
The reports prompted the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl to establish a seven-member commission, which began work last month, to examine doping abuse in Germany and make proposals for control. Underscoring official concern, Kohl told Parliament recently, "We support the declared intention of the sports clubs to take decisive steps against doping practices. Top-level sports must respect human dignity."
The mud-slinging has hardly hindered German sports groups in the western part of the country from snapping up former East German experts. Last fall, it was reported that Hermann Buhl, the deputy director of the medical department at the Leipzig research center, was hired by the Institute for Sports Medicine, in Paderborn. Hartmut Riedel, East Germany's track and field team physician, is now professor of sports medicine at Bayreuth, in the former West Germany. Much of the sports medical center at Kreischa, though not its doping lab, a major focus of the commission's attention, has been taken over by Bavaria Klinik, a western company. Though the commission has yet to begin hearings, many top-secret records are reportedly missing, evidently shredded or sold by former researchers.
At Leipzig University, Joachim Weiskopf, a dentistry professor who is also vice president of the National Olympic Committee of united Germany, said he had a "clear position regarding doping, and I think I have a clear conscience." But he said charges and countercharges were fed by the terrible struggle for jobs in a collapsing economy. The bloated German Gymnastics and Sports Union, the vast East German sports bureaucracy, had 12,000 employees, of which only about 1,500 can be kept on, he said. East Germany had about 600 track and field coaches, but now there are jobs for only 72 coaches, and those jobs are all taken at the moment.
"There's a psychological component," he said over sips of coffee, "the fact that so many were in the Communist Party, were bearers of state secrets. So now people are saying, 'He did doping.' There's envy, and everyone's taking potshots at everyone else."
Last June, Weiskopf, a 64-year-old, a former Olympic field hockey player, replaced Manfred Ewald, a staunch Communist, as head of the still existing East German National Olympic Committee, a post he assumed with the sole goal of leading East Germany back into a united German Olympic organization. Weiskopf, never a Communist, was known for his integrity. "Our states, our cities are looking at all our unemployment and saying, 'Let's first rebuild the factories and then invest in sports; let's put our money first where it's productive,' " he said. "So we're standing here with empty hands, so we can only go to the West Germans and say, 'Help us.' While their reaction is, 'There they go asking for money again.' "
Over at the college, the 1,000 or so students are already learning what this means. The Government of Saxony, where Leipzig lies, has ordered the school disbanded, announcing plans to refound it as a physical education department of Leipzig University.
Two years ago the faculty and staff totaled 1,050, Kirchgassner said, and now 700 remain. He estimates that the school will eventually have a staff of about 270, including 120 full-time professors.
Moreover, while the college once focused only on Olympic disciplines like swimming, diving, track and field, the syllabus was broadened to include gym teacher training, sports for rehabilitation and recreation, and even sports management.
But demands that the Federal Government in Bonn finance the school's continued independence are growing, fueled by students' desires that the college remain a center of competitive sports training in eastern Germany, to parallel a similar institute in Cologne, in the west.
Now, the Research Institute with its high-powered laboratories and testing equipment, is locked. But on a recent afternoon, desks in the bright library were filled with students while others worked out in the school's training halls.
But for Kirchgassner, it was clear that despite the semblance of business as usual, an epoch was drawing to a close.
"You have to be realistic," he said, "competitive sports as they were exercised here, or in the G.D.R. generally, are not salvageable. We have to find new forms, and that will be tough, because the conditions, financial and otherwise, are lacking."

HEADLINE: Careers;
Law Schools Put Stress on Specialization

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
BEYOND torts, property and other first-year basics, law schools are rethinking the second and third years of their programs.
"The practice of law has changed, reflecting changes in the business world and to some degree in the political world, while law school teaching has changed little in recent years," Ronald A. Cass said last week. Dean of Boston University's law school, he discussed a new focus for the curriculum: specialization. 
 Stressing the need for prospective lawyers to specialize, he said: "Every one of them increasingly needs a specialty. Our students need to study in greater depth."
He proposes a track of four different specialties for the second and third year of law school and hopes to have some in place by fall. These studies might include international law, corporate law, public law and environmental law.
Specialization would not be required but would be encouraged. "I don't want to be overly rigid about it," he said, adding that specialization would appeal to some because it would make them more marketable.
He thinks that lawyers increasingly require more knowledge of international events. For example, a lawyer involved in an antitrust case would have to recognize the international impact on a global corporation.
"To be effective these days as a lawyer I need to know something about business, economics and statistics," Dean Cass said. He hopes to integrate these fields into various courses for law students to give them a broad knowledge of their applications. Separate courses in the subjects are available now.
"I noticed when I worked for the Government that expert witnesses often spoke different languages from the lawyers," he said. To make proper use of witnesses, lawyers must know the terminology used by financial analysts, accountants and others.
Some young lawyers obtain master of business administration degrees to help them fit better into corporate life. Dean Cass said, "If law schools do the job right they don't need an M.B.A."
At Stanford University's law school, the dean, Paul Brest, agreed that lawyers in the 21st century should be offered "more specialization." He also agreed that specialization -- he prefers the word concentration -- should be encouraged, not required. "And not at the cost of a broad liberal education," he said.
Most previous efforts to change law school curriculums have been devoted to the first year, he said, adding that "the first year now works pretty well" and that hard work needed to be done on the second- and third-year offerings. "It is not done well," he said of those years, "and students have a feeling they are not progressing, and indeed they are not. They are right in wanting change." He thinks students are "not being challenged enough to deepen their intellectual horizons."
Dean Brest says the faculty now offers or hopes to offer so-called concentrations in business, environmental law and poverty law. "I call poverty law "lawyering with minorities." he said, stressing its growing importance.
He described the relatively new business concentration at Stanford, which he said was "fully implemented" last fall. Students take economics, if they did not take the subject in college, and also a course that Dean Brest calls financial theory.
In the second year of the three-year program for a law degree, the students take a first-semester course called Business Associations concurrently with an accounting course.
"I describe this Business Associations course as transactional because they learn how to put together deals and enterprises," Dean Brest said.
A second semester course follows in the track and it is called Capital Markets and Securities Regulation. When students have finished this they are ready for advanced courses. "We are now developing more such courses," he said.
"We do have one in place called What Every Lawyer Should Know About Business; I am excited about it," he said, explaining that it was in its second year and adding, "A textbook is being developed."
He mentioned another course, called Counseling the Business Enterprise, described as a clinical course that involves role playing. It covers topics like executive compensation, counseling for venture capitalists and expertise in negotiating.
Another new course, called Corporate Governance and Social Responsibility, deals with such issues as proxy fights and environmental problems.
Like Dean Cass, he hopes that a concentration would be adequate for a sophisticated lawyer not interested in working for a corporation and that an M.B.A. would not be necessary.

HEADLINE: Too Many A's Seen at A. M. Best

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 11

 BODY:
A. M. Best, the 92-year-old company on which thousands of American corporations and consumers depend for evaluations of the financial health of insurance companies, is being accused of grade inflation. A new study concludes that it is significantly easier for insurance companies to win a top rating from Best than from two other major raters of insurance companies -- Standard & Poor's and Moody's.
The study was conducted by Joseph Belth, an Indiana University professor who is an expert on the insurance industry. He published his findings in the December 1990 issue of his Insurance Forum newsletter. The study comes at a time when the number of insurance-company failures is rising and public concern about the solvency of insurers is increasing. 
 Professor Belth says that Best's apparent easing of requirements has caused some customers who buy its books, newsletters and other publications to lose faith in the rating agency. Some people in the industry agree.
 
Charges by Critics
 "The Moody's and Standard & Poor's process is much more rigorous and the results are more meaningful than Best's," said Peter Hutchings, chief financial officer of the Guardian Life Insurance Company, based in New York.
The real issue, people familiar with the situation say, is whether Best has loosened its requirements in response to increasing competitive pressures from S.& P., Moody's and a few smaller firms like Duff & Phelps.
Some critics have argued privately that to hold on to the thousands of insurance companies across the country that pay in some cases tens of thousands of dollars to buy its publications, Best has eased the requirements A+ companies must meet.
Best vigorously denies this accusation. "Totally untrue," said Paul Wish, the spokesman for the A. M. Best Company, based in Oldwick, N.J. "The ratings in the books have nothing to do with the sale of the books."
Mr. Wish, defending Best's rating system, said: "The major difference between us and them is that we take the long-term view. We look at an insurance company's long-term prospects, whereas Moody's and Standard & Poor's are more attuned to day-to-day changes in market conditions."
An agency's rating is crucial to insurers because independent agents who sell life insurance steer customers to higher-rated companies. Some industry experts say that lower-rated insurers have to offer higher yields to attract consumers. A rating reduction can also force an insurance company to pay more interest when it borrows in the capital markets.
And when many large corporations consider an insurance company, they want it to have top ratings from at least two major rating agencies.
 
Striking Differences in Ratings
 Professor Belth studied 100 life insurers rated by both the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Best. Of that group, 33 received Best's top A+ rating but were rated lower by S.& P. Over all, 53 of the 100 compared were rated higher by Best than by S.& P.; 36 were rated the same, and 11 were rated lower by Best.
The study also found 62 life insurers rated by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Best. Of that group, 34 were rated A+ by Best but received lower ratings from Moody's. Over all, 43 of the 62 fared better under the Best system than under the Moody's system; 16 were rated the same by both agencies, and 3 got a lower rating from Best.
Some of the differences between Best's ratings and the other agencies' were striking. For instance, Best gave the Executive Life Insurance Company of Los Angeles a rating of "contingent A," meaning it has the third-highest rating but is under review. The same insurer was rated 12 notches from the top by Moody's (a Ba2 rating) and by S.& P. (a BB rating). Executive Life's parent, the First Executive Corporation, has suffered hundreds of millions of dollars in losses on its portfolio of high-yield "junk bonds," and many customers have cashed in their policies.
"What all this suggests to me is that the Best system is significantly looser than that of the competition," Professor Belth said. "I am not saying that Best is selling out. I have no evidence of that. What I am saying is that it is easier to get a top rating from Best."
Best said recently that its rating system essentially paralleled that of S.& P. and Moody's, meaning that a top rating from Best was equivalent to a top rating from S.& P. or Moody's, and so forth.
 
Differing Criteria
 Other factors may explain how Best ends up with higher ratings. The S.& P. and Moody's ratings are based on a fairly narrow criterion -- the ability of an insurer to pay claims. Best says it bases its ratings on the ability of an insurance company to meet all financial obligations.
"The mechanics for rating are the same, but the underlying philosophy is different," said Mr. Wish, the Best spokesman.
Whatever the reason for Best's higher ratings, there is little disputing that Best, while still important in the insurance business, has seen its influence wane in recent years.
"While a decade ago most of the big brokers did not spend much time with it, today they have full-time research departments that get to know the insurers well," said Richard Heydinger, the senior insurance executive at Hallmark Cards Inc. in Kansas City, Mo.
 
A Near Monopoly Until 1983
 Nor is there much disputing that Best, which is privately held, has been facing new competition. For decades the company held a near monopoly on the business of rating insurers. Wall Street analysts published reports on publicly held insurance companies, but it was not until 1983 that S.& P. got into the business. Moody's started in 1986. Both companies still have much smaller operations than Best's but their influence has been rising as policyholders have grown concerned about the ability of insurers to pay claims.
Recognizing that the risks insurers face have been changing along with the investments insurers make with their income from premiums, many industrial companies now subscribe to more than one rating agency.
Moody's, S.& P. and Duff & Phelps tend to focus more than Best on an insurer's financial results. This emphasis reflects their background as bond-rating agencies. By contrast, Best, in making its rating, tends to look beyond the numbers at aspects of the overall quality of an organization, like experience of management, modernization of the back office and the speed of payment of claims.
"Some people are saying that in a much more complex world, Best may no longer be as adequate as it used to be," said Richard Hackenberg, an executive vice president in Boston for Caroon & Black, the big insurance brokerage firm.

HEADLINE: Mockery Is Made Of Disney Memo

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11

 BODY:
First came the Memo, a 28-page analysis of the state of the motion picture industry prepared last month by Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chairman of Disney Studios . An attack on "runaway costs and mindless competition," the memo quickly became required reading in Hollywood. Now there is the Sequel, a deft parody of Disney's and Mr. Katzenberg's corporate style that has studio executives here in stitches.
"This country faces some of the worst economic and political conditions imaginable," the parody memo reads. "Our streets are filled with the homeless, the uneducated; our troops face the constant threat of chemical weapons, Scud missiles and repeated shell fire; and attendance at our parks is down, way down. 
 "That's the bad news. Now the good news. We intend to save money by paying our employees even less."
 
An Example at the Top
 The parody mimics the form and substance of Mr. Katzenberg's original document, which first surfaced in mid-January. "Our great and noble leader, Michael Eisner himself," it states, referring to the chief executive of Disney, "took home a paltry $11 million in stock and salary this year, down from last year's haul of over $50 million. That's an 88 percent sacrifice!
"All I'm asking is that each of you make the same sacrifice that Michael Eisner has made. By reducing employees' salaries by 88 percent we will establish a platform to launch the next round of good times."
Disney has declined to comment on the parody, and its origin is not known. But executives at other studios said they believed one or more Disney employees wrote the mock memorandum and then faxed it to friends at other companies. Parts of it were published today in Variety.
"It's hilarious," said an executive at a rival studio who received a copy of the document last week. "It sounds just like Jeffrey Katzenberg."
 
No Wastrels Here
 Of Hollywood's major studios, Disney has earned a reputation as the most frugal, and the parody makes sport of that situation. It also takes a poke at Mr. Katzenberg's image as one of Hollywood's top power brokers and the gusto with which he exercises his authority. "In the dizzying world of movie making, we must not be distracted from one fundamental concept: I am king," he supposedly says, adding that his memo is intended to be "a reference guide not unlike the Ten Commandments."
Much of Disney's success in recent years has come from movies starring actors whose careers were on the skids and therefore were willing to work for less money than bigger stars. The mock memorandum gleefully notes both that tendency and Disney's penchant for reworking scripts to eliminate unhappy endings, as displayed in "Pretty Woman" and other hits.
"It's our job to find the great idea, then mangle it and sugarize it, until it has a shot at appealing to the lowest common denominator of our society," the parody says.
"This is why we should be aggressive on all fronts -- at the dining table with major stars" and "at the back door of the Betty Ford Clinic, with a pen and contract in hand," it continues.
 
Base Motive, Basically
 Mr. Katzenberg's original memo concluded with a clarion call to Disney employees to take inspiration from the magic of movies. The parody, however, suggests the underlying motivation in movie making is something less noble.
"Greed is the only word that can explain how we can force employees to work 60-hour weeks at the studio, paying them the lowest salaries of any major studio, while taking home incredible salaries ourselves," it concludes.

HEADLINE: War Renews Interest in Sea-Air-Space Museum

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Since the hostilities in the Persian Gulf began on Jan. 16, attendance has more than doubled at the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum in Manhattan, which has had more than its share of financial problems in recent years. During the last few weekends there have been 5,000 visitors, compared with less than half that number in the same period last year.
The curatorial staff of the museum -- a complex of the aircraft carrier Intrepid, the destroyer Edson and the guided-missile submarine Growler at 46th Street and the Hudson River -- is now racing to assemble and install the exhibition "War in the Gulf: The Liberation of Kuwait," which begins on Feb. 27. 
 "Everyone has been hearing about Tomahawks and Patriots and Scuds, but they're vague about them," Lawrence Sowinski, the museum's executive director, said in an interview the other day. "We felt we had a responsibility to our public to interpret this war that may change the world."
 
Explanation of Deployment
 The new show will chronicle the events leading to the Gulf conflict, explaining how the new high-tech tools of the military trade are being deployed in the Gulf.
"These are artifacts of war like the swords in the Metropolitan's collection of arms and armor," Mr. Sowinski said. "Many of the items in our collection are very rare, and in the future, some will be as treasured as the one-of-a-kind swords in the Metropolitan."
The recent attendance boom has not solved financial difficulties. The museum currently has a deficit of "several hundred thousand dollars," Mr. Sowinski said, because of the recession and the recent loss of about $200,000 in education grants from New York City.
From 1985 to 1988, the museum operated under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, but it had been in the black until last fall, when New York City tourism fell victim to the recession. "Right now, we're looking hard to find some additional income," Mr. Sowinski said.
 
Ingenuity and Strength
 At times, the peculiar nature of the Intrepid's exhibits tests the mettle of its curators. On a recent morning, a fragile, 1,000-pound artifact worth $700,000 had to be moved into a carefully prepared niche.
"Not the usual museum installation," said Scott Koen, the aircraft curator, after the heaving and aligning was done. The object was a 12 1/2-foot-long Harpoon cruise missile, of the kind that has reportedly destroyed much of the Iraqi Navy in the Persian Gulf war, and the niche was an A-6 Intruder attack bomber, like the ones that have been harrying Iraqi troops in Kuwait.
Some of the items for the new show have yet to arrive. A Patriot missile and a diorama displaying its deployment will soon be on the way from the Raytheon Company in Lexington, Mass. The museum has also found a spare 21-foot-long Tomahawk cruise missile -- disarmed, of course -- in the factory of a Titusville, Fla. contractor.
"We're working with the National Polish Armed Forces Museum to get a Scud missile," said Mr. Sowinski. "And we've located a Scud missile launcher in Germany -- but we haven't been able to find transportation for it yet."
In addition, the museum is negotiating with the Israeli Government for Scud missile fragments from Iraqi attacks on Tel Aviv.
 
Specially Built Models
 The exhibition will display more than 30 scale models of aircraft, ships and equipment, most of which are being constructed for the show.
A number of the elements come from the museum's collection. In addition to the Intruder fighter and the Harpoon missile, the museum has an AV8 Harrier jump jet, of the kind being used against the Iraqis; an F-4 Phantom similar to the Wild Weasel missile-hunting aircraft used by the Kuwaiti Air Force; an A-7 Corsair attack plane, and an M-60 main battle tank, the kind used by the Saudis in the recent battle for the town of Khafji. The museum also has a 2,700-pound armor-piercing shell identical to those fired by the 16-inch cannons on the battleship Missouri toward Iraqi positions in Kuwait.
Despite the fearsome power of much of the museum's inventory, a large part of the collection is quite fragile and needs constant maintenance. Plexiglas cockpits deteriorate after too many hours in the sun on the Intrepid's 900-foot flight deck, ship and airplane parts are corroded by the salt air, and the three vessels require $85,000 worth of paint every year.
To Mr. Koen, the aircraft curator, the installation of the Harpoon missile "was pretty easy compared to some of the installations we've done."
His toughest museum installation was a 10,000-pound Regulus missile, which had to be mounted on the launcher of the Growler. "But we found a way to do it," he said. "Once we got an 80-ton crane, the rest was easy."

HEADLINE: U.S. Giving Haiti Aid To Buttress Democracy

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The United States announced today that it was giving $82 million in aid to help Haiti complete its transition to democracy, an increase of $28 million over the $54 million granted in fiscal 1990.
The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide was sworn in as Haiti's first democratically elected President last week. Haiti has seen a violent and troubled transition to democracy since the collapse of the Duvalier family dictatorship five years ago.
The Agency for International Development, which announced the aid increase, said in a statement that the money would be used for programs in health, nutrition, business development, education, agriculture and preserving natural resources.
A major aim is to strengthen democracy and private sector growth, the statement said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at Low Against Mark Despite Central Bank Buying

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell to a new postwar low against the German mark in United States and European trading yesterday despite dollar-buying by the central banks of a number of nations.
Gold also fell, with prices on the Commodity Exchange in New York dropping to $367.10 an ounce, off $3 from late Friday. At the Republic National Bank, gold settled at $366, down $3.75. 
 The dollar has been falling in recent days on speculation that the Federal Reserve will move to lower interest rates further to stimulate economic growth.
Declining interest rates in the United States make the dollar less appealing to foreign investors. In addition, the German central bank recently raised important lending rates to fight inflation, making the mark even more attractive.
Trading in the currency markets was light yesterday until comments by an official of the German central bank sent the currency falling. The official said last week's dollar-buying by central banks was done to stabilize the dollar, not to halt its fall.
The official also said that such intervention had little effect when it was trying to counteract a market trend, said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange at Paine Webber International Ltd.
Mr. Troni said the market was taking the comments as an indication that intervention by Germany "will be sort of weak in the future." The mark, he noted, "immediately took off to new levels."
Later, the Federal Reserve and the central banks of France, Canada and England sold marks to buy dollars, Mr. Troni said, but the action did not prevent the dollar's decline.
The dollar finished at a new low of 1.4455 marks in Europe, down from 1.4575 marks late Friday and below the previous record closing low of 1.4490 marks Thursday. In New York, the dollar sank to a record low of 1.4477 marks, compared with 1.4556 marks late Friday. The previous domestic closing low of 1.4483 marks was set Wednesday.
The markets were closed in Tokyo for National Foundation Day, a national holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 127.65 Japanese yen, down from 128.20 yen late Friday in Tokyo. In New York, one dollar bought 127.73 yen, down from 127.78 yen late Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9980, from $1.9875 late Friday. In New York, one pound cost $1.9985, up from $1.9885 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.2368 Swiss francs, down from 1.2435; 4.9360 French francs, down from 4.9595; 1,091.00 Italian lire, down from 1,096.25, and 1.1553 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1580.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $367.25 an ounce, from $369 late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $367, from $368.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 67 cents an ounce, to $369.97.
Silver bullion for current delivery closed at $3.685 an ounce on the Comex, down from $3.820 late Friday. Silver fell in London to a late bid of $3.75, down from Friday's $3.83.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Windfall Exceeds $3 Billion From Oil Price Rise

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 11

 BODY:
After reeling for years because of low world oil prices, Mexico has pocketed a windfall of more than $3 billion thanks to the surge in oil prices since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, according to Mexican officials and a United Nations report.
But with oil prices receding on world markets, no one expects this gusher to keep flowing. So the Mexican Government is squirreling away the money to brace itself for a glut of crude oil, lower oil prices and the fallout from the United States recession. 
 "We know that this is one-time income, and one-time income is saved, not spent," one senior Government official said, repeating what has become a point of pride as well as principle for aides to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. "We will not repeat the same mistakes we have made in the past."
 
Net Gain for Latin America
 Although some Latin American countries like Chile and Brazil have paid sharply increased prices for imported fuel, the higher income and production of oil producers like Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador have largely outweighed those costs on a broader regional basis.
For Mexico, which earns 35 percent of its export revenue from oil sales, the market effects of the Persian Gulf conflict have been profound, defying early pessimism about the country's ability to respond to the crisis.
When oil prices first shot up as a result of the gulf crisis, many analysts doubted that Mexico's aging oil-production operations were capable of a serious increase in output.
 
Reserve of 68 Billion Barrels
 Mexico has proven oil reserves of more than 68 billion barrels, and untapped reserves that are estimated to be among the largest outside the Middle East and the Soviet Union. But its annual capital spending on oil exploration and drilling slid from nearly $6 billion in 1981 to a little more than $1 billion before the gulf crisis began.
As investment declined, output fell to 2.5 million barrels a day by the middle of last year, from 3 million barrels a day in 1982. When the gulf crisis arose, many analysts predicted that Mexican production could not be increased by more than about 15,000 barrels a day.
But they were wrong. By the end of 1990, according to official figures, overall production by Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, the state-run oil monopoly, had reached 2.65 million barrels a day, an increase of 4 percent, or 150,000 barrels a day, over pre-crisis production levels.
 
Added Profits Put in Savings
 The higher average prices of $22 to $25 a barrel in the last five months of 1990 for Mexico's three types of crude -- Isthmus, Olmeca and Maya -- plus the extra production in the same period, brought Mexico more than $3 billion over its budgeted oil income, which had been calculated on a projected price of $17 a barrel.
By contrast to the late 1970's and early 1980's, when the greatest share of additional Mexican oil revenues was added directly to the Government's budget, senior Mexican officials insisted from the beginning of the gulf crisis that none of the windfall income would be spent. Instead, it has been held, together with income from the continuing privatization of Government-held enterprises, in a special contingency fund to guard against future oil price drops and, eventually, to help pay down Mexico's debt load.
Despite widespread criticism here of the United States for its role in the gulf conflict, Mr. Salinas's Government has walked a fine line in keeping Mexican oil sales to the United States from becoming hostage to that debate.
 
Embargo Effort Rejected
 Last month, the leader of the opposition Democratic Revolutionary Party, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, called for a complete embargo on Mexican oil sales to the United States and all other parties to the conflict. Several Government officials also made statements appearing to support such a cutoff.
But in a statement issued later, the senior official for international affairs in Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party, Romeo Flores Caballero, rejected any suggestion that supplies to the United States would be restricted, declaring that "Mexico maintains its position of responding to the mechanisms of supply and demand in the international market."
According to statistics provided by Pemex, 61 percent of Mexico's 1990 oil production was sold in the Western Hemisphere, 27 percent in Europe and 12 percent in East Asia.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Industry's Tactics To Deflect Slump

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: BOCA RATON, Fla.

 BODY:
THE recession has severely damaged major industries, among them real estate, construction, auto making, banking and finance. But for the vast majority of manufacturers -- the heart of the American economy -- the recession is just beginning to undermine operations. And the great hope of the executives who run these companies is that by fall the recession will have ended, leaving them almost unscathed.
That hope showed up repeatedly in interviews and conversations over the weekend with more than two dozen chief executives and top corporate officers at the semiannual meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers. The association's staff economists embody the members' hopes -- indeed, their heartfelt expectation -- in a formal forecast predicting that the economy will rebound by late summer, if the Persian Gulf war ends soon. 
 "Everyone is looking for a turnaround in the last half of the year, but no one really knows," said Donald J. Krumm, chairman of the Maytag Corporation, the appliance maker. In the meantime, as the executives try to cope with the unfolding damage to their companies, the main problem so far is the great difficulty in raising product prices.
Without periodic price increases, profit margins are squeezed. And if profits shrink for long enough (say, through the end of this year), then companies begin to cut back spending for new machinery and product development. Such cutbacks would make the recession harder to shake off and, in the long run, would make the companies less competitive.
Valmont Industries, a Nebraska manufacturer of irrigation equipment and street lights, is at the beginning of this cycle. Orders are off, the costs oflabor and other expenses are still rising and price increases are hard to come by, so Valmont's return on original equity -- that is, the return on the money initially invested in Valmont -- fell to 16 percent last year from more than 20 percent annually in the late 1980's. "We can mark time for a while, continuing to re-invest profits, but over the long term we have to average 20 percent a year to justify capital spending," William F. Welsh 2d, the company's chief executive, said.
Data from the Commerce Department show that like Valmont most manufacturers managed to maintain capital spending levels for new equipment through the fourth quarter of 1990. But even the most profitable among them, exceptional companies like Rubbermaid Inc., are struggling for price increases that keep pace with inflation.
Some manufacturers are cutting advertising budgets, but Stanley C. Gault, Rubbermaid's chairman, says he has increased his company's spending, particularly for ads suggesting that Rubbermaid's plastic dustpans, kitchen utensils and other household items are indispensable. Rubbermaid and other companies are also introducing newproducts ahead of schedule, on the theory that new products will draw consumers more easily than old ones and will command relatively high prices even in hard times. Rubbermaid recently pushed ahead the introduction of a new line of brushes, mops and other cleaning items, and also a new plastic tool box. "If you can move production up a few weeks, it is very important," Mr. Gault said.
If customers reject price increases, then cutting costs can preserve profit margins and postpone the day that cuts must be made in capital spending. Many companies have cut dividend payments to preserve cash, reduced their work force and postponed pay increases. And they have put pressure on suppliers to hold down raw materials prices.
Exports are another way to beat the profit squeeze, as is manufacturing overseas for sale to foreign customers. As the dollar falls in value, sales in German marks, for example, convert into more and more dollars. "Without any change in the number of items sold, the profits earned overseas are worth more in dollars," said Joseph R. Oldfield, a vice president of the Polaroid Corporation.
Exports also help in another way. With orders falling, many companies are slowing assembly lines, which means they produce fewer items, even though the fixed costs of running a factory must still be covered. That problem has squeezed profits at the Labonco Corporation, a maker of electronic ventilation equipment in Kansas City, Mo. In response, Labonco opened a big warehouse in the Netherlands and stepped up production to fill it with inventory for distribution in Europe, which is mostly not in recession.
"The key is to work like the devil for the future, so that when the recession ends, you can move out of it quickly," said John N. McConnell, Labonco's chairman. But Labonco's Dutch warehouse can hold just so many ventilators. Mr. McConnell's tactic, and those of the others, assumes that the recession will be short-lived. If it is not, then capital spending will inevitably suffer and the recession will enter a new phase -- one harder to reverse.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, as dealers and investors began to acclimate themselves to interest rate levels they have not seen in a year or longer.
Long-term interest rates are at their lowest levels since January, 1990. Meanwhile, short-term rates have fallen even further. At yesterday's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the new securities sold at their lowest average levels since early 1988. 
 "These are pretty rich levels, and it takes a little getting used to," one government bond trader said. "But more money is coming off the sidelines and into the stock and bond markets. A reliquefication of the financial markets seems to be taking place."
At the bill auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.86 percent, down from the 5.97 percent average rate at last week's sale. It is the lowest three-month bill rate since the auction on April 18, 1988.
Meanwhile, bids on the new six-month bills generated an average rate of 5.85 percent, down from 5.94 percent a week ago. It is the lowest rate on a six-month bill since the bill auction on March 14, 1988.
 
Treasury Securities Sale
 Traders said the distribution of last week's $34.5 billion worth of Treasury securities that were sold at the quarterly refunding auctions was pretty much at an end.
However, that does not mean that a significant proportion of the new issues do not remain in the Wall Street's hands, some analysts said.
"All of the indications suggest that the dealers owned an unusual share of the auctions," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
Mr. McCarthy said that Wall Street bought slightly more than 97 percent of the issues sold last week, roughly three percentage points more than it normally does at refunding auctions.
"A lot of dealers seem to be positioned in expectation of more favorable news on the economy and inflation," Mr. McCarthy said.
While last week's auctions went well, a smaller but not insignificant supply hurdle will need to be addressed next week, when the Treasury will sell new two-year notes and five-year notes.
"Sometime next week, after the twos and fives are sold, the market really has a chance to do better," the trader said. "But for the time being, I would guess we'll just be churning around at these levels."
Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, said that "the market is moving around in a very listless, range-bound way, waiting for a reason to move."
 
Report on Retail Sales
 Economic data this week, including January reports on retail sales, producer prices and industrial production, are expected to show no signs of strength, Mr. Johnson and other analysts said. But weak numbers are widely forecast. As a result, if the figures meet market expectations there is little reason to anticipate that interest rates would quickly move lower, the analysts said.
"The data will be reasonably constructive," Mr. Johnson said, "but that is pretty much already incorporated in rates. The market will probably have to wait until early March, when we get the February employment numbers and a further reading on progress in the Middle East before it moves again. But the rally is not over."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the Treasury's new benchmark bonds, the 7 7/8 percent securities of 2021, were offered in late when-issued trading at a price of 99 1/ 32, down 3/32, to yield 7.96 percent, compared with 7.95 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the new 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a 99 29/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.76 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 14/32, up 1/ 32, to yield 6.75 percent.
New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market remained strong yesterday, as four companies, including Coca-Cola, priced a total of $600 million worth of new securities.
In the municipal bond market, the decision by Moody's Investors Service to lower its ratings on New York City bonds had little impact on prices of outstanding city issues, traders said. The ratings were lowered by Moody's one notch, citing huge fiscal problems and recession. Prices of 30-year city bonds were offered at a price to yield about 8.40 percent, in line with late Friday.
New York City is expected to sell just under $1 billion worth of new tax-exempt and taxable issues later this week.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to down about 1/8 point.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: 1990 Survey On Banking

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The nation's banks had a miserable year in 1990, with profits plummeting and problem loans soaring, according to a study released yesterday.
Over all, banks saw their nonperforming assets, or problem loans, rise 35 percent, to 3.03 percent of assets in 1990, up from 2.24 percent of assets the year before, according to SNL Securities, a banking research and publishing company in Charlottesville, Va.
The group's survey of 1990 banking results showed that when write-offs for third world loans were excluded, the nation's banks reported average return on assets was 0.54 percent, a 40 percent drop from the year before. Many of the nation's largest banks set aside millions in 1989 in one-time charges to cover failing loans to third world countries.
An SNL spokeswoman, Elisabeth Todaro, said the company's research showed earnings were the worst since the Depression, but she did not provide figures for comparison.
The report provided stark evidence of the credit problem, with banks' loan growth slowing to 1.89 percent in 1990, down from 5.88 percent the year before. The Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates in recent weeks to encourage banks to resume lending and stimulate growth.
