HEADLINE: Malaysia Trading Plan Seeks a Unified Voice

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
East Asia may be the site of some of the world's fastest-growing economic powers, but historically it has always been so fractious and competitive that it could never be organized into anything resembling a trading bloc.
Now, with the the unification of the European market approaching and feelings of alienation from the United States rising, Malaysia is trying a debated effort to organize the region into what it delicately calls an "economic grouping" of Asian nations.
 
Little Discussed in West
 The plan, laid out two months ago by Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysia's Prime Minister and the steward of one of Asia's biggest economic success stories, has been little discussed in the West, but it has become one of the hottest topics in East Asia. 
 It is still far from clear that Mr. Mahathir's East Asian economic grouping will ever come to pass, especially in a region that has never been able to translate its political alliances into economic ones. While his idea has attracted some support, its success hinges on the willingness of one participant: Japan, whose economy is the linchpin of the rest of Asia.
So far, Japanese politicians are skittish about any economic alliance that would seem to pit it against Europe and the United States, which has developed a free-trade agreement with Canada and is working toward one with Mexico.
The next few months will be crucial, as Malaysia completes its first round of explanations and seeks to create a formal trading body. It could pick up more support, especially if the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade talks fails, paving the way for fiercer direct competition.
 
Trade Barriers Common
 Many Asian countries are known for erecting huge trade barriers to protect their infant industries. Malaysia produces manufactured goods that it cannot sell to its closest neighbors, and it slaps huge taxes on imported cars and other goods.
But Mr. Mahathir, who in 10 years as Malaysia's Prime Minister has become a powerful and sometimes feared figure in Southeast Asian politics, has clearly struck a chord with his idea for a more organized and aggressive Asian economic alliance.
"Singly, we will have no hope of arguing our case," he said. "Only together will we have more bargaining power and be in a better position when negotiating for free trade."
No one, not even some of Mr. Mahathir's Cabinet members, can define precisely what kind of economic bloc he is trying to form. Everyone seems to agree that it would include the six members of the Association of South East Asian Nations, or Asean: Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines, Indonesia, Brunei and Malaysia. Mr. Mahathir has said that the group will also include Vietnam, Myanmar (formerly Burma), Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea.
But the list excludes countries populated chiefly by non-Asian races, including Australia and New Zealand. For weeks, Malaysia's Minister for International Trade and Industry, Rafidah Aziz, has been traveling through Asia seeking members.
"What we are talking about is enhancing regional trade among countries with commonalities here in Asia," said Mrs. Rafidah, who supports Mr. Mahathir.
The Prime Minister's plan has not been welcomed by everyone, and Malaysia has been amending parts of it. Indonesia has expressed no enthusiasm, and Taiwan and Hong Kong, among others, have been silent.
The reasons for the objections are not clear, but some Asian officials say they fear that a poisoning of relations with the United States or Japan could hurt their best chances for export. Last week, Mr. Mahathir said he thought the United States was trying to influence some nations not to join the trade group, which American officials in Kuala Lumpur deny.
In the last two months, since Mr. Mahathir took his Cabinet and neighboring nations by surprise with the proposal, the description of the trade grouping has begun to shift. He originally spoke of a trading bloc, immediately prompting fears that he was looking for a way to create trade barriers against countries outside Asia.
The word "bloc" was then deemed offensive because it could scare away Japan and could raise the ire of American officials, who have not supported the plan. Malaysia now is speaking of a "grouping" that would work within multilateral trading groups, like the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Officials in Kuala Lumpur also insist it would "complement" other organizations, like Asean, a 24-year old political alliance that has never been effective as an economic entity.
 
The Plan's Objective
 The object, Malaysia says, is to turn Southeast Asia into a leading exporting force and an investment haven, to give it power to match Europe and America. So far, exporting is dominated by Japan and, to a lesser degree, the nations known as the "four tigers": South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore. Only Japan enjoys such political influence.
"The whole line is that this will not exclude anybody, as long as they look Asian," one Western diplomat here said. "But no one can say what 'complement' means. And this is hardly a group of like-minded countries they are getting together."
Indeed, it is a collection of nations at different stages of development.
At one end of the spectrum are the "tigers." They have grown so quickly in the last decade that they are looking for cheap labor and investment opportunities abroad. Then comes nations like Thailand, perhaps Asia's greatest success story in the late 1980's, though it has begun to show signs of choking on its overexpansion. Malaysia follows, a country that has quickly moved beyond the days of tin and rubber plantations to become a manufacturing center.
But also in the group are countries mired in problems of economic reform, like China, Myanmar, North Korea and Vietnam, all of which have discussed various degrees of economic reform, but have actively resisted political liberalization. Each has considerable poverty and lack a skilled work force.
 
Capitalists and Communists
 If they joined, it would be the first time that some of the world's most fervent capitalists, like the Singaporeans, joined some of its most unreconstructed Communists, like the Vietnamese, in a trading group.
But the critical element to the grouping is Japan, which still has no formal relations with North Korea and is on strained terms with Myanmar and Vietnam. Some Japanese officials have suggested that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu may be unenthusiastic about the proposal.
So, at first, were most other countries. But Singapore changed its mind last month, and its new Prime Minister, Goh Chok Tong, said the grouping would give small Asian countries a voice they now lack. The Philippines has also been mildly supportive, and China termed the idea interesting. Indonesia and Thailand, Malaysia's biggest competitors, have all but dismissed the concept.
The United States has said little, but American diplomats in Asia seem unenthused, particularly because the United States would be excluded.
"It will take some time to fully develop a view," said one American diplomat here, "because no one can quite figure out what the idea is yet."

HEADLINE: Chapter 11 For Carter Hawley

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the largest department store chain on the West Coast, sought protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy law today in an effort to shore up its deteriorating finances.
In filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, Carter Hawley Hale became the latest retailer to fall victim to the combination of a weak economy and a crippling debt burden. 
 The company, based in Los Angeles, operates the Broadway chain in Southern California and Arizona, the Emporium chain in the San Francisco area and Weinstocks in the Sacramento region.
A large part of $800 million of Carter Hawley's $1.6 billion in long-term debt includes high-yield "junk bonds" sold in 1987 as part of a plan to evade a hostile takeover bid by the Limited Inc., a chain of women's specialty stores based in Columbus, Ohio.
 
New Financing Acquired
 Philip M. Hawley, chairman of the company, said he was optimistic that Carter Hawley could emerge from bankruptcy in stronger condition. He said the company had $800 million in new financing from Chemical Bank to pay suppliers and remodel and upgrade its stores.
Analysts, however, took a much dimmer view of the company's prospects, questioning whether creditors would allow the company to survive intact. Some said it was likely that the company would have to sell some or all of its 88 stores under pressure from bondholders and shareholders, including the company's employee stock-ownership plan, which holds 45 percent of the shares.
The Chapter 11 bankrupcty filing allows the company to operate while avoiding paying past debts until it files a business and reorganization plan, but it can buy new goods and pay for them from the new financing from Chemical Bank.
Carter Hawley Hale's stock closed today at $1.625 a share, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Originally known as Broadway-Hale Stores Inc., the company became Carter Hawley Hale in 1974 after Edward W. Carter, who had run the company since 1946, promoted Mr. Hawley, who had come up through the ranks, to president. The company grew quickly during the 1970's, acquiring regional department and specialty stores including Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus and John Wanamaker.
But in 1986 and 1987, the company was forced into a bitter takeover battle with a group led by the Limited. It responded with a plan that spun off some of the store chains but left Carter Hawley Hale with a huge debt. By the beginning of this year, the company had been forced to pare itself back to its West Coast chains.
 
Once Dominated West Coast
 The West Coast stores had once dominated their markets serving middle-class customers, but they suffered in recent years from what analysts say was an ill-defined image, uninspired merchandise and stores badly in need of physical upgrading.
The company has also been hurt by intense competition, particularly in California from competitors including the R. H. Macy Company and Nordstrom Inc. Hampered by a lack of cash, the company has lagged in upgrading stores and keeping shelves filled with best-selling merchandise, analysts said.
"It's one thing to have a bad balance sheet, but they have a bad balance sheet and a bad business," said Robert M. Raiff, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc., a New York brokerage. "The best thing for the company is to be sold."
 
Interest Payment Was Due
 The most immediate impact of the bankruptcy filing will be to relieve Carter Hawley Hale of its obligation to meet $44 million in annual interest payments on its high-yield junk bonds. A payment of $22 million was due on Friday.
Mr. Hawley said that apart from the suspension of the junk bond payments, the company should be able to conduct "business as usual" with its suppliers and employees and that it had received permission from the bankruptcy court to pay its routine bills. He said he believed the company could emerge from bankruptcy without selling any stores or other assets.
The company was pushed into bankruptcy by an inability to obtain credit that accelerated over the last month. Banks have become increasingly reluctant to lend to retailers, especially those that already have a heavy debt load. In addition, suppliers became skittish about advancing credit, hampering the company's ability to keep its stores stocked.
 
Trying to Raise Cash
 Carter Hawley Hale has been scrambling in recent months to raise cash and reduce its debt. It has eliminated 1,000 jobs, or 3.3 percent of its work force, for an estimated annual savings of $75 million. It sold its Thalhimers department store division to the May Department Stores Company in December for $317 million.
Last month, it announced that it would sell its credit card operation to the GE Capital Corporation for $50 million plus the removal of $600 million in debt. But the deal fell through last week on the same day that an agreement to borrow $100 million from the Bank of America also collapsed.
In its bankruptcy papers, filed early today with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Los Angeles, Carter Hawley Hale listed assets of $1.2 billion and liabilities of $1.38 billion. It did not provide a list of secured and unsecured creditors.
 
Mixed Reaction From Suppliers
 The bankruptcy filing drew mixed reactions from suppliers.
"It's a sad shame, of course, but we are a double-digit, million-dollar supplier to Carter Hawley, and we're waiting to hear more details of their financing," said Linda Wachner, chief executive of Warnaco Inc., a leading apparel producer based in Bridgeport, Conn. "We stopped shipping to them last week and won't resume until we get more financing information and are put on one of the creditors' committees."
Lee Abraham, chairman of the Associated Merchandising Corporation in New York, said Mr. Hawley and H. Michael Hecht, Carter Hawley Hale's president, were expected to travel to New York this week to speak with key suppliers.
"I think their willingness to communicate with the market and the funds they have available are cause for optimism," Mr. Abraham said, "but it seems that the bankruptcy trend is a never-ending one."
Carter Hawley Hale's bankruptcy comes one week after Hills Department Stores Inc., the nation's fifth-largest discount chain, filed for Chapter 11. Also having filed since the beginning of last year were the Federated Department Stores Company, the Allied Stores Corporation and the Ames Department Store Company.

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Welfare Plan: To Reward the Married

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, who has made a national reputation with his aggressive proposals to overhaul Wisconsin's welfare system, offered another one this month. He wants to reward teen-age mothers who marry and penalize those who do not.
As part of the budget he presented to the Legislature on Thursday, the Republican Governor unveiled a pilot program to cap welfare payments to unwed teen-age mothers regardless of how many children they have, and to pay larger grants to those who marry. Recipients would have to finish high school or get job training, or forgo benefits. 
 The plan is one of several across the nation based on the idea that welfare ought to be no more than a temporary safety net, with benefits engineered to discourage long-term dependency. Increasingly, states are offering cash incentives to get the behavior they want.
In Ohio, teen-age parents who stay in school can get child care, transportation and an extra $62 a month. In Kansas, lawmakers are considering a bill that would pay welfare recipients $500 for agreeing to use Norplant, a long-lasting contraceptive that is surgically implanted. Proposed legislation in Wyoming would have the state pay childbirth expenses for all women who put their babies up for adoption.
Under Mr. Thompson, who was first elected in 1986 after campaigning against high taxes and welfare benefits, Wisconsin has been in the forefront of efforts to require welfare recipients to work. And three years ago, the state began docking the welfare checks of parents whose teen-agers had three or more unexcused absences from school in a given month. So far, the state has withheld a total of $3 million from thousands of families, though it has not determined how the program is affecting school performance.
Now Mr. Thompson wants to tie welfare payments to marriage, saying the current system only encourages unmarried women to have more children. His proposal would not affect the 78,000 Wisconsin families who now receive welfare; it would apply only to new welfare applicants under 20 years of age. It would be tested in four counties, including Milwaukee, before expanding to the rest of the state. The administration says about 1,600 young women would face either marriage or a lower welfare check.
The current welfare payment in Wisconsin is $440 a month for a woman with one child, and about $80 a month for each additional child. Under the new plan, unwed mothers could receive no more than $440 a month no matter how many children they had. But those who married would get nearly $80 a month extra, and would be permitted to keep up to $14,500 in earnings from outside jobs.
The state said these recipients would be eligible for programs to help them get a high school diploma, for unpaid "work experience" in areas like garbage recycling and building maintenance, and for job training in fields like auto mechanics and television repair.
"I want to give people the elevator of opportunity and get away from the locked-in generations of welfare dependency," the 49-year-old Governor said in a telephone interview. "Now a man can come in and get trained for a job, become a useful member of society and take care of his family, so that society doesn't have to do it for him. I certainly don't want to force anybody to get married, but don't think the welfare system should act as an impediment."
Before the plan can be adopted, even as an experiment, Mr. Thompson will have to win over Democratic majorities in both houses of the Legislature and gain a waiver of rules from the Federal Department of Health and Human Services. Democrats said they were skeptical and officials in Washington would not comment, but the Governor has persuaded each before.
His proposal has attracted the attention of welfare policy analysts around the nation. Many applaud the effort to reinforce families and reward their working, but are troubled by the appearance of punishing other welfare recipients.
"To penalize people who don't get married in society in which family ties are weakening in general seems like tough medicine," said Prof. Richard P. Nathan, director of the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York at Albany. "This is not in the mainstream. This sounds like a sledgehammer policy."
Other analysts said the proposal went further than almost any other in drawing a line between acceptable and unacceptable family patterns in the welfare system.
"The notion of denying benefits when an additional child is born and providing generous subsidies to those who marry is unknown in the U.S. welfare system," said Gary Burtless of the Brookings Institution in Washington. But he and other analysts said there was little evidence that financial incentives changed patterns of marriage or childbearing, and they added that such inducements could hurt more than help.
"Giving financial incentives for parents to do right thing by their children is not out of bounds," Mr. Burtless said. "No one likes people having children out of wedlock, but it's very difficult to deny them the resources that they need. More damage could be done by making children destitute."
Even those who support the idea of curtailing benefits for unwed mothers question whether $80 a month is incentive enough. "I think this is better than the status quo, but how much better is the question," said Walter E. Williams, a professor of economics at George Mason University who has written extensively on the topic of welfare.
While married couples in general fare much better financially than single mothers, he said, marriage is one of the clearest routes out of poverty. The poverty rate for blacks who graduate from high school, get a job and stay married is 6 percent, as against more than 30 percent for blacks as a group, according to the Census Bureau.
But Professor Williams said that while encouraging marriage was a worthy goal paying people to take their vows corrupted the institution and offered no assurance that their lives would improve.
"Marriage is much deeper than some government program," he said. "When you you stand in front of the minister, you're supposed to be there because you love the person and are committed to them, not because you're going to get $80. That's a tainted marriage from the beginning. That trivializes marriage. If $80 will do it, that is bad news."
Local critics say the state should not be in the matchmaking business. "This is dressed-up marriage brokering for poor people," said Hannah Rosenthal, executive director of the Wisconsin Women's Council, a research and advocacy group. "It's dangling a paycheck in front of a girl and saying, 'We'll give you a bonus if you get married.' It assumes that the ticket out of poverty is a man."
 
Viewing Welfare Differently
 Governor Thompson said the point of the measure was not to make people get married but to get them to view welfare differently. He insists that his welfare initiatives are working and cites a 21 percent drop in the state's welfare rolls since he took office in January 1987, to 238,000 people, from almost 300,000.
"People don't like the fact that I'm putting strings on their welfare, that I'm making them go to school or get a job," he said. "They're not going to get rich off of this. This gives them incentive to go to work."
Women who have had to turn to welfare say life is not so simple. For one thing, they say, they have not exactly been flooded with marriage proposals. "These mothers have no control over whether these guys take a hike or not," said Deborah Darden, a former welfare recipient who is now a job counselor for women trying to get off welfare. "They haven't been given a choice. I think a lot of them would love to get married if they were given a chance. But what kind of song and dance are they supposed to do to get keep these men around?"
Julius Fourston, a 21-year-old mail-room clerk in Milwaukee, said a welfare check would not induce him to marry. "That's getting married for the wrong reason," he said. "You can't do anything with $20 a week. I want to have a good job before I get married. I can't support a wife and kid now. I want to have a job with a future. I want to do things right."
Ms. Darden, who pulled herself up from welfare to job counseling, said poor people, like anyone else, would follow society's norms when they felt they were part of society. "If the Governor improves the quality of life for them," she said, "people will naturally get married."

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
As Bombs Fall And Flags Fly, Business Booms

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

DATELINE: BLOOMFIELD, N.J.

 BODY:
Dan Connors thought he'd never see anything quite so bizarre at work. Squads of silent men in nice suits pulled open every drawer, every door, every closet, every box in the Annin Company factory here. They took nothing, these smile-free fellows, just poked through everything.
At every entrance they stationed guards in equally nice suits with government-issue sunglasses. They wouldn't admit Mr. Connors until the company president identified him. 
 That was the September week in 1988 when George Bush came to New Jersey to wrap his campaign for President in the American flag at one of the nation's biggest flag factories. Now, of course, George Bush is President Bush. He's leading one of modern history's largest military operations. And it's got all wrapped up in flags.
It's a funny thing about the American flag. Its viewers seem to see in it the color of the moment, like the same ocean shining deep blue on a sunny day and lurking dark gray beneath clouds. The flag has always been red, white and blue. Its design hasn't changed in three decades. But now the flag business sure has changed on Llewellyn Street, where Helga Hart is banging so many machine staples into little wooden flagpoles every day that her right foot is numb even before overtime.
If many families get flags freshly folded from caskets, feelings could change. But for now, the Persian Gulf operation has been great for the flag. Even on wintry days, flags appear in front of houses all over the suburbs. On businesses and restaurants. Car and truck radio antennas.
In Hartford, flags are so scarce that radio stations broadcast listener tips on which stores still have some. WOR gave them away and reported its phone lines were never so jammed. Professional and collegiate athletes wear flags, while Connecticut high school wrestlers seek flag stickers for the backs of mat shoes. Even New Jersey's criminals want flags; someone stole the flag from the South Orange Rescue Squad the other night.
There have been many peaks of flag fascination since 1820, when Alexander Annin began making them as a sideline at his New York hardware business. Since 1847, that's all the family company has done -- make flags, through good times and bad times, slow times and fast times.
 Congress gave Medals of Honor for capturing Civil War flags. But the best flag times are not just about causes; usually they also in volve an easily identified bad guy to fly the flag against. World War II was a good flag time. Although the 48-star flag hadn't changed since 1912, everyone wanted a new one to support the war effort, and there were obvious bad guys.
The Korean War was a little fuzzy; who'd ever heard of Kim Il Sung? But 1959 brought in two new states, which made obsolete every flag in existence. Then came Vietnam, which so divided this country that many of the flags not being burned went into hiding. The Bicentennial ignited great flag passion, although interest, uh, waned sharply on July 5, 1976.
There have been brief bubbles of flag fervency since -- the return of hostages from Iran, for instance, the 1984 Olympics. And the Reagan Presidency seemed to elevate flag exposure generally. Always, the South was the strongest market; the Midwest was good too, if the economy was strong.
The nation's half-dozen major flag manufacturers were aware of the United Nations January deadline to Iraq. Orders were stronger than usual all autumn.
But nothing prepared them for the morning after the first allied air attacks. "It was an explosion of orders," said Mr. Connors, "from everywhere." The cause was generally acceptable, the bad guy easily identifiable and the number of families and friends touched by military involvement many.
Within hours of Baghdad's bombing, the Memorial Day inventory was gone. Because Americans couldn't get flags, they wanted them even more, especially the 3-by-5-foot homeowner size.
With overtime and a second shift, the factory here ships over 10,000 flags a week, plus 40,000 on Mrs. Hart's little wooden sticks. If no more orders came in, the three-story brick factory on a quiet suburban street might catch up in seven weeks. Alfreda Kruk stiches white stripes to red stripes 200 yards at a time. Evangeline Archondes bangs grommets one after another. Rouba Khalia snips loose threads. Even Guilford Kempadoo, a supervisor, labels.
They're not famous like Betsy Ross. They're more like Mary Pickersgill. She's the little-known seamstress who responded to a rush order during a previous flag peak. It was her handiwork that Francis Scott Key saw through the rockets' red glare.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Co. Reports a Profit Of $12.2 Million in 4th Period

 BODY:
The New York Times Company yesterday reported net income for the fourth quarter of $12.2 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with a loss of $19 million for the quarter a year earlier.
The results for the 1989 period had been depressed by substantial one-time charges. 
 Disregarding special charges and credits for 1989 and 1990, the picture was considerably gloomier in the recent quarter. Excluding those factors, earnings from continuing operations in the fourth quarter of last year fell 31 percent, to 31 cents a share, from 45 cents a share a year earlier. Profits for the year were down 11.5 percent, to $1.46 a share from $1.65.
 
Weakness in Advertising
 The company attributed most of the decline to a poor advertising climate, particularly in New York City. Advertising volume at The New York Times newspaper for the fourth quarter of last year declined 19 percent from the corresponding quarter of 1989 (which had one more Sunday, a major advertising day).
About 65 percent of the decline in advertising was in help-wanted and real estate classified advertising, categories particularly likely to suffer in an economic downturn.
The special charges and credits were complex. In the fourth quarter of 1989, the company took charges totaling 60 cents a share for staff reductions, wholesaler settlements and a valuation reserve at its forest products group. By contrast, the 1990 fourth-quarter results were reduced by 7 cents a share for start-up costs, depreciation and interest expense at new plants in Edison, N.J., and Gwinnett County, Ga.
Revenues for the 1990 quarter declined to $456 million, from $470.2 million in 1989.
 
Sale Affected 1989 Results
 The company's net income for 1990 declined to $64.8 million, or 85 cents a share, compared with $266.6 million, or $3.39 a share, in 1989. The 1989 results were swollen by proceeds from the sale of the company's cable television operation.
Income from continuing operations, also $64.8 million, declined 5 percent for the year, from $68.2 million in 1989. The 1990 figure amounted to 85 cents a share, down from 87 cents in 1989.
Revenues for the year improved slightly, to $1.77 billion, from $1.76 billion in 1989.
The New York Times's average circulation reached record highs last year. Daily sales increased to 1.15 million, or 51,200 copies above the 1989 level, and Sunday circulation jumped almost 60,000, to 1.7 million. The Times became the nation's largest-circulation Sunday paper.
Operating profit of the company's newspaper group rose in the fourth quarter to $32.1 million, from $25.1 million in the 1989 period. The group's revenues were $350.1 million in the 1990 period, down from $375.2 million in the 1989 quarter. For the year, the group's operating profit declined 23 percent, to $140.3 million, and revenues dropped slightly, to $1.36 billion from $1.4 billion. The group includes The Times, a group of 32 regional newspapers and a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune.
The company sold three small newspapers in 1990, but record circulation was reached for the regional papers that remained, with daily sales up 21,100 copies, to 881,000, and Sunday sales up 16,500, to 871,000.
The company's magazine group had a fourth-quarter operating loss of $6.3 million, exactly half the loss for the fourth quarter of 1989. Revenues for the fourth quarter of 1990 were $85.2 million, compared with $75 million the year before.
Charges associated with the acquisitions of McCall's and Golf World magazines were 29 cents a share for 1990, compared with 18 cents in 1989.
"Excluding the effect of the McCall's acquisition, the group's 1990 fourth-quarter and full-year performance would have resulted in operating profits which were significantly higher than the respective 1989 periods," a company statement said.
Operating profit of the broadcasting and information services group increased to $4.7 million in the quarter, from $2.9 million in 1989. Operating profit for the year was $15.1 million, compared with $12.7 million in 1989. Profits suffered in 1989 from a $1.1 million write-down of certain syndicated program rights.
The forest products group reported a decline in profits from continuing operations to $38,000, from $2.1 million in 1989. Much of the decline resulted from big discounts in the price of newsprint.
The Times Company's class A stock closed at $24.875 yesterday, up 62.5 cents a share, on the American Stock Exchange. The earnings were released after the close of trading.

HEADLINE: Worn Out, Some Step Back From Fight Against AIDS

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Marie St. Cyr first encountered AIDS nine years ago when she headed a social-services program in Florida. A client in his 30's began losing weight and falling ill for no apparent reason; he soon died.
Two weeks ago, worn down by the seemingly endless effort against the disease, Ms. St. Cyr thought of that man as she sat through a memorial service at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York City for Richard Dunne, the former executive director of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, who died of AIDS-related causes at 46. 
 "It was such a stark reminder that we haven't moved very far in this crisis," said Ms. St. Cyr, who recently resigned as executive director of the Women and AIDS Resource Network in New York. "People are still dying. The resources are meager. There's still no cure. You come to a point where you realize, 'How effective can I be?' "
 
Emotional Toll
 Ten years into an epidemic that has claimed more than 100,000 lives in the United States, many of those who have long cared for or been advocates for people with AIDS find themselves overwhelmed by despair or struggling to cope. Some, like Ms. St. Cyr, who now works with the city's Human Rights Commission, have recognized signs of burnout and left the field, at least temporarily. Many others stay on, their commitment fueled by anger or hope, or the fear that if they quit nobody else will step in to take their place.
As the search for more funds to combat AIDS becomes harder amid budget crises and recession, and as the growing AIDS caseload both pressures and decimates their ranks, workers say the AIDS fight is extracting a higher emotional toll. More and more veterans of the field -- from volunteer "buddies" who do chores for the very sick to doctors on the cutting edge of research -- are pausing to assess the implications of that toll and to try to blunt its impact.
"Turnover costs us money and experience," said Paul Kawata, director of the National Minority AIDS Council in Washington, which provides technical assistance to 200 organizations. "We're all spending more time looking at how we can take care of our staff."
Within the last year, AIDS agencies like the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York City, which serves 4,500 clients a year, have increased efforts to address the stress and frustration of their workers. The director ofvolunteers for the Gay Men's Health Crisis, Joseph Ripple, said three-day "grief and healing" workshops, begun 10 months ago, have reduced turnover among the organization's cadre of 2,200 volunteers to a quarter of the previous rate.
Staff support groups, many with psychotherapists, are springing up among more nonprofit AIDS organizations and medical AIDS units. Some agencies are consideringflexible schedules, coffee breaks and other concepts borrowed from the private sector to relieve stress.
Some organizations are also making staff members take vacations, which many workers had not done because they felt guilty taking time off.
"It's not something that's been addressed because it sounds so self-serving," said Regina Quattrochi, who this month became executive director of the AIDS Resource Center, which provides housing and support services for homeless people with AIDS. "It's almost like it's taboo to say, 'I also have to take care of myself.' " She has vowed to give priority to the needs of her staff of 85.
 
Social Problems
 AIDS workers say that watching people in their 20's, 30's and 40's die -- most after wasting away physically and mentally -- is among the most difficult aspects of their job.
Many victims are friends and co-workers, and it is not unusual for workers to have to cope with seeing an entire family, including children, die from the disease.
As the epidemic has spread among intravenous drug users and their sex partners, mainly in poor black and Hispanic neighborhoods, those who work with AIDS victims must deal with the accompanying social ills, like homelessness and inadequate health care. They must also contend with policy debates like the dispute over whether to provide condoms to high school students to fight the spread of the disease.
"It's so frustrating to see political funding and religious barriers preventing us from stopping this epidemic in its tracks," said Mark Barnes, a lawyer who is resigning as director of policy for the New York State Department of Health's AIDS Institute.
Mr. Barnes, 30 years old, is switching to private practice after six years of AIDS-related work, including cases of housing and job discrimination against AIDS patients. Most recently he helped devise the state's guidelines for medical personnel infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS.
 
'You Never Win'
 Mr. Barnes said that although he thinks of his work as "a noble calling," the vastness of the crisis has gradually overwhelmed him, to the point that he feels inadequate and defeated. More than once in the last few months he has found himself crying while driving to work.
"In AIDS you never win -- all you do is stave off disaster," he said. "Even when you get what you want, all you're really doing is controlling the damage. We're always playing catch-up."
At the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, where pioneering research in pediatric AIDS includes an effort to develop a vaccine to block transmission of the AIDS virus from mother to fetus, AIDS work is a challenge. But the college's division of allergy and immunology, which is responsible for staffing AIDS clinics at Montefiore Medical Center and Bronx Municipal Hospital, must also contend with financial problems and neighborhood opposition to expanded AIDS services.
The division is frantically trying to make up for the loss of almost $1 million in state and private grants, in order to keep open the clinics, which served 1,200 patients last year.
"You can't do research without giving service to patients," said the division director, Dr. Arye Rubinstein.
 
Difficult to Recruit
 Those who treat AIDS patients say that despite strides made in treatment, their work still boils down to -- as one doctor put it -- "managing death."
"The patient that I treat in 1991 has a better life and lives longer than the kids I treated in 1981," said Dr. Marc Sicklick, an immunologist and AIDS researcher who treats children at Albert Einstein's AIDS clinic. "But we always have to make a decision about when it is not worth it to prolong misery."
Health workers in AIDS medical units say recruiting new staff is difficult, partly because AIDS workers are often ostracized by colleagues.
"There's absolutely no prestige associated with this job," said Cecilia Douglas, a nurse clinician on the Albert Einstein team. "People ask you what you do and you tell them and they think you're so weird."
 
Dedicated Workers
 But for all the emotional hardship that comes with the job, those who take up the fight against AIDS are moved by a commitment that gives them endurance. Suzanne C. Ouellette Kobasa, a professor of psychology at the City University of New York who studied 600 new volunteers at the Gay Men's Health Crisis from 1988 to 1990, found that they viewed AIDS work as highly rewarding. She also found that although the first volunteers had usually experienced AIDS through the death of a friend or lover, many new recruits, often women, had no such connection and simply want to help.
"The changing nature of the volunteer group is important and offers good news," she said. "Many of them are coming without a lot of AIDS stresses already in their lives."
Hal J. Moskowitz, a 37-year-old medical equipment specialist, joined G.M.H.C.'s volunteer corps in 1983. Since then he has done it all, from changing soiled bedsheets to talking on the telephone with AIDS patients for hours at a time. He is still going strong.
"This disease is preventable," he said. "If I educate somebody and prevent them from getting infected, I've done something."
Magda Martas, 27, who joined Albert Einstein's AIDS unit last July as an outreach worker, conceded that she was depressed over the recent death of a client, a 25-year-old woman with three children. "Every time this happens I will cry and be devastated," she said. "But there's always another person to help."
More than 161,000 Americans have been diagnosed with AIDS, and Federal health officials estimate that a million Americans are infected with the AIDS virus. Those afflicted with the disease still make up a major portion of the anti-AIDS work force.
"Some people need tranquillity when they're ill," said Larry Gutenberg, who serves on the board of the People With AIDS Coalition and who was diagnosed with AIDS in 1989. "I find that controlled anger is the elixir that prolongs one's life."
And many of those who have decided to quit AIDS work as a vocation, like Mr. Barnes and Ms. St. Cyr, still do volunteer work.
"I've learned a lot from the courage of those who have died," Ms. St. Cyr, 40, said. "It's not an ending struggle for me."
One night last month, 35 men and women -- the newest batch of volunteers -- gathered in a room at the Gay Men's Health Crisis headquarters in Chelsea for an orientation session. The group, which included waiters, computer specialists and grieving friends of some who had died, listened thoughtfully as Mr. Moskowitz shared his experiences with AIDS and encouraged them to lend a hand.
"This is something you shouldn't fear, but something you should get into with a lot of determination and hope," he said. "I can guarantee you, at the end of it, you won't recognize yourself."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Efforts Set Back by Cut In Bond Rating

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating on New York City bonds one notch yesterday, a blow to efforts by Mayor David N. Dinkins to show that his administration was mastering the city's finances.
The decision, which could eventually lead to higher interest rates for the city, was based on doubts about Mr. Dinkins's ability to carry out a plan he released last month to cut a $3 billion budget gap over the next 18 months with sharp reductions in services and higher taxes. 
 The Mayor said he was disappointed by the rating cut but pledged to continue his administration's efforts to improve the city's finances.
 
Fiscal Maneuvers
 The rating cut comes a week after the city completed an agreement to postpone thousands of layoffs of teachers this school year by deferring a portion of the wage increase won by 85,000 school employees. The move was cited by the ratings service as a "one shot" mechanism that does not address the underlying budget problems faced by the city.
Moody's, which has seven categories of municipal investment-grade ratings, lowered its rating on more than $15 billion in outstanding New York City general-obligation bonds from A to Baa1, one notch above its lowest investment rating of Baa. It is the lowest city bond rating since December 1985.
The ratings service warned that it would drop the city's rating even further if it continued to rely on fiscal maneuvers. City officials said they were particularly dismayed by the Moody's decision because it was announced one week after another rating agency, Standard & Poor's, reaffirmed a higher rating of A-, and praised the city for "meeting the challenges in the fiscal-balance question in a fairly reasonable fashion."
In lowering the rating, Moody's said Mr. Dinkins had made a "credible attempt" in January to deal with the budget problems. But it questioned whether the city would be able "to negotiate the political and managerial avenues needed to make the plan work."
"With a backdrop of worsening economic performance," the agency said in a statement distributed yesterday, "the likelihood that the city will have to move well beyond current plans to close continuous and increasingly large budget gaps raises additional uncertainty."
The rating puts the city's creditworthiness below that of Chicago, Los Angeles and some other large cities, on a par with Cleveland's and one notch above the ratings for New Orleans, Detroit and Massachusetts. New York State bonds are rated A by Moody's.
 
'All That We Can Do'
 Appearing angry and dismayed, Mayor Dinkins told a hastily called news conference at City Hall that he was satisfied that his administration "had done all that we can do."
"Sometimes, the umpire calls a high inside pitch a strike," Mr. Dinkins said before leaving for Albany to lobby for more state aid for the city.
But he pledged to be "resolute in our commitment to meet these challenges" and said that "we will continue to present spending plans that are socially responsible and fiscally prudent."
Standard & Poor's had raised many of the same concerns cited by Moody's yesterday, but it stopped short of downgrading the city's rating, highlighting the subjective elements in rating a city's creditworthiness.
"It is like going to the Supreme Court -- sometimes judges disagree in very close votes," said Hyman C. Grossman, a managing director at Standard & Poor's. "I hope the city justifies the rating."
But in a report issued yesterday, Standard & Poor's presented a bleak portrait of the city's problems while being buffeted by a deep recession. Like Moody's, it warned that the city's rating would fall if the city resorted to quick budget fixes. Its one-word outlook was "negative."
 
'Under a Cloud'
 Mr. Grossman said that while Standard & Poor's believed that the city would eventually rebound from the recession, perhaps by early 1992, the city would "remain under a cloud until it does so."
The lowered rating by Moody's could increase the city's interest costs in a $950 million bond sale scheduled for tomorrow, perhaps by as much as $150,000 a year for each $100 million in outstanding bonds, some traders predicted.
But late yesterday, city officials said preliminary efforts to set a price for the bonds showed that the downgrading did not appear to have much of an impact, mainly because New York City bonds have been already trading as if they had been downgraded, with the city paying higher interest costs.
"We have been trading as if this were our rating for some time now," said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "The market has made its decision to some degree independent of the ratings."
While Moody's and Standard & Poor's use different rating systems and refuse to compare them, bond traders and analysts agreed that the Moody's rating represented a considerably lower credit assessment than the one assigned by Standard & Poor's.
 
A 'Significant Notch'
 Daniel M. Heimowitz, an executive vice president at Moody's, said the Baa1 rating was a "significant notch" below the Moody's A rating and a little better than Baa, its lowest investment grade rating.
New York City is the largest single borrower in the municipal credit market. As it continues with a plan to sell more than $4 billion in bonds a year, some traders say it will likely have to face higher and higher interest costs to attract borrowers, and the doubts raised by yesterday's downgrading may come back to haunt the city in future bond sales.
Yesterday, long-term city bonds sold at about 8.35 percent, a slight decline from the 8.5 percent the city paid when it last sold bonds in December. But since December, interest rates in the municipal bond markets had fallen even further.
In the December sale, investors in 15-year New York City bonds received about 1.45 percentage points more than investors in other bonds rated A by Moody's, according to a market survey by the Delphis Hanover Corporation. Bondholders received 1.20 percentage points more than on bonds with the lowest investment rating, Baa.
 
Theoretical Possibility
 Last week, Mr. Dinkins set off a storm of controversy when heraised the theoretical possiblity of the city borrowing to pay its bills and balancing its budget over several years to avoid disastrous service cuts.
But Mr. Heimowitz of Moody's said Mr. Dinkins's remarks played no role in yesterday's rating decision. The agency, he said, had come to a tentative decision some time ago and acted after giving Mr. Dinkins a chance to appeal.
And it warned that if the city resorted to bond restructuring or other "one shots," the rating could go down further.
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman complained that the decison by Moody's had failed to take into account the city's "track record." But she pledged to avoid one shots in closing the city's future budget gaps.
"The city has closed budget gaps before without such measures," she said. "We will do so again, if we take prudent action now."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
Markets
The stock market caught fire, scoring strong new gains in heavy trading and rising to its highest level since just before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The Dow soared 71.54, or 2.5 percent, to a high for the year of 2,902.23. [Page A1.]
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed. Long-term rates are at their lowest levels since January 1990. [D14.]
Fuel prices ended higher, lifted by a bout of cold weather that sent heating oil up sharply. Crude rose 55 cents, to $22.47. [D15.]
The dollar fell to a new postwar low against the German mark despite dollar-buying by many central banks. [D15.]
 
The Economy
A proposal by bankers to refinance the shaky deposit insurance fund began circulating, and regulators and bank lobbyists cautioned that parts of it faced strong opposition. The proposal calls for borrowing up to $10 billion from the banking industry. [D1.]
Moody's dropped its rating on New York City bonds one notch, a blow to efforts by Mayor Dinkins to show that his administration was mastering the city's finances. [A1.]
 
Companies
Carter Hawley Hale Stores filed for bankruptcy protection in an effort to shore up its deteriorating finances, becoming the latest retailer to fall victim to slow sales and crippling debt. [D1.]
Sears, Roebuck said it was eliminating 9,000 more full- and part-time jobs in its struggling merchandise group. The trims will bring to 33,000 the number of jobs cut by the end of the year. [D1.]
It is easier for insurers to win a top rating from A. M. Best than from two other rating concerns, a study concludes. [D1.]
USAir said it would cut 3,585 employees, including 660 pilots, and eliminate 268 of its flights. [D1.]

Unisys suspended its preferred stock dividends, saving $120 million a year, and affirmed its plans to sell assets. [D4.]
Hasbro, despite a dismal Christmas for the toy industry, said its fourth-quarter performance was relatively strong. [D5.]
The New York Times Company reported net income for the fourth quarter of $12.2 million. [D17.]
Daewoo Group of South Korea plans to develop a significant auto parts manufacturing operation in the U.S. [D4.]

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: ISRAEL;
ISRAELI TELLS BUSH OF MISSILE DAMAGE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Israel's Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, in a hastily arranged one-day visit to Washington, told President Bush today that Israel was suffering heavy "destruction" from Iraqi missile attacks and that its willingness to refrain from retaliating was wearing thin, Administration officials said.
While Israeli leaders have consistently said since the missile attacks began that they are reserving the right to retaliate, until now they have refrained from doing so at Washington's behest. It is not clear what the Israelis could do to Iraq that the much larger American-led coalition air forces have not done. 
 Administration officials said Mr. Arens's visit to the White House seemed intended both to prepare Washington for any possible Israeli retaliation and to try to impress Mr. Bush with the sacrifices Israel has made in not retaliating so the Bush Administration might deal more favorably with Israel's financial needs.
In a 30-minute meeting with the President in the Oval Office, Mr. Arens reportedly detailed the effect of Iraq's missile attacks on Israel, telling reporters later, "We see sights of destruction in Israel that have not been seen in a Western country since World War II."
An Administration official said the Israeli official seemed to be "laying the groundwork, if the Israelis decide to retaliate" and "softening us up" for an new Israeli aid request -- something that some Americans in the meeting resented, Administration officials said. While officials did not say so explicitly, they left the impression that the Arens-Bush meeting did not enhance Israeli-American relations.
The Administration official said that in the talks with Mr. Bush, Mr. Arens "didn't say absolutely that the Israelis were going to retaliate."
"But he didn't say they were not, either," the official said. "He made a very emotional presentation, though. He told the President the Israelis are really taking a lot of hits and this can only go on so long."
Asked how the President responded to Mr. Arens's presentation, an Administration official said Mr. Bush reiterated his longstanding position that the United States appreciated Israel's restraint. The President also reportedly stressed how important this restraint was for the anti-Iraq coalition and expressed the hope that Israel would continue its policy.
An Administration official said he got the feeling that Mr. Arens was sent to emphasize to Mr. Bush how big a sacrifice it is for Israel to continue not responding to the Iraqi missile strikes in the hope that this will prompt the Administration to respond more favorably to Israel's increased economic aid needs. Israeli officials have estimated those needs -- for housing Soviet Jews and military spending -- at $13 billion over the next five years, in addition to the $3 billion Israel already receives annually from the United States.
 
Israeli Complaints on Aid
 Israeli officials have been complaining that despite their restraint, the Administration has refused to include additional economic aid as part of its supplemental budget request to Congress to pay for the war. While Washington has lined up economic support from Europe to help allies like Egypt and Turkey through the war, the Israelis really have only Washington to rely upon. Only by being included in the supplemental request could Israel get immediate compensation for war expenses without going through the long formal budget process, which offers little prospect for an aid increase.
Mr. Arens, while he stressed the costs to Israel of the missile strikes, said he made no aid request in his meeting with the President.
Administration officials also saw the Arens visit as an extension of domestic Israeli politics. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has come under pressure to act from some hard-line members of his right-wing coalition, particularly Ariel Sharon.
It is possible that Mr. Arens wanted to go to Washington to have his hands tied by the President so he would be able to return and say that he was prepared to order a retaliation but that the Americans pressed him not to attack Iraq. Up to now, the Israeli public has overwhelmingly supported Mr. Shamir's policy of restraint.
 
A Dramatic Note
 Mr. Arens's presentation was enhanced by the fact that while he was meeting with Mr. Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other top Middle East experts, he was handed a note that another Iraqi Scud missile had landed in central Israel.
After his talks with the President, Mr. Arens went to the Pentagon to meet again with Mr. Cheney and to the State Department to see Mr. Baker. The Defense Department spokesman, Pete Williams, made clear that the Pentagon was also hoping that Israel would continue to show restraint.
Mr. Williams, asked about the purpose of Mr. Arens's visit, said: "The consultations have focused on how to meet Israel's security needs and enable Israel to continue to pursue its commendable policy of restraint in staying out of the conflict in the Persian Gulf. One of Saddam Hussein's apparent goals has been to try to suck Israel into the conflict, and working together, we've frustrated those aims, and we hope that will continue to be the case."
Military analysts say it is not at all certain that the Israelis could be any more effective than the American-led coalition forces in knocking out the Iraqi missile launchers.
For the Israelis to use their air force over Iraq, while the American-led coalition is operating there, they would need the electronic identification codes of American aircraft. These codes, which enable pilots to identify whether another plane is a friend or foe, are changed every day. Without them, Israeli planes would risk either being shot down by American planes or shooting down American planes. Up to now, the Pentagon has withheld these codes, and Mr. Arens may have been seeking them.
 
2 Scuds Fired at Israel
 TEL AVIV, Tuesday, Feb. 12 (Special to The New York Times) -- Iraq carried out two missile attacks against Israel overnight, and in each case Patriot missiles engaged a single Scud carrying a conventional warhead over the Tel Aviv area.
Debris from the first attack, early Monday evening, fell harmlessly in an unpopulated area near Tel Aviv, causing no injuries or property damage.
But the second Scud was hit by the Patriot over a populated area early this morning, and flaming missile parts slammed into the city. At least seven people were lightly injured. The Army reported extensive damage to houses and businesses. Rescue workers, firemen and ambulance crews rushed to the scene and set up barricades to keep curious neighbors away from the damaged area.
At the site of impact, it appeared that the missile's warhead was largely intact when it fell to the ground adjacent to a single-family home, totally destroying it.
The front walls of the home next door were blown away and a car was flipped over on its roof in the driveway.
Early this morning, rescue teams using tracker dogs crawled through the rubble searching for people trapped under collapsed walls. Apparently no additional victims were found.
"One missile with a conventional warhead struck a residential area," Brig. Gen. Nachman Shai, the army spokesman, said this morning.
"There are a few people injured, mostly lightly, with perhaps one or two with medium injuries," he added. "There is also significant property damage."
There was no indication anyone was killed in the attack.
In the emergency room at Tel HaShomer Hospital here, Dr. Boris Goldman said "we admitted six people with light injuries -- light lacerations, one person rescued from rubble, one who broke his leg running to a bunker, and one woman in severe shock."
The light injuries were typical of those sustained by hundreds of Israelis in three weeks of Scud missile attacks by Iraq. Most people have been hurt by shrapnel, flying glass, falling furniture or shock. One man was killed when his house collapsed during an early Scud attack, and three elderly Israelis died of heart failure during another assault.
The Scuds fired overnight were the 12th and 13th attacks against Israel since the Persian Gulf war began.

HEADLINE: Take Our Poor, Angry Hartford Tells Suburbs

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Raymond Eugene Shipman says Hartford cannot afford to play nice anymore. Since arriving last fall to become City Manager, he has bluntly, repeatedly described what he sees as the main source of this troubled capital city's problems: its isolation as an urban core, kept impoverished by state tax policies and suburban attitudes.
His prescriptions are just as blunt. 
 With welfare rolls growing along with the recession, and tax collections either flat or falling, he says Hartford must "divest" itself of some of its poor by razing its oldest and largest housing projects. New housing for the projects' more than 1,000 families should be scattered among the towns surrounding Hartford, he says.
 
Wage Tax on Nonresidents
 And if Connecticut has no income tax to transfer wealth from rich communities to poor ones, he says Hartford should levy its own wage tax, but only on nonresidents, the thousands of commuters who flock to downtown office towers by day but flee back to their suburbs at night.
City officials and citizens groups say it is unclear whether Mr. Shipman galvanized Hartford's City Council or whether he is the instrument of a more assertive governing body. But the Council has taken an aggressive stand on other fronts. Two lawsuits are being planned seeking to overturn state tax and housing laws that officials say restrict the city's revenue and unfairly add to its poor population. The city may also join in a suit to overturn the state's education system.
 
Contrasts Are Harsh
 Hartford's problems with poverty and finances are shared by many other aging cities. But here, where an uneasy balance exists in the best of times between well-off suburbs, the banking and insurance companies downtown and the city's desperately poor neighborhoods, the contrasts have become particularly harsh.
It doesn't matter that many of the proposals -- especially those requiring legislative approval, like the commuter tax -- were considered doomed from the outset. Many people believe that by simply raising the questions, Mr. Shipman has set the tone of the debate on what Hartford will become.
Mr. Shipman's views reflect those of a majority on the City Council, his employer. But in giving voice to the harsh proposals, he has become a target of critics.
Advocates for the poor accuse him of looking for a scapegoat for Hartford's budget problems. The city faces an estimated shortfall of $50 million in next year's $440 million budget.
Business leaders say the plan to tax commuters would drive even more employers from downtown, which has been battered over the last year by store closings, bankruptcies and the loss of two hotels. Even the city's delegation to the General Assembly refused to endorse the tax.
"For the City Manager to make statements like that is outrageous," said Sandra E. Little, a City Council member and early supporter of Mr. Shipman who is now offended by his talk of "divesting" the city of its poor. "What does he think the surrounding towns are going to do?"
State Representative Robert Farr, a Republican from neighboring West Hartford, said of the wage tax, "It would be a suicidal policy on the part of the City of Hartford."
 
Fears for Hartford's Survival
 Mr. Shipman, a 49-year-old chain smoker who was an assistant city manager in Kansas City from 1981 until last year, had never lived in Connecticut until he arrived in September to take the $100,000-a-year city manager's job.
He soon began arguing that Hartford's long-term survival was threatened by the growing number of poor people and the state's refusal to allow cities to impose any taxes other than property taxes. Mr. Shipman argues that city residents simply cannot pay more taxes, but that suburban commuters can.
Unlike many newer cities, especially in the Southwest, that could take in new taxpayers through annexation, Hartford has been hemmed in by independent towns with no interest in being absorbed, especially now.
Hartford's population is 140,000, compared with 158,000 20 years ago. It was named the nation's fourth poorest city among those with populations over 100,000 in the 1980 census, with 25.2 percent of its population then below the Federal poverty line. Local officials say little has changed.
Of the 32,798 people receiving welfare benefits in December in the nine towns west of the Connecticut River covered by the Hartford office of the State Department of Income Maintenance, 31,010, or 94.5 percent, lived in Hartford, making up more than 22 percent of Hartford's population. The 1,788 living in the eight other towns made up less than 1 percent of their population of 190,356, according to the state.
 
Clusters of Public Housing
 About 16 percent of Hartford County's population lives in the city. But of the 3,436 public housing units in Hartford County, 70 percent are in Hartford. Most are clustered in the largely black and Puerto Rican neighborhoods of the North End, including the three projects Mr. Shipman wants to raze: Stowe Village, Nelton Court and Bellevue Square.
"It's no small secret that we'd be in the same dire straits as Bridgeport if we kept going at the pace we're going, being all things to all people," Mr. Shipman said, referring to the state's largest city, which has been in a financial crisis for months.
Hartford's Deputy Mayor, I. Charles Mathews, who is the City Council's chairman, says that a firm majority is behind Mr. Shipman and that the manager's ideas reflect the Council's.
Under Hartford's City Charter, the Council acts as the highest authority for both passing laws and formulating policy, while the city manager acts as chief operating officer.
 
Weicker Warns of Aid Cuts
 "There needs to be a new Hartford," Mr. Mathews said. "We can't continue to absorb all the poor of the region. We can't survive as a city."
Behind City Hall's anger are economic issues that could determine Hartford's fate for years. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has said that $850 million to $900 million must be cut from the state's next budget, and that aid to most towns and cities will probably be cut or frozen.
A billion dollars or more in new taxes will also be needed, Mr. Weicker said. Mr. Shipman said that while this year's city budget had a revenue shortfall of only $2 million to $4 million, Mr. Weicker's budget, which is to be released on Wednesday, could force the city to order layoffs and spending cuts that could harm the entire region.
Among some local groups, though, Mr. Shipman's ideas provoke fear.
 
Poor Residents Fear Trick
 "There's a lot of apprehension," said Dulcie Giadone, the president of Hartford Areas Rally Together, an umbrella organization of community groups across the city. Ms. Giadone said that her group had invited Mr. Shipman to meet with local leaders at least three times, and that her "skepticism" grew each time his busy schedule required him to send substitutes.
At Bellevue Square, a graffiti-splattered low-rise housing project north of downtown, some residents said they thought the talk of moving people to better housing elsewhere was a ruse to clear the way for new office towers.
"Most of the people want to be here," said Andre Ocasio, 16, who has lived in the project for four years. "They were born and raised here."
Many people say the Council's new tone is also important. Last month, the Council voted to ask city lawyers to prepare a suit challenging the state's entire property-tax system. The resolution said the laws unfairly penalize cities like Hartford by exempting from taxes so much property that is naturally clustered in cities. Hospitals and state office buildings, for example, pay no local property taxes.
The Council has also discussed a suit to force housing officials to consult the city before using state money to move poor people into Hartford's state-owned housing. They say the state should provide money for increased city services that poor residents need.
The Council has also tentatively approved joining a school desegregation suit against the state. That suit, filed in 1989 on behalf of some Hartford public school children, argues that racial isolation in the city and suburban schools violates the state constitution.
Mr. Shipman says simply that the state should take over authority for all public education, which has always been handled on the local level.

LENGTH: 876 words

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Clash Spurred Queens To End Boycott

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
When community leaders in Elmhurst, Queens, heard last week that an employee of a Korean-owned supermarket there had been charged with assaulting an 11-year-old black boy, and that anger was growing among black residents, they knew what they did not want to happen.
They swung into action, driven by a fear that their racially and ethnically diverse community could become embroiled in the kind of corrosive clash that raged last year in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, where black boycotters declared economic war against a Korean-owned grocery after a black customer said an employee had assaulted her. 
 "We don't want this to be a Brooklyn-type situation," Ruby Muhammad, one of the Elmhurst civic leaders, said yesterday.
 
Limiting the Damage
 On Friday, three days after the incident, leaders of local groups met at a fast-food restaurant with the store's owner and representatives of the Dinkins administration and the Police Department. The alleged assault took place, the police said, after a store employee accused the boy of shoplifting. The talk on Friday was about what had happened and how the participants could limit damage to the social fabric in its aftermath, Ms. Muhammad said.
Yesterday afternoon, after several days in which protesters picketed the supermarket and urged neighborhood residents to boycott it, the street outside the store -- an independently owned outlet of the C-Town chain, at 57th Avenue and 98th Street -- was devoid of demonstrators. Inside, shoppers, many of them black, wheeled carts down the aisles, fingered fruits for ripeness and plucked packaged products from shelves.
The emphasis on all sides was to calm rather than inflame. And above all, the goal, some local leaders said, was to keep people who did not live in the community from entering the dispute and keeping it alive.
"We wash our own linen here," said James E. Brown, a 73-year-old retired postal inspector. "We don't need outsiders to come in." Mr. Brown is acting vice president of the tenants association at Lefrak City, a huge high-rise apartment complex across the street from the supermarket. It provides many of the store's customers.
Ms. Muhammad, who is a director of the tenants association and who, like Mr. Brown, is black, predicted that "this will be different" from the battle at the Flatbush grocery, which came to symbolize tensions between blacks and Korean operators of stores in black neighborhoods.
 
Demand for Prosecution
 In contrast to the goals of many of the Flatbush pickets, she said, most of those demonstrating at the Elmhurst C-Town were not pressing "to close it down."
The lawyer for Bobby Yates, the Lefrak City boy who was said to have been assaulted, also said last night, "We don't want to see him closed down and destroyed." But the lawyer, Stephen G. James, said the Yates family wanted swift and effective prosecution of the store employee, Yong Cha Kim, who was arrested and charged with hitting the boy.
Mr. James said the Yates family also believed that more blacks should be employed at the C-Town and at other stores in the neighborhood, in which most of residents are black, Hispanic or Asian people who hold blue-collar and white-collar jobs.
Most of those calling for a boycott are black, as are many of those working to defuse the protest.
Mr. Kim, a 53-year-old man who speaks little English, could not be reached yesterday for comment, but Francis An, the store's owner, said Mr. Kim denied having hit the boy in the incident last Tuesday.
Nonetheless, Mr. An said yesterday that he had let Mr. Kim go because, "whether he was right or wrong, he raised this problem in the community" and that it was "not right for the neighborhood to keep him here."
The police said Mr. Kim cuffed the boy on the ear, accused him of shoplifting and took him to a back room, where he kept him for almost a half-hour, until his mother, Cynthia, was located.
Ms. Yates is a member of the congregation of the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn, whose minister, the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, a black community advocate, led one group of demonstrators in front of the supermarket on Saturday.
Mr. Daughtry said yesterday that he had informed the local leaders in Elmhurst that he wanted "to move in concert with the community leaders." Noting that he had taken part in last Friday's meeting, Mr. Daughtry said, "I don't have any interest in making more of it than it is but I do have an interest in seeing justice prevail."
Besides the Lefrak tenants association, the talks included members of Concerned Community Adults, a local civic group that works with youths; a representative of Community Board 4, which covers the area; the local Assemblywoman, Helen M. Marshall, and representatives of the Mayor's Community Assistance Unit, the City Commission on Human Rights and the 110th Police Precinct.
A spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, Ruby Ryles, said the Community Assistance Unit had also become swiftly involved in the Flatbush dispute. But that dispute escalated and lingered, and critics said the Mayor had not brought it quickly to an end. A store employee charged with slapping a black customer in that incident was acquitted earlier this month.

LENGTH: 500 words

HEADLINE: Earning the Right to Borrow

 BODY:
Deficit financing -- jargon for going into debt -- is getting attention right now because the financier Felix Rohatyn has suggested that borrowing might save New York City from fiscal disaster. Mayor David Dinkins hasn't ruled out the idea. But it's a dangerous one.
Mr. Rohatyn warns that a worsening economy could lead to such a large budget deficit that the city would have to seek paralyzing budget cuts and intolerable tax increases to balance its budget. To lessen the pain, Mr. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, suggests that the city avoid disruptive cuts by using money borrowed through bonds issued by M.A.C. The bonds would be paid off in the future, presumably after the economy had improved. 
 The idea sounds enticing. Which is precisely why it is to be avoided if possible. Borrowing is the ultimate temptation for politicians. It lets them duck, lets them avoid the difficult choices that should be the essence of responsible government.
That is especially true in New York. The state has spent beyond its means for years and now, damaged by the economy, is passing the burden on to its cities and towns through deep cuts in state aid. And though New York City balances its budget, it has yet to provide a trenchant proposal for addressing its growing fiscal problems. The Mayor's preliminary budget for the coming fiscal year, though balanced, relies mostly on taxes, not reforms. That budget now appears so fragile that Moody's downgraded the city's credit rating yesterday.
The recession demands fundamental, structural change in the way the city and state deliver every service, from medical care to education. Mr. Rohatyn says he would only make M.A.C. money available if the city agreed to a tough retrenchment plan involving the state, M.A.C. and the Financial Control Board. But where is the plan? And how would it be enforced? That's not yet clear. Besides, it's up to the Mayor, not Mr. Rohatyn, to enlist the Governor's support and push for state and city reforms.
New York City borrowed and spent its way to the door of bankruptcy in 1975, when state law forced the city to balance its budget every year. Under the Rohatyn plan, M.A.C. would be doing the borrowing. But by relying on borrowed money, the city would still be spending beyond its means.
That would let both the Mayor and Gov. Mario Cuomo off the hook. The city wouldn't have to reduce its workforce or function more efficiently. The Governor wouldn't have to find equitable solutions to the state's huge budget gap because, with M.A.C. money available to soften the blow, he could continue to make severe reductions in state aid to the city.
Although it may seem seductive to make things easier in the bad times and repay debt in the good times, there's sorry evidence that the payback never happens. If the city must turn again to borrowed money, it has to earn that right first, by showing it's prepared to make fundamental changes to cope with mounting deficits.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
