HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Hard Times, Easy Subsidies

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
DOES one bad subsidy deserve another? Easy credit offered to the Soviet Union is likely to increase Western sales at the expense of cash-and-carry Eastern European exports. That is why Daniel L. Bond of the United States Export-Import Bank and Anthony M. Solomon, the former president of the New York Federal Reserve and now an adviser to the S. G. Warburg Group, want to help the Eastern Europeans build a subsidy system of their own.
The proposal to fight subsidies with more subsidies did not delight the economists, bankers and diplomats assembled last week at the Institute for East-West Security Studies in New York. But it may win converts among pragmatists who say Stalin's victims deserve every break they can get -- and fear that the West does not have the generosity to see Eastern Europe's transition to capitalism through to a successful end. 
 Export subsidies may be on their way out. While there is still a free-for-all in food and weapons trade, Western governments have become tougher on exporters who use guaranteed loans to woo customers. Mr. Bond, the chief economist for America's export finance agency, said that someday soon governments would charge enough to cover the real cost of credit -- including the risk of default.
But someday is not now. Mr. Bond and Mr. Solomon worry that in the worldwide scramble to export to the Soviet Union, backward industries in Eastern Europe will be driven out of business before they have been fairly tested.
Eastern Europe's export woes flow from the collapse of the Soviet trading system. Under the old rules set by Moscow, the satellites delivered a wide range of products in return for Soviet fuel and raw materials. In a sense, the system worked to Eastern Europe's advantage. Export markets were guaranteed, and at highly favorable terms; Moscow effectively subsidized the empire by selling oil and natural gas at far below world prices.
But over the long run, managed trade has proved a disaster. Lacking both competition and access to modern technology, Eastern Europe was never disciplined for delivering computers that were instant museum pieces or cars that belched rotten-egg fumes. When the Kremlin announced last year that the colonies must make their own way in a global market, hundreds of seemingly productive factories became obsolete overnight.
Mr. Bond and Mr. Solomon say they fear that trade within the former Soviet bloc will fall by 30 percent in 1991. That is not necessarily bad news. One way or another, the cycle of incompetence begetting incompetence must come to an end. But the two economists argue that the West has no business piling on; Western-subsidized competition may ruin enterprises that could otherwise have survived the transition.
The economists estimate that Western companies will fight for roughly $20 billion worth of the exports Eastern Europe now funnels to the SovietUnion. The creaky Eastern economies will be able to hang on to some of this trade by offering lower prices or longer warranties. But the two economists guess that credit subsidies from Western governments could still cost Eastern Europe some $4 billion in sales each year.
Mr. Bond and Mr. Solomon propose to right the balance by subsidizing what amounts to a reinsurance system. Where credit proved to be the decisive factor in export competition, Eastern European governments would be encouraged to guarantee the repayment of bank loans made to Soviet customers. Western governments, in turn, would guarantee the guarantees.
No Western outlays would be needed on Day 1. But the economists suggest that it would be prudent to set aside $400 million a year to cover potential Soviet defaults.
Objections leap to mind. Local officials would decide which exports deserved guaranteed financing, effectively strengthening the planning bureaucracies that made a shambles of the Soviet-bloc economy. Western government guarantees might end up costing a lot more than $400 million a year if the Soviet economy disintegrates and the Kremlin stops paying its bills.
But the proposal may offer a relatively appealing alternative to subsidy-as-usual. No Eastern European government is ready to abandon every money-losing enterprise to its fate. Most are now inclined to plow cash into the enterprises with the most employees or the most political clout. Export credit guarantees, by contrast, would be tied in part to objective market performance: They would not save enterprises that could not convince foreigners of the value of their products.
What is more, no-money-down credit guarantees might prove a more palatable form of aid to budget-pinched Western governments than cash loans or grants -- indeed, that is precisely why credit guarantees are so loathed by free marketers. But as long as back-door subsidies remain on the table, why not use them in a virtuous cause?
